\t El vaso no se rompió , lo rompiste tú .
\g the glass no SE broke, it broke you
\l The vase didn’t break, you broke it.

\g no managed to.solve some problem, managed to.solve.them all
\l (S)he didn’t manage to solve some problem, (s)he managed to solve them all!

\t *No consiguió resolver ningún problema , consiguió resolverlos todos .
\g no managed to.solve any problem, managed to.solve.them all\t No se rompió ningún vaso , los rompiste todos tú .
\g no SE broke any glass, them broke all you
\l There didn’t break any glass, you broke them all.

\t Luisa no odia a los niños , los aborrece .
\g Luisa no hates to the children, them loathe
\l Luisa doesn’t hate children, she loathes them.

\t Luisa no odia a ningún niño , los aborrece a todos .
\g Luisa no hates to no child, them loathes to all
\l Luisa doesn’t hate any child, she loathes them all.

\t #Luisa no odia siquiera a los niños , los aborrece .
\g Luisa no hates even to the children them loathes
\l Luisa doesn’t (even) hate children (at all), she loathes them.

\t #El vaso no se rompió siquiera , tú lo rompiste .
\g the glass no SE broke even you it broke
\l The glass didn’t (even) break, you broke it.

\t #Los precios no aumentaron siquiera , tú los aumentaste .
\g the prices no increased even, you them increased
\l The prices didn’t (even) increase, you increased them.

\t #El rosal no floreció siquiera , el jardinero lo hizo florecer .
\g the rosebush no blossomed even, the gardener it made blossom
\l The rosebush didn’t (even) blossom, the gardener made it blossom.

\t #El niño no se puso enfermo siquiera , tú lo infectaste .
\g the child no SE get sick even, you him infected
\l The child didn’t (even) get sick, you infected him.

\t El niño no se lavó siquiera , lo lavó la niñera .
\g the kid no SE washed even him washed the nanny
\l The kid didn’t even wash, the nanny washed him.

\t Die Tür hat sich nicht (einfach (nur)) geöffnet . DU hast sie geöffnet .
\g the door has SE not simply only opened. you have her opened
\l The door did not (just) open. You opened it.

\t Das Kind hat sich nicht (#einfach (nur)) gewaschen . DU hast es gewaschen .
\g the child has SE not simply only washed. you have it washed
\l The child didn’t (#just) wash, you washed him.

\t Hans ist nicht reich , (sondern) er ist arm .
\g Hans is not rich, but2 he is poor
\l Pepe is not rich, but he is poor.

\t Das Wasser ist nicht heiß , (sondern) es ist kochend heiß .
\g the water is not hot but2 it is scalding hot
\l The water is not hot, it is scalding.

\t Der Ring ist schön , aber (er ist) teuer .
\g the ring is nice, but1 it is expensive
\l The ring is nice, but it is expensive.

\t Hans ist nicht schön , aber er ist intelligent .
\g Hans is not beautiful, but he is intelligent
\l John is not beautiful but he is intelligent.

\t Hans ist nicht schön {aber / sondern} er ist intelligent .
\g Hans is not beautiful, but1 / but2 he is intelligent
\l Hans is not beautiful but1/but2 he is intelligent.

\t Das Wasser ist nicht heiß , #aber / sondern es ist kochend heiß .
\g the water is not hot but1 / but2 it is scalding hot
\l The water is not hot, it is scalding.

\t Hans hat nicht einige Probleme gelöst , #aber/sondern er hat alle gelöst
\g John has not some problems solved but1/but2 he has all solved
\l John did not solve some problems, he solved all of them.

\t Das Fenster hat sich nicht geöffnet , #aber/sondern du hast es geöffnet .
\g the window has SE not opened but1/but2 you have it opened
\l The window did not open, you opened it.

\t Das Klima hat sich nicht verändert , #aber/sondern die Menscheit hat es verändert .
\g the climate has SE not change but1/but 2 the mankind has it changed
\l The climate did not change, the mankind changed the climate.

\t Die Vase ist nicht zerbrochen #aber/sondern du hast sie zerbrochen .
\g the vase is not broken but1/but2 you have it broken
\l The vase did not break, you broke it.

\t Das Seil ist nicht zerrissen , #aber/sondern du hast her zerrissen .
\g the rope is not torn but1/but2 you have it torn
\l The rope did not tear, you tore it.

\t Das Fenster ist nicht aufgegangen #aber/sondern du hast es geöffnet .
\g the window is not open-gone but1/but2 you have it opened
\l The window did not open, you opened it.

\t Ich bin nicht krank geworden , #aber/sondern du hast mich angesteckt .
\g I am not sick become but1/but2 you have me infected
\l I did not get sick, you infected me.

\t Das Kind hat sich nicht gewaschen , aber/sondern die Mutter hat es gewaschen .
\g the child has SE not washed but1/but2 the mother has it washed
\l The child did not wash, but the mother washed her.

\t Der Star hat sich nicht angezogen , aber/sondern sein Manager hat ihn angezogen .
\g the star has SE not dressed but1/but2 his manager has him dressed
\l The star did not dress, but his manager dressed him.

\t Il bicchiere non si è rotto , (#ma) l’hai rotto TU !
\g the glass not SE is broken, (but) it-have broken you
\l The glass did not break, you broke it!

\t Il bambino non si è lavato , (ma) l’ha lavato la BAMBINAIA !
\g the child not SE is washed, (but) him-have washed the baby.sitter
\l The child did not wash, the baby sitter washed him!

\t Vinduet åpna seg ikke , (#men) DU åpna det !
\g window.DEF opened SE not (but) you opened it
\l The window did not open, you opened it!

\t Jenta har ikke vaska seg , (men) FAREN har vaska henne !
\g girl.DEF has not washed SE but father.DEF has washed her
\l The girl did not wash, the father washed her!

\t Immer wenn Peter sich wäscht , ist seine Mutter glücklich .

\l Whenever little Peter washes (himself), his mother his happy.

\l Today, the nanny washed little Peter, and his mother was not happy.

\t Hver gang døren åpner seg , går en alarm av .
\g each time the.door open SE, goes an alarm off
\l Each time the door opens, an alarm starts.

\g in today opened Peter the.door, and no alarm went off
\l Today, Peter opened the door, and no alarm started.

\t Når gutten vasker seg , er moren fornøyd .
\g when the.boy washes SE, is the.mother happy
\l When the boy washes, the mother is happy.

\t I dag har dagmammaen vasket ham , og moren var ikke fornøyd .
\g in today has the.nanny washed him and the.mother was not happy
\l Today, the nanny washed him, and the mother was not happy.

\t Tutte le volte che un vetro si rompe , si arrabbia il boss .

\l Whenever a glass breaks, the boss gets angry.

\l Today, Mary broke a glass, and the boss did not get angry.

\t Se rompió el vaso . De hecho , Juan lo rompió .
\g SE broke the glass of fact Juan it broke
\l The glass broke. In fact, Juan broke it.

\t Se rompió el vaso . De hecho , el terremoto lo rompió .
\g SE broke the glass of fact the earthquake it broke
\l The glass broke. In fact, the earthquake broke it.

\t La puerta se abrió . De hecho , el (golpe de) viento abrió la puerta .
\g the door SE opened of fact the gust of wind opened the door
\l The door opened. In fact, the (gust of) wind opened the door.

\t #La bomba destruyó el edificio . De hecho , el ejército destruyó el edificio .
\g the bomb destroyed the building of fact the army destroyed the building
\l The bomb destroyed the building. In fact, the army destroyed the building.

\t #La bala lo mató . De hecho , el policía lo mató .
\g the bullet him killed of fact the policeman him killed
\l The bullet killed him. In fact, the policeman killed him.

\t #El hombre se mató . De hecho , la bala lo mató .
\g the man SE killed of fact the bullet him killed
\l The man killed himself. In fact, the bullet killed him.

\t Luisa odia a los niños . De hecho , los aborrece .
\g Luisa hates to the children of fact them loathes
\l Luisa hates children. In fact, she loathes them.

\t #Pepe es rico . De hecho , es inteligente .
\g Pepe is rich of fact is intelligent
\l Pepe is rich. In fact, he is intelligent.

\t Die Tür öffnete sich .
\g the door opened SE
\l The door opened.

\t Die Tür ging auf .
\g the door went open
\l The door went open.

\t Die Tür {hat sich nicht geöffnet/ist nicht aufgegangen} , #aber/sondern Peter hat sie geöffnet .
\g the door has SE not opened/is not open.gone but1/but2 Peter has she opened
\l The door did not open, (*but) Peter opened it.

\t #Die Tür ist nicht aufgegangen , aber/sondern sie hat sich geöffnet .
\g the door is not open.gone but1/but2 she has SE opened
\l The door did not go open, (but) it opened.

\t Das Klima wurde anders .
\g the climate became different\t Das Klima änderte sich .
\g the climate changed SE
\l The climate changed.

\t #Das Klima ist nicht anders geworden , aber/sondern es hat sich verändert .
\g the climate is not different become, but1/but2 it has SE changed
\l The climate did not get different, (but) it changed.

\t El vaso no se rompió a sí mismo , lógicamente , {pero /sino que} tú lo rompiste .
\g the glass no SE broke to himself logically but1 /but2 that you him broke
\l The glass didn’t break itself, logically, but1/but2 you broke it.

\t Los precios no se aumentaron a sí mismos , lógicamente , {pero/sino que} Ana los aumentó .
\g the prices no SE increased to themselves logically but1/but2 that Ana them increased
\l The prices didn’t increase themselves, logically, but1/but2 Ana increased them.

\t El vaso no se rompió . {Más bien / *En vez de eso} tú lo rompiste .
\g the glass no SE broke more well/ in time of that you it broke
\l The glass did not break. Rather/*Instead you broke it.

\t El vaso no se rompió a sí mismo . {Más bien / En vez de eso} tú lo rompiste .
\g the glass no SE broke to itself more well/ in time of that you it broke
\l The glass did not break itself. Rather/Instead you broke it.

\t Las tostadas se quemaron .
\g the toasts SE burnt (inchoative)
\l The toasts got burned.

\t El niño se quemó .
\g the child SE burnt
\l The kid got burnt/burnt itself.

\t Gianni mi ha picchiato da sé .
\g Gianni me has hit by himself
\l Gianni hit me by himself.

\t (*) Gianni conosce il latino/ ha sudato da sé .
\g Gianni knows the Latin/ has sweated by himself
\l Gianni knows Latin/sweat by himself.

\t * La porta è stata aperta da sé .
\g the door is been opened by itself
\l The door was opened by itself.

\t La porta si è aperta da sé .
\g the door SE is opened by itself
\l The door opened by itself.

\t Maria ha dovuto suggerire la risposta ? No , Gianni sapeva la risposta da sé .
\g Mary has need suggest the answer? no, Gianni knew the answer by SE
\l Did Mary have to suggest the answer? No, Gianni knew the answer by himself.

\t Non devi asciugarli . Diventeranno asciutti da sé .
\g no need.you towel. become.they dry by SE
\l You do not have to dry the dishes with a towel. They become dry by themselves.

\t Non innervosire Maria ! Diventa gia’ nervosa da sé !
\g not make.nervous Mary! become.she already nervous by SE
\l Do not make Mary nervous! She gets nervous already by herself.

\t Non ho dovuto pregare troppo Gianni . A dire il vero , ha portato il pianoforte DA SÉ insieme agli altri al secondo piano .
\g not have.1SG must ask a.lot Gianni. to say the truth, has carried the piano by himself with others at the second floor
\l I did not have to beg Gianni a lot. To tell the truth, he carried by himself the piano to the second floor together with others.

\t #Juan / el terremoto rompió el cristal . De hecho , el cristal se rompió .
\g Juan/ the earthquake broke the glass of fact, the glass SE broke
\l #Juan/the earthquake broke the glass. In fact the glass broke.

\t Das wurde von selbst erkannt , niemand musste sie darauf hinweisen .
\g This was by self recognized, no.one had them on.it indicate
\l People recognized that by themselves, no one had indicate it to them.

\t A dire il vero , ho portato il pianoforte DA ME insieme agli altri al secondo piano .
\g to say the truth, have.1sg carried the piano by ME together with others at second floor
\l To say the truth, I carried by myself the piano together with others to the second floor.

\t Mali zuotian maile shenme shu ne ?
\g Mary yesterday buy-PERF shenme book Q-MARKER
\l What kind of book has Mary bought yesterday?

\t Mali zuotian mei mai shenme shu .
\g Mary yesterday not buy shenme book
\l Mary did not buy (a) book(s) yesterday.

\t Ruguo Mali zuotian maile shenme shu ta yiding hui gaosu wo .
\g if Mary yesterday buy-PERF shenme book she definitely will tell me
\l If Mary bought a book yesterday she will definitely let me know.

\t Mali zuotian haoxiang maile shenme shu .
\g Mary yesterday probably buy-PERF shenme book
\l Mary has probably bought a book yesterday.

\t Makesi zuotian gei Mali maile shenme shu me ?
\g Max yesterday for Mary buy-PERF shenme book Q-MARKER
\l Has Max bought (a/some) book(s) for Mary yesterday?

\t *Makesi zuotian maile shenme shu .
\g Max yesterday buy-PERF shenme book
\l Intended: ‘Max has bought (a) book(s) yesterday.

\t *Wo zhidao Mali zuotian maile shenme shu .
\g I know Mary yesterday buy-PERF shenme book
\l Intended: ‘I know that Mary has bought (a) book(s) yesterday.

\l Tiger and Winnie the Pooh are probably reading a storybook.

\t Tiaotiaohu keneng zai kan shenme gushi shu .
\g Tiger probably PROG read shenme story book
\l Tiger is probably reading a storybook.

\t Tiaotiaohu Weinixiong keneng kan shenme gushi shu .
\g Tiger Winnie the Pooh probably read shenme story book
\l Tiger, Winnie the Pooh probably read a storybook.

\t Tiaotiaohu he Weinixiong keneng zhengzai kan (yige) gushi shu .
\g Tiger with Winnie the Pooh probably PROG read (one-CL) story book
\l Tiger, Winnie the Pooh probably read a storybook.

\t Tiaotiaohu he Weinixiong zhengzai kan shenme gushi shu .
\g Tiger with Winnie the Pooh PROG read shenme story book
\l Tiger and Winnie the Pooh are reading a storybook.

\t Tiaotiaohu he Weinixiong keneng zhengzai kan shenme gushi shu ne ?
\g Tiger with Winnie the Pooh possibly PROG read shenme story book Q MARKER
\l What kind of storybook are Tiger and Winnie the Pooh possibly reading?

\t Iedereen gaat de kamer uit .
\g everybody goes the room out
\l Everybody leaves the room.

\t Nee , onzin . Iedereen gaat niet de kamer uit; alleen Jan en Piet .
\g no, nonsense. everybody goes not the room out; only Jan and Piet
\l No, nonsense. Not everybody leaves the room, only John and Piet do.

\t Ik zeg niet dat iedereen vertrekt; alleen Jan vertrekt .
\g I say not that everybody leaves; only Jan leaves
\l I’m not saying that everybody leaves; only John leaves.

\t Iedereen gaat niet altijd de kamer uit .
\g everybody goes not always the room out
\l It is not always the case that everybody leaves the room.

\t Het verbaast me dat iedereen niet blijft .
\g it surprises me that everybody not stays
\l It surprises me that not everybody stays.

\t … dat Jan niet zou moeten vertrekken *not > should; should > not
\g … that Jan not would must leave 
\l … that Jan shouldn’t leave

\t … dass Hans nicht gehen soll    *not > should; should > not
\g … that Hans not go should    
\l … that Hans shouldn’t go

\t Ranjit  Chitra aawa dənæddə kiyəla  æhuwa .

\l Ranjit asked whether Chitra came.

\t Ranjit  Chitra aawa (kiyəla)  kiiwa .

\l Ranjit said (that) Chitra came.

\t Ranjit  Chitra aawa dənæddə (kiyəla)  æhuwa .

\l Ranjit asked if Chitra came.

\t  Chitra aawa *(kiyəla)  , Ranjit kiiwa .

\l That Chitra came, Ranjit said.

\t  Chitra aawa dənæddə *(kiyəla)  , Ranjit æhuwa .

\l Whether Chitra came, Ranjit asked.

\t Ranjit  kau də aawe kiyəla  æhuwa .

\l Ranjit asked who it was that came.’ (Embedded wh-question)

\t Ranjit  Chitra də aawe kiyəla  æhuwa .

\l Ranjit asked whether it was Chitra that came.’ (Embedded yes-no question)

\l (lit.) ‘Ranjit asked that it was (only) Chitra that came.

\g that book you who Q  read.E that know.A
\l That book, you know who read.

\t  ? ?Ee potə oyaa  kauru t kieuwa də kiyəla  dannəwa .
\g that book you who  read.A Q that know.A
\l That book, you know who read.

\t  ? ?Ee potə oyaa  Chitra də t kieuwe kiyəla  dannəwa .
\g that book you Chitra Q  read.E that know.A
\l That book, you know whether Chitra read.

\t  ? ?Ee potə oyaa  Chitra t kieuwa də kiyəla  dannəwa .
\g that book you Chitra  read.A Q that know.A
\l That book, you know whether Chitra read.

\t Ee potə oyaa  Chitra tamay t kieuwe kiyəla  dannəwa .
\g that book you Chitra FOC  read.A that know.A
\l That book, you know that it is Chitra that read.

\t Ee potə oyaa  Chitra t kieuwa tamay kiyəla  dannəwa .
\g that book you Chitra  read.A FOC that know.A
\l That book, you know that it is the case that Chitra read.

\t *Oyaa   Chitra t dunnə  potə  kieuwe Ranjitʈə .
\g you Chitra  gave book read.E Ranjit-DAT
\l It was to Ranjit that you read the book that Chitra gave t.

\t *Chitra   Ranjit t gatta kiənə  kaʈəkataawə  æhuwe ee potə .
\g Chitra Ranjit  bought.A that rumor heard.E that book
\l It was that book that Chitra heard the rumor that Ranjit bought t.

\t *Oyaa   Chitra Ranjitʈə tamay dunnə  potə  kieuwe .
\g you Chitra Ranjit-DAT FOC gave book read.E
\l It was to Ranjit that you read the book that Chitra gave t.

\t *Chitra   Ranjit ee potə tamay gatta kiənə  kaʈəkataawə  æhuwe .
\g Chitra Ranjit that book FOC bought.A that rumor heard.E
\l It was that book that Chitra heard the rumor that Ranjit bought t.

\t Oyaa   Chitra Ranjitʈə dunnə  potə  tamay kieuwe .
\g you Chitra Ranjit-DAT gave book FOC read.E
\l It was the book that Chitra gave to Ranjit that you read.

\t Chitra   Ranjit ee potə gatta kiənə  kaʈəkataawə  tamay æhuwe .
\g Chitra Ranjit that book bought.A that rumor FOC heard.E
\l It was the rumor that Ranjit bought that book that Chitra heard.

\t *Oyaa   Chitra kaaʈə də dunnə  potə  kieuwe ?
\g you Chitra who-DAT Q gave book read.E
\l To whom did you read the book that Chitra gave t?

\t *Chitra   Ranjit monəwa də gatta kiənə  kaʈəkataawə  æhuwe ?
\g Chitra Ranjit what Q bought.A that rumor heard.E
\l What did Chitra hear the rumor that Ranjit bought t?

\t Oyaa   Chitra kaaʈə dunnə  potə  də kieuwe ?
\g you Chitra who-DAT gave book Q read.E
\l You read the book that Chitra gave to who?

\t Chitra   Ranjit monəwa gatta kiənə  kaʈəkataawə  də æhuwe ?
\g Chitra Ranjit what bought.A that rumor Q heard.E
\l Chitra heard the rumor that Ranjit bought what?

\t *Oyaa   Chitra Ramʈə də dunnə  potə  kieuwe ?
\g you Chitra Ram-DAT Q gave book read.E
\l Was it to Ram that you read the book that Chitra gave t?

\t *Chitra   Ranjit potə də gatta kiənə  kaʈəkataawə  æhuwe ?
\g Chitra Ranjit book Q bought.A that rumor heard.E
\l Was it the book that Chitra hear the rumor that Ranjit bought t?

\t Oyaa   Chitra Ramʈə dunnə    potə  də kieuwe ?
\g you Chitra Ram-DAT gave  book Q read.E
\l Was it the book that Chitra gave to Ram that you read?

\t Chitra   Ranjit potə gatta kiənə  kaʈəkataawə  də æhuwe ?
\g Chitra Ranjit book bought.A that rumor Q heard.E
\l Was it the rumor that Ranjit bought the book that Chitra heard?

\t Kau də aawe ?
\g who Q came.E
\l Who came?

\t Ranjit  kau də aawe kiyəla  dannəwa .
\g Ranjit who Q came.E that know.A
\l Ranjit knows who came.

\t Kaurut  mamə tamay monəwa də yawanne kiyəla  hoyanne .
\g everyone I FOC what Q send.E that search.E
\l It is me that everyone looks for what is sent.

\t *Kaurut  mamə tamay monəwa yawənəwa də kiyəla  hoyanne .
\g everyone I FOC what send.A Q that search.E
\l It is me that everyone looks for what is sent.

\t *Kaurut  mamə tamay potə də yawanne kiyəla  hoyanne .

\l It is me that everyone looks for whether the book is sent.

\t Chitra kieuwe  ee potə  tamay .
\g Chitra read.E that book FOC
\l It was that book that Chitra read.

\t *Ranjit  Chitra dənæddə aawe kiyəla  æhuwa .
\g Ranjit Chitra whether came.E that asked.A
\l Ranjit asked whether Chitra came.

\t *Ranjit  kauru aawa də kiyəla  æhuwa .
\g Ranjit who came.A Q that asked.A
\l Ranjit asked who came.

\t *Kaurut  mamə tamay potə yawənəwa də kiyəla  hoyanne .
\g everyone I FOC book send.A Q that search.E
\l It is me that everyone looks for whether the book is sent.

\t Junyawa  Ayakaga ringoo mittsu muitano o (zenbu) tabeta .
\g Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM apple.ACC three.CL peel.PAST.NO.ACC (all) eat.PAST
\l [i] ‘Ayaka peeled three apples and Junya ate (all) the three peeled apples.’ [ii] ‘Ayaka peeled three apples and Junya ate (all) the contextually pertinent apples.

\t Junyawa  Ayakaga mittsu muita ringo o (zenbu) tabeta .
\g Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM three.CL peel.PAST apple.ACC (all) eat.PAST
\l [i] ‘Junya ate (all) the three apples that Ayaka peeled.’ [ii] ‘Junya ate (all) the apples that Ayaka peeled three of.

\t Junyawa  Ayakaga ringoo mittsu muita sono ringo o (zenbu) tabeta .
\g Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM apple.ACC three.CL peel.PAST that apple.ACC (all) eat.PAST
\l [i] ‘Junya ate (all) those three apples that Ayaka peeled.’ [ii] ‘Junya ate (all) those apples that Ayaka peeled three of.

\t Junyawa  Ayakaga <gap> orenzio mittsu muita tiisana yama niwa odorokanakatta ga , pro  Ayakaga <gap> ringoo mittsu muita ookina no niwa totemo odoroita .
\g Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM  orange.ACC three.CL peel.PAST small pile.DAT.CONT get-surprised.NEG.PAST but  Ayaka.NOM  apple.ACC three.CL peel.PAST large NO.DAT.CONT extremely get-surprise.PAST
\l While Junya was not surprised at the small pile that Ayaka peeled 3 oranges from, he got extremely surprised at the large one that she peeled 3 apples from.

\t sono paatiiniwa gesutoga nizyuugonin ita . Junyawa  Ayakaga kareni gesutoo sannin syookaisitekureta no o kookyuuna resutoranni (zenbu/zenin) syootaisita .

\l There were twenty five guests at the party. Ayaka introduced three (of the) guests to Junya, and he marveled at their elegant behavior.

\l Ayaka having peeled three apples, Junya ate all twelve apples.

\g Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM three.CL peel.PAST apple.ACC eat.NEG.PAST
\l [i] ‘Junya did not eat [of] the three apples that Ayaka peeled.’ [ii] ‘Junya did not eat [of] the apples that Ayaka peeled three of.

\t Junyawa  Ayakaga ringoo mittsu muita no o tabenakatta .
\g Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM apple.ACC three.CL peel.PAST NO.ACC eat.NEG.PAST
\l Ayaka peeled three (of the) apples and Junya did not eat [of] them.

\t Junyawa  Ayakaga mittsu muita ringo o (zenbuwa) tabenakatta .

\l [i] ‘Junya did not eat [of] (all) the three apples that Ayaka peeled.’ [ii] ‘Junya did not eat [of] (all) the apples that Ayaka peeled three of.

\t Junyawa  Ayakaga ringoo mittsu muita no o (zenbuwa) tabenakatta .
\g Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM apple.ACC three.CL peel.PAST NO.ACC (all.CONT) eat.NEG.PAST
\l Ayaka peeled three (of the) apples and Junya did not eat (all) [of] them.

\l John had boasted that his student proposed an important hypothesis and Mary pointed out a defect in it.

\t *Marywa    Johnga   atarasii kasetuo teiansita  gakusei o hometeita  no no kekkan o sitekisita .
\g Mary.TOP John.NOM new hypothesis.ACC propose.PAST student.ACC praise-had NO.GEN defect.ACC point.out-do.PAST
\l John praised the student [who proposed a new hypothesis] and Mary pointed out a defect in it.

\t    Johnga  kareno gakuseiga atarasii kasetuo teiansita node kankino koeo ageta  no no akirakana kekkan o suguni sitekisita .

\l John shouted with joy [because his student proposed a new hypothesis], and Mary promptly pointed out an obvious defect in it.

\t Marywa    Johnga     e   e  teiansita  gakusei o hometeita  atarasii kasetu no kekkan o sitekisita .
\g Mary.TOP John.NOM  propose.PAST student.ACC praise-had new hypothesis.GEN defect.ACC point.out-do.PAST
\l Mary pointed out the defect of a new hypothesis such that John praised the student who proposed (it).

\t Marywa    Johnga     e  atarasii kasetuo teiansita  gakuse o hometeita  sono atarasii kasetu no kekkan o sitekisita .
\g Mary.TOP John.NOM  new hypothesis.ACC propose.PAST student.ACC praise-had that hypothesis.GEN defect.ACC point.out-do.PAST
\l literally: ‘Mary pointed out a defect in that new hypothesis [that John praised the student who proposed a new hypothesis].

\t Marywa    Johnga  kareno gakuseiga  e  teiansita node kankino koeo ageta  atarasii kasetu no akirakana kekkan o suguni sitekisita .
\g Mary.TOP John.NOM he.NOM student.NOM  propose.PAST because joy.GEN voice.ACC raise.PAST new hypothesis.GEN obvious defect.ACC promptly point.out-do.PAST
\l Mary pointed out an obvious defect in a new hypothesis that John (had) shouted with joy because his student (had) proposed (it).

\t Marywa    Johnga  kareno gakuseiga atarasii kasetuo teiansita node kankino koeo ageta  sono atarasii kasetu no akirakana kekkan o suguni sitekisita .

\l literally: ‘Mary promptly pointed out an obvious defect in that new hypothesis [that John (had) shouted with joy [because his student (had) proposed a new hypothesis].

\t   daidokorono madokara siroi nekoga kinoo deteitta  no ga sakanao tabeteiru .

\t sono paatiiniwa gesutoga nizyuugonin ita .  Junyawa   Ayakaga kareni gesutoo sannin syookaisitekureta no no hutarino hinnoyoi hurumai ni taisite kantanno io hyoosita  wakedewa nakatta .
\g that party-at.TOP guest.NOM twenty five.CL exist.PAST Junya.TOP Ayaka.NOM he.DAT guest.ACC three.CL introduce.PAST NO.GEN two.CL.GEN elegant behavior.DAT toward admiration.GEN thought.ACC express.PAST reason.COP.CONT NEG.PAST

\t Sā siva  le teine  .
\g PST dance DET girl.ABS
\l The girl danced.

\t Sā fau  e le tamāloa   le fale  .
\g PST build ERG DET man DET house.ABS
\l The man built the house.

\t Sā siva  le teine   i le siva  .
\g PST dance DET girl.ABS  DET dance
\l The girl danced a/the dance.

\t Sā mulimuli  le leoleo   i le au gaoi  .
\g PST follow DET police.ABS  DET robbers
\l The police followed the robbers.

\t Sā kiki  e le teine   le polo  .
\g PST kick ERG DET girl DET ball.ABS
\l The girl kicked the ball.

\t Sā asulu  le teine  .
\g PST fall DET girl.ABS
\l The girl fell.

\t Ua maua  e Toma   (ia) Jerry  .
\g PST caught ERG Tom  Jerry
\l Tom caught Jerry.

\t Sā siva  (ia) Anna  .
\g PST dance  Anna
\l Anna danced.

\t Sā siva (*e) le teine .
\g PST dance (*ERG) DET girl.ABS
\l The girl danced.

\t Sā siva  le teine   i le uosi  .
\g PST dance DET girl.ABS  DET waltz
\l The girl danced a/the waltz.

\t Sā ata  le teine  .
\g PST laugh DET girl.ABS
\l The girl laughed.

\t Sā ata  le teine   i le ata (a le…)  .
\g PST laugh DET girl.ABS  DET laugh (POSS DET)
\l The girl laughed the laugh (of the….).

\t Sā toe miti fo’i  le teine  .
\g PST again dream again DET girl.ABS
\l The girl dreamed again.

\t Sā toe miti fo’i  le teine   i le miti fefe  .
\g PST again dream again DET girl.ABS  DET dream bad
\l The girl dreamed a bad dream (∼nightmare) again.

\t *Sā siva  e le teine   le uosi  . (cf . 11b)
\g PST dance ERG DET girl DET waltz.ABS 
\l The girl danced a/the waltz.

\t *Sā ata  e le teine   le ata (a le…)  . (cf . 12b)
\g PST laugh ERG DET girl DET laugh.ABS (POSS) DET 
\l The girl laughed the laugh (of the….).

\t *Sā toe miti fo’i  e le teine   le miti fefe  . (cf . 13b)
\g PST again dream again ERG DET girl DET dream bad.ABS 
\l The girl dreamed a bad dream again.

\t Sā usu  *(e) le tamāloa   *(le pese)  .
\g PST sing ERG DET man DET song.ABS
\l The man sang a song.

\t Sā pese  le tamāloa  .
\g PST sing DET man.ABS
\l The man sang.

\t Sā pese  le tamāloa   i le pese/fati  .
\g PST sing DET man.ABS  DET song/melody
\l (*Sā pese e le tamāloa le pese/fati.) ‘The man sang a song/melody.

\t Sā tatalo  le teine  .
\g PST pray DET girl.ABS
\l The man prayed.

\t Sā tatalo  e le teine   le talosaga  .

\t … korraldused ,  mille kõiki nüansse            ma praegu sulle seletama ei hakka , …
\g  rule-PL.NOM what.GEN all-PL.PAR nuance-PL.PAR I now you-ALL explain-SUP NEG begin 
\l (I have brought on board my own) rules, whose every nuance I will not try to explain to you at the moment, …’ (ETTENTEN)

\t Millise võistleja kõik medalid ripuvad spordimuuseumis ?
\g which.GEN competitor.GEN all.PL.NOM medal-PL.NOM hang-PRS.3PL sports.museum-INE
\l All of which competitor’s medals are hanging in the sports museum?

\t Millise helilooja kõiki sümfooniaid hoitakse ülikooli raamatukogus ?
\g which.GEN composer.GEN all.PL.PAR symphony-PL.PAR keep-PASS.PRS university.GEN library-INE
\l All of which composer’s symphonies are kept in the university library?

\t Linanun  Thomika ku kapangul sassta/*nya ko cwucanghayssta/mitessta .

\l Lina claimed/believed that Tommy bought that bag.

\t Linanun wulieykey  ku kapangul saca/*ta/*nya ko ceyanhayssta/seltukhayssta .

\l Lina suggested to us/persuaded us to buy that bag.

\t Linanun wulieykey  ku kapangul sala/*ca/*ta/*nya ko myenglyenghayssta/cisihayssta .

\t choysenul tahan neeykey tolul tencil salamun amwuto epsul kesita .
\g best-ACC do-ADN you-DAT stone-ACC throw-ADN.FUT person-TOP anyone not.exist-ACC NML-COP-DECL
\l There would not be anybody that criticizes you who did your best.’ (throw a stone = criticize)

\t il .il .kwu kwukup .chaka cholul tatwue talliko issta .
\g one.one.nine emergency.car-NOM second-ACC dispute-E run-KO exist-DECL
\l The 119 ambulance is running in a very urgent situation.’ (dispute a second = be very urgent)

\t moin salamtuli motwu hyelul naytwulessta .
\g gathered person-PL-NOM all tongue-ACC wave-PST-DECL
\l All gathered people were very astonished.’ (wave a tongue = be astonished)

\t ku congun temthekilul ssuko cwukimul tanghayessta .
\g that servant-TOP worry-ACC wear-and killing-ACC suffer-PST-DECL
\l That servant got all the blame, and was killed.’ (wear worry = get blamed)

\t nanun chel .phanul kkalko ku namcaeykey kopaykhayessta .
\g I-TOP iron.pad-ACC spread.out-and that guy-DAT propose-PST-DECL
\l I was brash, and proposed to the guy.’ (spread out iron pad = be brash)

\t han wumwulman kkwucwuni phaseyyo .
\g one well-only steadily dig-HON-POL
\l Focus on one matter!’ (dig one well = focus on one matter)

\t nenun sinsalosse ettehkey twu malul hani ?
\g you-TOP gentleman-as how two word-ACC do-ACC
\l How can you as a gentleman change your mind so easily?’ (do two words = change one’s mind easily)

\t Hananun mikwukeyse twu mali thokkilul motwu capassta .
\g Hana-TOP America-in two CL rabbit-ACC all catch-PST-DECL
\l Hana accomplished what she has planned in America.’ (catch two rabbits = accomplish)

\t i malul thanun swunkan , yelepwunuy messulewumun ce hanulul ccilul kesipnita .
\g this horse-ACC ride-ADN moment you.PL-GEN niceness-TOP that sky-ACC poke-ACC NML-COP-DECL.DEFL
\l At the moment you ride on this horse, you will look much nicer.’ (poke a sky = have a great force)

\t ku nomun yel .tays kulusuy khong .pap cengto mekeya cengsin chalil nomita .
\g that guy-TOP ten.five bowl-GEN rice.bean thereabouts eat-should mind wake.up-ADN.FUT guy-COP-DECL
\l That guy will be a normal person if he goes to prison around fifteen times.’ (eat rice with beans = go to prison)

\t tangsin halapecikkeysenun totaychey wuli nala yeksaey myech kayuy hoykul kuusin kesipnikka ?
\g your grandfather-HON-TOP ever our country history-in how.many CL-GEN stroke-ACC draw-u-HON-ADN NML-COP-Q.DEF
\l Literal: ‘How many strokes did your grandfather ever draw to our country’s history?’ Idiomatic: ‘Your grandfather made a number of great contributions to our country’s history.

\t kulekeyo . cengmal swusip kayuy hoykul kuusyessta malhayto kwaeni anikesssupnita .
\g Yes really tens CL-GEN stroke-ACC draw-u-HON-PST-DECL tell-even.if exaggeration-NOM NEG-FUT-HON-DECL.DEF
\l Literal: ‘Yes, even if we say that he drew tens of strokes, that is not an exag geration at all.’ Idiomatic: ‘Yes, he made numerous contributions.

\t Lee sacangi motun santhongul kkay nohassta .
\g Lee boss-NOM every container-ACC break put-PST-DECL
\l The boss Lee ruined everything.’ (break a container = ruin) (example modified from Tongeun Shin 2013, The Wabper)

\t emmaka atulhantey yang sonul ta tulessta .
\g mother-NOM son-DAT both hand-ACC all hold.up-PST-DECL
\l The mother gave up her son.’ (hold up hand = give away/up)

\t kwucheycekulo malhamyen Kimyohan senswunimkkeyse key imkyeey han hoykul kuusyeya hapnita .
\g specifically tell-if Kimyohan player-NON-NOM.HON game-field-in one stroke-ACC draw-u-HON-should do-DECL.DEF
\l Specifically speaking, the player Kim, Yohan should make a crucial contribution to the game field.’ (draw a stroke = make a crucial contribution)

\t kyengkiuy sung .phaynun ku ttwukkengul yelepwaya alkeya .
\g game-GEN victory.defeat-TOP that lid-ACC open-e-try know-FUT-INT
\l We will know the result of the victory or defeat of the game once the game is done.’ (open lid = find out a result)

\t han salami yele kay(uy) kamthwu(lul) ssunun kesun poki cohci anhta .
\g One person-NOM numerous CI-GEN hat-ACC wear-AND NML-TOP see-NML good-ci NEG-DAT
\l It does not look good that one person has a lot of authority.’ (wear a traditional hat = have authority)

\t kutulun sikminci thongchiey saylowun/cainhan makakul tulenayessta .
\g they-TOP colony reign-in new/mean horse.leg-ACC bring.out-PST-DECL
\l They disclosed the hidden/mean details of their colonization.’ (bring out a horse leg = disclose hidden details) (https://prezi.com/schunikn6saj/presentation/)

\t nenun emma(uy) sokul elmana kulkeya eluni toykessni ?
\g you-TOP mother(-GEN) stomach-ACC how.much scratch-indeed adult-NOM become-FUT-Q
\l How much do you have to worry your mother to become an adult?’ (scratch stomach = make someone worry)

\t i cakun kanul elmana coliessnunci .
\g this small liver-ACC how.much boil.down-PST-ADN-END
\l I have been very nervous.’ (boil down liver = be very nervous)

\t Kim sacangi motun telewun temthekilul ssuko saimhayess
\g Kim boss-NOM every dirty worry-ACC wear-and resign-PST-DECL
\l The boss Kim had all the blame shifted on to himself and resigned.’ (wear worry = get blamed)

\t na Kim .sicangi pwuceng kongcikcauy motun ssilul mallikessta .
\g I Kim.mayor-NOM corruption official-GEN every seed-ACC dry-FUT-DECL
\l I, the mayor Kim, will get rid of all the officials’ corruptions.’ (dry seeds = get rid of)

\t phalliuy sashiptay wekhingmam sey mali thokkilul capta .
\g Paris-GEN forties working-mother three CL rabbit-ACC catch-DECL
\l Working mothers in their forties in Paris accomplish many things.’ (http://www.ohmynews.com/nws_web/view/at_pg.aspx?CNTN_CD=A0001334135)

\t twu wumwul phanun cwung .kitul .
\g two well dig-ADN middle.business-PL
\l Small and medium-sized business are focusing on more than one thing.’ (http://www.fnnews.com/news/201303181734385875)

\t sinsalosse ettehkey twu mal sey mal yele malul hani ?
\g gentle.man-as how two word three word many word-ACC do-Q
\l How can you as a gentleman change your mind so easily?’ (literal: ‘say two words, three words, many words’) (similar example at http://news.kukmin.tv/news/articleView.html?idxno=828)

\t Chelswunun yang talilul kelchinta .
\g Chelswu-TOP both leg-ACC span-PRES-DECL
\l Chelswu is a two-timer.’ (span two legs = date more than one person at a time)

\t Seysang pwulkongphyeng .haci . nwukwun sey tali ney talito kelchiko pwulepta .
\g world unfair.do-END someone-TOP three leg four leg-even span-and jealous-DECL
\l The world is unfair. Some people date with even three or four partners at one time, and I am jealous of it.’ (literal: ‘span three legs, four legs’) (similar example at http://news.zum.com/zum/view?id=029201307087742103&t=0&cm=newsbox&v=2)

\t El libro está en la mesa .

\t Pöydällä on kirja . (Existential Construction)
\g Table.AD is book 
\l There is a book on the table.

\t Kirja on pöydällä . (Locative Construction)
\g Book is table.AD 
\l The book is on the table.

\t Tomilla on kirja . (Possessive₁ Construction)
\g Tom.AD is book 
\l Tom has a book.

\t Kirja on Tomin . (Possessive₂ Construction)
\g Book is Tom.GEN 
\l The book is Tom’s.

\t Mesapi libru tiyan . (Existential Construction)
\g Table-on book be-3SUBJ 
\l There is a book on the table.

\t Librus mesapi kanku . (Locative Construction)
\g book-PL table-on be-3SUBJ-PL 
\l The books are on the table.

\t Tompata librun tiyan . (Possessive₁ Construction)
\g Tom-GEN book-3POSS be-3SUBJ 
\l Tom has a book.

\t Librus Tompata kanku . (Possessive₂ Construction)
\g book-PL Tom-GEN be-3SUBJ-PL 
\l The books are Tom’s.

\t Libru mesapi tiyan . (Locative Construction)
\g Book table-on be-3SUBJ 
\l The book is on the table.

\t Tom libruta apin . (Possessive₁ Construction)
\g Tom book-ACC have-3SUBJ 
\l Tom has a book.

\t Libru Tompa kan . (Possessive₂ Construction)
\g Book Tom-GEN be-3SUBJ 
\l The book is Tom’s.

\t Noqa lingüista kani . (Nominal Predicate)
\g I linguist be-1SUBJ 
\l I am a linguist.

\t Noqa jatun kani . (Individuallevel Adjectival Predicate)
\g I big be-1SUBJ 
\l I am big.

\t Noqa kusisqa kashani . (Stagelevel Adjectival Predicate)
\g I happy be-DUR-1SUBJ 
\l I am happy.

\t Noqa Inglaterramanta kani . (Ilevel PP Predicate)
\g I England-from be-1SUBJ 
\l I am from England.

\t Mesapi libru karqa∅ .
\g Table-on book be-PAST-3SUBJ
\l There was a book on the table.

\t Mesapi libru kanqa .
\g Table-on book be-3SUBJ-FUT
\l There will be a book on the table.

\t Pierre viendra non pas demain , *(mais après demain) .
\g Pierre come-FUT NEG NEG tomorrow but after tomorrow
\l Pierre is not coming tomorrow, but after tomorrow.’ As they say, “It is therefore not surprising that [the correction] is introduced by mais = SN, if we admit that the utterance p SN q is the object of one unique act of enunciation. If mais = PA is, on the other hand, impossible in these conditions, it is because it would cause a succession of two acts of enunciation (which is blocked by non).” (Anscombre & Ducrot 1977: 40)27

\g Abi is NEG NEG beautiful but ugly
\l Abi is not beautiful, but ugly.

\g Abi is NEG NEG beautiful but gorgeous
\l Abi is not beautiful, but gorgeous.

\l Abi is not beautiful, she is ordinary.

\t Kati is , Mari is         ‘K as well as M’
\g Kati too Mari too         \t Kati sem , Mari sem        ‘neither K nor M’
\g Kati nor Mari nor        \t mind Kati , mind Mari        ‘both K and M’
\g all Kati all Mari        \t vagy Kati , vagy Mari        ‘either K or M , not both’
\g or Kati or Mari        \t akár Kati , akár Mari      ‘whether/either K or M’
\g whether Kati whether Mari      \t sem Kati , sem Mari        ‘neither K nor M’
\g nor Kati nor Mari        \t Kati és Mari aludt .      
\g Kati and Mari sleep-PAST.3SG      ‘K and M slept.’\t Kati is , Mari is aludt .    
\g Kati too Mari too sleep-PAST.3SG    ‘K as well as M slept.’\t Mind Kati , mind Mari aludt .   
\g all Kati all Mari sleep-PAST.3SG   ‘Both K and M slept.’\t Kati is aludt .   Aludt Kati is .
\g Kati too slept   slept Kati too\t Kati sem aludt .   Nem aludt Kati sem .
\g Kati nor slept   not slept Kati nor\t *Mind Kati aludt .        *Aludt mind Kati .

\g nor Kati not slept       not slept nor Kati\t *Akár Kati aludt , nem számít .3   *Aludt akár Kati , nem számít .

\l On Tuesday, home, on Wednesday (*PEDIG) to sing, today (PEDIG) to swim.

\t mindenki , minden(*mi) , mindenhol
\g all-EN-who all-EN-what all-EN-where
\l everyone, everything, everywhere

\l someone, something, somewhere

\t akárki , akármi , akárhol
\g whether-who whether-what whether-where
\l whoever, whatever, wherever

\t senki , semmi , sehol
\g nor-who nor-what nor-where
\l no one, nothing, nowhere

\t mind Kati , mind Mari , mind (pedig) Peti ≈ mindenki   (etc .)
\g all Kati all Mari all PEDIG Peti  everyone   \t valaki is
\g some-who too
\l anyone, NPI

\t akárki is
\g whether-who too
\l anyone, NPI/FCI

\t Senki nem aludt . vs . *Senki aludt .     preV , strict NC ,
\g n-one not slept  n-one slept     requires nem\t Senki sem aludt . vs . *Senki sem nem aludt . preV , nonstrict NC ,
\g n-one nor slept  n-one nor not slept rejects nem\t Nem aludt senki (sem) . vs . *Aludt senki (sem) . postV , strict/nonstrict ,
\g not slept n-one nor  slept n-one nor require nem\t Sem Kati , sem Mari *(nem) aludt .     preV , strict NC ,
\g nor Kati nor Mari not slept     requires nem\t Kati sem , Mari sem (*nem) aludt .     preV , nonstrict NC ,
\g Kati nor Mari nor not slept     rejects nem\t Nem aludt sem K , sem M / K sem , M sem . postV , strict/nonstrict ,
\g not slept nor K nor M  K nor M nor require nem\t sem Kati , sem Mari ≈ senki       strict NCI , cf . nikto
\g nor Kati nor Mari  n-one       \t Kati sem , Mari sem ≈ senki sem     nonstrict NCI , cf . nessuno
\g Kati nor Mari nor  n-one nor     \t A hó is/sem esik , … a gyerek is/sem nyűgös .
\g the snow too/nor falls … the child too/nor cranky
\l The snow is falling, likewise the child is cranky.’ / ‘The snow isn’t falling, likewise the child isn’t cranky.

\t   Kati is/sem 100 kg volt   (és)  Mari is/sem 100 kg volt    .
\g  Kati too/nor  and Mari too/nor 100 kg was
\l Kati as well as Mari was 100 kg.’ / ‘Neither Kati nor Mari was 100 kg.

\t Mind Kati , mind Mari , mind (pedig) Peti alszik . ≈ Mindenki alszik .
\g all Kati all Mari all PEDIG Peti sleeps  everyone sleeps\t Vagy Kati , vagy Mari , vagy (pedig) Peti alszik . ≈ Valaki alszik .
\g or Kati or Mari or PEDIG Peti sleeps  someone sleeps\t Mind Kati (alszik) , mind Mari (alszik) , mind Peti alszik .
\g all Kati sleeps all Mari sleeps all Peti sleeps\t Kati is (alszik) , Mari is (alszik) , Peti is alszik .
\g Kati too sleeps Mari too sleeps Peti too sleeps\t *Peti hallott__ és Mari olvasott__ MINDEN NOBELDÍJASróL .
\g Peti heard and Mari read every Nobelist-ABOUT\t Mind egy MAGAS __ mind hat ALACSONY gyereket meghívtam .
\g all one tall  all six short child-ACC invited-1SG
\l I invited both one tall and six short children.

\t Meghívtam mind egy magas __ mind hat alacsony gyereket .
\g invited-1SG all one tall  all six short child-ACC\t Sem a JOBB __ sem a BALkezes gyerekek nem sírtak .
\g nor the right-  nor the left-handed child-PL not cried-3PL
\l Neither the right- nor the left-handed children cried.

\t Nem sírtak sem a JOBB __ sem a BALkezes gyerekek .
\g not cried-PL nor the right-  nor the left-handed child-PL\t Adjál vagy minden fiúnak négy KÉK __ vagy minden lánynak hat ZÖLD golyót .
\g give-2SG or every boy-DAT four blue  or every girl-DAT six green marble-ACC
\l Give either every boy four blue __ or every girl six green marbles.

\t Vagy sok fiú , vagy kevés lány aludt .
\g or many boy or few girl slept
\l Either many boys or few girls slept.

\t Kati sem aludt (és) Mari sem aludt .   cf . Senki sem aludt .
\g Kati nor aludt and Mari nor slept    n-one nor slept
\l Neither Kati (slept), nor Mari slept.’ ‘No one slept.

\t Nem aludt sem Kati , sem (pedig) Mari .  cf . Nem aludt senki .
\g not slept nor Kati nor PEDIG Mari   not slept n-one
\l Neither Kati slept, nor Kati slept.’ ‘No one slept.

\t Sem Kati , sem (pedig) Mari nem aludt .  cf . Senki nem aludt .
\g nor Kati nor PEDIG Mari not slept   n-one not slept
\l Neither Kati slept, nor Mari slept.’ ‘No one slept.

\t Peti sem nem evett , sem (pedig) nem ivott .
\g Peti nor not ate nor PEDIG not drank
\l Peti neither ate nor drank.

\t Peti sem enni nem evett , sem (pedig) inni nem ivott .
\g Peti nor eat-INF not ate nor PEDIG drink-INF not drank
\l As for eating, Peti didn’t eat, as for drinking, he didn’t drink.

\t Sem Mari nem evett , sem (pedig) Kati nem ivott .
\g nor Mari not ate nor PEDIG Kati not drank
\l Neither Mari ate, nor Kati drank.

\t (*)     nem evett sem Mari      nem ivott sem Kati   
\g   not ate nor Mari  not drank nor Kati\t (*)   nem …      sem Mari evett      sem Kati ivott       
\g   not nor Mari ate  nor Kati drank \t   senki   sem  …     ‘nonstrict NCI’
\g  n-who  nor   \t   valaki   is  …     ‘anyone , NPI’
\g  some-who  too   \t   akárki   is  …     ‘anyone , NPI’
\g  whether-who  too   \t  ?Akár KATI jöhet .
\g whether Kati come-may\t Akár Kati is jöhet .
\g whether Kati too come-may
\l Even Kati may come.

\t Akár Kati , akár Mari jöhet .
\g whether Kati whether Mari come-may
\l Either Kati or Mari may come.

\t *Akár Kati is , akár Mari is jöhet .
\g whether Kati too whether Mari too come-may\t omdat zij noch de hunnen , noch zichzelf , noch tenslotte hun eigen leven ontzien hebben
\g because they neither the theirs nor themselves nor finally their own life spared have
\l because they spared neither their [families], nor themselves, nor finally their own lives

\t Det stämmer att Olof Ersson blivit huggen i huvudet med en yxa . En yxhammare , närmare bestämt . Den rev upp ett fem centimeter långt sår och krossade hjässbenen . Men den saken överlevde den tjockskallige Olof .
\g it is.true that Olof Ersson been stabbed in head.the with an axe an axhammer closer decided it tore up a five centimeter long wound and crushed crown.bones.the but that thing survived the thickheaded Olof
\l It’s correct that Olof Ersson was stabbed in the head with an ax. An axhammer, to be precise. It tore up a five centimeter long wound and crushed the skull. But that thing the thick-headed Olof survived.

\t Samtidigt som vi andas måste vi nämligen spänna ett antal småmuskler i svalget så att slemhinnorna inte ska dras in och förminska luftkanalen . Det kan man visa med ett enkelt experiment .
\g simultaneously as we breathe must we namely flex a number small.muscles in throat.the so that mucosa.the not will pulled in and diminish air.duct.the that can one show with a simple experiment
\l At the same time as we breathe, we have to flex a number of small muscles in the throat, in order for the mucosa not to get pulled in and diminish the air duct. That can be shown with a simple experiment.

\l Tarragon is good in an omelette, basil as well – in particular if the omelette is served with tomato salad. Oregano can also be used.

\t I ateljén står bland färger ett gammalt skrivbord fullt av vykort och andra bilder av kvinnor i konsten , från Marilyn till Botticelli och Cranach . En bok om Picasso är uppslagen och där finns en bild av Les Demosielles d’Avignon . Några kvinnliga konstnärsidoler har Cecilia inte , tyvärr , säger hon . Stimulansen kommer från manliga konstnärer som Rousseau , Picasso , Cranach . Kvinnliga konstnärer som Derkert , Hjertén och Delauney är mer moraliskt stöd .
\g in studio.the stand among paint an old desk full of post.cards and other pictures of women in art.the from Marilyn to Botticelli and Cranach a book about Picasso is opened and there is a picture of Les Demosielles d’Avignon any female favorite-artists have Cecilia not unfortunately says she spur.the comes from male artists like Rousseau Picasso Cranach female artists like Derkert Hjertén and Delauney is more moral support
\l In the studio, among paint, stands an old desk cluttered with post cards and other pictures of women in the art, from Marilyn to Botticelli and Cranach. A book about Picasso is opened and in it, there is a picture of Les Demosielles d’Avignon. Unfortunately, Cecilia does not have any female favorite artists, she says. The spur comes from male artists such as Rousseau, Picasso, Cranach. Female artists such as Derkert, Hjertén and Delauney is more of a moral support.

\t Lok6jyu5 tim1 .
\g Rain SFP
\l It’s raining!

\t John hou2 lek1 . BOB lek1 GWO3 keoi5 tim1 .
\g John very smart Bob smart COMP him SFP
\l John is smart. Bob is even smarter.’ Existential presupposition: there is a contextually salient individual y such that y ≠ Bob and y possesses smartness to a certain degree Scalar presupposition: the degree to which y is smart is smaller than that of x (which is trivially verified given (13)).

\t Bob sik1 POU4MAN2 tim1 .
\g Bob know Portuguese SFP
\l Bob also knows Portuguese.’ Existential presupposition: there has to be a language/skill y such that Bob knows it and y ≠ Portuguese Scalar presupposition: the set of languages/skills known by Bob is incremented by one.

\t LOK6JYU5 tim1 .
\g rain SFP
\l It’s raining!’ Existential presupposition: there must exist a proposition p′ such that p′ is contextually accessible and p′ is true. Scalar presupposition: raining is more unexpected than p′.

\l (int.) ‘A-Mei was born in HK. She studied in Argentina!

\t tot het einde
\g to the end\t tot aan het einde
\g to on the end\t tot het einde toe
\g to the end to\t tot aan het einde toe
\g to on the end to\t tot het einde aan toe
\g to the end on to\t tot aan het einde aan toe
\g to on the end on to\t *tot het einde aan
\g to the end on\t *tot aan het einde aan
\g to on the end on\t Jan heeft tot (aan) het einde ((aan) toe) geslapen .         temporal 
\g Jan has to on the end on to slept        
\l Jan has slept up to the end (of e.g. the meeting).

\t Jan heeft het gras tot (aan) het einde ((aan) toe) verwijderd .      spatial 
\g Jan has the grass to on the end on to removed     
\l Jan has removed the grass up to the end (e.g. from the garden path).

\t Jan heeft/*is tot (aan) het einde ((aan) toe) gelopen .       not predicative 
\g Jan has/is to on the end on to walked      
\l Jan has walked up to the end.

\t tot/naar het einde
\g to/to the end\t tot/*naar aan het einde
\g to/to on the end\t tot/naar de kerk
\g to/to the church\t tot/*naar voor de kerk
\g to/to in.front.of the church\t tot/naar de hoek

\t *tot aan toe het einde

\g to here/there on to\t tot dit/dat aan toe

\l to moor to the pier

\l to moor near the pier

\g to there/then\t tot daar/dan toe

\t Johnga migimedakeo tumureru .
\g John-NOM right.eye-only-ACC close-can-PRES
\l John can close only his right eye.’ (i) can > only (John can wink his right eye.) (ii) ?*only > can (It is only his right eye that he can close.)

\g phone-DET.ABS lose-PTCP-PRED (LOC).be.1sgABS,

\t Úchè pụ̀rụ̀ túpú Òbí àhụ́ Àdá n’áhị́á .
\g Uche left before Obi saw Ada P-market
\l Úchè left before Òbí saw Àdá at the market.’ declarative

\l Úchè knows the man who Àdá saw at the market.’ DO-RC

\g Uche know man  saw Àdá P-market
\l Úchè knows the man who saw Ada at the market.’ SU-RC

\t *Ònyé kà Úchè mà nwókē   OP ___ hụ̄rū ___ n’áhị́á   ?
\g who FOC Uche know man  saw P-market 
\l Lit. ‘Who does Úchè know the man who saw at the market?’ DO question from SU-RC

\t Ézè hụ̀rụ̀   Àdá nà ònyé   ?
\g Eze saw  Ada and who
\l Lit. ‘Ézè saw Àdá and who?’ in-situ wh-Conj2

\l Lit. ‘Who did Ézè see Àdá and?’ ex-situ wh-Conj2

\l Lit. ‘Who s/he and Úchè ate yam?’ ex-situ wh-Conj1 + RP

\t Gị́nị̄ kà Àdá kwèrè ___ ọ̀nụ̄ túpú ọ̀ zụ́rụ́ pg ?
\g what FOC Ada agree  mouth before she bought pg\t Àdá kwèrè gị́nị̄ ọ̀nụ̄ túpú ọ̀ zụ́rụ́ pg  ?

\l What did Àdá price before buying?

\g Ada met  woman DEM bought what 
\l Lit. ‘Àdá met the woman who bought what?’ CNPC-island

\g Ada saw Obi  before she bought what P-market

\t *  Nwááǹyị̀ àhụ́ zụ̄rụ̄ gị́nī   kà Àdá zùrù ?

\l Àdá met the woman who bought what?’ CNPC-island

\l Àdá saw Òbí before she bought what at the market?’ ADJ island

\t Anna läuft schneller als Maria (läuft) .
\g Anne walks faster than Mary walks
\l Anne walks faster than Mary (does).

\t Anna läuft so schnell wie Maria (läuft) .
\g Anne walks as fast as Mary walks
\l Anne walks as fast as Mary (does).

\t Anna läuft so wie Maria (läuft) .
\g Anne walks so as/like Mary walks
\l Anne walks as Mary does. / Anne walks like Mary.

\g Anne walks/runs as fast as if she for her life ran as ran she for her life
\l Anne is running as if she was running for her life.

\g Anne loves me more than you.ACC you.NOM
\l Anne loves me more than {(she loves) you / you (do)}.

\t Andem dritten tage . so wirdit er , alsor ê was .
\g on-the third day so becomes he as-he before was
\l On the third day, he becomes as he was before.

\t … so ligit er   also er tôt sî 
\g  so lies he  as he dead was
\l So he lies as if he was dead

\t *… so liegt er ,   als er tot sei 
\g  so lies he  as he dead was\t … so liegt er ,   als sei er tot 
\g  so lies he  as was he dead\t do kam ain grosser ludem vnd gerumppel ,   als vil mit harnasch an der tuer wëren 
\g there came a big noise and rumbling  as many with armour at the door were
\l There was a big noise and rumbling as if many men in armour were at the door.

\t *… als viele mit Harnischen an der Tür wären
\g  as many with armour at the door were\t … als wären viele mit Harnischen an der Tür
\g  as were many with armour at the door\t Filweiniger soellet jr darab vrsach nemmen/ an meinen worten zu zweifelen/ als das jch solchs zu thun nit vermoechte .
\g much-less should you therefore cause take at my words to doubt as that I such to do not might
\l All the less should you therefore doubt my words as if I was not able to do this.

\t da erkam der man als hart , daz er die varib verkerat , als ob er halber tod wër
\g then feared the man as much thet he the colour turned as if he half dead was
\l The man was frightened so much that he changed colour as if he was half-dead.

\t so bedunckt jn zun zyten er hoᵉre etwas susen oder prastlen als wenn es windete
\g so seems-to him at times he heard something whistle or crackle as if it was-windy
\l So it seemed to him at times as if he heard a whistling or crackling as if it was windy.

\t Die speiß die jch euch geben werde ( wolche wort hie Emphatica sein) als durch wólche der Herr nit ein gemein/ aber ein sondere speiß  …  zuverstehen geben wil …
\g the food which I you give will  which words here Emphatica are as through which the Lord not a common but a special food to-understand give wants
\l The food which I will give you (which words are Emphatica here) by which the Lord did not want to denominate a common food but a special one …

\t Ich weiß , wie Anna lebt , aber ich möchte mal wissen , wie Maria *(lebt) .
\g I know how Anne lives but I like PTCL know how Mary lives
\l I know how Anne lives but I would like to know how Mary lives.

\g Anne likes the person  the (one) whom Mary likes
\l Anne likes the person / him whom Maria likes.

\t Anna mag , wen Maria *(mag) .
\g Anne likes whom Mary likes
\l Anne likes whom Mary likes.

\g Anne wants  at the place  there live where Mary lives
\l Anne wants to live at the place/(there) where Mary lives.

\t Anna möchte leben , wo Maria *(lebt) .
\g Anne wants live where Mary lives
\l Anne wants to live where Mary lives.

\g Anne wants  in the way so  as well live as Mary lives
\l Anne wants to live the way that / as well as Mary lives.

\t Anna möchte leben , wie Maria (lebt) .
\g Anne wants live as Mary lives
\l Anne wants to live as Mary does/like Mary.

\t Er hörte , wie der Schlüssel im Schloss herumgedreht wurde .
\g he heard how the key in-the keyhole around-turned was
\l He heard that (/how) the key was being turned in the keyhole.

\t Wie sie sich dem Haus näherten , bemerkten sie , dass es ganz verfallen war .
\g as they REFL the house appoached noticed they that it rather dilapidated was
\l As (/when) they were approaching the house, they noticed that is was rather dilapidated.

\t Anna stieg die Treppe (so schnell) hinauf , wie Maria (die Treppe hinaufstieg) .
\g Anne climbed the stairs as quickly up as/like Mary the stairs up-climbed
\l Anne climbed up the stairs (as quickly), as/like Mary (climbed up the stairs).

\t Als Anna die Treppe hinaufstieg , hörte sie , {dass / wie} Maria *(die Treppe hinauftieg) .
\g when Anne the stairs up-climbed heard she that  how Mary the stairs up-climbed
\l When Anne was climbing up the stairs she heard that/how Mary was climbing up the stairs.

\t Hanno hustet , wie wenn ein Hofhund bellt .
\g Hanno coughes as if a watchdog barks
\l Hanno is coughing (as if/) like a watchdog barks.’ = (i) Hanno hustet. Der Husten klingt, wie es klingt, wenn ein Hofhund bellt. ‘Hanno is coughing. The cough sounds as it sounds if a watchdog barks.’ ≠ (ii) Hanno hustet, wie er hustet, wenn ein Hofhund bellt. ‘Hanno is coughing as he is coughing if a watchdog barks.

\t De Vader dirmeld (so)  wie häd er gesuf  .
\g the father staggers (so) as had he drunk
\l The father is staggering as if he was drunk.

\t Ear hot szo to  wie hättn szi eam zum Treschn otinnka  .
\g he has so done as had they him to-the flailing ordered
\l He behaved as if they had called him for flailing.

\t er bi unsih tod thulti · so wio so er selbo wolti
\g he with us death suffered  so how so he self wanted
\l He suffered death among us just as (/however) he himself wanted to

\t Iâ uuóltôn îuuere fórderen  . álso dû uuâno îh kehúgest  . uuîo dû lâse  . úmbe dîa úbermûoti dero consulum  . tîligôn iro ámbácht

\l Because of the presumption of the consuls, your ancestors, as you will, I trust, remember, as you read, wanted to efface consulship

\t swie si sint , sô wil ich sîn
\g how/as they are so want I be
\l However/as they are, so do I want to be.

\l You have as yet brought very little of it [= the treasure] to me into this country, although it used to be my own

\t  Schneller als Maria (läuft)  läuft Anna t t .
\g faster than Mary walks walks Anne 
\l Faster than Mary (walks), Anne walks.

\t  So schnell wie Maria (läuft)  läuft Anna t t .
\g as fast as Mary walks walks Anne 
\l As fast as Mary (walks), Anne walks.

\g  so as Mary walks walks Anne 
\l Like/as Mary (walks), Anne walks.

\t  { Den Menschen / den(jenigen)} , den Maria mag  mag sicher auch Anna t t .
\g  the person  the one whom Mary likes likes probably also Anne 
\l The person / the one whom Mary likes, Anne probably likes, too.

\t Anna liebt es mehr ,   zu trinken  als   zu essen  .
\g Anne loves it more  to drink than  to eat
\l Anne loves to drink more than to eat.

\t Anna liebt es so (sehr)  zu trinken  wie  zu essen  .
\g Anne loves it so/as (much) to drink as to eat
\l Anne loves to eat (as much) as to drink. / Anne loves to drink like she eats (i.e. to drink and to eat in the same manner).

\t Anna liebt es ,  zu trinken  und  zu essen  .
\g Anne loves it to drink and to eat
\l Anne loves to eat and to drink.

\t *Es liebt  zu trinken  , wer  zu essen  .
\g it loves to drink who to eat
\l He who (loves) to eat loves to drink.

\t *Anna liebt es ,  zu trinken  , weil  zu essen  .
\g Anne loves it to drink because to eat
\l Anne loves to drink because (she loves) to eat.

\t Maria steigt eher  auf  als  ab  .
\g Mary climbs rather up than down
\l Mary will rather go up than down.

\t Maria steigt so(viel)  auf  wie  ab  .
\g Mary climbs so/as much up as down
\l Mary will go up as much as down. / Mary will go up like she goes down.

\t Maria steigt  auf  und  ab  .
\g Mary climbs up and down
\l Mary will go up and down.

\t *Es steigt  auf  , wer  ab  .
\g it climbs up who down
\l He who (goes) down will go up.

\t *Maria steigt  auf  , nachdem  ab  .
\g Mary climbs up after down
\l Mary goes up after (she has gone) down.

\t Anna liest ihren Studenten Bücher so (oft) vor wie  Maria   ihren Kindern  .
\g Anne reads her students books so/as often PTCL as Mary her children
\l Anne reads books to her students as often as / like Mary to her children.

\t Anna liest ihren Studenten Bücher vor und  Maria   ihren Kindern  .
\g Anne reads her students books PTCL than Mary her children
\l Anne reads books to her students and Mary to her children.

\t *Anna liest ihren Studenten vor , was  Maria   ihren Kindern  .
\g Anne reads her students PTCL what Mary her children
\l Anne reads to her students what Mary (reads) to her children.

\t *Anna liest ihren Studenten vor , weil  Maria   ihren Kindern  .
\g Anne reads her students PTCL because Mary her children
\l Anne reads to her students because Mary (reads) to her children.

\t Was ist Anna mehr t als Maria t ist ?
\g what is Anne more  than Mary  is
\l What is Anne more than Mary is?

\t Was ist Anna so (sehr) t wie Maria t ist ?
\g what is Anne so/as much  as Mary  is
\l What is Anne as much / in the same way as Mary is?

\t Was mag Anna t und hasst Maria t ?
\g what likes Anne  and hates Mary 
\l What does Anne like and Mary hate?

\t *Was gibt Anna t , wem auch Maria t gibt ?
\g what gives Anne  whom also Mary  gives
\l What does Anne give to whom also Mary gives (it)?

\t *Was mag Anna t , obwohl Maria t hasst ?
\g what likes Anne  although Mary  hates
\l What does Anne like although Mary hates (it)?

\t dass Anna schneller hinfährt als zurückfährt
\g that Anne faster there-goes than back-goes
\l that Anne goes there faster than she goes back

\t dass Anna so (schnell) hinfährt wie zurückfährt
\g that Anne so/as fast there-goes as back-goes
\l that Anne goes there as fast / in the same way as she goes back

\t dass Anna hinfährt und zurückfährt
\g that Anne there-goes and back-goes
\l that Anne will go there and back

\t dass hinfährt , wer zurückfährt
\g that there-goes who back-goes
\l that he will go there who goes back

\t dass Anna hinfährt , wenn Maria zurückfährt
\g that Anne there-goes if Mary back-goes
\l that Anne will go there if Mary goes back

\t Ez sol auch ieclich flaischhacker seín flaisch svnd’n  …  vn̄ sol ieclich flaisch da fuͤr geben , vnd es ist . als dicke , vnd er daz bricht , als dick gibt er sehtzic pfenninge
\g it shall also every butcher his meat separate and shall every meat that for give and/that it is as often and/as he that breaks as often gives he sixty pfennigs
\l Every butcher shall separate his meat and shall give each meat for what it is. As often as he breaks this (rule), as often shall he give sixty pfennigs.

\t Die Buͤrger Reich vnd Arm/ Trachteten nicht nach eigenem sondern nach gemeinem nutze/ dem Armen als dem Reichen .
\g the citizens rich and poor sought not after own but after common benefit to-the poor as to-the rich
\l The citizens rich and poor did not seek their own but common benefit for the poor as/and for the rich.

\t Und wie ein Medicus damit er so wol seiner eignen Wissenschafft/ alß auch andrer Wolstand aufhelffe/ den Außrath des Leibs besichtiget …
\g and as a doctor so-that he as well his own science as also others’ well-being promote the excrement of-the body inspects
\l And as a doctor, in order to promote his own science as well as the well-being of others inspects the excrements of the body …

\t Vnd ist nit nur mit der Schrifft/ sondern auch mit den so geschribenen als muͤndlich vbergegebenen Glaubens bekantnuͤssen geschehen/ was S . Augustinus sagt: …
\g and is not only with the script but also with the as written as orally transmitted faith testimonies happened what St. Augustin says
\l And not only to the bible, but also to the written and the orally transmitted testimonies of faith, it happened as St. Augustin says: …

\t lasz die thoren , die zu wagen , so wie die zu rosz und fusz , böses oder gutes sagen .
\g let the fools who in carridges so as those on horseback and foot bad or good say
\l Let the fools in their carridges just as those on horseback and by foot say bad or good things.

\l Strictly speaking, they should have a lot more points than they have.

\t Ben bastelt mit an einer Seifenkiste .
\g Ben tinkers mit with a soapbox
\l Ben belongs to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox.

\t Ben fährt mit nach Rom .
\g Ben rides mit to Rome
\l Ben belongs to a set of people riding to Rome.

\t {Auch / *Mit} Ben bastelt an einer Seifenkiste .
\g {also / mit} Ben tinkers with a soapbox\t In diesem Raum ist Ben mit der größte .
\g in this room is Ben mit the tallest
\l Ben belongs to the tallest people in this room.

\t In dieser Gruppe kocht Mia mit am besten .
\g in this group cooks Mia mit PTC best
\l Mia cooks in a way that belongs to the best ways of cooking in this group.

\t In seiner Klasse hat Paul mit das eleganteste Outfit .
\g in his class has Paul mit the most elegant outfit
\l Paul has an outfit that belongs to the most elegant outfits in his class.

\t #Ben ist {auch / mit anderen} der größte .
\g Ben is {also / with others} the tallest
\l Ben is {also / together with other people} the tallest.

\t Ben ist mit der größte . ↛ Ben ist der größte .
\g Ben is mit the tallest  Ben is the tallest\t Ben bastelt mit an einer Seifenkiste . → Ben bastelt an einer Seifenkiste .
\g Ben tinkers mit with a soapbox  Ben tinkers with a soapbox\t Ben und Paul sind die größten . ↛ Ben ist der größte .
\g Ben and Paul are the tallest  Ben is the tallest\t #Ben ist mit {groß / größer als Paul} .
\g Ben is mit {tall / taller than Paul}\t Ben hat mit am Rad gebastelt . (mit)
\g Ben has mit with the bike tinkered \t Ben hat am Rad mitgebastelt . (verbal particle)
\g Ben has with the bike with:tinkered \t Ben ist mit zur Werkstatt gefahren . (mit)
\g Ben is mit to the garage ridden 
\l Ben belonged to a set of people riding to the garage.

\t Ben ist zur Werkstatt mitgefahren . (verbal particle)
\g Ben is to the garage with:ridden \t Mia sprang {mit  ʔ auf / *mitauf} . (mit)
\g Mia jumps {mit up / with:up} 
\l Mia belonged to a set of people jumping up.

\t Mia läuft {*vor  ʔ an / voran} . (verbal particle)
\g Mia runs {forward at / forward:at} 
\l Mia is running ahead.

\g Ben puts the bike mit in the hall
\l Ben is putting the bike in the hall, which accompanies Ben’s putting at least one other thing in the hall.

\t Ben bastelt AUCH an einer Seifenkiste .
\g Ben tinkers also with a soapbox
\l Ben is ALso tinkering with a soapbox.

\g also Ben tinkers with a soapbox\t Auch an einer SEIfenkiste basteln wird Ben .
\g also with a soapbox tinker will Ben
\l Ben will be tinkering also with a SOAPbox.

\g mit Ben tinkers with a soapbox\t Ben bastelt mit an einer SEIfenkiste .
\g Ben tinkers mit with a soapbox\t Mit an einer SEIfenkiste basteln wird Ben .
\g mit with a soapbox tinker will Ben
\l Ben will belong to a set of people tinkering with a SOAPbox.

\g Ben rides also mit to Rome
\l Ben ALso belongs to a set of people riding to Rome.

\g only Ben is mit to Rome ridden
\l Only Ben belonged to a set of people riding to Rome.

\g Ben tinkers with Mia with a soapbox
\l Ben is tinkering with a soapbox together with Mia.

\l Ben is tinkering with Mia’s bike {with his new tool / with care}.

\t Es ist unmöglich , dass Ben mit an einer Seifenkiste bastelt; er hasst jede Form von Teamarbeit .
\g it is impossible that Ben mit with a soapbox tinkers; he hates every kind of teamwork
\l It is impossible that Ben belongs to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox; he hates all kinds of teamwork.

\t Wenn Ben mit an einer Seifenkiste bastelt , kann sich das entsprechende Team freuen; er ist ein echter Kenner .
\g if Ben mit with a soapbox tinkers can REFL the corresponding team rejoice he is a true expert
\l If Ben belongs to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox, the team in question can rejoice; he is a true expert.

\t Ben bastelt nicht (bloß) mit an einer Seifenkiste , sondern er bastelt daran with it
\g Ben tinkers not (merely) mit with a soapbox but he tinkers allein. alone
\l Ben does not (merely) belong to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox, but he is tinkering with it on his own.

\t Mia bastelt nicht mit an einer fliegenden Seifenkiste . An so etwas bastelt niemand !
\g Mia tinkers not mit with a flying soapbox with such a thing tinkers nobody
\l Mia does not belong to a set of people tinkering with a flying soapbox. Nobody tinkers with such a thing!

\t #Es ist möglich , dass Ben AUCH an Seifenkisten bastelt .
\g it is possible that Ben also with soapboxes tinkers
\l It is possible that Ben ALso tinkers with soapboxes.

\t #Paul glaubt , dass Ben mit an einer Seifenkiste bastelt .
\g Paul believes that Ben mit with a soapbox tinkers
\l Paul believes that Ben belongs to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox.

\t Paul glaubt , dass Ben AUCH an einer Seifenkiste bastelt .
\g Paul believes that Ben also with a soapbox tinkers
\l Paul believes that Ben is ALso tinkering with a soapbox.

\t #Mia schraubt mit an einem Bentley . Sie treffen sich montags .
\g Mia screws mit with a Bentley they meet REFL Mondays.
\l Mia belongs to a set of people working on a Bentley. They meet on Mondays.

\t Mia schraubt mit an einem Bentley . Das ist toll .
\g Mia screws mit with a Bentley that is great
\l Mia belongs to a set of people working on a Bentley. That (= her accompaniment / ≠ the cooperation) is great.

\t Mia schraubt #(mit) an einem Bentley .
\g Mia screws (mit) with a Bentley
\l Mia belongs to a set of people working on a Bentley.

\t {Das Team / Die Teamarbeit} ist toll .
\g {the team / the teamwork} is great
\l {The team / The teamwork} is great.

\t Die Partner sind sehr kompetent .
\g the partners are very competent
\l The partners are very competent.

\t Ben bastelt mit an einer Seifenkiste , {obwohl / #weil} er gern für sich arbeitet .
\g Ben tinkers mit with a soapbox {although / because} he gladly for himself works
\l Ben belongs to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox {although / because} he likes to work on his own.

\t #Ben hat sich gestern mit Lilli und Mia getroffen . Er hat mit an einer Seifenkiste gebastelt , weil  beide gerne basteln .
\g Ben has REFL yesterday with Lilli and Mia met he has mit with a soapbox tinkered because  both gladly tinker
\l Ben met Lilli and Mia yesterday. He belonged to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox because both like to tinker.

\t Beteiligt sich Ben an einem Basteln an einer Seifenkiste ? – Ja , Ben bastelt mit an einer Seifenkiste .
\g participates REFL Ben in a tinkering with a soapbox – yes Ben tinkers mit with a soapbox
\l Does Ben participate in a tinkering with a soapbox? – Yes, Ben belongs to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox.

\t Bastelt Ben alLEIN an der Seifenkiste ? – Nein , Ben bastelt nur MIT an der Seifenkiste .
\g tinkers Ben alone with the soapbox – no Ben tinkers only mit with the soapbox
\l Does Ben tinker with the soapbox aLONE? – No, Ben only belongs to a SET of people tinkering with the soapbox.

\t #Was tun Mia und Lilli ? – Ben bastelt mit an einer Seifenkiste .
\g what do Mia and Lilli – Ben tinkers mit with a soapbox
\l What are Mia and Lilli doing? – Ben belongs to a set of people tinkering with a soapbox.

\g Mia screws with others with a Bentley they meet REFL Mondays
\l Mia works on a Bentley with others. They meet on Mondays.

\t Ben hat sich gestern mit Lilli und Mia getroffen . Er hat mit ihnen an einer Seifenkiste gebastelt , weil beide gerne basteln .
\g Ben has REFL yesterday with Lilli and Mia met he has with them with a soapbox tinkered because both gladly tinker
\l Ben met Lilli and Mia yesterday. He was tinkering with a soapbox with them because both like to tinker.

\t Was tun Mia und Lilli ? – Ben bastelt mit ihnen an einer Seifenkiste .
\g what do Mia and Lilli – Ben tinkers with them with a soapbox
\l What are Mia and Lilli doing? – Ben is tinkering with a soapbox with them.

\t Ben alLEIN an der Seifenkiste ? – Nein , Ben bastelt nur mit Lilli und MIa an der Seifenkiste .
\g Ben alone with the soapbox – no Ben tinkers only with Lilli and Mia with the soapbox
\l Bastelt tinkers ‘Does Ben tinker with the soapbox aLONE? – No, Ben only tinkers with the soapbox with Lilli and MIa.

\t Allerdings trägt er nur wenig bei .
\g however contributes he only little to
\l However, he only is contributing little to it.

\t Tatsächlich macht er das meiste .
\g in fact does he the most
\l In fact, he is doing the most.

\g Ben carried the piano mit up  Ben carried the piano up
\l Ben belonged to a set of people carrying up the piano.’ ↛ ‘Ben carried up the piano.

\t Ben schließt das Projekt mit ab . ↛ Ben schließt das Projekt ab .
\g Ben closes the project mit off  Ben closes the project off
\l Ben belongs to a set of people finishing the project.’ ↛ ‘Ben finishes the project.

\t Der Sessel füllt den Raum mit aus . ↛ Der Sessel füllt den Raum aus .
\g the armchair fills the room mit out  the armchair fills the room out
\l The armchair belongs to a set of things filling out the room.’ ↛ ‘The armchair fills out the room.

\t #Ben ist mit {groß / blond / müde / wütend} .
\g Ben is mit {tall / blond / tired / angry}
\l Ben belongs to a set of {tall / blond / tired / angry} people.

\t #Ben ist mit {größer / müder / wütender} als Mia .
\g Ben is mit {taller / more tired / more angry} than Mia
\l Ben belongs to a set of people that are {taller / more tired / more angry} than Mia.

\t Ben ist AUCH {groß / größer als Mia} .
\g Ben is also {tall / taller than Mia}
\l Ben is ALso {tall / taller than Mia}.

\t Ben ist mit {auf dem Dachboden / im Keller} . 
\g Ben is mit {in the attic / in the basement}
\l Ben belongs to a set of people {in the attic / in the basement}.

\t Der Schlüssel ist mit in der Kiste .
\g the key is mit in the box
\l The key belongs to a set of things in the box.

\t Ben ist mit anwesend .
\g Ben is mit present
\l Ben belongs to a set of people present.

\g Ben {resembles Tim mit / weighs mit 70 kg / loves Mia mit}
\l Ben belongs to a set of people that {resemble Tim / weigh 70 kg / love Mia}.

\g this belongs mit to our tasks
\l This belongs to a set of things that are our tasks.

\l Ben belongs to a set of people standing at the corner.

\g the key lies mit in the box
\l The key belongs to a set of things lying in the box.

\l And thus all the lesser judiciaries must act… complaints must be brought to the judicial officer’ (1300, Grand coutumier de Normandie)

\t et seur ce demanda il l’establie
\g and on this ask-PST-3S 3S-NOM the ordinance
\l and on this he asked for the ordinance (to be pronounced)’ (1250, Établissements de Normandie)

\t Richarz dist que il ne devoit pas donner aide ne fere servise en ost , mes à Biaumont devoit il service de V chevaliers
\g Richard say-PST that 3S-NOM NEG must-PST-3S NEG give-INF help nor do-PR-3S service in army but to Biaumont owe-PST-3S 3S-NOM service of five knights
\l Richard said that he didn’t have to give help nor give service to the army, but to Biaumont he owes the service of 5 knights’ (1207–1211, Arrêt de l’échiquier)

\t Ben put un home achater Choses a sun oes …
\g well can-PST-3S a man buy-INF things to his army …
\l A man can well buy things from his army’ (1236, Coutume d’Exeter)

\t quar toz jours doit ele son siège , espousée ou à espouser
\g since always must-PR-3S 3-F-S-NOM her seat espoused-PTCP or to espouse-INF
\l For she [the ship] must always pay anchorage fees.’ (1291, Vicompté de l’eau de Rouen)

\t et , se ele fu feite en Engleterre ,14 bien soit ele de Flandres , si doit ele estre espousée
\g and, if 3-F-S-NOM be-PST-3S made-PCTP in England, well be-PR-SUBJ 3-F-S-NOM of Flanders, if must-PR-3S 3-F-S-NOM be-INF espoused-PTCP
\l And, if it is made in England, even if it comes from Flanders, it [a ship] must be taxed.’ (1291, Vicompté de l’eau de Rouen)

\t Il fu jugié que por la foi que uns chevaliers donna à l’évesque ne pueit pas li évesques contraindre le de respondINF
\g 3S-NOM be-PST-3S judge-PTCP that for the faith-F that a-NOM knight-NOM give-PST-3S to-the bishop NEG can-PR NEG the-NOM bishop-NOM constrain-INF 3S-ACC to respond-INF
\l It was judged that for the faith that a knight gave to a bishop, the bishop can’t constrain him to respond

\t Il fu jugié que à la suer Richart … remaint la terre de son mariage qe Richart li demandoit
\g 3S-NOM be-PST-3S judge-PTCP that to the-F sister Richard remain-PR-3S the-F land of her marriage that Richard 3S-DAT ask-PST-3S
\l It was judged that to the sister of Richard remains the land of her marriage that he was asking for

\t … distrent: que chacune nef qui vient au port de Caen … , elle doura la sole et loial coustume
\g … say-PR-3P: that each boat that come-PR-3P in-the port of Caen 3-F-S-NOM give-FUT-3S the-F only and loyal custom
\l (they) said that each boat that comes into Caen’s harbor, it should pay the regular custom’ (1205, Patronage)

\g A-ing want buy one-CL book
\l A-ing would like to buy a book.‘ (tone group, the entire VP; ‘buy’, combination tone; tsheh ‘book’, isolation tone)

\l A-ing would like to buy one (book).’ (tone group, the entire VP; ‘buy’, combination tone; the Cl pun, isolation tone)

\g  I=GEN husband-GEN lord=GEN alone=QUE sleep-SPP.ANP

\t … pototogisu nakite sa .watar .u . Kimipa kikit .uya .
\g  cuckoo cry-GER PRF.pass.FNP you=GEN hear-PFV.FNP=QUE
\l …the cuckoo has passed crying. Have you heard it?

\t Miyosinono yamano arasino samu .kyekuni pataya koyopwimo aga pitori nem .u .
\g PN=GEN mountain=GEN storm=GEN cold.NMZ=ADV perhaps=QUE tonight=FOC I=GEN alone sleep-FUT.ANP
\l Will I have to sleep alone again tonight in the cold of the storm blowing from Mt. Yoshino?

\t Ameno sitano maturigotopa tapirakye .ku yasurakye .ku tukape~matur .ube .sitonamo omoposimes .u .
\g heaven=GEN below=GEN government=TOP smooth.ADV peaceful.ADV serve~conduct.FNP=DEO.FNP=QUO=FOC think[hon].ANP
\l [The emperor] deigns to think that the government of the world should be conducted smoothly and peacefully.

\t  poem totenamu yari~tamafeker .eba , itoni na .ku mede .te notimadenamu katariker .u .
\g [poem]=QUO=FOC send~give-PRT.CON=TOP really not.be.ADV be.lovable=GER later=LMT.FOC tell-PRT.ANP
\l Since he sent the poem saying [….], [Toshiko] was very much touched, and kept telling [everyone] about it until much later.

\t Kinopukoso tosipa pate .sika paru~kasumi kasugano yamanipa haya tatinikeri .
\g yesterday=CFC year=TOP end-PRP spring~mist PN=GEN mountain=LOC=TOP early rise-PFV.PRT
\l While it is just yesterday that the year has ended, [today] the spring mist is [already] rising on Mount Kasuga.

\t Uretakiya siko~pototogisu . Imakosoba koweno kar .ugani ki naki~toyomem .e .
\g annoying=EXC bad-cuckoo now=CFC=TOP voice=GEN get.hoarse.ANP=LIM come cry-resound-FUT.PRE
\l Bad, bad cuckoo! You should come and sing now [and not before] so loud that your voice gets hoarse, [but you actually don’t].

\t Medurasito aga omop .u kimipa aki~yamano patumomiti~bani ni .tekoso ariker .e .
\g adorable=QUO I=GEN long.for.ANP lord=TOP fall~moutain=GEN first-maple~leave=DAT resemble.GER=CFC be-PRT.PRE
\l It is the first red leaves of the mountain in fall that you, who I adore, resemble.

\t Oso~payamo nawokoso matam .e . Mukatuwono sipino koyadeno apipa tagap .azi
\g late~early=FOC you=ACC=CFC wait-FUT.PRE distant-GEN-hill=GEN oak=DAT twig=GEN meet=TOP miss.NFU
\l Early or late, it is for you that I will wait. We will meet without fail, like the twigs of the oak trees on the hills over there.

\t Nagekitutu masurawono kwono kwop .urekoso waga yup .u kamino pitite nureker .e .
\g cry-DUR strong man=GEN son=GEN love.PRE=CFC I=GEN tie.ANP hair=GEN get.wet-GER get.wet-PRT.PRE
\l It is because you strong man are longing for me with deep sighs, that my tied up hair has got wet and untied.

\l What nonsense, even now you talk like a child, though you are so old!

\t …kimiga tukapiwo mati .si yono nagoriso . Imamo i nen .u yono opo .ki .

\g Ones I_have seen two of_the participants
\l lit. ‘I have seen two ones (=participants) of the participants.

\t Ne ho visti due , dei partecipanti .
\g Ones I_have seen two, of_the participants
\l (like above, but with a pause before the PP)

\t Meyvelerden üç elmasin(yi) yedim .

\l I ate three apples of the (set of) fruits.

\t parecchi dei partecipanti
\g several of_the participants
\l several of the participants
