\t Ne ha fatte di {quelle ! / *queste ! / *quelle laggiù} .
\g them he_has done of {those! / these! / those over_there}
\l He did such (naughty) things!

\t Di stupidaggini , ne ha fatte di quelle (*dieci) t…
\g of silly things, NE he_has done of those ten
\l He made silly actions of such magnitude…’ not ‘He did some of those ten silly actions…

\t J’ ai eu à traiter un certain nombre de dossiers de ce type et je traite encore un certain nombre de dossiers de ce type .
\g I have had to treat a certain number of files of this type and I treat still a certain number of files of this type
\l I had to deal with and I still deal with a certain number of such files.’ (Frank Méjean, Le guide du divorce)

\t Certaines agences immobilières ont déjà fermé leurs portes , ou vont bientôt fermer leurs portes .
\g certain agencies real.estate have already, closed their doors, or will soon close their doors
\l Some real estate agencies have already, or will soon close their doors.’ (Le Monde newspaper)

\t … une carte interactive de tous les sites de production à grande échelle qui ont vu le jour , ou qui vont voir le jour dans les mois qui viennent en France .
\g … a map interactive of all the sites of manufacturing at large scale REL have seen the day, or REL will see the day in the months REL come in France
\l …an interactive map of all the large scale manufacturing sites that have, or that will open in the following months in France.’ (franceinter.fr, 2015/02/20)

\t Parler de sujets scientifiques , des innovations qui ont impacté le quotidien du grand public ou qui vont impacter le quotidien du grand public .

\l Talking about scientific topics, innovations that have or that will impact the daily life of the population at large.’ (http://www.cnrs.fr/centre-est)

\t Parmi les nominés , on retrouve les artistes qui ont investi les scènes de France ou qui vont investir les scènes de France .
\g among the nominees, we find the artists REL have invested the scenes of France or REL will invest the scenes of France
\l Among the nominees, we find the artists who have or who will invest the French scenes.’ (www.etudiant-france.info)

\l Peter is moving out of his flat. He did not give notice because the rent has risen, but because his flatmates smoke.

\t Maryga  Johnga  zibunno gakuseiga juuyoona kasetsuo teianshita to  jimanshiteitano no kekkano shitekishita .
\g Mary-NOM John-NOM self-GEN student-NOM important hypothesis-ACC propose-do-PAST COMP boasted-had-no-GEN defect-ACC point.out-do-PAST
\l [John had boasted [that his student proposed an important hypothesis]] and Mary pointed out a defect in it.

\t   Maryga itsu ronbuno shiageruka  Johnga Tomni tazuneteita nono shuppanga okureta .
\g Mary-NOM when paper-ACC finish-Q John-NOM Tom-DAT asked-had-no-GEN publication-NOM was delayed
\l [[John had asked Tom [when Mary would finish a (certain) paper]] and the publication of that paper was delayed.

\t *Maryga    Johnga   atarasii kasetuo teiansita  gakusei o hometeita no no kekkan o sitekisita .
\g Mary-NOM John-NOM new
                                                hypothesis-ACC propose-PAST student-ACC praise-had-no-GEN defect-ACC point.out-do-PAST
\l John praised the student [who proposed a new hypothesis] and Mary pointed out a defect in it.

\t  ?*Marywa    Johnga  kareno gakuseiga atarasii kasetuo teiansita node kankino koeo ageta no no akirakana kekkan o suguni sitekisita .
\g Mary-TOP John-NOM his student-NOM new hypothesis-ACC propose-PAST because joy-GEN voice-ACC
                                            raise-PAST-no-GEN obvious defect-ACC promptly point.out-do-PAST
\l John shouted with joy [because his student proposed a new hypothesis], and Mary promptly pointed out an obvious defect in it.

\t Bokuwa      sono toppina kaiketuhooo teiansita  seibisi ga imadewa moo Amerika no kaisyade erakunatteiru  no  pro   no habahiroi zituyooseini imasaranagara kantansita .

\l The engineer who proposed that preposterous solution is now a big shot in an American company, and I marveled again at its wide-range applicability.

\l There’s a corn cob in here.

\t beseder , yesh lanu po dapim .
\g fine, be to.us here pages.

\t hine ktanim .
\g here small.PL.
\l Here are some small ones.

\t tiri .
\g look.FM.
\l Look.

\t ze shaxor .
\g this black.
\l This is black.

\t hine cahov .
\g here yellow.
\l Here’s(a) yellow one.

\t hine shaxor .
\g here black.
\l Here’s a black one.

\t hine uga .

\l Here’s a cake.

\t hine hamon ugot .

\l Here are a lot of cakes.

\t bo nistakel kan batmunot .
\g come will.look.1.PL here in-the-pictures.
\l Let’s look at the pictures here.

\t ani marsha .
\g I allow.FM.
\l I agree.

\t anaxnu lo yexolim lakaxat .
\g we not able to-take.
\l We can’t take [it].

\t oy , ze kimat nofel .
\g oy, this almost falls.
\l Oy, it’s almost falling.

\t bo’u .
\g come.PL.
\l Come.

\t ze omed lipol .
\g it stands to-fall.
\l It’s going to fall.

\t mexaleket . 
\g handing out.FM.
\l Handing out.

\t xaser kos .
\g missing.MS.SG glass.FM.SG.
\l A glass is missing.

\l Plates are missing.

\t ki yesh od kos axat .
\g because be more glass one.
\l Because there’s one more glass.

\t bekeilu at lakaxt et ze .
\g in-as if you.FM.SG took.2.FM.SG ACC this.
\l Let’s pretend you took it.

\t lo , nisharti po im ima .
\g no, stayed.1.SG here with mommy.
\l No, I stayed here with mommy.

\t tihye mesiba nehederet .
\g will.be.3.FM.SG party.FM great.FM.
\l There will be a great party.

\t axshav nikax balonim .
\g now will-take.1.PL balloons.
\l Now we’ll take balloons.

\t bo’u na’ase hacba’a .
\g come.2.PL will.do.1.PL voting.
\l Let’s vote.

\t Amit , at yexola lehaxzik et habama kaxa ? 
\g Amit, you.FM can.FM to-hold ACC the-stage like this?
\l Amit, can you hold the stage like this?

\t ani lo yexola kol hahacaga .
\g I not can.FM all the-show.
\l I can’t do it throughout the show.

\t bekei’lu at lakaxt et ze , velo hersheti , vepit’om amarti lax asur .

\l Let’s pretend that you took it, and I didn’t allow it, and suddenly I told you “no.

\t bo’i .
\g come.2.FM.SG.
\l Come.

\t rega , ani sama xulca .

\l I also have this ball.

\t yesh lexa gam et hasha’on .

\l You also have the watch.

\l The woman comes to us, the women are sitting here.

\t yṣarxūn maʕa baʕaḍ wuhma gāʕdīn ʕala alqanafa
\g 3-shout.IPFV-PL with each other CONJ-3PL.NOM sit.ACT.PTCP-PL on DEF-sofa
\l They shout at one another while they are sitting on the sofa.

\t niħna mā ğīna albaħar ʕašān nifḍal gāʕdīn
\g we NEG come.PFV-1PL DEF-beach in order to 1PL-remain.IPFV sit.ACT.PTCP-PL
\l We did not come to the beach to remain sitting.

\t ʕādi kull wāħid gāʕid bbētuh wa ma leh šuɣl ṯāni

\l He argues, therefore, wrongly, who argues that he is innocent, if he appropriates especially to himself the good things God gave us for common use.

\g {die.DEM.F diese.DEM.F neither} / {die.DEM.M diese.DEM.M neither} one more case take must
\l The judge informed the public prosecutor that {she, he, neither} must take on another case.

\g the public prosecutor.ACC.M informed the judge.NOM.M that diese.DEM one more case take must

\l …that he credited me in the Senate, not once but often and at length, with having saved the empire and the world.

\t quod mortem hominis necessārī graviter ferō
\g because death.ACC person.GEN close.GEN grievously bear-1SG
\l because I take the death of a close friend grievously

\t ut cohortēs ex castrīs celeriter ēdūceret
\g that cohorts.ACC out.of camp.ABL quickly lead.out-TH-IMPF.SJV-3SG
\l that he should lead the cohorts out of the camp quickly

\t   Nōn     ego illud parvī aestim ₁ō    .
\g  not  I.NOM that.ACC small.GEN estimate-1SG 
\l I don’t consider that a small thing.

\t …cum cēterī₂ centūriās₃ nōn     exple ₁ssent   .
\g since others.NOM centuries.ACC not  fill-PLUP.SJV-3PL 
\l …since the others did not win the required number of centuries.

\t Corbulō₂ …   nōn     eam speciem īnsignium et armōrum praetul ₁it    …
\g Corbulo.NOM  not  that.ACC show.ACC emblems.GEN and weapons.GEN display-PERF.3SG 
\l Corbulo did not make such a display of emblems and weaponry…

\t Iīs  ne rēbus manūs adferre nōn dubitāstī… ?
\g those.DAT = YNQ things.DAT hands.ACC lay.on-PRS.INF-ACT not hesitate-TH-PERF.2SG
\l Did you not hesitate to lay your hands on those things…?

\t Praetor hērēdēs facere ⟨*potest⟩ nōn ⟨potest⟩ .

\l to make an enormous amount of money

\t *¿Quién preguntaste si __ llamó por teléfono ?
\g who ask-2SG.PST if  call-3SG.PST by phone
\l Who did you ask if__ phoned?

\l What dictionary didn’t you know if Celia had returned already?

\l Who don’t you know why__wrote the report?

\t ¿Quién __ cree  que el discurso ofendió tanto a Julia ayer  ?

\l Who__believes that the discourse offended Julia so much yesterday?

\t ¿Quién __ cree  que el discurso del director ofendió a Julia  ?

\l Who__believes that the director’s discourse offended Julia?

\l Who do you believe that__offended Julia so much with the discourse?

\t *¿De quién crees  que el discurso __ ofendió tanto a Julia  ?
\g of who believe-2SG.PRS COMP DET discourse  offend-3SG.PST so.much to Julia
\l Of who do you believe that the discourse__offended Julia so much?

\t ¿Quién __ ha pedido  que resolvamos el problema en la reunión  ?
\g who  have.3SG.PRS ask-PTCP COMP solve-1PL.PRS DET problem in DET meeting
\l Who__has asked that we solve the problem at the meeting?

\t ¿Quién __ ha hecho la petición de  que resolvamos el problema  ?
\g who  have.3SG.PRS make.PTCP DET petition of COMP solve-1PL.PRS DET problem
\l Who__has made the petition that we solve the problem?

\t ¿Qué has pedido  que resolvamos __ en la reunión el viernes  ?

\l What have you asked that we solve__at the meeting on Friday?

\t *¿Qué has hecho la petición de  que resolvamos __ el viernes  ?
\g what have-2SG.PRS make.PTCP DET petition of COMP solve-1PL.PRS  DET Friday
\l What have you made the petition that we solve__on Friday?

\l Who__complained when we announced the dismissals at the meeting?

\l What did you think that we unexpectedly announced__at the meeting?

\t *¿Qué protestaste  cuando anunciamos __ en la reunión de improviso  ?
\g what complain-2SG.PST when announce-1PL.PST  in DET meeting of unexpected
\l What did you complain when we unexpectedly announced__at the meeting?

\l Who__thinks that we have found some keys?

\t Hans will/darf/kann/muss ø ein Eis essen . modal verb
\g Hans wants/may/must  an ice(cream) eat 
\l Hans wants/may/must eat some ice cream.

\t Er sieht/lässt die Kinder ø spielen . perception verbs , let
\g he sees/let the children  play 
\l He sees/let the children play.

\t Ich verspreche , den Rasen zu mähen . propositional
\g I promise  the lawn to mow attitude verb
\l I promise to mow the lawn.

\t Der Rasen scheint zu wachsen . raising verb
\g the lawn seems to grow 
\l The lawn seems to grow.

\t Diese Wolle ist gut zu stricken . toughconstruction
\g this wool is good/easy to knit 
\l This wool is easy to knit.

\t Ich habe vergessen/versucht , die Türe zu schließen . forget/trytype
\g I have forgotten/tried the door to close 
\l I forgot to close the door.

\t Ich habe nicht genug Geld , um eine Fahrkarte zu kaufen purpose infinitive
\g I have not enough change in-order a ticket to buy. 
\l I do not have enough change to by a ticket.

\t Hans will mehr Geld verdienen
\g Hans will more money earn
\l Hans wants to earn more money.

\t Hans will , dass er mehr Geld verdient
\g Hans will that he more money earns
\l Hans wants/wishes that he earns/would earn more money.

\t Du brauchst das nicht (zu) tun
\g you need that not (to) do
\l You don’t need to do that.

\t Ich versuchte stundenlang ihn zu erreichen . try + ADV ok
\g I tried for hours him to reach  
\l I tried to reach him for hours.

\t Ich erreichte ihn (*stundenlang) . lex + ADV *
\g I reached him (for hours)  
\l intended: ‘I reached him (for hours).

\t Ich musste/durfte/konnte30 ihn (*stundenlang) erreichen . mod + ADV *
\g I must-/was allowed/was able him (for hours) reach  
\l intended: ‘I had to/was allowed to/was able to reach him (for hours).

\t Ich versuchte (stundenlang) zu arbeiten try + ADV ok
\g I tried (for hours) to work  
\l I tried to work for hours.

\t Ich arbeitete (stundenlang) lex + ADV ok
\g I worked (for hours)  
\l I worked for hours.

\t Ich musste/durfte/konnte (stundenlang) arbeiten mod + ADV ok
\g I must/was allowed/was able (for hours) work  
\l I had to/was allowed to/was able to reach him (for hours).

\t Ich habe zu wenig Kleingeld , um eineFahrkarte zu kaufen
\g I have too less cash in order a ticket to buy
\l I don’t have enough cash (in order) to buy a ticket.

\t Die sell woll isch guet (zu) strigge ALM
\g the that wool is good to knit 
\l This wool is good/easy to knit.

\t Gestern hab ich versucht ihn morgen nicht treffen zu müssen .
\g Yesterday have I tried him tomorrow not meet to must
\l Yesterday, I tried to not have to meet him tomorrow.

\l Don’t you find that we get (more) dumb by staying all the time on the beach?

\g Pierre REFL = TRZ.naive.PRES.3SG REFL = TRZ.rascal.PRES.3SG
\l Pierre gets/is getting (more) stupid’ or ‘Pierre causes/is causing himself to get (more) stupid.

\l We will go even if it is raining.’ (elicited)

\t Papataqa qasarapunpaschá
\g potato-ACC=TOP freeze-HORT-BEN-3=ADD=CONJ
\l Maybe it froze the potatoes.’ (Cusihuaman 2001: 239)

\t Phaway manapas ayparuwaq .
\g run-IMP not=ADD catch.up-HORT-2.COND
\l Run, you might not get there in time.’ (Espinoza 1997: 86)

\t Kunanqa Qosqopi imaynas aqha kakunpas .
\g now=TOP Cusco-LOC how=REP beer be-REFL-3=ADD
\l Now, how (much) might the beer be in Cusco?’ (Espinoza 1997: 26)

\t …pisiparusaqchu imasaqchu kampas , manachu puntunpipas mihunata apaysaq !
\g …little-BEN-HORT-1=FUT=POL what-1.FUT=POL be-3.ADD not=POL point-3-LOC=ADD food-ACC take-1.FUT
\l Or perhaps I will get weak or I might do something, perhaps I might not take the food on time.’ (Espinoza 1997: 190)

\t Manapas ayparuwaq .
\g not=ADD catch.up-HORT-2.COND
\l You might not get there in time.’ (Espinoza 1997: 86)

\t Noqatapas chaypaschá pasawanqa .
\g I-ACC=ADD this=ADD=CONJ happen-1O-3.FUT
\l This may also happen to me.’ (Valderrama & Escalante 1982: 88)

\t Chayqa , machasqapas kashayman karan hina , chay señora uyariruspa , juicioyman kutini .
\g that=TOP drunk-PRTC=ADD be-PROG-1-COND be-PST-3 like that lady hear-HORT-NMLZ.SS reason-1-ILLA return-1
\l Then, as if I had been drunk, when I heard this lady, I returned to reason.’ (Valderrama & Escalante 1982: 96).

\t … ñawiykuna nanayta qallariwan , ñawiykunamanpassi chay caballo markana ruphashaq fierrota sat’iruwankuman karan hinaraq .
\g  eye-1-PL hurt-INF-ACC start-1O-3 eye-1-PL-ILLA=ADD=REP that horse mark heat-PROG-AG iron-ACC stick-HORT-1O-3-PL-COND be-PST-3 like=CONT
\l My eyes started to hurt as if someone had stuck that burning iron for marking horses into my eyes.’ (Valderrama & Escalante 1982: 20)

\t Paulallapas kayman Inglaterrata ch’usanaypaq .
\g Paula=EXCL=ADD be-1-COND England-ACC travel-NMLZ-1-DAT
\l I wish I was Paula so that I could travel to England.’ (spontaneous)

\t Congresistallapas kayman askha qulqeyuq kanaypaq .
\g congresista=EXCL=ADD be-1-COND much money-POSS be-NMLZ-1-DAT
\l I wish I was a member of congress so that I had lots of money.’ (elicited)

\t Icha pillapas hamunman yanapaqniy .
\g perhaps who=EXCL=ADD come-3-COND help-DAT-EUPH-1
\l Maybe someone will come to help me.’ (Mejía Huamán 2016: 194)

\t wiraqocha dueñon nin nisitansi pillatapas kaypi tiyayta
\g mister owner-3 say-3 need-3.REP who=EXCL-ACC=ADD this-LOC live-INF-ACC
\l Its owner says he needs someone to live here.’ (Valderrama & Escalante 1982: 78)

\t *Marya ima pukllanatapas rantimusqa .
\g Marya what toy-ACC=ADD buy-CISL-NX.PST
\l (Intended: ‘Marya bought a toy.’)

\t *Qayniunchaw pi warmipas qanwan rimaq hamurqan .
\g yesterday who woman=ADD you-COM speak-AG come-PST-3
\l (Intended: ‘Yesterday, a woman came to speak to you.’)

\t Pipas hamunman .
\g who=ADD come-3-COND
\l Someone may come.

\t Mana pitapas ni cheqnikunichu .
\g not who-ACC=ADD not hate-REFL-1=POL
\l I don’t hate anyone/I hate nobody.’ (Espinoza 1997: 26)

\t Ima cosakuna ruranaytapas estimacionwan kamachiwaq
\g what thing-PL do-NMLZ-1-ACC-ADD respect-COM order-CAUS-1O-AG
\l She would give me orders for anything I had to do with respect.’ (Espinoza 1997)

\t hemus uciti kuĝun , toliti kuĝun , xeti kuĝun .
\g DEM2-DAT ear-ADD PV-II3.VAL4-have-STH-I3S eye-ADD PV-II3.VAL4-have-STH-I3S hand-ADD PV-II3.VAL4-have-STH-I3S
\l She has ears, eyes and hands.’ (Lacroix 2009: 79)

\t Parapaschá apiyamuwanqa !
\g rain=ADD=CONJ wet-TRANS-CISL-1O-3.FUT
\l Maybe the rain will get me wet.’ (Cusihuaman 2001: 233)

\g where-ABL=BPG be-2-PL say-NMLZ.SS ask-1O-3 one man
\l Where are you from?” a man asked me.’ (Espinoza 1997: 16)

\l There are many kids at that party.

\l Many kids appeared at that party.

\t Aparecieron muchos niños en esa fiesta .
\g appeared.3pl many kids in that party
\l There appeared many kids at that party.

\g what go.3sg to.the cinema
\l Are you going to the movies?

\t Qué tienes , que ir a la compra ?
\g what have.3sg that go to the shopping
\l Do you have to do the shopping?

\t Tsitkhuan sann (*tsang) tsin utshing .
\g this-CL clothing yesterday very have-wear
\l For anyone to wear it, this kind of clothing is very durable/lasts quite long.

\t Yi (tsang) (*tsin) tshing tsitkhuan sann .
\g s/he yesterday very wear this-CL clothing
\l S/He wore this kind of clothing (yesterday).

\t Yi yonn tsitkhuan pi sia gi .
\g he use this-CL pen write word
\l He writes words by this kind of pens.

\t Tsitkhuan pi kha usia .
\g this-CL pen more u-write
\l This kind of pens is more durable for writing.

\t Yi ti tshanlin tsing tshai .
\g he at field-inside plant vegetable
\l He plants vegetables in the field.

\t Tsitkhu tshan kha utsing .
\g this-CL field more u-plant
\l The planting capacity of this field (or the harvest from this field) is larger.

\t Yi tsuekin thiaukang kha ulim kapi .
\g he recently intentionally more u-drink coffee
\l Recently, he intentionally drinks coffee more frequently.

\t Yi kinalit tsai kha ulim kapi .
\g he today morning more u-drink coffee
\l This morning, he drank coffee more frequently.

\t Tshaikue tshang kai usiau .
\g loofah yesterday very u-sell/consume
\l Yesterday, the loofah sold well/people consumed many loofahs.

\g this-CL clothing more u-wear
\l For anyone to wear it, this kind of clothing is more durable for wearing/lasts longer.

\t Yi tsuekin kha utshing tsitkhuan sann .
\g s/he recently more u-wear this-CL clothing
\l Recently, s/he wears this kind of clothing more frequently.

\t Bikim kha utsio .
\g dollar more u-lend
\l The amount of dollars lent by a lender to borrowers is larger.

\t Tionn sio khigiap kha utsio .
\g medium small enterprise more u-lend
\l The number of small and medium enterprises to which a lender lends money is larger.

\g bat all the-same night-PRT more u-show-up
\l All kinds of bats are the same in that the night is more susceptible to their showing up.

\g this-CL spring-mattress more u-jump
\l This spring mattress is more durable for jumping on it.

\g this-CL umbrella more u-lose

\g this-CL pain more u-feel
\l This kind of pain is more perceivable.

\g s/he more lose one-CL umbrella\t Gua (*tsiok) kamkak kha le thiang .

\g this-CL bowl more u-hit-break\t Tsitkhuan sann kha utshing . (agent)

\t Bo mtio , bikim pi auguan kha utsio , mko sanntsap pi bikim e sohbok pi be kue gitsap pi auguan e sohbok .

\l Yes, the number of the events of lending dollars to someone is larger than the number of the events of lending euros to someone; however, the amount of the thirty sums of dollars lent is less than the amount of the twenty sums of euros lent.

\t Thaoke tui guankang tsiok tangsng e , tampetkong thaoke siu (*u) hitle .
\g boss to employee very stingy SFP frankly-speaking boss too u that-CL
\l Intended: The boss is very stingy with his employees. Frankly speaking, the boss is too much so.

\t Her Ecgbriht cing forðferde , 7 hyne hæfde ær Offa Mircna cing 7 Brihtric Wessexena cing aflymed  .iii . gear of Angelcynnes lande on Francland ær he cing wære .
\g Here egbert.NOM king.NOM died and him.ACC had previously offa.NOM mercians.GEN king.NOM and bertric.NOM west-saxons.GEN king.NOM banished three years from angles.GEN land on france before he.NOM king was
\l In this year king Egbert died, and Offa king of the Mercians and Bertric king of the West Saxons had banished him for three years from England to France, before he became king.

\t Ne wrec þu þe mid wussinge . ne mid warienge ac heald me þe wrache . and ich him wile his iuel mid werse forgelde .
\g NEG avenge you.NOM yourself.ACC with evil-wishing NEG with cursing but hold me.DAT DET.ACC vengeance.ACC and I.NOM him.DAT will his evil.ACC with worse recompense

\g he has the dog kicked
\l He kicked the dog.

\t Er HAT den Hund getreten .
\g he has the dog kicked
\l He DID kick the dog.

\t Ivan skazal , čto  druzjam Maši  nužno / možno pojti odnim / * odnoj / * odnomu .

\t Ja ne velel čёrnoj koške probegat’ meždu nimi .
\g I NEG ordered black cat.DAT run.INF between them
\l Literally: ‘I did not order the black cat to run between them.’ Idiomatic reading available: ‘I did not order them to quarrel.

\t Čёrnoj koške bylo nel’zja probegat’ meždu nimi .
\g black cat.DAT was.N.SG not.allowed run.INF between them
\l Literally: ‘For a black cat it is not allowed to run between them.’ Idiomatic reading available: ‘It is not allowed for them to quarrel.

\t Ja vynudil čёrnuju košku probežat’ meždu nimi .
\g I forced black cat.ACC run.INF between them
\l Literally: ‘I forced a black cat to run between them.’ Idiomatic reading not available: ‘I forced them to quarrel.

\t Direktor prikazal mal’čiku byt’ ubitym Voldemortom .
\g director.NOM ordered boy.DAT be.INF kill.PTCP Voldemort.INS
\l (i) ‘The director ordered the boy that he should be killed by Voldemort.’ (≠ b) (ii) ‘The director ordered that the boy should be killed by Voldemort.’ (= b)

\t Direktor prikazal Voldemortu ubit’ mal’čika .
\g director.NOM ordered Voldemort.DAT kill.INF boy.ACC
\l (i) ‘The director ordered Voldemort that he should kill the boy.’ (≠ a) (ii) ‘The director ordered that Voldemort should kill the boy.’ (= a)

\t Mal’čiku neobxodimo / nado byt’ ubitym Voldemortom .
\g boy.DAT necessary necessary be.INF kill.PTCP Voldemort.INS
\l (i) ‘For the boy it is necessary that he be killed by Voldemort.’ (≠ d) (ii) ‘It is necessary that the boy be killed by Voldemort.’ (= d)

\t Voldemortu neobxodimo / nado ubit’ mal’čika .
\g Voldemort.DAT necessary necessary kill.INF boy.ACC
\l (i) ‘For Voldemort it is necessary that he kill the boy.’ (≠ c) (ii) ‘It is necessary that Voldemort kill the boy.’ (= c)

\t Direktor zastavil mal’čika byt’ ubitym Voldemortom .
\g director.NOM forced boy.ACC be.INF kill.PTCP Voldemort.INS
\l The director forced the boy to be killed by Voldemort.’ (≠ b)

\t Direktor zastavil Voldemorta ubit’ mal’čika .
\g director.NOM forced Voldemort.ACC kill.INF boy.ACC
\l The director forced Voldemort to kill the boy.’ (≠ a)

\t Direktor razrešil večerinke prodolžat’sja do polunoči .
\g director.NOM permitted party.DAT continue.INF until midnight
\l The director permitted that the party continue until midnight.

\t Nado stroitel’stvu zakončit’sja k martu .
\g necessary construction.DAT complete.INF by March
\l It is necessary for the construction to be complete by March.

\t *Direktor zastavil večerinku prodolžat’sja do polunoči .
\g director.NOM forced party.ACC continue.INF until midnight
\l Intended: ‘The director forced the party to continue until midnight.

\t Maša velela Anne , čtoby ona pomyla posudu .
\g Maša.NOM ordered Anna.DAT so that she.NOM wash.SBJV dishes
\l Maša ordered Anna to wash the dishes.

\t Maša skazala Anne , čto Vanja pomyl posudu .
\g Maša.NOM said Anna.DAT that Ivan.NOM washed dishes
\l Maša said to Anna that Ivan had washed the dishes.

\t Pjanym Pete nel’zja , čtoby Anna ostavalas’ .
\g drunk.INS Petja.DAT not.allowed so that Anna.NOM stay.INF
\l When Petja is drunk it is not allowed for him for Anna to stay.

\t Petja udaril Ivana izza Borisa pjanym .
\g Petja.NOM hit Ivan.ACC because.of Boris.GEN drunk.INS
\l When Petja was drunk he hit Ivan because of Boris.’ ‘When Ivan was drunk Petja hit him because of Boris.’ Not available: ‘When Boris was drunk Petja hit Ivan because of him.

\t ec uxodja iz doma , Pete nel’zja , čtoby Anna ostavalas’ .
\g  leaving from house Petja.DAT not.allowed so that Anna.NOM stay.SBJV
\l When Petja leaves the house, it is not allowed for him for Anna to stay.

\t ec uxodja iz doma , Petja opazdyval izza Anny .
\g  leaving from house Petja.DAT was.late because.of Anna.GEN
\l When Petja was leaving the house, he was late because of Anna.

\t Ivan ne dolžen delat’ zadanije .
\g Ivan.NOM NEG must do.INF task.ACC
\l (i) ‘Ivan does not have to do the task.’ NEG > MUST (ii) ‘Ivan must not do the task.’ MUST > NEG

\t Ivan ne možet delat’ zadanije .
\g Ivan.NOM NEG can do.INF task.ACC
\l (i) ‘Ivan is not able to do the task.’ NEG > CAN (ii) Not available: ‘Ivan is able not to do the task.’ *CAN > NEG

\l we/you linguists

\t *við/þið málfræðingur
\g we/you.PL linguist.SG\t  ? ?þeir málfræðingar
\g they.M linguist.PL\t Það er hörkuléleg skráning að austan í ár , okkur vantar þær stelpur alveg .
\g there is extremely-weak registration from east.DET this year, we.ACC lack those girls completely
\l The registration in the East [of Iceland] has been slow this year, those girls [who could have registered there] are missing completely [from our registry].’15

\l The man with the mustache hit [the girl] in the face.

\l He planted the trees in the garden.

\l He planted the trees in the garden.

\l The thief saw him, the policeman, when he / that one / the same was turning the corner.

\t Ena koritsi kinigise kathe gata .
\g A girl chased every cat.
\l A girl chased every cat.

\t Kinigise enas astinomos kathe klefti .
\g Chased a.NOM policeman.NOM every thief.ACC
\l A policeman chased every thief.

\t i Ira plirose ton ktiniatro . I Ana ohi .
\g the Ira.NOM payed the vet.ACC the Anna.NOM not.
\l Ira paid the vet. Anna didn’t.

\t Ton ktiniatro ton plirose i Ira . Ton nosokomo ohi .
\g the vet.ACC CL.HIM payed the Ira.NOM the nurse.ACC not
\l The vet was paid by Ira. The nurse wasn’t.’ Broadly, we can distinguish two approaches for LLD:

\t Kapjon klefti ton sinelave kathe astinomos .
\g some thief.ACC CL.HIM arrested every policeman.NOM
\l Some thief was arrested by every policeman.

\t Kapjos astinomos sinelave kathe klefti .
\g some policeman.NOM arrested every thief.ACC
\l Some policeman arrested every thief.

\t Kapja gineka filise mono ton Petro .
\g some woman kissed only the Peter.ACC
\l Some woman kissed only Peter.’ ✓only > ∃: Nobody except for Peter was woman-kissed. ✓∃ > only: A specific woman kissed nobody except for Peter.

\t Mono ton Petro ton filise kapja gineka .
\g only the Peter.ACC CL kissed some woman.
\l Only Peter is such that he was kissed by a woman.’ ✓only > ∃: Nobody except for Peter was woman-kissed. #∃ > only: A specific woman kissed nobody except Peter.

\t Kapja gineka filise akomi ke ton Petro .
\g some woman kissed even ADD the Peter.ACC
\l Some woman kissed even Peter.’ ✓even > ∃: Even Peter, the least likely to be kissed, was woman-kissed. ✓∃ > even: There is a woman who kissed (among others) even Peter.

\t Akomi ke ton Petro ton filise kapja gineka .
\g even ADD the Peter.ACC CL kissed some woman.
\l Even Peter is such that he was kissed by a woman.’ ✓even > ∃: Even Peter, the least likely to be kissed, was woman-kissed. #∃ > even: There is a woman who kissed (among others) even Peter.

\t Potise kapjos andras kathe luludi . VSO (EXP1)
\g watered some man.NOM every flower.ACC \t Kapjos andras potise kathe luludi . SVO (EXP2)
\g some man.NOM watered every flower.ACC 
\l Some man watered every flower.

\t Kathe zografos zografise kapja gineka . VSO (EXP1)
\g every painter.NOM painted some woman.ACC \t Zografise kathe zografos kapja gineka SVO (EXP2)
\g painted every painter.NOM some woman.ACC 
\l Every painter painted some woman.

\t Kapjos ipurgos sinatnise kathe epihirimatia . SVO
\g some minister.NOM met every entrepreneur. 
\l Some minister met every entrepreneur.

\t Kathe fotografos fotografise kapja tragudistria . SVO
\g Every photographer photographed some singer. \t Kapjos IPURGOS sinatnise kathe epihirimatia . SVO
\g Some minister.NOM met every entrepreneur. 
\l Some MINISTER met every entrepreneur.

\t Kapja TRAGUDISTRIA fotografise kathe fotografos .
\g some singer.ACC photographed every photographer.NOM.
\l Some SINGER was photographed by every photographer.

\t Kapjos ipurgos sinatnise KATHE epihirimatia .
\g some.NOM minister.NOM met every entrepreneur.
\l Some minister met every entrepreneur.

\t Kapja tragudistria ti fotografise KATHE fotografos .
\g some singer.ACC her.CL photographed every photographer.NOM.
\l Some singer was photographed by every photographer.

\t Kapjos IPURGOS sinantise kathe epihirimatia .
\g some minister.NOM met every entrepreneur.ACC
\l Some MINISTER met every entrepreneur.

\l No student I saw yesterday.

\l No student from those you talk about I saw yesterday.

\t Kathe gineka ti fotografise enas andras .
\g Every woman her,CL photographed a.NOM man
\l Every woman, a man photographed her.

\t an fear   a bhí ___ breoite 
\g the man  aᴸ was  ill
\l the man that was ill’ (Ó Baoill & Maki 2012: 361)

\t *an fear   a raibh sé breoite 
\g the man  aᴺ was he ill
\l literally ‘the man that he was ill’ (McCloskey 2002: 201)

\t čovjek   što tvrdiš   da je (on) sreo Petra  
\g man  C claim.2SG  C PRES.3SG he.NOM met Petar.ACC
\l literally ‘the man that you claim that (he) met Petar

\l literally ‘the man that we thought he was ill

\t To je človek ,   ki ga iščejo  .
\g this is man  C he.ACC search.3PL
\l literally ‘This is the man that they are looking for him.

\t Poznam človeka ,   ki (*on) išče službo  .
\g know.1SG man.ACC  C he.NOM search.3SG job
\l I know a man who is looking for a job.

\t On je sreo Petra .
\g he.NOM PRES.3SG met Petar.ACC
\l He met Petar.

\t čovjek   što  samo Mariju  on voli ___ 
\g man  C only Marija.ACC he.NOM loves 
\l literally ‘the man that he loves only Marija

\t človek ,   ki  samo Marijo  (on) ljubi ___ 
\g man  C only Marija.ACC he.NOM love.3SG \t človek ,   ki (*on) ljubi  samo Marijo  
\g man  C he.NOM love.3SG only Marija.ACC
\l the man that loves only Marija

\t človek ,   ki  tudi on  kadi 
\g man  C also he.NOM smokes
\l the man that also he smokes’ (Hladnik 2015: 42)

\t Poznam človeka ,   ki mislim ,   da (*on) išče službo   .

\t It sabzini xomligicha g’ajidimi ?

\g no swallow-PST-3
\l intended: ‘No, [he] swallowed [it].’ 3/5 = *, 2/5 = ✓ (but ≠ raw)

\t *Ez düa te eginahala egin ? (cf . 32)
\g not AUX.PART PART effort.ABS do 
\l (Intended reading: ‘Didn’t s/he do everything possible?’)

\t DIE ist  vielleicht > leicht  schlau !
\g this.F is PART PART smart
\l My God, how smart this one is!

\t * Vielleicht > Leicht  DIE ist schlau !
\g PART PART this.F is smart\t Non ote ?
\g where PART
\l Where? (‘I’m wondering)

\t Pentsatzen dizü bihamonin oano harri hoi nola elkhiko ote .
\g think.IPFV AUX following.day.IN still stone that.ABS how leave.FUT PART
\l The following day you keep thinking how they will remove that stone.

\t Eztüta nik othian egün bonür handia ?
\g not.have.PART I.ERG PART.IN today happiness big.ABS
\l Don’t I have perhaps today great joy?

\t Ez , eta otherik gabe oraino . Zu hunen irakurtzen ari ziren bezen segur .
\g not and PART.PRTT without still you.ABS this.GEN read.IPFV PROG AUX.COMP so sure
\l No, and even with no doubt. As sure as you’re reading this.

\t Negar egingo zenuke (…) biharrik ez balego .
\g cry do.FUT AUX  tomorrow.PRTT not if.be
\l You would cry if there were no tomorrow.

\t Non ote Aitor egon da ?

\l In Berlin (may Aitor be)? (‘I’m wondering)

\t Non ote utzi dut kazeta ?
\g where PART leave AUX newspaper.ABS
\l Where did I leave the newspaper? (‘I’m wondering)

\t Ez dakit nik nola ote egiten ahal zükean .
\g not know I.ERG how PART do.IPFV can AUX.COMP
\l I don’t know how it could be done.

\t Nork ote jan züan ?
\g who.ERG PART eat AUX
\l Who ate it? (‘I’m wondering)

\t Nondik bada zetozen eskatu zien .
\g where.ABL PART come.COMP ask AUX
\l S/he asked them where they were coming then from.

\g What yesterday buy AUX Asier.ERG   
\l (Intended reading: ‘What did Asier buy yesterday?’)

\l Where did I leave the newspaper? (I’m wondering)

\t La tormenta hundió al barco .
\g the storm sank DOM.the ship
\l The storm sank the ship.

\t Se hundió el barco con la tormenta .
\g SE sank the ship with the storm
\l The ship sank by the storm.

\t La policía cerró las puertas para bloquear la salida .
\g the police closed the doors for block.INF the exit
\l The police closed the doors in order to block the exit.

\t Se cerraron las puertas para bloquear la salida .
\g SE closed.3PL the doors for block.INF the exit
\l The doors were closed in order to block the exit.

\t Juan criticó a Ana .
\g Juan criticized DOM Ana
\l Juan criticized Ana.

\t Se criticó a Ana .
\g SE criticized DOM Ana
\l One/someone criticized Ana.

\t Ana se criticó .
\g Ana SE criticized
\l Ana criticized herself.

\t Juan comió la manzana .
\g Juan ate the apple
\l Juan ate the apple.

\t Juan se comió la manzana .
\g Juan SE ate the apple
\l Juan ate the apple.

\t Juan (*se) comió pizza .
\g Juan (*SE) ate pizza
\l Juan ate pizza.

\t Juan se quejó .
\g Juan SE complained
\l Juan complained.

\t *Juan quejó .
\g Juan complained\t *Juan lo quejó .
\g Juan him/it complained\t Ana depende de sí misma .
\g Ana depends of herself
\l Ana depends on herself.

\t Ana soñó consigo misma .
\g Ana dreamed with herself
\l Ana dreamed with herself.

\t Se encontraron cadáveres .
\g SE found.3PL bodies
\l Bodies were found.

\t *Se encontró Juan/él .
\g SE found.3SG Juan/he
\l INTENDED: ‘He was found.

\t *Me encontré yo .
\g CL.1SG.ACC found.1SG I
\l INTENDED: ‘I was found.’ (b-c OK as reflexives; see Pujalte & Saab 2012)

\t Se los encontró .
\g SE CL.MASC.3PL.ACC found.3SG
\l They were found.

\t Se me encontró .
\g SE CL.1SG.ACC found.3SG
\l I was found.

\t Se encontró a Juan .
\g SE found.3SG DOM Juan
\l Juan was found.

\t Juan entregó el libro a María .
\g Juan gave the book to María
\l Juan gave the book to María.

\t Juan le entregó el libro a María .
\g Juan CL.3SG.DAT gave the book to María
\l Juan gave María the book.

\t Juan se entregó a la policía .
\g Juan SE delivered to the police
\l Juan turned himself in/over the police.

\t *Juan se le entregó a la policía .
\g Juan SE CL.3SG.DAT delivered to the police
\l (NB: Ok in some dialects if read idiomatically as Juan made things easy for the police to have sex with him.)

\t Juan se recomendó a su jefe para ese trabajo .
\g Juan SE recommended to her/his boss for that job
\l Juan recommended himself to her/his boss for that job.

\t *Juan se le recomendó a su jefe para ese trabajo .
\g Juan SE CL.3SG.DAT recommended to her/his boss for that job\t Juan se presentó a María .
\g Juan SE introduced to María
\l Juan introduced himself to María.

\t *Juan se le presentó a María .
\g Juan SE CL.3SG.DAT introduced to María
\l (NB: OK if read as Juan suddenly appeared in front of María.)

\t Juan se regaló a María envuelto en un paquete .
\g Juan SE give-a-present to María wrapped in a package
\l Juan gave himself as a present to María wrapped in a package.

\t *Juan se le regaló a María .
\g Juan SE CL.3SG.DAT give-a-present to María
\l (NB: Ok in some dialects if interpreted approximately as Juan did not oppose any resistance to María.)

\t Juan se entregó el libro .
\g Juan SE gave the book
\l Juan gave himself the book.

\t Se le entregó el libro a Juan .
\g SE CL.3SG.DAT gave the book to Juan
\l Someone/one gave Juan the book.

\t ¿A quién  ? ?(le) dio un libro su madre ?
\g to whom CL.3SG.DAT gave a book his/her mother
\l Whom does his/her mother give a book?

\t Solo Juan se considera inteligente .

\l Only Juan considers himself intelligent.

\l No, Juan considers me intelligent, too.

\t En la India , solo el arroz se come con los dedos .

\l No, in India, bread too is eaten with the fingers.

\t No , los indios comen también el pan con los dedos .
\g no, the Indians eat also the bread with the fingers
\l No, Indian people too eat bread with the fingers.

\g the ship SE sank only

\t O Petros episkefthike enan/*mia arosto/*arosti adherfo tu .

\l Petros visited a male sibling of his.

\g the Petros visited *a.M/a.F *sick.M/sick.F sibling.F his
\l Petros visited a female sibling of his.

\t O Petros episkefthike enan kalo jatro .
\g the Petros visited a.M good.M doctor
\l Petros visited a good male doctor.

\t O Petros episkefthike mia kali jatro .
\g the Petros visited a.F good.F doctor
\l Petros visited a good female doctor.

\t *O Petros ine kalos adherfos , ala i Maria ine mia kakia adherfi .
\g the Petros is good.M brother.M but the Maria is a.F bad.F (sister)
\l (intended) ‘Petros is a good brother, but Maria is a bad (sister).

\t *I Maria ine kali adherfi , ala o Petros ine enas kakos adherfos .
\g the Maria is good.F sister.F but the Petros is a.M bad.M (brother)
\l (intended) ‘Maria is a good sister, but Petros is a bad (brother).

\t O Petros ine kalos jatros , ala i Maria ine mia kakia jatros .
\g the Petros is good.M doctor but the Maria is a.F bad.F (doctor)
\l Petros is a good doctor, but Maria is a bad one.

\t I Maria ine kali jatros , ala o Petros ine enas kakos jatros .
\g the Maria is good.F doctor but the Petros is a.M bad.M (doctor)
\l Maria is a good doctor, but Petros is a bad one.

\t O Petros ine kalos dhaskalos , ala i Maria ine mia kakia dhaskala .
\g the Petros is good.M teacher.M but the Maria is a.F bad.F (teacher.F)
\l Petros is a good teacher, but Maria is a bad one.

\t *I Maria ine kali dhaskala , ala o Petros ine enas kakos dhaskalos .
\g the Maria is good.F teacher.F but the Petros is a.M bad.M (teacher.M)
\l (intended) ‘Maria is a good teacher, but Petros is a bad one.

\t Mono o Petros ine adherfos tu Jani .
\g only the Petros is sibling.M the.GEN Janis.GEN
\l Only Petros is a brother of Janis’.’ ⇏Maria is not Janis’s sister

\t Mono i Maria ine adherfi tu Jani .
\g only the Maria is sibling.F the.GEN Janis.GEN
\l Only Maria is a sister of Janis’.’ ⇏Petros is not Janis’s brother

\t Mono o Petros ine kalos jatros .
\g only the Petros is good.M doctor
\l Only Petros is a good doctor.’ ⟹Maria is not a good doctor

\t Mono i Maria ine kali jatros .
\g only the Maria is good.F doctor
\l Only Maria is a good doctor.’ ⟹Petros is not a good doctor

\t Mono o Petros ine dhaskalos .
\g only the Petros is teacher.M
\l Only Petros is a teacher.’ ⟹Maria is not a teacher

\t Mono i Maria ine dhaskala .
\g only the Maria is teacher.F
\l Only Maria is a teacher.’ ⇏Petros is not a teacher

\t O Petros ine o kaliteros adherfos tu Jani .
\g the Petros is the.M best.M sibling.M the.GEN Janis.GEN
\l Petros is the best brother of Janis’ (among Janis’ brothers).

\t I Maria ine i kaliteri adherfi tu Jani .
\g the Maria is the.F best.F sibling.F the.GEN Janis.GEN
\l Maria is the best sister of Janis’ (among Janis’ sisters).

\t O Petros ine o kaliteros jatros .
\g the Petros is the.M best.M doctor
\l Petros is the best doctor (among the male and female doctors).

\t I Maria ine i kaliteri jatros .
\g the Maria is the.F best.F doctor
\l Maria is the best doctor (among the male and female doctors).

\t O Petros ine o kaliteros dhaskalos .
\g the Petros is the.M best.M teacher.M
\l Petros is the best teacher (among the male and female teachers).

\t I Maria ine i kaliteri dhaskala .
\g the Maria is the.F best.F teacher.F
\l Maria is the best teacher (among the female teachers).

\t *O Petros exi enan adherfo stin Veria , ala dhen exi mia adherfi stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.M brother in.the Veria but not has one.F (sister) in.the Katerini
\l (intended) ‘Petros has a brother in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (sister) in Katerini.

\t *O Petros exi mia adherfi stin Veria , ala dhen exi enan adherfo stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.F sister in.the Veria but not has one.M (brother) in.the Katerini
\l (intended) ‘Petros has a sister in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (brother) in Katerini.

\t *O Petros exi enan jatro stin Veria , ala dhen exi mia jatro stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.M doctor in.the Veria but not has one.F (doctor) in.the Katerini
\l (intended) ‘Petros has a male doctor in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (female doctor) in Katerini.

\t *O Petros exi mia jatro stin Veria , ala dhen exi enan jatro stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.F doctor in.the Veria but not has one.M (doctor) in.the Katerini
\l (intended) ‘Petros has a female doctor in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (male doctor) in Katerini.

\t *O Petros exi enan dhaskalo stin Veria , ala dhen exi mia dhaskala stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.M teacher.M in.the Veria but not has one.F (teacher.F) in.the Katerini
\l (intended) ‘Petros has a male teacher in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (female teacher) in Katerini.

\t *O Petros exi mia dhaskala stin Veria , ala dhen exi enan dhaskalo stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.F teacher.F in.the Veria but not has one.M (teacher.M) in.the Katerini
\l (intended) ‘Petros has a female teacher in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (male teacher) in Katerini.

\t O Petros exi enan adherfo stin Veria , ala dhen exi enan adherfo stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.M brother in.the Veria but not has one.M (brother) in.the Katerini
\l Petros has a brother in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (brother) in Katerini.

\t O Petros exi mia adherfi stin Veria , ala dhen exi mia adherfi stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.F sister in.the Veria but not has one.F (sister) in.the Katerini
\l Petros has a siter in Veria, but he doesn’t have one (sister) in Katerini.

\t O Petros exi enan kalo adherfo , ala dhen exi enan kako adherfo .
\g the Petros has a.M good.M brother but not has one.M bad.M (brother)
\l Petros has a good brother but he doesn’t have a bad one (brother).

\t O Petros exi mia kali adherfi , ala dhen exi mia kakia adherfi .
\g the Petros has a.F good.F sister, but not has one.F bad.F (sister)
\l Petros has a good sister but he doesn’t have a bad one (sister).

\t O Petros exi enan adherfo stin Veria , ke exi mia adherfi stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.M brother in.the Veria and has one.F sister in.the Katerini
\l Petros has a brother in Veria, and he has a sister in Katerini.

\t O Petros exi mia adherfi stin Veria , ke exi enan adherfo stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.F sister in.the Veria and has one.M brother in.the Katerini
\l Petros has a sister in Veria, and he has a sister in Katerini.

\t O Petros exi enan jatro stin Veria , ke exi mia jatro stin Katerini .
\g the Petros has a.M doctor in.the Veria and has one.F doctor in.the Katerini
\l Petros has a male doctor in Veria, and he has a female doctor in Katerini.

\t Jas ruuk’ xØkitij wi le kirikiil ?
\g WH A3S-RN COM-B3S-A3P-eat FP DET A3P-food
\l With what did they eat their food?’ (Adapted from Can Pixabaj 2015: 162)

\t Ankuchi xØtzopin (wi) a Lu’ ?
\g where COM-B3S-jump (FP) CLF Pedro
\l Where did Pedro jump?

\t Achoj k’in xØuqupij (wi) ruwäch che’ ri Ixchel ?

\t Ri a Lu’ xØtzopin (*wi) chwa jay .
\g DET CLF Pedro COM-B3S-jump (*FP) PREP.A3S.RN house
\l Pedro jumped in the garden.

\t NØabän ri qaway pa toq’a .

\l You make our food at night.

\t *Pa toq’a nØabän wi ri qaway .
\g PREP night INC-B3S-A2S-make FP DET A1P-food
\l At night you make our food.’ (Adapted from Henderson 2008)

\t Jampe’ xØatej knaq’ ?
\g when COM-B3S-A2S-eat beans
\l When did you eat beans?

\t  Iwir  xØintej (*wi) knaq’ .
\g yesterday COM-B3S-A1S-eat (*FP) beans
\l I ate beans [yesterday].

\t  Chaq’ab’  xØkik’ux le atz’yaq .

\t (…) ob Adorno (…) glaube , dass man denn wirklich alle Menschen belasten müsse mit Grundsatzproblematik und Reflexionsaufwand , (…)

\l (…) whether Adorno thinks that one DENN really should bother everybody with fundamental problems and reflection (…)

\t Otto hat auch ALTE Bücher gekauft .
\g Otto has also old books bought
\l Otto also bought OLD books.’ PRESUPP ≈ Otto bought other kinds of books (e.g., new books).

\g Otto has also old books bought
\l Otto also bought old BOOKS.’ PRESUPP ≈ Otto bought other old things (e.g., old furniture).

\t Dann hat Otto noch ALTE Bücher gekauft .
\g Then has Otto still old books bought
\l Otto bought OLD books in addition.’ PRESUPP ≈ Otto bought other kinds of books (e.g., new books).

\t Dann hat Otto noch alte BÜCHER gekauft .
\g Then has Otto still old books bought
\l Otto bought old BOOKS in addition.’ PRESUPP ≈ Otto bought other old things (e.g., old furniture).

\g then has he still a schnaps drunk \t Dann hat er auch einen SCHNAPS getrunken . (beer ≺ schnaps)
\g then has he also a schnaps drunk 
\l Then he drank a schnaps in addition.

\g he has still a schnaps drunk 
\l He had another schnaps.’/‘# He had a schnaps, too

\g Otto has also still a schnaps drunk
\l Otto also drank a schnaps.’ (PRESUPP: Otto drank something else (e.g., a beer))

\g then has he still a schnaps drunk
\l And he also drank a schnaps.

\l The sun is very bright.’ (Speaker comment on the demonstrative: there is more than one sun)

\t phutsáaj kɔ̂ nɯŋ kwàa ti hâan khǎaj mǎa tàa sɯ̂ mǎa ʔɔ̀n tǒ nɯŋ pǎn lukjíŋ mántsáaj… phutsáaj (kɔ̂ nân) khɯ́n tɔ̀p waa ,
\g person-man CLF.HUM one go at store sell dog for buy dog small CLF.ANML one give daughter 3-man person-man CLF.HUM that back respond that
\l A man went to a dog store to buy a puppy for his daughter… The/that man replied, …

\t jɔ̂n kɔ́k kɔ́fì mí nɤ̌ phɤ̌n mí hímtsǎm pâplik lɛ , háw laj ʔǎw kɔ́k kɔ́fì (nân) he sàj pâplik (nân)
\g because cup coffee exist on desk exist near book and 1 get take cup coffee that spill in book that
\l Since a cup of coffee was on the table near a book, I spilled the/that coffee on the/that book.

\t tsɔn tǒ nɯŋ máa mí nɤ̌ tonmâj ʔǎn mí hímtsǎm hɤ́n háw nân sě mɤnâj phǒn lóm haaŋ hâaj nàa lɛ hét haj kìŋmâj jàat tók njǎa tě phât njáa tsɔn (tǒ nân) páa jâw
\g squirrel CLF.ANML one come exist on tree COMP exist near house 1 that and today rain wind appearance bad very and do cause branch-tree break fall almost IRR hit meet squirrel CLF.ANML that with finish
\l A squirrel was on the tree near my house. Then one day, a bad storm caused a branch to break and fall almost hitting the squirrel.

\t mɛ́w lɛ nǔ ʔàm mɛn kǎn . pɔ́ mɛ́w hǎn nǔ nǎjtsɯ̌ŋ , mɛ́w lɯp lám tî njɔ́p nǔ tàasè
\g cat and rat NEG right together if cat see rat then cat follow chase grab snatch rat always
\l Cats and rats don’t get along together. If a cat sees a rat, the cat chases and catches the rat always.

\t mǎa nâj hǎn mɛ́w tǒ lǎj kɔ tě lɯp mɛ́w (tǒ nân) tàasè .
\g dog this see cat CLF.ANML which PRT will follow cat CLF.ANML that always
\l Dogs, whichever cat they see they will always chase the/that cat

\t mǎa ku tǒ nâj pɔ́ hǎn mɛ́w tǒ nɯŋ kój kɔ tě lɯp lám mɛ́w *(tǒ nân) tàasè .
\g dog every CLF.ANML this if/when see cat CLF.ANML one only PRT will follow chase cat CLF.ANML that always
\l Every dog, if it sees only one cat, will always chase that cat.

\t Isidora Stojanović , … pronašla je novčanik pun para gde se nalazilo 4000 evra i 16 .000 dinara a Isidora se nije dvoumila šta treba da učini . Uzela je novčanik i otišla do MUPa i predala novac…
\g Isidora Stojanovic  found is wallet full money where refl. located 4000 euros and 16.000 dinars and Isidora self did-not think_twice what needs that do Took is wallet and left to police_station and turned_in money
\l Isidora Stojanović, …found a wallet full with money, which contained 4000 euros and 16.000 dinars. Isidora did not think twice what she needs to do. She took the wallet and went to the police station and turned in the money…”5

\l My one-year old son sometimes does unexpected things. For instance, every time he sees a bucket and a ball, he tries to put the bucket on the ball.

\t lûukchaai wai nɯ̀ŋ khùap khɔ̌ŋ chǎn baaŋ kràŋ kɔ̂ tham nai sìŋ thî mâi khâatkhít . nai thúk thúk khráŋ thî khǎw hěn thǎŋnám lɛ lûukbɔn khǎw mák ca waaŋ thǎŋnám bon lûukbɔn .

\t mɛw lɛ nǔ mâi khɔ̂ɔi ca thùuk kan . mɯ̂arài thî mɛw hěn nǔ , man mák ca lâicàp nǔ

\l Cats and rats don’t get along. Whenever a cat sees a rat, it usually chases and catches the rat.

\g I want absolutely that I am.SBJV left in ten minutes

\g I NEG want not that I miss.SBJV a chance same
\l I do not want for me to miss a chance like that.’ (Lit. ‘I do not want that I miss …’)

\t Je veux que je puisse partir dès demain .

\l I want for me to be able to leave (by) tomorrow.

\g I want can.INF leave from tomorrow
\l I want to be able to leave (by) tomorrow.

\l I want for me to go and for you to stay.’ (Lit. ‘I want that I leave and that you stay.’)

\t Je veux que tu partes et que je reste .

\l I want for you to leave and for me to stay.

\l Yesterday, I got out of my house very quickly.

\l I want you to leave and never come back.

\l John is taller than Tom.

\l More students attend the University of Chicago than Northwestern.

\t *Daugiau žmonių kas gyvena valstijoje , kurią valdo Obama , už Medvedeva .
\g more people.GEN who.NOM live.PRS.3 state.LOC which.ACC govern.PRS.3 Obama.NOM than.PHRASAL Medvedev.ACC
\l More people live in the state that Obama governs than in the state that Medvedev governs.’ (Grinsell 2012: 41)

\t Jonas suvalgė daugiau sausainių , kuriuos iškėpė Agnė negu Tomas .
\g John.NOM eat.PST.3 more cookie.GEN which.ACC bake.PST.3 Agne.NOM than.CLAUSAL Tomas.NOM
\l John ate more cookies that Agne baked than Tom.

\t Jonas suvalgė daugiau sausainių , kuriuos iškėpė Agnė už Tomą .
\g John.NOM eat.PST.3 more cookie.GEN which.ACC bake.PST.3 Agne.NOM than.PHRASAL Tom.ACC
\l John ate more cookies that Agne baked than Tom.

\t Jonas suvalgė daugiau spurgų už Tomą .
\g John.NOM eat.PST.3 more doughnut.GEN than.PHRASAL Tom.ACC
\l John ate more doughnuts than Tom (ate).

\t *Jonas suvalgė daugiau spurgų už sausainius .
\g John.NOM eat.PST.3 more doughnut.GEN than.PHRASAL cookie.ACC
\l Intended meaning: ‘John ate more doughnuts than cookies.

\t Jonas padovanojo Marijai daugiau dovanų už Tomą .
\g John.NOM gift.PST.3 Maria.DAT more present.GEN than.PHRASAL Tom.ACC
\l John gave more presents to Maria than Tom (did).’ #‘John gave more presents to Maria than (he did to) Tom.

\t Jonas aukštesnis   už   Tomą .  
\g John.NOM tall-ER-NOM  than.PHRASAL  Tom.ACC
\l John is taller than Tom.

\t Jonas už visus savo klasiokus aukštesnis .
\g Jonas.NOM than.PHRASAL all.ACC self.GEN classmate.ACC.PL taller.NOM.SG
\l Jonas is taller than all of his classmates.

\t Visi Jono klasiokai už jį aukštesni .
\g all.NOM John.GEN classmate.NOM.PL than.PHRASAL he.ACC taller.NOM.PL
\l All John’s classmates are taller than him.

\t Jonas suvalgė daugiau obuolių už Tomą .
\g John.NOM eat.PST.3 more apple.GEN than.PHRASAL Tom.ACC
\l John ate more apples than Tom.

\t Jonas padovanojo Tomui daugiau dovanų už Agnę .
\g John.NOM gift.PST.3 Tom.DAT more gift.GEN than.PHRASAL Agne.ACC
\l John gave more presents to Tom than Agne.

\t Kažkoks vyras pabučiavo kiekvieną merginą .
\g some.NOM man.NOM kiss.PST.3 every.ACC woman.ACC
\l Some man kissed every woman.’ (some>every): One (specific) man kissed every woman. *(every>some): For every woman, she was kissed by some (potentially different) man.

\t Jonas suvalgė daugiau už Tomą sausainių , kuriuos iškėpė Agnė .
\g John.NOM eat.PST.3 more than.PHRASAL Tom.ACC biscuit.GEN which.ACC bake.PST.3 Agne.NOM
\l John ate more biscuits that Agne baked than Tom.

\t *Daugiau žmonių gerė vyną už alų .
\g more people.GEN drink.PST.3 wine.ACC than.PHRASAL beer.ACC
\l More people drank wine than beer.

\t Jonas nusiuntė Agnei daugiau laiškų už Tomą .
\g John.NOM send.PST.3 Agne.DAT more letters.GEN than.PHRASAL Tom.ACC
\l John sent more letters to Agne than Tom (did).

\t Jonas aukštesnis už Tomą <yra aukštas .>
\g John.NOM taller.NOM than.PHRASAL Tom.ACC be.PRS.3 tall.NOM
\l John is taller than Tom.

\t *Daugiau žmonių gyvena valstybėje , kurią valdo Obama , už Medvedevą .
\g more people.GEN live.PRS.3 state.LOC which.ACC govern.PRS.3 Obama.NOM than.PHRASAL Medvedev.ACC
\l More people live in the state that Obama governs than in the state that Medvedev governs.’ (adapted from Grinsell 2012: 41)

\t Daugiau žmonių kas gyvena valstijoje , kurią valdo Obama , negu Medvedevas .
\g more people.GEN who.NOM live.PRS.3 state.LOC which.ACC govern.PRS.3 Obama.NOM than.CLAUSAL Medvedev.NOM
\l More people live in the state that Obama governs than in the state that Medvedev governs.’ (Grinsell 2012: 41)

\t *Jonas auštesnis už du metrus <aukštas> .
\g John.NOM taller.NOM than.PHRASAL two.ACC meter.ACC tall
\l John is taller than two meters.

\t *Daugiau žmonių perskaitė Altorių Šešėly už Baltą Drobulę .
\g more people.GEN read.PST.3 altar.GEN shadow.LOC than white.ACC cloth.ACC
\l More people read the novel Altoriu Sesely than Balta Drobule.

\t Jonas perskaitė daugiau knygų negu Marija perskaitė .
\g John.NOM read.PST.3 more book.GEN than.CLAUSAL Maria.NOM read.PST.3
\l John read more books than Maria.

\g today John.NOM read.PST.3 more book.GEN than.CLAUSAL yesterday
\l John read more books today than yesterday.

\t Jonas suvalgė daugiau negu Tomas sausainių , kuriuos iškėpė Agnė .
\g John.NOM eat.PST.3 more than.CLAUSAL Tom.NOM cookie.GEN which.ACC bake.PST.3 Agne.NOM
\l John ate more cookies that Agne baked than Tom (ate).

\t  ?Jonui patinka savo naujas švarkas .
\g John please.PRS.3 self.GEN new.NOM jacket.NOM
\l John likes his new jacket.’ (adapted from Holvoet 2013: 266))

\t Man spurgos patinka labiau už Joną .
\g I.DAT doughnut.NOM like.PRS.3 more than John.ACC
\l I like doughnuts more than I like John.’ #‘I like doughnuts more than John likes doughnuts.

\t Le facteur a rencontré le balayeur avant de PRO rentrer à la maison .
\g The postman met the streetsweeper before PRO go.INF home.\t Kumaga azarasi no koo tukamta . (tukamta → tukanda)
\g bear-NOM seal ’s baby-ACC grab-PAST 
\l A bear grabbed a baby seal.

\t Azarasi no koga kumani tukamATta . (ARta → ATta)
\g seal ’s baby-NOM bear-by grab-AR-PAST 
\l A baby seal was caught by a bear.’ (AR here is a lexical passive in accordance to (2a).)

\t Azarasi no koga kumani(yotte) tukamareta .
\g seal ’s baby-NOM bear-by grab-PASSIVE-PAST
\l A baby seal was grabbed by a bear.

\t Hutatu no hito .kagega Sue no kageo hasanda . (← hasamta)
\g two ’s human.shadow-NOM S ’s shadow-ACC put.in.between-PAST
\l Two human shadows encroached upon Sue’s shadow from the sides.

\t Sue no kagega hutatu no hitokageni(*yotte) hasamATta .
\g S ’s shadow-NOM two ’s shadow-by put.in.between-AR-PAST
\l Sue’s shadow was encroached upon by two human shadows from the sides.’ (AR here is a lexical passive in accordance to (2a).)

\t Sue no kagega hutatu no hitokageni(yotte) hasamareta .
\g S ’s shadow-NOM two ’s shadow-by put.inbetween-PASSIVE-PAST
\l Sue’s shadow was encroached upon by two human shadows from the sides.

\t Dokubariga kare no kubio sasita .
\g poison.needle-NOM he ’s neck-ACC stick-PAST
\l A poisoned needle pierced his neck.

\t Dokubariga kare no kubini sasATta .
\g poison.needle-NOM he ’s neck-into stick-AR-PAST
\l A poisoned needle stuck into his neck.’ (AR here is an intransitivizer in accordance with (2b).)

\t Kare no kubiga dokubarini(yotte) sas{*AT , (r)are}ta . (sas(r)are → sasare)
\g he ’s neck-NOM poison.needle-by stick-{*AR, PASSIVE}-PAST
\l His neck was pierced by a poisoned needle.’ (As marked, AR here is not a lexical passive since it does not follow (2a).)

\t Karega uzukumaru Kansin no senakao mataida .
\g he-NOM crouching K ’s back-ACC straddle-PAST
\l He straddled crouching Kansin’s back.

\t Karega uzukumaru Kansin no senakani matagATta .
\g he-NOM crouching K ’s back-onto straddle-AR-PAST
\l He straddled the back of crouching Kansin.’ (AR here is an intransitivizer in accordance to (2b).)

\t Uzukumaru Kansin no senakaga kareni(yotte) matag{*AT , (r)are}ta .
\g crouching K ’s back-NOM he-by stralddle-{AR, PASSIVE}-PAST
\l The back of crouching Kansin was straddled by him.’ (AR here is not a lexical passive, since it does not follow (2a).)

\t {Kare , Yokisinakatta bakuhatu}ga sono sawagio osamEta .
\g {he, expect-not-PAST explosion}-NOM that uproar-ACC suppress-E-PAST
\l {He, The unexpected explosion} suppressed that disturbance.

\t Sono sawagiga {kare , yokisinakatta bakuhatu}niyotte osamATta .
\g that uproar-NOM {he, expect-not-PAST explosion}-by suppress-AR-PAST
\l That disturbance was suppressed by {him, the unexpected explosion}.’ (AR here is lexical passive, satisfying (9a).)

\t *{Kare , Yokisinakatta bakuhatu}ga sono sawagini osamATta .
\g {he, expect-not-PAST explosion}-NOM that uproar-in regulate-AR-PAST
\l (Intended: ‘{He, The unexpected explosion} was suppressed by that disturbance.’) (This sentence should have been fine if the AR here were an intransitivizer, satisfying (9b). The fact that it is illicit shows that this AR is a lexical passive.)

\t *Sono sawagiga {kare , yokisinakatta bakuhatu}niyotte osamareta .
\g that uproar-NOM {he, expect-not-PAST explosion}-by pacify-PASSIVE-PAST
\l (Intended: ‘The disturbance was suppressed by {him, the unexpected explosion}.’)

\t Sono sawagiga {kare , *yokisinakatta bakuhatu}niyotte osamErareta .
\g that uproar-NOM he, expect-not-PAST explosion-by pacify-E-passive-PAST
\l The disturbance was suppressed by {him, *the unexpected explosion}.’ (The fact that (11d) with passive (r)are directly attached to R is illicit, while (11e) in which it is attached to [R-E] is felicitous, shows that in the context of Type (1C) the syntactically active passive (r)are cannot directly attach to an R).

\t {Sumibi , Sue}ga soupo atatamEta .
\g {charcoal.fire, Sue}-NOM soup-ACC warm-E-PAST
\l {Charcoal.fire, Sue} warmed the soup.

\t Soupga {sumibi , *Sue}niyotte atatamATta .
\g soup-NOM {charcoal.fire, *Sue}-by warm-AR-PAST
\l The soup was warmed by {charcoal.fire, *Sue}.’ (AR here is a lexical passive, cannot be forced to behave as an intransitivizer.)

\t *{Sumibi , Sue}ga suupuni atatamATta .14
\g {charcoal.fire, Sue}-NOM soup-ACC warm-AR-PAST
\l (Intended: ‘{Charcoal.fire, Sue} warmed by the soup.’) (AR here is intended to be an intransitivizer.)

\t {Toppuu , Sue}ga kurumao kini butukEta .
\g {gust.of.wind, Sue}-NOM car-ACC tree-to strike-E-PAST
\l {A.sudden.gust.of.wind, Sue} crashed the car into a tree

\t Kurumaga {toppuu , *Sue}niyotte kini butukATta .
\g car-NOM {gust.of.wind, *Sue}-by tree-to strike-AR-PAST
\l A car struck a tree by {a.sudden.gust.of.wind, *Sue}.

\t *{Toppuu , Sue}ga kurumani kini butukATta .
\g {gust.of.wind, Sue}-NOM car-ACC tree-to strike-AR-PAST
\l (Intended: ‘{A.sudden.gust.of.wind, Sue} crashed the car into a tree’) (AR here is a lexical passive.)

\t Ten’inga manbikio mitukEta
\g clerk-NOM shop.lifting-ACC notice-E-PAST
\l A clerk spotted shoplifting.

\t Manbikiga ten’inni( ? ?yotte) mitukATta .
\g shop.lifting-NOM clerk-by find-AR-PAST
\l Shoplifting was spotted by a clerk.

\t Kenga Sueni kamerao azukEta .
\g K-NOM S-DAT camera-ACC entrust-E-PAST
\l Ken entrusted a camera to Sue.

\t Suega Ken{ni , kara} kamerao azukATta .
\g S-NOM K-{by, from} camera-ACC entrust-AR-PAST
\l Sue was entrusted a camera by Ken.’ (Note that the status of AR here is ambiguous: it is a lexical passive according to diagnostic test (9a), but “intransitivizer-like” according to (9b) in that Ken-{ni, kara} no longer has indirect object status.)

\t *Kameraga Kenni Sueni azukATta .
\g camera-NOM K-by S-to entrust-AR-PAST
\l (Intended: ‘The camera was entrusted to Sue by Ken.’)

\t Kameraga Kenniyotte Sueni azukErareta .
\g camera-NOM K-by S-to entrust-E-PASSIVE-PAST
\l The camera was entrusted to Sue by Ken.

\t {*Sumibi , Sue}ga suupuni(yotte) atatamATta .
\g {charcoal.fire, Sue}-NOM soup-by warm-AR-PAST
\l {*Charcoal fire, Sue} was warmed by soup.’ (The status of AR is ambiguous: it is a lexical passive with respect to the diagnostic test (9a) but an intransitivizer according to (9b).)

\t Suega kurumani(*yotte) butukATta .
\g S-NOM car-to hit-AR-PAST
\l Sue was hit by a car.” (AR is a lexical passive with respect to the diagnostic test (9a), but is an intransitivizer according to (9b).)

\t Senseiga seitoni eigoo osieta .
\g teacher-NOM student-to English-ACC teach-PAST
\l the teacher taught the students English.

\t Seitoga senseini eigoo osowatta .
\g student-NOM teacher-by English-ACC learn-PAST
\l Students learned English from the teacher.

\t  ?Ho , konnani ookiku .natta . Dore , dakATte miro .
\g Wow like.this big.become-PAST well embrace-AR-and try-IMP
\l Wow, you’ve grown big. Well, let me hold you (lit. get yourself be held by me).’ (from Tayama Katai’s novel, Toki-wa Sugiyuku ‘Time passes by’)

\g Wow like.this big.become-PAST well embrace-PASSIVE-and try-IMP
\l Wow, you’ve grown big. Well, let me hold you (lit. get yourself be held by me).

\t Asagao no turuga ikegakini karanda .

\t Yasyawa kodomoni zibuno tabesaseta .

\l Yasya gave her own body to feed her children.’ (Yasya is a legendary figure who fed her children with her own flesh when their lives were threatened with starvation.)

\t Satooo ireru to dare .de .mo oisiku nomeru .
\g sugar-ACC put.in-PRES if anybody deliciously drink-be.able.to-PRES.
\l If you put in sugar, anyone can drink it smoothly.

\g salt-ACC sprinkle-PRES deliciously eat-be.able.to-PRES
\l If you sprinkle salt over it, you can enjoy eating it.

\t *Kono kamiwa suite iru . (sukte → suite)

\l (Intended: ‘This paper is transparent.’)

\l This paper is transparent.’ (See Suga 1980: 36, (39A,B))

\g this paper-TOP spacious-E-and look-PRES
\l This paper looks transparent.’ (Suga 1980: 36, (39A,B))

\t Bokuwa sono toki totemo  kurusin  da . (kurusimta → kurusinda)
\g I-TOP that time very [suffer-m]-PAST 
\l I really suffered at that time.

\t Bokumo  kurusiku  wa . aru .
\g I-too. [am.in.pain-ku]-CONTRASTIVE be-PRES
\l I too am in pain.

\t Bokuwa kono .yoona  kurusisa  o kanzita kotoga nai .
\g I-TOP such.like-be [torment]-ACC feel-PASt that-NOM not.be-PRES
\l I’ve never felt this level of anguish.

\t Ona pokupala štonibud i shla domoj .
\g She bought.IMPERF what-INDEF and went.IMPERF home
\l She bought something and went home. (usually)

\t Kažetsja , ktonibud’ približaetsja .
\g seems who-INDEF approaches
\l Apparently someone is approaching. (The speaker is not sure).

\t On skazal mne vziat’ / chtoby ja vzial štonibud .
\g He tell.PAST me take.INF / that I take-PAST what-INDEF
\l He told me to take something (it didn’t matter what).

\t On sprosil nas , vstretili li my kogonibud’ v parke .
\g He ask-PAST us meet-PAST whether we who-INDEF in the park
\l He asked us whether we met anyone (someone non-specific) in the park.

\t Ona pokupala štonibud/*štoto i shla domoj .
\g She bought.IMPERF what-INDEF and went.IMPERF home
\l She bought something (non-specific) and went home. (usually)

\t Ona kupila štoto/*štonibud i poshla domoj .
\g she bought.PERF what-INDEF and went.PERF home
\l She bought something (specific) and went home (once).

\t Za stenoj *ktonibud/ktoto smejalsia .
\g behind wall who-INDEF laugh-PAST
\l Someone was laughing behind the wall.

\t Masha prigotovit *štonibud/štoto vkusnoje na uzhin .
\g Masha cook-FUT what-INDEF delicious for dinner
\l Masha will cook something delicious for dinner (and she knows what it is going to be, but the speaker does not).

\t Ty kupila *štoto/štonibud’ na uzhin ?
\g You buy-PAST what-INDEF for dinner?
\l Did you buy anything (something non-specific) for dinner?

\t Kažetsja , *ktoto/ktonibud’ približaetsja .
\g seems who-INDEF approaches
\l Apparently someone is approaching. (The speaker is not sure).

\t On skazal mne vziat’ / chtoby ja vzial *štoto/štonibud .
\g He tell-PAST me take-INF / that I take-PAST what-INDEF
\l He told me to take something (it didn’t matter what).

\t On sprosil nas , vstretili li my *kogoto/kogonibud’ v parke .
\g He ask-PAST us meet-PAST whether we who-INDEF in the park
\l He asked us whether we met anyone (someone non-specific) in the park.

\t Kazhdyj prepodavatel’ slyshal , chto kogoto/*kogonibud’ iz moix studentov vsegda vyzyvajut k dekanu .
\g every teacher hear-PAST that who-INDEF from my students always call-PRES-3RDPL(impers.) to dean
\l Every teacher heard that some (one) of my students is always called before the dean (the same specific person is called every time).

\t Ja nashla koešto interesnoje v etoj knige .
\g I found INDEF-what interesting in this book
\l I found something interesting in this book.

\t Ja tebe koešto prines . Smotri , kakaja dynia .
\g I you-DAT INDEF-what brought. Look which melon.
\l I brought you something. Look at this melon.

\t Przyprowadź mi kogoś kto zna angielski .
\g bring.IMPV I.DAT who.ACC-INDEF who.NOM knows English.ACC
\l Bring me someone(non-specific) who knows English.

\t Ktoś jest w łazience .
\g who.NOM-INDEF is in bathroom.LOC
\l Someone (specific unknown) is in the bathroom.

\t Ktoś dzwonił . Zgadnij kto .
\g who.NOM-INDEF phoned guess.IMPV who.NOM
\l Someone (specific known) called. Guess who.

\t Dareka ni kiite mimashou .
\g who-INDEF DAT ask-CONV try-POL-HORT
\l Let’s ask somebody (non-specific).

\t Dareka kare denwa atta kedo , dare kara da ka wakaranai
\g who-INDEF from phone be.PAST though who from be.PRES Q know-Neg-PRES
\l Somebody (specific unknown) called, – I don’t know who.

\t Dareka kare denwa atta kedo , dare kara da ka atete goran
\g who-INDEF from phone be.PAST though who from be.PRES Q figure.out-CONV try-IMPV

\g chyba where-COND him.DAT go.l-PTCP.SG.N about kind-heartedness
\l unless the issue concerns kind-heartedness

\l unless he would be so sick

\t Montags und dienstags bleibt die Gaststätte im Winter geschlossen ,  ⁰ außer    wenn sich Gesellschaften anmelden  .
\g Mondays and Tuesdays remain.3SG the restaurant in:the winter closed  except  if REFL societies sign:up.3PL
\l On Mondays and Tuesdays the restaurant is closed in the winter time, unless societies sign up.

\t  S ie will mehr überzeugen als befehlen –  ⁰ außer    wo es notwendig ist  .
\g she want.3SG more convince.INF than command.INF –  except  where it necessary be.3SG
\l She wants to convince more than to command – except where it is necessary.

\t Eigentlich finde ich es ziemlich gut ,  ⁰ außer    dass wir so lange unterwegs sind  .
\g actually find.1SG I it.ACC quite good  except  that we so long underway be.1PL
\l Actually, I find it quite good, except that we are so long on the way.

\t *Dzisiaj po południu mogą wyjść na wolność , chyba że sądu zdecyduje inaczej .
\g today after midday.LOC can.3PL go:out.INF on freedom.ACC unless court.GEN decide.3SG differently
\l Intended: ‘They are allowed to be released from the prison today afternoon, unless the court will take a different decision.

\t Dzisiaj po południu mogą wyjść na wolność , jeśli sąd nie zdecyduje inaczej .
\g today after midday can.3PL go:out.INF on freedom.ACC if court NEG decide.3SG differently
\l They are allowed to be released from the prison today afternoon, if the court will not take a different decision.

\t Powiedział , że żeście tam poszli .
\g say.l-PTCP.SG.M COMP FOC.PTCL-2PL there go.l-PTCP.PL.VIR
\l He said you had gone there.

\t Experimenter: Was siehst du ?
\g  (What do you see?)\t Expected answer: Eine blaue (Kerze) und eine rote Kerze .
\g  (a blue (candle) and a red candle)\t Experimenter: Was ist verschwunden ?
\g  (what disappeared?)\t Expected answer: Die rote Kerze .
\g  (the red candle)\t Experimenter: Was du hier siehst heißt Knett . Was ist das ?
\g  (What you see here is called Knett. What do you see?)\t Expected answer: Ein gelbes (Knett) und ein blaues Knett .
\g  (a yellow (Knett) and a blue Knett)\t Experimenter: Was klaut der Dieb ?
\g  (What’s the thief stealing?)\t Expected answer: Das blaue Knett .
\g  (the blue Knett)\t Exp . Answer: Eine rote Glett/ein rotes Glett .
\g  (a red Glett/a red Glett)\t Experimenter: Und was ist weg ?
\g  (And what is gone?)\t Exp . Answer: Die rote Glett/das rote Glett .
\g  (the red Glett/the red Glett)\t Podłoga została zabrudzona (przez dzieci) .
\g floor became soil.PFV.PASS.PTCP by children
\l The floor got soiled (by the children).’ (Laskowski 1999: 196)

\t Podłoga była zabrudzona (*przez dzieci) .
\g floor was soil.PFV.PASS.PTCP by children
\l The floor was dirty (*by the children).’ (ibid.)

\t Podłoga była brudzona (przez dzieci) .
\g floor was soil.IPFV.PASS.PTCP by children
\l The floor was (repeatedly) soiled / was being soiled (by the children).’ (ibid.)

\t Szkoła buduje się .
\g school.NOM.SG build.IPFV.PRS.3SG REFL
\l The school is being built.’ (Laskowski 1999: 195)

\g in room be.PST.3SG nicely tidy_up.PFV.PASS.PTCP.NOM.SG.N by Piotr
\l It was nicely tidied up (by Piotr) in the room.’ (Kibort 2011: 358)

\l (Intended:) Zhangsan’s cat is not multiple “cats.

\l (Intended:) Lisi has two cats, therefore it’s not the case that he has a single cat.

\t Kupio sam haljina .
\g bought.1SG.M.PFV AUX dresses.PL.GEN
\l I bought (some) dresses.’ PRESUPPOSITION: There is a (plural) individual of dresses and x is a proper subpart of this plural individual. ASSERTION: I bought dresses.

\l I bought the dresses.

\g bought.1SG.M.PFV AUX dresses.PL.GEN  PARTITIVE GENITIVE
\l I bought (some) dresses.’ PRESUPPOSITION: There is a (plural) individual that consists of a proper subpart of dresses.

\g the house her
\l his/her/their house

\t e assim fiquei sem poder negar a minha vaidade .
\g and like.this stayed without be.able deny the my.LONG vanity
\l and so I was unable to deny my vanity

\t Assim que meu pai morrer
\g like.this as my.LONG father dies
\l As soon as my father dies.’

\t Pois como dizedes vos aa mha alma
\g for how you.say you to.DEF my.SHORT soul
\l For how you say to my soul…

\t Flérida Aquel tal que lamenta su ventura y exclama su tristeza
\g Flérida Aquel that which regrets his.SHORT fate and exclaim his.SHORT sadness
\l Flérida Aquel, the one who regrets his fate and exclaims his sadness

\t o meu livro
\g the my book
\l my book

\t um livro meu
\g a book my
\l a book of mine

\t *O só meu problema é que não percebo nada disto .
\g DEF only my problem is that not understand nothing of.this
\l Intended: “My only problem is that I don’t understand it.

\t Um problema só meu é que não percebo nada disto .
\g INDF problem only my is that not understand nothing of.this
\l My only problem is that I don’t understand it.

\t Hey ! Tumne kabhi kisise pyaar kiyaa ?
\g Hey! 2SG=ERG ever someone=OBL love do-PRF.M.SG
\l Hey! Have you ever loved someone?

\t Kiyaa !
\g do-PRF.M.SG
\l Did!’ = ‘I have loved someone!

\t aslaman dits mohnas kitaab raamIni khəətri raath
\g aslam=ERG give.PRF Mohan=DAT book Ram=DAT for yesterday
\l Aslam gave Mohan a book for Ram yesterday.

\t təmis chu pataa  ki aslaman dits mohnas gər 
\g he.DAT AUX know-PRF.M that aslam=ERG give.PRF Mohan=DAT watch
\l He knew that Aslam gave a watch to Mohan.’ (Wali and Koul 1997: 18)

\t ShiilI cha kitaab paraan
\g Sheila AUX book read-PRP
\l Sheila is reading a book. (Wali and Koul 1997: 104)

\t  yosI kitab Samiraan rajas dits  , so kitaab…
\g REL book Samir=ERG raj=DAT give.PRF that book…
\l Which book Samir gave to Raj, that book…’ (Munshi and Bhatt 2009: (18a))

\t kəmis dits rajan kitaab ?
\g who.DAT give.PRF Raj=ERG book
\l To whom did Raj give a book?’ (Munshi and Bhatt 2009: (27a))

\t rajan kəmis həəv nəəv kitaab ?
\g raj=ERG whom.DAT show.PRF new book
\l As for Raj, to whom did he show his new book?’ (Wali and Koul 1997: 12)

\t tsI gatashakh naa pagaah garI
\g you go-2SGPS.FUT Neg-Q tomorrow home
\l Won’t you go home tomorrow?’ (Wali and Koul 1997: 12)

\t AtSERKl chu aksar monomer aasaan
\g AtSERKI AUX generally monomer be.PRP
\l AtSERKI is generally a monomer.’ (https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/29305846.pdf accessed 9/15/19)

\t  yus laRkI dili aksar chu roozaan  … .
\g k boy Delhi often AUX live-PRP
\l The boy who often lives in Delhi …’ (JC 9/18/19)

\t  yosI kitaab samiiran raajas ditsnI   so kitaab… 
\g which book.F Samir=ERG Raj=DAT give.PRF-NEG that book.F
\l the book that Samir did not give to Raj, that book…

\t Təm cha ciTh’ liichmIts ganTas .
\g 3SG.ERG AUX.PST.F letter.F write-PSP.F hour-for
\l He has written a letter for an hour.

\t tami ti cha
\g 3SG.ERG also AUX.PST.F
\l She also has (written a letter for an hour).

\t tsI dikh pagaah təmis kitaab
\g 2SG.NOM give-FUT.2SG tomorrow 3SG.DAT book
\l You will give him a book tomorrow

\t Kabir ti diyi
\g Kabir also give-FUT.3SG
\l Kabir will also give (him a book tomorrow)

\t Mohanan khev batI kinI tsot
\g Mohan=ERG eat.PRF rice or bread
\l Mohan ate either rice or bread.’ (I don’t know which)

\t Pranavan ti khev
\g Pranav=ERG also eat.PRF
\l Pranav also ate (rice or bread)’ (= not necessarily what Mohan ate)

\t Pranavan ti khev su
\g Pranav=ERG also eat.PRF it
\l Pranav also ate it.’ (= whichever one it was that Mohan ate)

\t az sokuul gavaa ? A: Aa , gav .
\g to school go.PRF-Q  Yes, go.PRF
\l Did he/#someone go to school? Yes he/#someone went.

\t kaaNh az sokuul gavaa ? A: Aa , gav .
\g Somone to school go.PRF-Q  Yes, go.PRF
\l Did someone go to school? Yes, someone went.

\t Təm buuz zi miiraa diyi mohnas kitaab yaa shiilas ciTh
\g 3SG.ERG hear.PRF that Mira give-FUT Mohan=DAT book or Sheila=DAT letter
\l He heard that Mira will give Mohan a book or Sheila a letter.

\t Na , miiraa diyi nI
\g No Mira give-FUT Neg
\l No, Mira will not give (Mohan a book or Sheila a letter).’ (Manetta 2020b)

\t Rameshan kor darwaaz vozul rung tI Mohanan kor dos
\g Ramesh=ERG do.PRF door red color and Mohan=ERG do.PRF wall
\l Ramesh painted the door red and Mohan painted the wall.’ (≠red).

\t Aslaman vuchukh tsI naaraaz tI Mohanan vuch Sita .
\g Aslam=ERG see.PRF-2SG 2SG angry and Mohan=Erg see.PRF Sita
\l Aslam saw you angry and Mohan saw Sita (≠angry).

\t Rameshan kor darwaaz vozul rung tI Mohanan ti kor
\g Ramesh=ERG do.PRF door red color and Mohan=ERG also did.PRF
\l Ramesh painted the door red and Mohan did too (painted the door red).

\t kyaa Aslaman vuchukhaa tsI naaraaz ? Aa , vuchunas
\g Q Aslam=ERG see.PRF-2SG-Q 2SG angry yes, see.PRF-SG
\l Did Aslam see you angry? Yes, saw.’ (= he saw me angry)1

\t Təm buuz zi kəNsi diyi mohnas kitaab yaa shiilas ciTh pagaah
\g 3SG.ERG hear.PRF that someone give-FUT Mohan=DAT book or Sheila=DAT letter tomorrow
\l He heard that someone will give Mohan a book or Sheila a letter tomorrow.

\t Təm cha ciTh’ liichmIts , chan naa ?
\g 3SG AUX.PST.F letter.F write-PSP.F AUX.F-3SGPS NEG-Q
\l He has written a letter, hasn’t he?’ (Wali and Koul 1997: 7)

\t su leekhi nI ciTh’ leekh’aa ?
\g 3SG write.3SG.FUT NEG letter write.3SG.FUT-Q
\l He won’t write a letter, will he?’ (Wali and Koul 1997: 7)

\t O João comprou o carro , não comprou ?
\g DEF Juan bought the car, NEG bought
\l Juan bought the car, didn’t he?

\t *O João comprou o carro , não comprou o carro ?
\g DEF Juan bought the car, NEG bought DEF car\t  demos um telefone novo ao João , não demos ?
\g We gave.1PL a telephone new to Juan NEG gave.1PL
\l We gave a new telephone to Juan, didn’t we?

\t *Nós demos um telefone novo ao João , não demos um telefone / não demos ao João ?
\g We gave.1PL a telephone new to Juan NEG gave.1PL a telephone/NEG gave.1PL to Juan\t Ra:jI rani ka: nḣ magar me chunI pataa k’a .
\g Raj cook.FUT something, but 1SG.DAT AUX-NEG know what
\l Raj will cook something, but I don’t know what.’ (Rakesh Bhatt, p.c.)

\t Mona og Jasper havde vasket bilen , eller rettere Mona havde
\g Mona and Jasper has.PAST wash-PART car.DEF or rather Mona has.PAST
\l Mona and Jasper have washed the car, or rather Mona has.’ (Sailor 2018: (6a))

\g Mona and Jasper wash.PAST car.DEF or rather Mona wash.PAST
\l Mona and Jasper have washed the car, or rather Mona has.’ (Sailor 2018: (7b))

\t Im se dat siem ting de .  (Durrleman 2008; p .28)
\g s/he say that same thing there  
\l S/he said that very thing.

\t Im did se dat siem ting de .
\g s/he PAST say that same thing there
\l S/he had said that very thing.

\t Jan tingk se im a di bes .   (Durrleman 2008; p .29)
\g John think that he [equative] the best   
\l John thinks/*thought that he is/*was the best.

\t Jan did tingk se im a di bes .
\g John PAST think that he [equative] the best
\l John thought that he was the best.

\t Jan nyam i .
\g John eat it
\l John ate it/John eats it (habitually)/*John is eating it.

\g John [+PROG] eat it  
\l John is eating it.

\t Jan a_go nyam i .
\g John [+PROS] eat it
\l John is going to eat it.

\t ajwe ba klwaa
\g rice CLASS every
\l every category/kind of rice

\t bla ngba dũmã assengou wa lɛ kɔnã .
\g woman all name assengou here COP konan
\l All the women’s name here in Assengou is Konan.

\t ba nga (ɛ) wɔ sukulu .
\g child this (pro-3sg) go school
\l this child (he) goes to school.

\t *ba klwaa nga (ɛ) ɲãã fluwanĩ .
\g child every this pro.3SG pass-FACT.PST test-SPECIF\t *ba ngba nga wɔ sukulu .
\g child/children all this/these go school\t ba ɲnã ngba
\g Child four all
\l all four children

\t *ba ɲnã klwaa
\g child four every\t ajwe ba nsã ngba
\g rice CLASS three all
\l all three grains of rice

\t *ajwe ba nsã klwaa
\g rice CLASS three every\t cɛ̃ klwaa ngba , n wɔ blo .
\g day every all pro.1SG go bush
\l Every single day, I go to the bush.’ (lit: all (of) every day)

\t wo kũũ  me klwaa ngba   akɔ .
\g snake kill-FACT.PST pro.3PL every all chicken
\l The snake killed the chickens of absolutely everyone.’ (=lit: chickens of all [the set] (of) every (of) them)

\t wo kũũ me   akɔ klwaa ngba  .
\g snake kill-FACT.PST pro.3PL chicken every all
\l the snake killed every single one of their chickens.’ (=lit. all (of) every of their chickens)

\t srã ngba klwaa di fje kɔ̃ngɔ̃ .
\g human all every eat (=farm) field one-by-one
\l Each of all humans farms the fields one by one.

\t Abo dii fje ngba klwaa .
\g Abo farm-FACT.PST field all every
\l Abo farmed every (one) of all the fields.

\t Abo dii fje klwaa ngba
\g Abo farm-FACT.PST field every all
\l Abo farmed all of every field

\t fje ngba klwaa
\g field all every\t Me jwe klo utře třa su .
\g pro.3PL some like fight much
\l some of them like fighting a lot.

\t kpãflɛ̃ jwe mũ si able klɔ̃ nĩ nũ .
\g boy some PL dance village SPEC in
\l some boys dance in the village.

\t me jwe mũ si able klɔ̃ nĩ nũ .
\g pro.3pl some PL dance village SPEC in
\l some (of them) dance in the village.’ (=lit: (of) them, some dance in the village)

\t kpãflɛ̃ jwe nĩ si able klɔ̃’n nũ .
\g boy some spec dance village-SPEC in
\l some boy dances in the village.

\t bla mũ me wu ba kɔ̃ngɔ̃ .
\g Woman PL pro.3PL give child one-after
\l women give birth to children one after another.

\t srã kũngba di ɉumã lɛ nã jaswa ɔ
\g human unique work there and man disc.part.
\l a unique person works there, and he is a man.

\t jaswa klo loto klu .
\g man like car some
\l a man/men like some (category of) cars.

\l Mary is Georg Preuße. She is a well-known figure in show business.

\l No goat who has picked up a candy returned it to Wolffy.

\l No goat picked up any candy.
