\t Wesnara Tsoma keenai . (PV: 785)
\g Wesna.ABS=EV Tsoma.ABS want-IPFV 
\l Wesna loves/wants Tsoma.

\t Wesnara janbix keenai . (not *keemeetai)
\g Wesna.ABS=EV 3-NOM-EM-S want-IPFV  want-REFL.IPFV
\l Wesna loves/wants herself.’ (Also ‘Wesna herself wants him/her/it.’)

\t Wesnara kirika bomakaa t ke . (PV: 785)
\g Wesna.ABS=EV letter.ABS carry-CAUS-REFL-PFV 
\l Wesna sent a letter to herself.

\t Jabora piti meniananke . (fieldnotes)
\g they.ABS=EV food give-RECIP-PFV 
\l They gave each other food.

\t Wesnanra chomo ja pekáo ake . (PV: 787)
\g Wesna-ERG=EV jar.ABS 3 behind do-PFV 
\l Wesna put the jar behind her(self).

\t Janra jawen poi reteke . (PV: 787)
\g 3-ERG=EV 3.POSS opposite.sex.sibling.ABS kill-PFV 
\l She killed her brother.

\t Wesnara Tsomaki sináke . (PV: 783)
\g Wesna=EV Tsoma-DAT get.angry.at-PFV 
\l Wesna got angry at Tsoma.

\t Wesnara sináke .
\g Wesna=EV get.angry.at-PFV
\l Wesna got angry at herself.’ (Also ‘Wesna got angry.’)

\g they.ABS=EV word.ABS tell-RECIP-IPFV 
\l They tell each other stories.

\t Tarowa   Jiroga kita toyuu uwasa o kiita .

\l Taro heard the rumor that Jiro came.

\t Tarowa   Jiroga kita toyuu shooko o mitsuketa .
\g T-TOP  J-NOM come-PST that.say evidence-ACC find-PST
\l Taro found the evidence that Jiro came.

\t Tarowa   Jiroga kita no o mita .
\g T-TOP  J-NOM come-PST NO-ACC see-PST
\l Taro saw Jiro come.

\t Tarowa   Jiroga kita koto o shitta .
\g T-TOP  J-NOM come-PST KOTO-ACC know-PST
\l Taro found out that Jiro came.

\t Tarowa   kawaita taoru o tanonda .

\t Tarowa   taoruga kawaita toyuu hookoku o shita .
\g T-TOP  towel-NOM dry-PST that.say report-ACC do-PST
\l Taro made a report that the towel dried.

\t Maryo watashiwa   ec Billni  shookaishitai toyuu kiboo o motteiru .
\g M-ACC I-TOP  B-DAT  introduce-want-NPST that.say desire-ACC have-NPST
\l I have a desire such that I want to introduce Mary to Bill.’ (Haig 1976: 369; (25))

\t *Ano hono watashiwa   ec  kaita hito ni aitai .
\g that book-ACC I-TOP   write-PST person-to meet-want-NPST
\l (‘I want to meet the person who wrote that book.’) (Haig 1976: 370; (30))

\t  ?Billo Johnga   Maryga  saketeiru toyuu uwasa o kiita .
\g B-ACC J-NOM  M-NOM  avoid-NPST that.say rumor-ACC hear-PST
\l John heard a rumor that Mary is avoiding Bill.’ (Saito 1985: 246; (146b))

\t  ?*Ano hono Johnga   ec  katta hito o sagashiteiru rasii .
\g that book-ACC J-NOM   buy-PST person-ACC search-NPST seem
\l (‘It seems that John is looking for the person who bought that book.’) (Saito 1985: 246; (146a))

\l Miren said that they came.

\g Miren NEG AUX Q Ana come AUX-C ask
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana came.

\t *Mirenek ez du  Ana ez den etorri  galdetu .                                    In situ negative clause 
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana NEG AUX-C come ask
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana didn’t come.

\t *Mirenek ez du  noiz etorri den Ana  galdetu .                                             In situ whclause 
\g Miren NEG AUX when come AUX-C Ana ask
\l Miren didn’t ask when Ana came.

\t Mirenek ez du galdetu  ea Ana etorri den  .                                                   Extraposed ea clause 
\g Miren NEG AUX ask Q Ana come AUX-C
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana came.

\t Mirenek ez du galdetu  Ana ez den etorri  .                                    Extraposed negative clause 
\g Miren NEG AUX ask Ana NEG AUX-C come
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana didn’t come.

\t Mirenek ez du galdetu  noiz etorri den Ana  .                                            Extraposed whclause 
\g Miren NEG AUX ask when come AUX-C Ana
\l Miren didn’t ask when Ana came.

\t  Ea Ana etorri den  ez du galdetu Mirenek .                                                Piedpiped ea clause 
\g Q Ana come AUX-C NEG AUX ask Miren
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana came.

\t  Ana ez den etorri  ez du galdetu Mirenek .                                     Piedpiped negative clause 
\g Ana NEG AUX-C come NEG AUX ask Miren
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana didn’t come.

\t  Noiz etorri den Ana  ez du galdetu Mirenek .                                             Piedpiped whclause 
\g when come AUX-C Ana NEG AUX ask Miren
\l Miren didn’t ask when Ana came.

\t Mirenek ez du  Anak leihoa itxi duela  esan .                                    In situ declarative clause 
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana window close AUX-C say
\l Miren did not say that Ana closed the window.

\t Mirenek ez du  leihoa Anak itxi duela  esan .
\g Miren NEG AUX window Ana close AUX-C say
\l Lit. Miren did not say that the window, Ana closed.

\t Mirenek  ez dela etorri  esan du .                                         Inverted 
\g Miren NEG AUX-C come say AUX
\l Miren said that she didn’t come.

\t Mirenek  etorri ez dela  esan du .                                    Noninverted 
\g Miren come NEG AUX-C say AUX\t *Mirenek ez du  Ana ez den etorri  galdetu . ((32b))                       Inversion + Quasifocus 
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana NEG AUX-C come ask 
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana didn’t come.

\t Mirenek ez du  Ana etorri ez den  galdetu .                                    Noninversion + Quasifocus 
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana come NEG AUX-C ask
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana didn’t come.

\t *Mirenek esan du  Ana etorri ez dela  .                                             Noninversion + Extraposition 
\g Miren say AUX Ana come NEG AUX-C
\l Miren said that Ana didn’t come.

\t */ ? ? Nor etorri ez dela  esan du Mirenek ?                                    Noninversion + Piedpiping 
\g Who come NEG AUX-C say AUX Miren
\l Lit. That who didn’t come did Miren say?

\t *Mirenek ez du  Ana etorri ez den gaur  galdetu .                                    Noninverted 
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana come NEG AUX-C today ask
\l Miren didn’t ask whether Ana didn’t come today.

\t *Mirenek ez du  noiz etorri den Ana  galdetu .                                    Quasifocus 
\g Miren NEG AUX when come AUX-C Ana ask
\l Miren didn’t ask when Ana came.

\t Mirenek ez du  Ana noiz etorri den  galdetu .
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana when come AUX-C ask
\l Miren didn’t ask when Ana came.

\t *Mirenek ez du  zerbait ere noiz gertatuko den  galdetu .
\g Miren NEG AUX something ADDP when happen AUX-C ask
\l Miren didn’t ask when something or other will happen.

\t *Mirenek ez du  Ana noiz etorri den etxera  galdetu .
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana when come AUX-C house-to ask
\l Miren didn’t ask when Ana came home.

\t Mirenek ez du  Ana etxera noiz etorri den  galdetu .
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana house-to when come AUX-C ask
\l Miren didn’t ask when Ana came home.

\t Mirenek galdetu du  noiz etorri den Ana  .                                         Extraposition 
\g Miren ask AUX when come AUX-C Ana
\l Miren asked when Ana came.

\t ( ?)  Noiz etorri den Ana  galdetu du Mirenek .                                    Piedpiping 
\g  when come AUX-C Ana ask AUX Miren
\l Miren asked when Ana came.

\t Mirenek ez du  Anak leihoa itxi ez duela  esan .
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana window close NEG AUX-C say
\l Miren didn’t say that Ana didn’t close the window.

\t Mirenek ez du  Anak (leihoa) itxi (*leihoa) ez (*leihoa) duela  esan .
\g Miren NEG AUX Ana window close window NEG window AUX-C say
\l Miren didn’t say that Ana didn’t close the window.

\g Ana fast came AUX
\l Ana came fast.

\t Ana ez da azkar etorri .
\g Ana NEG AUX fast come
\l Ana didn’t come fast.

\g fast NEG AUX Ana come
\l Ana didn’t come fast.

\l Miren did not say that Ana didn’t come fast.

\t Ez du inork ezer egin .                                                              Etxepare (2003: 545) 
\g NEG AUX anybody anything do
\l Nobody did anything.

\t Inork ez du ezer egin .
\g anybody NEG AUX anything do\t  ? ?Inork ezer ez du egin .
\g anybody anything NEG AUX do\t Jonek  inork ezer egin ez duela  esan du .  Adapted from Etxepare (2003: 546) 
\g Jon anybody anything do NEG AUX-C say AUX 
\l Jon said that nobody did anything.

\t Mirenek ez du  leihoa nork itxi duen  galdetu .
\g Miren NEG AUX window who close AUX-C ask
\l Miren didn’t ask who closed the window.

\t Nork itxi du leihoa ?                                   Standard whinterrogative 
\g who close AUX window
\l Who closed the window?

\t Nork du leihoa itxi ?                                  Reinforced whinterrogative 
\g who AUX window close
\l Who closed the window?

\t Anak ez du  leihoa nork itxi duen  galdetu .              Standard 
\g Ana NEG AUX window who close AUX-C ask
\l Ana didn’t ask who closed the window.

\t *Anak ez du  leihoa nork duen itxi  galdetu .           Reinforced 
\g Ana NEG AUX window who AUX-C close ask
\l Ana didn’t ask who closed the window.

\t Anak ez du galdetu  nork duen itxi leihoa  .
\g Ana NEG AUX ask who AUX-C close window
\l Ana didn’t ask who closed the window.

\g other for the fear that he dreaded that he it so worthily do not might it refused

\t ‘as is most advantageous to the convent  XP that he distribute them _  ’:
\g λP. it is most advantageous to the convent that he distribute them in manner P\t Gif him ðonne God ryhtlice & stræclice deman wile , & he him for his mildheortnesse ne arað , ðonne beoð hie sua monegum scyldum scyldige sua hie manegra unðeawa gestiran meahton mid hiora larum & bisenum , gif hi ongemong monnum beon wolden .
\g if them then God rightously & severly judge want & he them for his mercy not ?spare then are they so many sins guilty so they many faults correct might with their teaching & example if they among men be wanted
\l (cocura,CP:5.45.20.257) ʻBut if God determines to judge them righteously and severely, and does not of his mercy spare them, they are guilty of as many sins as they could have corrected faults with their instruction and example, if they had been willing to associate with men’ (Sweet)

\t Se ðe ænigne ðissa ierminga besuicð , him wære betere ðæt him wære sumu esulcweorn to ðæm suiran getiged , & sua aworpen to sæs grunde .

\l (cocura,CP:2.31.14.140) ‘He who deceives one of these little ones, it were better for him to have a millstone tied to his neck, and so to be thrown to the bottom of the sea.’ (Sweet)

\t Gief we ðonne habbað sua micle sorge & sua micle gieman urra niehstena sua ure selfra , ðonne hæbbe we begen fet gescode suiðe untællice;
\g if we then have so much trouble & so much care our neighbours so our selves then have we both feet shod very blamelessly
\l (cocura,CP:5.45.10.254) ʻIf we take as much trouble and care about our neighbours as ourselves, we have both feet shod very blamelessly;’ (Sweet)

\t Forðæm sua sua unwærlicu & giemeleaslicu spræc menn dweleð , sua eac sio ungemetgode suige ðæs lareowes on gedwolan gebringð ða ðe he læran meahte , gif he sprecende beon wolde .
\g because so so unguarded & careless speech men lead astray so also the excessive silence the teacher in error brings them that he teach may if he speaking be wanted
\l (cocura,CP:15.89.7.571) ʻFor as unguarded and careless speaking leads men astray, so the excessive silence of the teacher leads into error those whom he might teach if he were willing to speak.’ (Sweet)

\t Sua se æppel bið betogen mid anfealdre rinde , & ðeah monig corn oninnan him hæfð , sua sio halige cirice unrim folces befehð mid anfealde geleafan ,
\g so the apple is covered with onefold rind & though many seed within it has so the holy church innumerable people comprehends with onefold belief
\l (cocura,CP:15.95.5.619) ‘As the apple is covered with a single skin, and yet has many pips inside it, so the holy church encloses a multitude of people with one faith,’ (Sweet)

\t Se ceac wæs sua micel ðæt he oferhelede ða oxan ealle , buton ða heafudu totodon ut .
\g the basin was so big that it covered the oxen all except the heads peeped out
\l (cocura,CP:16.105.4.688) ʻThe basin was big enough to cover the oxen entirely, except the projecting heads.ʼ (Sweet) ʻ… so big that …

\t & sua ðurhfærð his andgit ðæt mod his hieremonna ðætte him bið eall cuð ðæt hie unaliefedes ðenceað .
\g & so penetrates his understanfing the mind his subjects that him is all known that they illicit think
\l (cocura,CP:21.155.8.1057) ʻand thus his understanding penetrates the heart of his subjects, so that all their unlawful thoughts are known to him.’ (Sweet)

\t Gif hwa stalie , swa his wif nyte & his bearn , geselle LX scillinga to wite .
\g if who stells so his wife not.know & his children give 60 shillings to punishment
\l (colawine,LawIne:7.26) ‘If someone steals, if his wife and his children don’t know, let him give 60 shillings as fine.

\t ond sua hwelc sua wille betweoxn eow mæst beon , sie se eower ðeow .
\g and so which so wants between you most be be that your slave
\l (cocura,CP:17.121.4.810) ʻand whoever whishes to be greatest among you, shall be your slave.ʼ (Sweet)

\t & geðence he simle sie sua æðele sua unæðele suæðer he sie ða æðelu ðære æfterran acennesse , ðæt is on ðæm fulluhte ,
\g & think he always be so noble so common whichever he be the nobility the afterwards nativity that is in the baptism
\l (cocura,CP:14.85.14.552) ʻand whether he be noble or of low birth, let him ever consider the nobility of regeneration, which is in baptism,ʼ (Sweet)

\t Sua micle he mæg ieð his hieremenn geteon to beteran , & he bið sua micle sel gehiered sua he ufor gestent on his lifes geearnungum .
\g so much he may easier his subjects bring to better & he is so much better heard so he higher stands in his life’s merits
\l (cocura,CP:14.81.16.532) ‘He can the more easily improve his disciples, and the better he will be heard, the higher he stands in his life’s merits.’ (Sweet)

\t a . swa : definiteness marking – “the”
\g b. swa : marking predicate abstraction – “λaˮ\t   he₃  ᵍ    def   (  C  ᵍ)
\g  = the unique x such that g(C₃)(x) =1 if there is such a unique x, undefined otherwise.\t   the dogs    max(λx .x are dogs)
\g  = the largest sum of dogs (in the context)\t   swa₃  ᵍ    def   (   C  ᵍ)
\g  = max(λP.g(C₃)(P) = 1)
\l if there is such a maximal P, undefined otherwise.

\t swa: trigger of Predicate Abstraction                                                                                 “λαˮ
\g  (over variables of semantic types <e>, <e,t>, <v,t>, <i>, <d>, resulting in properties of type <e,t>, <<e,t>,t>, <<v,t>,t>, <i,t>, <d,t>)\t   Billy is as tall as Alex    1 iff Height(B)≥Height(A)
\g  ‘B’s height reaches or exceeds A’s height.’\t Geðenc hwelc witu us ða becomon for ðisse worulde , ða ða         we hit nohwæðer ne selfe ne lufodon ne eac oðrum monnum ne lefdon:
\g consider which punishment us then befall for this world, then when we it neither neg self neg loved neg also other men neg left
\l (coprefcura,CPLetW+arf:23.10) ʻConsider what punishment would come upon us on account of this world, if we neither loved it (wisdom) ourselves nor suffered other men to obtain it:ʼ (Sweet)

\g  [CP [ᶦᶦᶦswa₁ IDENT] [3[C’ B t₃ tall is]]] ]\t     CP swa2 Alex t is    ᵍ   λd . A is dtall 
\g  = [λd.Height(A)≥d]\t   CP  ᵍ  λdʼ . Height(B)≥ dʼ)

\l Which books did Jon ask who had written?’ (Maling & Zaenen 1982: 232)

\l Which cakes did the guest wonder whether Hanne baked?’ (Kush et al. 2018)

\g sailors-DEF.PL saw signal-DEF REL they knew  what  meant
\l The sailors saw the signal that they knew what meant.

\g cake-DEF wonders he on  if/whether Hanne baked
\l The cake he wonders whether Hanne baked.’ ~ ‘He wonders whether Hanne baked the cake.’ (Kush et al. 2019: 6)

\g how asked he  who C had behaved SELF
\l How did he ask [who had behaved ___ ]?

\t Det er mange   som ___ snakker det språket  .
\g it is many  REL speak that language-DEF
\l There are many (people) who speak that language.’ ~ ‘Many people speak that language.

\g that language-DEF is it many  REL speak

\l That language, it’s only Andrew that speaks.

\t Lakris er Odd den eneste (personen)   som ___ ikke liker ___   .
\g licorice is Odd the only person-DEF  REL  NEG likes
\l Licorice, Odd is the only person who doesn’t like.

\t Ein må ikkje vere meir redd for å gjere feil på nynorsk enn på bokmål .

\l You shouldn’t be more afraid of making mistakes in Nynorsk than in Bokmål.

\g that know I many actual-Nynorsk.users  REL are
\l That, I know many actual Nynorsk users who are.’ ~ ‘I know many actual Nynorsk users who are that(= afraid to make mistakes).

\t Rødsprit slipper vi ingen inn   som ___ har drukket ____   .
\g red.spirit let we nobody in  REL has drunk
\l We don’t let anybody in who has drunk grain alcohol.’ (Taraldsen 1982: 206)

\t Det huset misunner jeg folka   som ____ bor i ___   .
\g that house-DEF envy I folk-DEF.PL  REL live in
\l That house I envy the people that live in.’ (based on Löwenadler 2015: 44, ex. 22)

\t  ?*Det klemte jeg ingen   som ____ gjorde ____   .
\g That hugged I nobody  REL did
\l I hugged nobody who did that.

\t Matte var det bare pappa  (som) jeg kunne be ___ om å hjelpe meg med ___   .
\g math was it only Dad REL I could ask about to help me with
\l Math, it was only Dad that I could ask to help me with.’ ~ ‘Dad was the only one that I could ask to help me with math.

\t Meg/*jeg er det mange   som ___ vil snakke med ___   .
\g me/I is it many  REL want speak.INF with
\l There are many people who want to speak with me.

\t Med meg er det mange   som ____ vil snakke ___   .
\g with me is it many  REL want speak.INF
\l There are many people who want to speak with me.

\t Så sent kjenner jeg ingen   som ____ hadde turt å ringe ___   .
\g so late know I no.one  REL had dared to call.INF
\l I don’t know anyone who would dare to call that late.

\t Det språket er det mange   som ____ snakker ___ /*det  .
\g that language-DEF is it many  REL speak *it
\l That language there are many people who speak (*it).

\t Det er det ingen   som ___ har prøvd å fikse ___ uten å ødelegge ___  .
\g that is it no.one  REL has tried to fix.INF without to destroy.INF
\l That, there is no one who has tried to fix without destroying.

\t … en hvitvin   som det ikke er mange   som ____ kan måle seg med ____    .
\g  a white.wine  REL it not is many  REL can measure self with
\l … a white wine that there weren’t many wines that could compete with.’ ~ ‘… a white wine that not many other wines could compete with.’ (https://no.tripadvisor.com/LocationPhotoDirectLink-g1189136-d2408913-i234544745-Restaurante_Palm_Garden-Patalavaca_Gran_Canaria_Canary_Islands.html)

\t … en løype   som det ikke er mange   som ____ ferdes i ____    .
\g  a trail  REL it not is many  REL fare in
\l … a trail that there aren’t many people that use.’ ~ ‘… a trail that not many people use.’ (https://frisomfuglen.wordpress.com/tag/midtre-kytetjern/)

\t Hvilken bok var det mange/Ronja   som ____ likte ____   ?
\g which book was it many/Ronja  REL  liked
\l Which book were there many/was it Ronja who liked?

\t Plutselig fant han en   som han syntes   han ble fin med ___    
\g suddenly found he one  REL he felt  he became fine with
\l Suddenly he found one that he thought he looked good in.’ (Jonas får briller, #132)

\t … hva tror dere   at jeg fant ___   ?
\g  what believe you.PL  that I found
\l What do you think I found?’ (Pippi er tingleter og havner i slagsmål, #53)

\t … dette forslaget føler jeg   ___ er dumt  
\g  this suggestion-DEF feel I  is dumb
\l That suggestion, I feel is dumb.’ (Gjemmestedet, #893)

\t Det var det (som) jeg ikke skjønte   hva ___ var ___  .
\g it was that REL I NEG understood  what was 
\l That was the thing that I didn’t understand what ___ was.’ ~ ‘That’s the thing that we don’t understand what it was.’ (Ompadorasedet. #1809)

\t … Men det vil jeg ikke si   hva ___ er ___  .
\g  but that want I NEG say.INF  what is
\l But that I won’t say what is.’ ~ ‘But I won’t say what that is.’ (Thea og Jens på pensjonat Forglemmegei, #4024)

\t Han var en sånn unge   som du ikke skjønner  om ___ er lei seg eller _ ler   .
\g he was a such child  REL you NEG understand whether  is sad SELF or laughs
\l ~ ‘He was the kind of child that you don’t know whether [he] is sad or is laughing.’ (Blåveispiken, #3844)

\t Han ene typen vet vi jo ikke engang   hva ___ heter ___  .
\g he one guy know we PRT NEG even  what is.called
\l That one guy, we don’t even know what is called.’ ~ ‘That one guy, we don’t even know the name of.’ (Døden på Oslo S, #1319)

\t Denne vet jeg   hvordan jeg skal bruke ___  .
\g this know I  how I shall use
\l This I know how I will/should use.’ (Sirkusponnien, #602)

\t Jeg har en litt spesiell jobb ,   som jeg lurte på   om du kunne ta ___ på deg   .

\l There is a lady who is in the room.

\l It is Ronja who is in the room.

\g that is it no.one  REL knows

\l Two students kicked a ball diligently.

\t uysatuli pwunmyenghi isipphulo chamkahayssta .
\g doctor-PL-NOM certainly twenty-percent participate-PAST-DECL
\l Certainly, 20% of the doctors participated.’ [conservative] ‘Certainly, 20% of those who participated were doctors.’ [non-conservative]

\t uysatulI {capalcekulo / sengsilhi} isipphulo chamkahayssta .
\g doctor-PL-NOM voluntarily / diligently twenty-percent participate-PAST-DECL
\l 20% of the doctors voluntarily/diligently participated.

\t malathon tayhoyey uysatuli  adverb  isipphulo chamkahayssta .
\g marathon game-DAT doctor-PL-NOM [adverb] 20-% participate-PAST-DECL
\l ([Adverb],) 20% of the doctors participated ([adverb]) in the marathon.

\t  HIGH  … pwunmyenghi …
\g  certainly
\l Certainly, 20% of the doctors participated in the marathon.’ ‘Certainly, 20% of those who participated in the marathon were doctors.

\t  LOW  … sengsilhi …
\g  diligently
\l 20% of the doctors participated in the marathon diligently.’ *‘20% of those who participated diligently in the marathon were doctors.

\t ku kyowsutuli taypwupwun wassta .
\g DEM professor-textscpl-NOM most come-PAST-DECL
\l Most of the professors came.’ [conservative] *‘Most of those who came were the professors.’ [non-conservative]

\t kyowsuka capalcekulo taypwupwun wassta
\g professor-NOM voluntarily most came
\l Most of the professors came voluntarily.’ [conservative] *‘Most of those who came voluntarily were professors.’ [non-conservative]

\t cinan hakhoyey kyoswutuli twinuckey sasipphulo tunglokhayssta .
\g last conference-DAT professor-PL-NOM late 40-% register-PAST-DECL
\l At the last conference, 40% of those who registered late were professors.

\t cinan hakhoyey kyoswutuli twinuckey sasipphuloka tunglokhayssta .
\g last conference-DAT professor-PL-NOM late 40-%-NOM register-PAST-DECL
\l At the last conference, professors, 40% of them, registered late.

\t Haksayng myechmyengi khemphyuthe chaykul sassni ?
\g student how.many-CL-NOM computer book-ACC bought-Q
\l How many students bought the computer book?

\t  ?Haksayngi kukesul twumyeng sasse .
\g Student-NOM it-ACC 2-CL buy-PAST-DECL
\l Two students bought it.

\t Haksayngi khemphyuthelul twumyeng , phulinthelul seymyeng sassta .
\g student-NOM computer-ACC 2-CL printer-ACC 3-CL bought
\l Two student bought computers and three students bought printers.

\t Haksayngtuli maykcwulul seymyeng motwu masiessta .
\g student-PL-NOM beer-ACC 3-CL all drink–PAST-DECL
\l All three students drank beer.

\l Cats eat mice’ (Ferreira 2021: 501)

\g João likes of dog

\g he bought computer
\l He bought computers/a computer.’ (Schmitt & Munn 2002: 187)

\g dog barks (when is angry)
\l Dogs bark (when they are angry).’ (Ferreira 2021: 500)

\l In the year 2030, royal hawks will be extinct.’ (Schmitt & Munn 2002: 187)

\g lost the my ring shouted Didi  and nothing of find ring
\l I have lost my wedding ring!” cried Didi. (…) And it was impossible to find it.’ (Cyrino & Espinal 2015: 480)

\t Tem que colocar 30% de mulheres , certo ? O partido que não coloca , ele vai incorrer em uma ilicitude . Vários candidatos masculinos foram cortados , porque tem que ter    , disse Bivar .
\g must put thirty percent of women right the part that NEG put he will incur in a illegality. many candidates masculine were cut because must have thirty percent of woman, said Bivar
\l There must be 30% of women, right? The political party that does not include it will be doing something illegal. Several male candidates were cut because we must have 30% of women, said Bivar.’ (Twitter)

\t Tipo pelo que falam dele e da empresa eu penso que nos EUA tem uns     já kk
\g like about.the that speak of.him and of.the business I think that in.the USA have some 40 percent of car electric already kk
\l Based on what they say about him [Elon Musk] and his business, I would think that the US already has 40% of electric cars kk’ (Twitter)

\t (…) Depois dá uma lida na biografia dele . Mas até ter     vai levar uns anos aí de muita gente fabricando carro elétrico (…)
\g  afterwards give a read in.the biography of.him but until have 40 percent of car electric will take some years there of many people producing car electric
\l (…) When you can, read his biography. It will take a few years of many people fabricating electric cars [to have 40% of electric cars] (…)’ (Twitter)

\t Li já irritada por ser cliché e a cada capítulo eu falo que vou parar e já se foram   (…) .

\l (…) I was already irritated when reading it because it is cliché, and every chapter I tell myself I am going to stop, and 20% of the book is already gone (…).’ (Twitter)

\t dos 190 milhões de brasileiros 60 milhões têm menos de 18 anos . É

\l (…) Of the 190 millions of Brazilians, 60 millions are less than 18 years old. It is one third of the children/teenager of Latin America/the Caribbean.’ (Twitter)

\t Kaže Pingvin: ‘Mora da mede prave snješka .’ Koja je to slika ?
\g says penguin must.3SG.PRS DA bear.cubs make.IPF.3SG.PRS snowman. which is that picture

\l Penguin said they must make a snowman.’ (3;06)

\l Which picture did Penguin see? … How do you know?

\g hunting-EZ deer

\t xordane keyk
\g eating-EZ cake
\l eating of (the) cake

\t xundane ketaab
\g reading-EZ book
\l reading of (the) book/books

\l this cake eating of Ali

\t in ketaab xundanhaa

\l these acts of book reading

\t Ali sexaavatmandaane komak kard
\g Ali generously help did
\l Ali helped generously.’ (with main prominence on sexaavatmandaane) manner reading ‘It was generous of Ali to help.’ (with main prominence on komak) subject-oriented reading

\t in sexaavatmandaane komak kardane Ali
\g this generously help doing-EZ Ali
\l this helping generously of Ali’/‘this helping of Ali in a generous way’ ‘#this generous act of helping by Ali

\t *in ketaabo xundane Ali
\g this book-RA reading-EZ Ali
\l *this reading the book of Ali

\t *in keyko xordane Ali

\l *this eating the cake of Ali

\l these acts of Ali eating ice-cream

\l these acts of ice-cream eating by Ali

\t *in  bastani xordane Ali  – haa
\g this ice-cream eating-EZ Ali – PL\t in ketaab naxundanhaa
\g this book NEG-reading-PL
\l these acts of not reading books

\t in sariʔ qazaa naxordane Ali
\g this fast food NEG-eating-EZ Ali
\l this habit of Ali not eating food fast’ (Lit. this not fast food eating of Ali)

\t Ali in ketaabo naxarid
\g Ali this book-RA NEG-bought

\t Der Frosch ist ganz nass und macht laut platschende Geräusche , als er voran springt . # Er geht plitschplatsch die Treppe hoch .
\g The frog is completely wet and makes loud splashing noises as he forward jumps  he goes PLITSCH-PLATSCH the stairs high
\l The frog is completely wet and makes loud splashing noises as he jumps along. He goes splish-splash up the stairs.

\t Nein , das stimmt nicht . Der Frosch geht die Treppe runter .
\g No that is right not the frog goes the stairs down
\l No, that’s not true. The frog goes down the stairs.

\t #Nein , das stimmt nicht . Der Frosch geht doch völlig geräuschlos die Treppe hoch .
\g No that is right not the frog goes but completely silently the stairs high
\l No, that’s not true. The frog goes up the stairs in complete silence.

\l Hey, wait a minute! The frog goes up the stairs in complete silence.

\l No, that’s not true. It sounds completely different!

\t Das geht aber holterdiepolter !
\g that goes but HOLTERDIEPOLTER
\l That’s a bit helter-skelter!

\t Nein , das stimmt nicht . Es läuft doch völlig geordnet ab !
\g no that is right not it runs but completely orderly off
\l No, that’s not true. It is completely orderly!

\l The frog goes like splish-splash up the stairs.

\l How does the frog go up the stairs?

\t So plitschplatsch .
\g DEM PLITSCH-PLATSCH
\l Like splish-splash.

\t #Plitschplatsch .
\g PLITSCH-PLATSCH
\l Splish-splash.

\l Thabani will cook the meat.

\t UThabani uzapheka inyama . only subject agreement

\l Thabani will cook meat.

\l The child broke the pot.’ Luguru, (Marten & van der Wal 2014: 330–331)

\t asitaraa “umaaidu midunnu kisisaga”tsi azzi ufupadzɨsai , eigosi . “kamaai iki kamaai iki”tsi mmja azzidjaa .
\g then here=ALL=FOC woman=NOM come.PST=SFP=QUOT say CONJEC=CONJEC=SFP english=INS over.there=ALL go.PST over.there=ALL go.PST=QUOT DM say.PST=RPT
\l Then I guess (the American soldier) had said in English “a woman came here, didn’t she?” The old man said, I hear, “she went over there, she went over there,” (telling him the wrong direction).’ (F₁₉₂₆)

\g  die-PST grenade finish-GER=after DEM=ACC play-GER explode-GER

\t kiinu sɨtaaran kidzjuun jarari sɨnisaga . Mijagunijaanu sɨgu nisɨnu katanu ra . Mijagunijaaja jaamutusai . jaamuturibadu kamangi asubi ufusai .
\g tree=GEN bottom=LOC machine.gun=DAT do-PASS die.PST=SFP name.of.house=GEN right west=GEN side=GEN DM name.of.house=TOP parental.home=SFP parental.home=CSL=FOC there=LOC play CONJEC=SFP
\l He died, shot by a machine gun, under the tree. It was right next to the west side of Miyaguniyaa. Miyaguniyaa is the parental home of his family. I guess he had been playing there because it is his parental home.’ (F₁₉₂₆)

\t nootsinu andzinu ssaffu udaa patarafukatsi jana kɨmutsɨ obaadu ari ufupadzɨ .
\g how=GEN such=GEN terrible.thing=ACC REFL=TOP work=Q=QUOT bad heart old.woman=FOC COP CONJEC=CONJEC
\l The reason why she did such a terrible thing is that, I guess, she was bad-minded.’ (F₁₉₂₆)

\t maradaara naranriba mmi putun maraditsi asɨtaraadu mmja atunna tsintsinnu …
\g poop-NEG.COND become-NEG=CSL more once-ADV poop-VOL=QUOT do-COND=FOC DM after-ADV=TOP penis=ACC
\l Because he had to poop, he tried to poop again. Then, the pig was about to lick his crotch.

\g DEM=TOP pig=also=FOC no.good pig COP CONJEC DM

\t karigadu kisinu tusɨndu ari ufurjaa ? ammu futaatsɨ kaijuu .
\g DEM=NOM=FOC come.PST=GEN year-ADV=FOC COP CONJEC=Q net=ACC two-CLF buy.PST=SFP
\l Was it, I guess, the year when my daughter came back home? I bought two fishing nets.’ (M₁₉₂₆)

\t ketāb roo mize va daftar too kifet
\g book on table-be.3SG and notebook in bag-POSS.2SG
\l The book is on the table and the notebook is in your bag.

\t Araz ketāb kharid , Ayda na
\g Araz book bought.3SG Ayda NEG
\l Araz bought book/books, Ayda did not.

\t Araz ketāb kharid , na Ayda
\g Araz book bought.3SG NEG Ayda
\l Araz bought book/books, not Ayda.

\t modir monshi estekhdām nakard vali moāven cherā
\g manager secretary hire= NEG-did but assistant why
\l a. ‘The manager didn’t hire a secretary but s/he hired an assistant.’ (Object contrast) b. ‘The manager didn’t hire a secretary but the assistant hired a secretary.’ (Subject contrast)

\t modir monshi estekhdāmkard vali moāven na monshi estekhdāmnakard
\g manager secretary hire=did.3SG but assistant NEG secretary hire=NEG-did.3SG
\l Lit: ‘The manager hired a secretary but the assistant not, did not hire a secretary.

\t Ayakaga kukkiio 20mai tsukutta . integrated DHRC
\g Ayaka-NOM cookies-ACC 20-CL make-PAST \t Junyawa    Yokoga hotondono kukkiio reezookoni ireteoita  sono kukkii o zenbu tabeta .
\g Junya-TOP Yoko-NOM most-GEN cookie-ACC fridge-in put-PAST those cookies-ACC all eat-PAST
\l Ayaka made 20 cookies. Yoko put most cookies in the fridge and Junya ate all the cookies [= the 18 cookies in the fridge].

\t Ayakaga kukkiio 20mai tsukutta . appositive DHRC
\g Ayaka-NOM cookies-ACC 20-CL make-PAST \t Junyawa    Yokoga korekara hotondono kukkiio reezookoni ireyooto omotteiru  ano/sono/kono kukkii o zenbu taberu tsumori da .
\g Junya-TOP Yoko-NOM this-after most-GEN cookies-ACC fridge-in put-will-COMP think-PRES those/those/these cookies-ACC all eat-PRES intention COP
\l Ayaka made 20 cookies. Junya intends to eat all those/these cookies [= 20 cookies made by Ayaka], most of which Yoko is thinking of putting in the fridge after this.

\t *Junyawa     korekara hotondono kukkiio reezookoni ireyooto omotteiru  ano/kono4 kukkii o zenbu taberu tsumori na no
\g Junya-TOP who-NOM this-after most-GEN cookies-ACC fridge-in put-will-COMP think-PRES those/these cookies-ACC all eat-PRES intention COP Q
\l Ayaka made 20 cookies. Who is such that (s)he is thinking of putting most of the cookies [= 18 cookies] in the fridge after this and Junya intends to eat all of them [= 20 cookies]?

\t Ayakaga kukkiio 20mai tsukutta .
\g Ayaka-NOM cookies-ACC 20-CL make-PAST\t Junyawa    korekara hotondono kukkiio reezookoni ireyooto omotteiru  ano/kono kukkiio  zenbu taberu tsumori na wakedewa nai .5 
\g Junya-TOP Ayaka-NOM this-after most-GEN cookies-ACC fridge-in put-will-COMP think-PRES those/these cookies-ACC all eat-PRES intention COP reason-COP-TOP NEG-PRES 
\l Ayaka made 20 cookies. Impossible intended construal: It is not true that Ayaka is thinking of putting most of the cookies [= 18 cookies] in the fridge after this and that Junya intends to eat all of them [= 20 cookies]. (It’s Yoko who is thinking of putting most of the cookies in the fridge.)’ ‘Available construal: It is not true that Junya intends to eat all of those/these cookies [= 20 cookies], most of which Ayaka is thinking of putting in the fridge after this.’ (NEG can only target the matrix; association with Ayaka in the RC is excluded)

\t Los maestros/Lxs maestrxs/Les maestres usan recursos variados durante la alfabetización inicial .

\g Plumbers-M /Plumbers-NB/Plumbers-NB with license can do works on buildings and consortiums.\t I gata ine piso apo to kuti .            projective
\g the cat is BACK apo the box
\l The cat is behind the box.

\t I gata ine mesa sto kuti .1               nonprojective
\g the cat is IN se-the box
\l The cat is in the box.

\t a . # The cat is five feet on the box .
\g b. # The cat is straight at the box.\t a . The nail is 1 inch inside the wall .                     (from Zwarts & Winter 2000; their (27))
\g b. *The nail is 1 inch in the wall.                                                                       (mine)\t I gata ine mesa sto kuti .               nonprojective
\g the cat is IN se-the box
\l The cat is in the box.

\t kathome piso                                    adverb
\g sit.I BACK
\l I’m sitting at the back.

\t kano piso                     verb particle
\g do.I BACK
\l I’m moving backwards / I’m withdrawing.

\t to piso kathisma       nominal modifier
\g the BACK seat\t Ta klidia ine sto trapezi .
\g the keys are se-the table
\l The keys are on the table.

\t Ta ruxa ine stin dulapa .
\g the clothes are se-the closet
\l The clothes are in the closet.

\t I Maria ine sto spiti .
\g the Mary is se-the house
\l Mary is at home.

\t I Maria / ta psaria / to spiti ine sti thalasa .
\g the Mary  the fish  the house is/are se-the sea
\l Mary/the fish/the house is/are at/in/by the sea.

\t mesa stin dulapa
\g IN se-the closet
\l in the closet

\t piso apo ton kanape
\g BACK apo the couch
\l behind the couch

\t I Maria ine brosta stin tileorasi .              ‘in front of’
\g the Mary is FRONT se-the TV\t I Maria ine brosta apo tin tileorasi .         ‘in front of’
\g the Mary is FRONT apo the TV
\l Mary is in front of the TV.

\t I laba ine pano sto trapezi .                 ‘on’
\g the lamp is UP se-the table
\l The lamp is on the table.

\t I laba ine pano apo to trapezi .              ‘above/over’
\g the lamp is UP apo the table
\l The lamp is above the table.

\t I gata ine ( pano  ) sto trapezi .
\g the cat is  UP se-the table
\l The cat is on the table.

\t I gata ine #(kato  ) apo to trapezi .
\g the cat is DOWN apo the table
\l The cat is under the table.’ / # ‘The cat is from the table.

\t a . The tree is behind the house .
\g b. The doghouse is behind the house.\t a .  ?The workers are waiting straight/diagonally outside the building .
\g b. *The workers are waiting straight/diagonally out of the building.\t O Yanis kathete 2 m brosta / dipla apo tin tileorasi .
\g the Yanis sits 2 m FRONT  SIDE apo the TV
\l IM: ‘Yanis is sitting 2 meters in front of / beside the TV.

\t To dentro ine 10m ekso / piso apo to spiti .
\g the tree is 10m OUT  BACK apo the house
\l The tree is 10m outside / behind the house.

\t To aeroplano petuse 1000 podia pano apo to stadio .
\g the plane flew 1000 ft UP apo the stadium
\l The plane was flying at 1000 ft above the stadium.

\t O thisavros ine krimenos 50m kato apo tin eklisia .
\g the treasure is hidden 50m DOWN apo the church
\l The treasure is hidden 50m under the church.

\t I Maria kathete 2m aristera / deksia apo ti Georgia .
\g the Mary sits 2m LEFT  RIGHT apo the Georgia
\l Mary is sitting 2m to the left/right of Georgia.

\t Ta Meteora vriskonte 200km voria/notia/anatolika/dytika apo to Miami .
\g the Meteora lie 200km NORTH/SOUTH/EAST/WEST apo the Miami
\l Meteora lies 200 km north/south/east/west of Miami.

\t %  To xrimatokivotio ine (2m) mesa apo afton ton tixo .
\g the safe is 2m IN apo this the wall
\l The safe is on the other (inner) side of this wall at a 2m distance.

\t O Yanis kathete isia/diagonia brosta/dipla apo tin tileorasi .
\g the Yanis sits straight/diagonally FRONT/SIDE apo the TV
\l Yanis is sitting straight/diagonally in front of / beside the TV.

\t To dentro ine isia/diagonia ekso / piso apo to spiti .
\g the tree is straight/diagonally OUT / BACK apo the house
\l The tree is straight/diagonally outside / behind the house.

\t To aeroplano petuse isia/diagonia pano apo to stadio .
\g the plane flew straight/diagonally UP apo the stadium
\l The plane was flying straight/diagonally above the stadium.

\t O thisavros ine krimenos isia/diagonia kato apo tin eklisia .
\g the treasure is hidden straight/diagonally DOWN apo the church
\l The treasure is hidden straight/diagonally under the church.

\t I Maria kathete isia/diagonia aristera /deksia apo ti Georgia
\g the Mary sits straight/diagonally LEFT /RIGHT apo the Georgia
\l Mary is sitting straight/diagonally to the left/right of Georgia.

\t To xrimatokivotio ine isia/diagonia mesa apo afton ton tixo .
\g the safe is straight/diagonally IN apo this the wall
\l The safe is straight/diagonally behind this wall.

\t To farmakio ine (* isia/diagonia ) konta / makria apo tin eklisia .
\g the pharmacy is straight/diagonally close far apo the church\t %  Eksaxronos vrethike (*250m) konta apo to nipiagogio tu .
\g 6-year-old was_found 250m away apo the kindergarten his.cl\t Eksaxronos vrethike 250m makria apo to nipiagogio tu .
\g 6-year-old was_found 250m away apo the kindergarten his.cl
\l A 6-year-old was found 250m away/*far from his kindergarten.

\t I Chios ine konta stin /  apo tin   Turkia .

\l The island of Chios is [close to] / [not far from] Turkey.

\l Turkey is #[close to] / [not far from] Chios.

\t To plithos ine gyro apo to dikastirio .
\g the crowd is ROUND apo the courthouse
\l The crowd is gathered around the courthouse.

\t To rixtari ine pano apo ton kanape .
\g the drape is UP apo the couch
\l R1 (route/“extended”): ‘The drape is over the couch.’ #R2 (projective): ‘The drape is above the couch.

\l The pencils are (* 5 cm) on the table.

\g the Mary leaned 10 cm against se-the wall
\l Mary was leaning (*10cm) against the wall.

\t Pano se ti to evales ?
\g UP se what it.cl put.2sg

\t Se ti to evales pano ?
\g se what it.cl put.2sg UP\t Kato apo ti to evales ?
\g DOWN apo what it.cl put.2sg
\l What did you put it under?

\t * Apo ti to evales kato ?
\g apo what it.cl put.2sg DOWN\t Gia pion ine to doro ?
\g for whom is the present
\l For whom is the present?

\t * Pion ine to doro gia ?
\g whom is the present for
\l Who is the present for?

\t San pion milai o Yanis ?
\g like whom talks the Yanis
\l Like whom does Yanis talk?

\t * Pion milai o Yanis san ?
\g whom talks the Yanis like
\l Who does he talk like?

\t anti gia ti Maria

\l instead of Mary

\t *  gia ti Maria anti
\g for the Mary instead
\l instead of Mary

\t Pige o Yanis anti gia ti Maria .
\g went.3sg the Yanis instead for the Mary
\l Yanis went in Mary’s place (on Mary’s behalf).

\t * (Anti) gia pion pige o Yanis (*anti) ?
\g instead for who went.3sg the Yanis 
\l Yanis went in Mary’s place (on Mary’s behalf).

\t I motosikleta ine apo to aftokinito (ligo) pio piso .
\g the motorcycle is apo the car little more BACK\t  ? Apo ti to evales (ligo) pio kato ?
\g apo what it.cl put.2sg little more DOWN\t I gata ine (# (ligo) pio ) kato apo to krevati .
\g the cat is little more  DOWN apo the bed
\l Modified: ‘The cat is further down/below than the bed.’ Unmodified: ‘The cat is under the bed.

\t Oi pinakes ine (# (ligo) pio ) piso apo to piano .
\g the paintings are little more  BACK apo the piano
\l Modified: ‘The paintings are further back/behind than the piano.’ Unmodified: ‘The paintings are behind the piano.

\t I motosikleta ine apo to aftokinito (ligo) pio kato .
\g the motorcycle is apo the car little more DOWN
\l The motorcycle is a bit further down (the road) than the car.’ ⊭‘The motorcycle is under the car.

\t Apo pion ine pio psili i Maria ?

\l Who is Mary taller than?

\t I gata kathete pano sto trapezi .

\l The cat is sitting on the table.

\l (Over) there is a table and the cat is sitting on top.

\l # ‘(Over) there is a tree and Michael is sitting in the back.

\g there is a tree and the Michael sits apo-BACK
\l (Over) there is a tree and Michael is standing/sitting behind it.

\t I Maria ine ston kipo .            locative
\g the Mary is se-the garden
\l Mary is in the garden.

\t I Maria pige ston kipo .          goal
\g the Mary went se-the garden
\l Mary went to the garden.

\t I Maria xorepse sto saloni .              locative only
\g the Mary danced se-the living-room
\l Mary danced in the living-room.

\t I Maria efige apo ton kipo .               source
\g the Mary left apo the garden
\l Mary left (from) the garden.

\t I Maria perase apo to spiti .         route
\g the Mary passed apo the house
\l Mary went/stopped by the house.

\t I Maria efige sti Germania .            goal
\g the Mary left se-the Germany
\l Mary went away to Germany.

\t I Maria perase sto saloni .                goal
\g the Mary passed se-the living-room
\l Mary moved on into the living room.

\t * I gata vgike / perase apo mesa sto kuti .
\g the cat got_out / passed apo IN se-the box
\l The cat [got out of] / [went through] the box.

\l on the couch

\t i gata (ine) pano ston kanape
\g the cat (is) UP se-the couch
\l The cat is on the couch.

\t (I gata anevike) pano ston kanape .
\g the cat got_on UP se-the couch
\l The cat jumped onto the couch.

\t (I gata efige) (apo) pano apo ton kanape .
\g the cat left apo UP apo the couch
\l The cat got off the couch.

\t i gata (ine) piso apo ton kanape
\g the cat is BACK apo the couch
\l The cat (is) behind the couch.

\t (i gata pige) piso apo ton kanape
\g the cat went BACK apo the couch
\l The cat went behind the couch.

\t (i gata efige) apo piso apo ton kanape
\g the cat left apo BACK apo the couch
\l The cat left from behind the couch.

\t a . some < half < every (positive)
\g b. not every < less than half < no (negative)\t a . Almost everybody showed up . In fact , everybody did .
\g b. Not quite everybody showed up. *In fact, everybody did.\t a . ⟦some⟧  λQ .λP .Ǝx Q(x) ∧ P(x) 
\g b. ⟦SOME⟧ = λQ.λP.ƎX[Q(X) ∧ X(P)]\t a . I saw nowhere near every student .
\g b. I didn’t see anywhere near every student.\t a . Nowhere near everybody will be at the party .
\g b. *Somewhere near everybody will be at the party.\t a . I parked nowhere near here .
\g b. I parked somewhere near here.\t a . John is nowhere near as smart as Bill .
\g b. *John is somewhere near as smart as Bill.\t a . He is nowhere near a  .300 hitter .
\g b. *He is somewhere near a .300 hitter.\t a . *Somewhere near everybody was at the party .
\g b. *Somewhere around everybody was the party.\t a . Somewhere around half of the people showed up .
\g b. ƎX[around(X, ⟦half of the people⟧) ∧ X(⟦showed up⟧)]\t A: Nobody at all showed up at my party .
\g B: Nowhere NEAR nobody showed up, the party was packed.\t a . Everybody who has ever been to France smokes .
\g b. Almost everybody who has ever been to France smokes.\t a . Almost everybody who owns a car is happy .
\g b. Almost everybody who owns a Jaguar is happy.\t a . We’ll change your oil in Madera .
\g b. #We’re going to change your oil in Madera.                                   (Copley 2009: 77)\t Gyukwsxwhl smax .

\t Wilaayis Maryhl wat / simhe .
\g know-TR.PN Mary=CN name-3.II / truth
\l Mary knows his name/the truth.

\t *Yukwt wilaaxs Maryhl wat /simhe .
\g =3SG.II know=PN Mary=CN name-3.II /truth
\l Consultants’ comments: “It’s like saying, ‘She’s knowing the truth.” “Yukw and wilaax don’t match.” (Schwan 2019: 14)

\t Dim wis .
\g  rain
\l It will rain.

\t Yukw dim wis .
\g   rain
\l It is going to rain.

\t Dim dibagwi'yhl eejam t'ilix .
\g  COM-arrive.PL-TR-1SG.II=CN fry-ATTR grease
\l I’ll bring fry bread.

\t Dim dikw'itxwi'y eeja'am anaax .
\g  COM-arrive-TR.1SG.II fry-ATTR bread
\l I’ll bring fry bread.

\t #Yukw dimin dibakwhl eejam t'ilix .
\g  =1SG.I COM-arrive.PL=CN fry-ATTR grease
\l I’m going to bring fry bread.’ Consultant’s comment: “No, it’s not offering to be the one to bring the fried bread, it’s just saying that you’re going to bring the fried bread.

\t #Yukw dimin dikw'itxw eeja'am anaax .
\g  =1SG.I COM-arrive fry-ATTR bread
\l I’m going to bring fry bread.’ Consultant’s comment: “When you say yukw dim, it doesn’t sound good in the context … when people use yukw dim, you are literally going to.

\t Dim ts‘ilim 'nii'y ehl eejam anaax , ji asagan .
\g  bring 1SG.III PREP=CN fry-ATTR bread IRR want-2SG.II
\l I’ll bring fry bread, if you want.

\t #Yukw dim ts'ilimi'y ehl eejam anaax , ji asagan .
\g   bring-1SG.II PREP=CN fry-ATTR bread IRR want-2SG.II
\l I’m going to bring fry bread, if you want.

\t Dim ḵ'oji'yhl g̱esin ahl xwsdins .
\g  cut-TR-1SG.II=CN hair-2SG.II PREP=CN five
\l I’ll cut your hair for five dollars.

\t Xwsdinshl gwiikw dim win dip ḵ'otshl gesin .12
\g five=CN groundhog  COMP 1PL.I cut=CN hair-2SG.II
\l For five dollars we’ll cut your hair.

\t #Yukwni dim ḵ'otshl g̱esin ahl xwsdins .
\g =1SG.I  cut-1SG.II hair-2SG.II PREP.CN five
\l I’m going to cut your hair for five dollars.

\t #Xwsdinshl gwiikw yukw dim win dip ḵ'otshl gesin .
\g five=CN groundhog   COMP 1PL.I cut=CN hair-2SG.II
\l For five dollars we’re gonna cut your hair.

\t Ham ji dashl aats'ip , dim x̱hluxwhl bomb !
\g don’t.2SG IRR touch=CN door  explode=CN bomb
\l Don’t touch the door, the bomb will explode!

\t Ham ji deshl aats'ip , dim hluxwt !
\g don’t.2SG IRR touch=CN door  explode-3.II
\l Don’t touch the door, it will explode!

\t #Ham ji dashl aats'ip , yukw dim xhluxwhl bomb !
\g don’t.2SG IRR touch=CN door   explode=CN bomb
\l Don’t touch the door, the bomb is gonna explode!’ Consultant’s comment: “When you say Yukw dim xhluxwhl bomb, there is a certainty at some point the bomb will explode whether you touch the door or not.

\t Ham ji deshl aats'ip , yukw dim hluxwt .
\g don’t.2SG IRR touch=CN door   explode=3.II
\l Don’t touch the door, it’s gonna explode!’ Consultant’s comment: “Yukw dim means it’s going to. It’s something like a plan that you’re gonna go through. [(35)a’] is better.

\t #Ham ji dulbint … dim x̲hluxwhl bomb !
\g don’t.2SG IRR be.near-3SG.II  explode=CN bomb
\l Don’t go near it, the bomb will explode!’ Consultant’s comment: “When you say Dim x̲hluxwhl bomb, it’s if you touch the door.

\t #Ha'w ji hagwin yin loot , dim xhluxwdis !
\g don’t IRR toward go-2SG.II OBL-3.II  explode-3.II=QUDD
\l Don’t go near it, it will explode!

\t Ham ji dulbint … yukw dim x̲hluxwhl bomb !
\g don’t.2SG IRR near-3SG   explode=CN bomb
\l Don’t go near it, the bomb is going to explode!

\t Ha'w ji hagwin yin loot , yukw dim xhluxwdis !
\g don’t IRR toward go-2SG.II OBL-3.II   explode-3.II=QUDD
\l Don’t go near it, it’s going to explode!

\t #'Wihlii dim wis .
\g INDIRECT  rain
\l It will rain!

\t 'Wihlii yugwii dim wis .
\g INDIRECT =like  rain
\l It’s going to rain!

\t Oo nee , yukwhl dim saa gost !
\g oh NEG =CN  away jump-3.II
\l Oh no, he’s going to jump!’ CHOSEN

\t Oo nee , dim saa gos 'nit !
\g oh NEG  away jump 3.III
\l Oh no, he’ll jump!’ NOT CHOSEN

\t Dim wis !
\g  rain
\l It’ll rain.’ NOT CHOSEN

\t Yukw dim wis !
\g   rain
\l It’s gonna rain!’ CHOSEN

\t Yukwhl dim neksi'y !
\g =CN  marry-1SG.II
\l I’m going to get married!

\t #Dim neksi'y !
\g  marry-1SG.II
\l I will get married!’ Consultant’s comment: “She could be so excited she forgot some words [i.e., she forgot yukw].

\t Bax̱t Yoko .
\g run=PN Yoko
\l Yoko ran’ / ‘Yoko is running.’ (Jóhannsdóttir and Matthewson 2007)

\t Gilbilhl ganuutxwhl hlidaat mahlis Diana dim wil yeet goohl Winnipeg ji hlaa (am) k'i'yhl ganuutxw .
\g two=CN week=CN PRT=SPT=3.I tell-T=PN Diana  COMP go-3.II LOC=CN Winnipeg IRR PROX (only) one=CN week
\l Diana said two weeks ago that she would go to Winnipeg after one week.’ (Rullmann and Matthewson 2018: 292; adapted from Jóhannsdóttir & Matthewson 2007)

\t Mahldis Aidan loo'y yukw dim iijam anaaxt .
\g tell-T-TR=PN Aidan OBL-1SG.II   fry-ATTR bread-3.II
\l Aidan told me that he was going to cook fried bread.

\t Da'ahlxwis Henry #(dim) jamt .
\g -TR=PN Henry #() cook-3.II
\l Henry is able to cook.’ / ‘Henry was able to cook.’ (Matthewson 2013: 371)

\t Sgi #(dim) (ap) ha'ws Lisa .
\g  #() (VERUM) go.home-PN Lisa
\l ʻLisa should/must go home.ʼ / ‘Lisa should have gone home.’ (Matthewson 2013: 380)

\t Yugwimaa/ima'hl dim wis .
\g IPFV==CN  rain
\l ≠‘It might have rained.’ / ≠‘It might be raining.’ / ‘It might rain (in the future).’ #Context: You see puddles, and the flowers looking fresh and damp. #Context: You hear pattering on the roof. √Context: You hear thunder, so you think it might rain soon. (Matthewson 2013: 365)

\t Yugwimaa/ima’hl wis .
\g IPFV==CN rain
\l It might have rained.’ / ‘It might be raining.’ / ≠‘It might rain (in the future).’ √Context: You see puddles, and the flowers looking fresh and damp. √Context: You hear pattering on the roof. #Context: You hear thunder, so you think it might rain soon. (Matthewson 2013: 364–365)

\t Yukwhl wis .
\g =CN rain
\l It is raining.

\g  (HYP)  tell-T.PN Hector=CN MANR LVB-3.II TIME LVB.CN arrive=PN Michael
\l Hector was going to tell a story when Michael showed up.

\t Dim ḵ'otsdi'yhl g̱esin .
\g  cut-T-TR-1SG.II=CN hair-2SG.II
\l I’ll cut your hair.’ Consultant’s comment: “It’ll either be right now, or in the future.

\t Hlaa dimin ḵ'otshl g̱esin .
\g  =1SG.I cut=CN hair-2SG.II
\l I’m about to cut your hair.’ Consultant’s comment: “Means five minutes, ten minutes, I’m gonna cut your hair.

\g   run-3.II

\l Marko bought books and movies.’ (Bošković 2009: (30))

\g sabers.FPL AUX.PL REFL yesterday collided. t and spears.NPL in battle
\l Sabers and spears collided in battle.’ (examples modified from Arsenijević et al. 2020b)

\t Danas se sudaraju sablje i koplja u bici .
\g today REFL collide.3PL.PRES sabers.FPL and spears.NPL in battle
\l Sabers and spears are colliding in battle today.’ (baseline w/o CSCV) mean of 30 = 4.6

\t Sablje₁ se danas t₁ i koplja sudaraju u bici .
\g sabers.FPL₁ REFL today  and spears.NPL collide.3PL.PRES in battle
\l Sabers and spears are colliding in battle today.’ (CSCV scrambling) mean of 30 = 2.6

\t Šta₁ se danas t₁ i koplja sudaraju u bici ?
\g what₁ REFL today  and spears.NPL collide.3PL.PRES in battle?
\l What and spears are colliding today in battle?’ (CSCV wh-movement) mean of 30 = 1.37

\t Sablje su se juče sudarila   i koplja  u bici .
\g sabers.FPL AUX.PL REFL yesterday collided.  and spears. in battle
\l C2 agreement: mean of 30 = 1.3 ‘Sabers and spears collided in battle yesterday.

\t Sablje₁ …   t₁ i koplja  
\g sabers₁ … [ t₁ and spears ]\t  Sablje su se juče sudarile  i  koplja su se juče sudarila u bici 
\g sabers. AUX.PL REFL yesterday collided. and spears. AUX.PL REFL yesterday collided. in battle\t Sablje su se juče sudarile t₁ i koplja u bici .
\g Sabers. AUX REFL yesterday collided. t₁ and spears.NPL in battle
\l Sabers and spears collided in battle yesterday.’ Collective reading: Da.: 19, Ne.: 11

\t Sablje su danas stavljene t₁ i koplja u 3 kutije …
\g Sabers. AUX today put.PASSIVE. t₁ and spears.NPL in three boxes
\l Sabers and spears were put in three boxes today …’ Cumulative reading: Da.: 20, Ne.: 10

\t Sablje su danas stavljene t₁ i koplja u različite kutije .
\g Sabers. AUX today put.PASSIVE. t₁ and spears in different boxes
\l Sabers and spears were put in different boxes.’ Internal reading: Da.: 19, Ne.: 11

\t Juče su se sablje sudarile t i koplja u bici .
\g yesterday AUX REFL sabers. collided. t and spears.NPL in battle
\l C1 agreement: mean = 2.8

\g yesterday AUX REFL sabers.FPL collided. t and spears.npl in battle
\l Masculine agreement: mean = 1.2

\g yesterday AUX REFL sabers.FPL collided. t and spears. in battle
\l C2 agreement: mean = 1.4 ‘Sabers and spears were collided in battle yesterday.

\l C1 agreement: mean = 2.1

\g sabers.FPL AUX REFL yesterday t and spears.NPL collided. in battle
\l M agreement: mean = 3

\t Sablje su se juče t i koplja sudarila u bici .
\g sabers.FPL AUX REFL yesterday t and spears. collided. in battle
\l C2 agreement: mean = 2.7 ‘Sabers and spears were collided in battle yesterday.

\t Juče su se sudarila koplja , sekire i sablje .
\g yesterday AUX REFL collided. spears., axes.FPL, and sabers.FPL
\l C1 agreement: mean = 4.7

\t Juče su se sudarili koplja , sekire i sablje .
\g yesterday AUX REFL collided. spears.NPL, axes.FPL, and sabers.FPL
\l M agreement: mean = 4.3

\g yesterday AUX REFL collided. spears.NPL, axes., and sabers.FPL
\l C2 agreement: mean = 2.7 ‘Spears, axes, and sabers collided yesterday.

\g yesterday AUX REFL spears. collided. t axes.FPL, and sabers.FPL in battle
\l C1 agreement: mean = 2.3

\l M agreement: mean = 1.3

\g manager will and his secretary come.late
\l The manager and his secretary will be late.’ (Gračanin-Yuksek & Arsenijević 2017: (1))

\t Haljine₁ su juče prodate t₁ odela i suknje . (3 .6/7)
\g dresses. AUX yesterday sold.  suits.NPL and skirts.FPL \t *Haljine su juče prodati t₁ odela i suknje . (1/7)
\g dresses.FPL AUX yesterday sold.  suits.NPL and skirts.FPL \t *Haljine su juče prodata t₁ odela i suknje . (1 .2/7)
\g dresses.FPL AUX yesterday sold.  suits. and skirts.FPL 
\l Dresses and suits and skirts were sold yesterday.

\t Voavohan’ilay vavy ilay varavarana .
\g PV-open-N-DEM girl DEM door
\l That door was opened by that girl.’ Verb + EA

\g house-N-DEM person
\l that person’s house’ Possessee + Possessor

\t amin’ilay seza
\g PREP-N-DEM chair
\l on that chair’ Preposition + Complement

\g PV.cut DET person DET cord
\l The cord is cut by the person.’ Verb + EA

\t tongotry ny zaza
\g foot DET child
\l the child’s feet’ Possessee + Possessor

\l Rabe is eating the banana.’ Verbal predicate

\l Bakoly is a doctor.’ Nominal predicate

\l She was at the market.’ Prepositional predicate

\l Rasoa has two children.’ (lit. ‘Rasoa’s children are two.’) Weak quant. predicate

\t Feno rano ny tavoahangy .
\g full water DET bottle
\l The bottle is full of water.’ Adjectival predicate

\g AV-PFX-cut DET fish with-DET knife DET girl
\l The girl cuts the fish with the knife.

\t Bu çukura düşülür .
\g This hole-DAT fall-PASS-AOR
\l One may fall to this hole.’ Lit(eral): ‘It is fallen to this hole.’ (unaccusative)

\t Dün maratonda koşuldu .
\g yesterday marathon-LOC run-PASS-PST
\l There was running in the marathon yesterday.’ Lit: ‘It was run in the marathon yesterday.’ (unergative)

\t Harpte vurulunur .
\g war-LOC shoot-PASS-PASS-AOR
\l One is shot (by one) in war.’ (Özkaragöz 1986: 76)

\t Bu kitap dün okundu .
\g This book yesterday read-PASS-PST
\l This book was read yesterday.’ (canonical passive)

\t Dün konserde bağırıldı .
\g yesterday concert-LOC shout-PASS-PST
\l Someone/People shouted in the concert yesterday.’ Lit: ‘It was shouted in the concert yesterday.’ (passive of unergative)

\g Oh, short before hole-DAT fall-PASS-PST
\l Int(ended): ‘Oh, people/someone fell to this hole a short time ago.’ Lit: ‘It was fallen to this hole a short time ago.’ (passive of unaccusative)

\g first world war-POSS-LOC shoot-PASS-PASS-PST
\l Int: ‘One/Someone was shot (by someone) in WWI.’ (double passive)

\g that.one dog-ABS bite-AP-NPAST-INDICATIVE
\l That dog bites (me/us …).’ (Fleck 2006: 559)

\l One is chased (by someone) in this game.’ Lit: ‘It is chased in this game.

\l (I thank you) for taking trouble to come (to see me) when you are so busy.

\t cikapul kkamppakhayss(*sup)unikka amwukesto saci moshaysssupnita/eyo .
\g wallet-ACC forget-PAST-(*UH)-because anything buy-COMP cannot-be-PAST-UH
\l Because I forgot my wallet, I could not buy anything.

\t cikapul kkamppakhayss(*sup)ese amwukesto saci moshaysssupnita/eyo .
\g wallet-ACC forget-PAST-(*UH)-because anything buy-COMP cannot-be-PAST-UH
\l Because I forgot my wallet, I could not buy anything.

\t cikapul kkamppakhayss(*sup)ciman hayntuphonulo sasssupnita/eyo .
\g wallet-ACC forget-PAST-(*UH)-but phone-Instrumental buy-PAST-UH
\l I forgot my wallet, but I bought things using my phone.

\t Kore , oishiidesu yo / ne / naa
\g This tasty-be.UH DPART / DPART / DPART
\l This is tasty, (I tell you) / (isn’t it?) / (I’m impressed).

\t *Raishuuwa isogashiidesuyokara , saraishuuni shitekudasai
\g Next.week-TOP busy-be.UH-DPART-because the.week.after.next-DAT make-please
\l Because I will be busy next week, please make it to the following week.

\t *Raishuuwa isogashiidesuyoga/kedo , kanarazu aini ikimasu .
\g Next.week-TOP busy-be.UH-DPART-but/but, certainly see-DAT go-UH
\l Although I will be busy next week, I will definitely come see you.

\t  Kaigino junbiga fujuubundeshita  kotoo fukaku owabimoushiagemasu .
\g Meeting-GEN preparation-NOM inadequate-be.UH-PAST fact-ACC deeply apology-say-UH
\l We sincerely apologize for the fact that our preparation for the meeting was inadequate.

\t  ?Sono atsumariniwa ,  Tanakasenseio gozonjideshita  kataga takusan irasshaimashita .
\g that gathering-at-TOP [Tanaka-teacher-ACC know-UH-PAST] person-NOM many be.present-UH-PAST
\l At the gathering, there were many people who knew Professor Tanaka.

\t  Senjitsu senseiga gobyoukideshita  saini omimaini ukagaimashita .
\g the.other.day teacher-NOM sick-be.UH-PAST occasion-at visit-DAT go-UH-PAST
\l When the professor fell sick the other day, I visited her.

\t kono ryokanwa teienga yuumeida / *na

\l Lit. Speaking of this inn, its garden is famous.

\t  teienga yuumeina  ryokanni ikitai
\g teien-NOM famous-be inn-LOC go-want
\l (I) want to go to an inn which is famous for its garden.

\t Senjitsu Ginzani ikimashite , sokode guuzen Suzukisanni oaishimashita .
\g the.other.day Ginza-LOC go-UH-GERUND, there by.chance Suzuki-Mr.-DAT HON-meet-do-UH-PAST
\l The other day, I went to Ginza and ran into Mr. Suzuki there.

\t Hayaku gokaifukunasaru / nasaimasu kotoo oinorishiteorimasu .
\g Quickly HON-recover–do.HON / do.HON-UH fact-ACC HON-pray-do-be.humble-UH
\l I pray for your speedy recovery.

\t Hayaku gokaifukunasaimasu kotoo inotteimasu .
\g Quickly HON-recover-do.HON-UH fact-ACC pray-GERUND-be-UH
\l I pray for your speedy recovery.

\t Senseiga okakini natta / narimashita gohonga shuppanno hakobini natta / narimashitakotono kinenni , oiwaino kaio hirakitaku zonjimasu .
\g Teacher-NOM Honor-write-DAT become-PAST / become-UH-PAST Honor-book-NOM publish-GEN plan-DAT become-PAST / become-UH-PAST-fact-GEN commemoration-DAT, celebration-GEN party-ACC hold-want think-UH
\l For the commemoration of the occasion that the book that the professor wrote will now be published, we would like to host a celebration.

\t  Hayaku gokaifuku nasaru / *nasaimasu  to shinjiteorimasu .
\g quickly HON-recovery do.HON / do.HON-UH COMP believe-do-be-UH
\l I pray for your quick recovery.

\t  kaigiwa raishuunosuiyoubida / *desu  to , zonjiteorimasu .
\g meeting-TOP next.week-GEN-Wednesday-be / be.UH C know-be-UH

\t  senshuuwa oisogashikattaØ / *desu  to , ukagatteorimasu .
\g last.week-TOP HON-busy-PAST-Ø / -UH C hear-be-UH
\l I heard that you were busy last week.

\t Watakushiwa  senseiga okakini narimashita gohono zehi yomasete itadakitai(*desu)to  omotteorimasu .

\l I will inform you as soon as possible where (I) will go tomorrow.

\t *Watashiwa  Kenga nansaidesuka  tazunemashita

\l I asked how old Ken is.

\t  ? Watakushidomoni okotaedekimasukadooka  wakarimasenga…

\l (Though) we are not sure whether we can answer your question.

\t Nneɣokwiru na omutemi unɔ akuutʃa .

\t *Cúz’lhkan melyís kucúz’a kúkwpi7 láku7 Fountain .
\g PROSP=1SG.SBJ marry-CAUS =PROSP= chief DEIC Fountain
\l I will marry the next chief of Fountain.’ (whoever it is).

\t Omuɣáruka aŋgaβɔnɛkire Maria naŋgatʃɔɔmiru .
\g =C1-elder SA3-COND-show.up-PFV Maria FOC=PST-COND-be.happy-FV
\l If an/the elder showed up Mary would be happy.’ (adapted from Gambarage 2019:202–203) Accepted in context: A mother has a sick child and only elderly people know the traditional cure for the disease. There is a specific elder who knows the medicine for the disease. The mother says she will be happy if that elder showed up. Rejected in context: A mother has a sick child and only elderly people know the traditional cure for the disease. She would be happy if any elder comes, but that’s impossible, because there are no elders in this community.

\t Ømuɣáruka aŋgaβɔnɛkire Maria naŋgatʃɔɔmiru .
\g =C1-elder SA1--show.up-PFV Maria FOC=SA1-COND-be.happy-FV
\l If any elder showed up Mary would be happy.’ (adapted from Gambarage 2019:166–167) Rejected in context: A mother has a sick child and only elderly people know the traditional cure for the disease. There is a specific elder who knows the medicine for the disease. The mother says she will be happy if that elder showed up. Accepted in context: A mother has a sick child and only elderly people know the traditional cure for the disease. She would be happy if any elder comes, but that’s impossible, because there are no elders in this community.

\t Wa7 tsu7c tamáq7a .

\l The snow is melting (I saw it).

\l The snow has melted.

\l Alfonso stole the emeralds and I regret that Mugsy stole the pearls.

\l Alfonso stole the emeralds and I think that Mugsy stole the pearls.

\t Indianin karmi pelikana .
\g Native American.NOM feeds pelican.ACC\t Pelikana karmi Indianin .
\g O V S\t Indianin pelikana karmi .
\g S O V\t Pelikana Indianin karmi .
\g O S V\t Karmi Indianin pelikana .
\g V S O\t Karmi pelikana Indianin .
\g V O S\t Indianin karmi psa i Indianin karmi pelikana .
\g Native American.NOM feeds dog.ACC and Native American.NOM feeds pelican.ACC
\l A Native American is feeding a dog and {a|the} native American is feeding a pelican.13

\t Rybak karmi pelikana i pelikana karmi Indianin .
\g fisherman.NOM feeds pelican.ACC and pelican.ACC feeds Native American.NOM
\l A fisherman is feeding a pelican and a Native American is also feeding {a|the} pelican.

\t Piotr (szybko) dał jakiemuś chłopcu każdą naszą monetę .

\t Spać , to Janek spał , ale nie odpoczął .
\g sleep.INF TO John slept but not rested
\l Though John did sleep, he didn’t rest.

\l Though John did read books, he hasn’t written any.

\l Though John did read books, he hasn’t written any.

\t Dawać ryby rekinom , to rybak dawał , ale sam nic nie zjadł .
\g give.INF fish.ACC sharks.DAT TO fisherman.NOM gave but himself nothing not ate
\l Though the fisherman gave fish to the sharks, he himself didn’t eat.

\t Dawać , to rybak dawał ryby rekinom , ale sam nic nie zjadł .
\g give.INF TO fisherman.NOM gave fish.ACC sharks.DAT but himself nothing not ate\t Dawać rekinom ryby , to rybak dawał , ale sam nic nie zjadł .

\l I know the fact that Alex is a scholar.

\t  Alexga gakusya {de aru/da} to sitteiru .
\g Alex-NOM scholar PRED COP-PRS/PRED.COP.PRS-COMP know-PRS
\l I know that Alex is a scholar.

\t  Alexga gakusya {de aru/da} ka o sitteiru .
\g Alex-NOM scholar PRED COP-PRS/PRED.COP.PRS Q-ACC know-PRS
\l I know whether Alex is a scholar.

\t Berniega Alexo home{masi/*desi}ta .
\g Bernie-NOM Alex-ACC praise-AH-PST
\l Bernie praised Alex.

\t Alexga homerare{masi/*desi}ta .
\g Alex-NOM praise-PASS-AH-PST
\l Alex was praised.

\t Alexga siawase na {hazu/yoo} {desi/*masi}ta .
\g Alex-NOM happy COP.ADN should/seem PRED.COP.AH/AH-PST
\l Alex {should/seems to be} be happy.

\t  Watasiwa desune   totemo desune  tukareta desuyo .
\g Alex-TOP AH-PFP very AH-PFP get tired-PST AH-SFP
\l I got so tired.

\l Alex was not a scholar.

\t … (⤳ it is unimportant who told Mel about the party
\g  ≈ ‘who cares’, ‘it doesn’t matter’, …)\t Can you pass the salt ? Direct speech: question
\g  Indirect speech act: request\t … (⤳ {p , ¬p} is unimportant
\g  ≈ ‘Who cares about him?’, ‘Who cares about parties?’, etc.)\t  (web blog; stored in COCA and retrieved on Dec . 7 , 2021 from https://www .escapeartistes .com/2012/07/11/justatummybug/)
\g  \t Mi hanno detto che hai invitato Marina .
\g to-me have.3PL told that have.2SG invited Marina
\l I have been told that you have invited Marina.

\t Non l’ho mica invitata !
\g NEG her-have.1SG mica invited.F.SG
\l I have not invited her at all!

\t Non fa mica freddo qui !
\g NEG does mica cold here
\l It is not cold at all in here!’ (expectation: ‘it is cold in there’) (from Cinque 1976: 109)

\t Mica MARINA abbiamo invitato (ma Giulio) !
\g Mica Marina have.1PL invited (but Giulio)
\l We did not invite MARINA (we invited Giulio)!

\t Mi hanno detto che hai invitato Marina…
\g me have.3PL told that have.2SG invited Marina
\l I have been told that you have invited Marina.

\t Mica l’ho invitata !
\g mica her-have.1SG invited.F.SG
\l I have not invited her at all!

\t *Mica fa freddo qui !
\g mica does cold here
\l It is not cold at all in here!’ (from Cinque 1976:109)

\t Vado a prendere una giacca , sto tremando !
\g go.1SG to take a jacket, am trembling
\l I will go and get a jacket, I am trembling.

\t Mica fa freddo qua
\g mica does cold here
\l It is not cold at all in here.

\t Non vai a letto ?
\g NEG go.2SG to bed
\l Don’t you go to bed?’ +> Don’t you go sleeping?

\t No . Mica ho sonno !
\g no mica have.1SG sleep
\l No, I am not sleepy at all!

\t Perché piangi ?
\g Why cry.2SG
\l Why are you crying?

\t *Mica ho passato l’esame .
\g mica have.1SG passed the-exam
\l I have not passed the exam at all.

\t Non ho mica passato l’esame .
\g NEG have.1SG mica passed the-exam.
\l I have not passed the exam at all.

\t Mica non l’ho fatto !
\g mica NEG it-have.1SG did!
\l It is false that I didn’t do it!’ +> I did it!

\t Mica gli ho dato 100 euro .
\g mica to-him have.1SG given 100 euros
\l I have not given 100 euros to him.’ +> I gave him less than 100 euros: 98, 97, 96…

\t Non gli ho mica dato 100 euro .
\g NEG to-him have.1SG mica given 100 euros
\l I have not given 100 euros to him.’ +> I gave him less than 100 euros OR I did not give him any money at all (not even 100 euros).

\t Mica possiamo vincere sempre .
\g mica can.1PL win.INF always
\l We cannot always win.’ (Corriere della Sera, 19 May 2008, p.3)

\t Non possiamo mica attendere il nuovo codice penale  … 
\g NEG can.1PL mica wait.INF the new code penal
\l We cannot wait for the new Penal code […]’ (Corriere della Sera, 03 December 2005, p.25)

\t Mica sono il tuo barista  … 
\g mica am the your barista
\l I am not your barista […]’ (KIParla, Speaker PTA016, from Piedmont)

\t Non siamo mica stati degli eroi  … 
\g NEG are.1PL mica been some.MPL heroes
\l We have not been heroes […]’ (KIParla, Speaker PTA018, from Piedmont)

\t Maria ha mangiato la torta che hai preparato ?
\g Maria has eaten the cake that have.2SG prepared
\l Did Mary eat the cake you had baked?

\t Non ho mica preparato la torta . Non ho avuto per niente tempo .
\g NEG have.1SG mica prepared the cake. NEG have.1SG had for nothing time.
\l I hadn’t baked the cake at all. I didn’t have any time.

\t Quindi che farai ?
\g So what do.FUT.2SG
\l So, what will you do?

\t Non prendo mica la macchina . Ho deciso di andare a piedi .
\g NEG take.1SG mica the car Have decided to go.INF on foot
\l I won’t drive my car at all. I have decided to go there on foot.

\t Come è stato vedere le gondole ?
\g how is been see.INF the gondolas
\l What was it like to see the gondolas?

\t Mica ho visto le gondole: sono rimasto in albergo .
\g mica have.1SG seen the gondolas am stayed in hotel
\l I didn’t see the gondolas at all: I stayed at the hotel.

\t Perché vuoi tornare a Venezia ?
\g why want go-back.INF to Venice
\l Why do you want to go back to Venice?

\t Mica ho visto le gondole: sono rimasta in albergo .
\g mica have.1SG seen the gondolas. am stayed in hotel
\l I didn’t see the gondolas at all: I stayed at the hotel. ‘

\l *‘I have taken not the book already.

\l I baked a lemon cake.

\l They told me that you invited Giulio.

\l I have invited MARINA.’ (adapted from Cruschina 2021)

\l Santa Claus could not have the same paper as ours.

\l Women do not spray the packaging.

\g even the scientists NEG are sure of this new vaccine have.2SG.PRES heard what have.3PL said?
\l Even the scientists are not sure about this new vaccine… Have you heard what they said?

\l Yes, but the scientists could not say “the probability is 0.

\l She wore an Armani dress, not a cheap dress from H&M.’ (from Bianchi & Bocci 2012:2)

\l He gifted me those books that he didn’t read at all.

\t a .  +γ , +δ  → Ø / ___  future / conditional  (affects only type partir)
\g b. [+γ] → Ø/ ___ [passé simple / past subjunctive (affects type partir and type vendre)\t Eva meint , dass  wahrscheinlich   auf Mallorca  alle Urlauber betrunken sind .
\g Eva means that probably on Majorca all tourists drunk are\t Eva meint , dass  auf Mallorca   wahrscheinlich  alle Urlauber betrunken sind .
\g Eva means that on Majorca probably all tourists drunk are
\l Eva thinks that probably in Majorca all tourists are drunk.

\t Hanna sagt , dass  wahrscheinlich   gesundheitlich  Tim etwas vorgetäuscht hat .
\g Hanna says that probably healthwise Tim something pretended has\t Hanna sagt , dass  gesundheitlich   wahrscheinlich  Tim etwas vorgetäuscht hat .
\g Hanna says that healthwise probably Tim something pretended has
\l Hanna says that healthwise Tim probably faked something.

\t  In Australien  sind alle Schwäne schwarz .
\g in Australia are all swans black
\l In Australia, all swans are black.

\t  Gesundheitlich  geht es Peter gut .
\g healthwise goes it Peter good
\l Healthwise, Peter is doing fine.

\t Präsident Franklin war wahrscheinlich / angeblich Veganer .
\g President Franklin was probably allegedly vegan
\l President Franklin was probably/allegedly a vegan.

\t Dieses Beispiel ist syntaktisch nicht (*syntaktisch) interessant .
\g this example is syntactically not syntactically interesting
\l Syntactically, this sentence is not interesting.

\t Peter sagt , dass Björn (*laut) nicht laut singt .
\g Peter says that Björn loudly not loudly sings.
\l Peter says that Björn does not sing loudly.

\t Überarbeite den Artikel inhaltlich !
\g Revise the article contentwise
\l Revise the article with regard to content.

\t Hast du den Artikel orthografisch verbessert ?
\g Have you the article orthographically improved
\l Did you improve the article regarding orthography?

\t *Überarbeite den Artikel wahrscheinlich !
\g Revise the article probably\t *Hast du den Artikel wahrscheinlich überarbeitet ?
\g Have you the article probably revised\t Eva meint , dass  wahrscheinlich   finanziell  alle Studierenden Probleme haben .
\g Eva means that probably financially all students problems have
\l Eva thinks that probably financially all students are in difficult situations.

\l Maria said that Peter probably will marry his colleague.

\l Hanna says that [ADV] Tim [ADV] faked something and thus apologizes.

\l Lukas reports that Clara is presumably economically informed.

\t Il ne faut pas fumer ici .
\g EXPL NEG must NEG smoke here
\l One must not smoke here

\l You shouldn’t have smoked.’ ✔□ > ¬

\l I shouldn’t have broken up with her’ ✔□ > ¬

\g NEG go.2SG to have.INF to go.out today

\l He took sips from the tea to its exhaustion.

\t Milan je celo jutro punio buriće vinom za tri minuta .
\g Milan.NOM AUX whole morning.ACC filled barrels.ACC wine.INS in three minutes
\l Milan filled barrels with wine in three minutes the whole morning.’ (Result: each barrel from a contextually specified set of barrels is filled/fuller with wine.)

\l Milan sprayed barrels with wine in three minutes the whole morning.’ (No result available.)

\t oˈɾ a ti , ˈoɾ je mo (a/je)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t oˈɾ a ti , ˈoɾj e mo (a/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t oˈɾa ∅ ti , ˈoɾj e mo 
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL (∅/e)
\l to plow, we plow

\t ˈʒg a ti , ˈʒg ɛ mo (a/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t ˈʒga ∅ ti , ˈʒg ɛ mo (∅/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL 
\l to burn, we burn

\t daˈj a ti , ˈdaj je mo (a/je)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t daˈj a ti , ˈdaj e mo (a/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t daˈja ∅ ti , ˈdaj e mo (∅/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL 
\l to give, we give

\t ˈkl a ti , ˈkol je mo (a/je)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t ˈkl a ti , ˈkolj e mo (a/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t ˈkla ∅ ti , ˈkolj e mo (∅/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL 
\l to slaughter, we slaughter

\t ˈwz e ti , ˈwzam e mo (e/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL \t ˈwze ∅ ti , ˈwzam e mo (∅/e)
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL 
\l to take, we take

\t deˈl i ti , deˈl i mo
\g √ -TV -INF, √ -TV -PRS.1PL
\l to share, we share

\t pɾe ˈdel a ti , pɾe ˈdel a mo
\g PREFIX- √ -TV -INF, PREFIX- √ -TV -PRS.1PL
\l to process.PFV, we process.PFV

\t pɾe del oˈυa ti , pɾe deˈl uje mo

\l to process.IPFV, we process.IPFV

\t *Janez je prebal magari Sintaktic̆ne Structure .
\g Janez AUX read:3SG MAGARI Syntactic Structures
\l John read even Syntactic Structures.’ (Crnic̆ 2011a: p. 105)

\t Vsak s̆tudent , ki je res̆il magari ENO samo nalogo , je zdelal izpit .
\g Every student who AUX solved:3SG MAGARI one alone exercise has passed exam
\l Every student that solved even one single exercise passed the exam.

\t Janez dvomi , da bo Peter odgovoril na magari ENO vpras̆anje .
\g Janez doubt:3SG that AUX Peter answer on MAGARI one question
\l John doubts that Peter will answer even one question.

\t Janez je konc̆al letnik brez da bi res̆il magari ENO nalogo .
\g Janez AUX finished:3SG year without that AUX solve MAGARI one exercise
\l John finished the school year without solving even one exercise.

\t C̆e Peter osvoji magari BRONASTO medaljo , bo postal junak .
\g if Peter win:3SG MAGARI bronze medal will become hero
\l If Peter wins even (just) the bronze medal, he will become a hero.’ (Crnic̆ 2011a: p. 106)

\t Je Janez res̆il magari ENO nalogo ?
\g AUX John solve MAGARI one exercise?
\l Did John solve even one exercise?’ (Crnic̆ 2011a: p. 107)

\t Za potnilist mi mora Janez poslati magari POSKENIRANO sliko .
\g for passport me must John send MAGARI scanned photo
\l To get a passport, John must send at least a scanned photo.

\t Preberi magari SINTAKTIC̆NE STRUKTURE .
\g read:IMP MAGARI Syntactic Structures
\l Read at least Syntactic Structures.’ (Crnic̆ 2011a: pp. 107–108)

\t Za potnilist mi anez lahko pos̆lje magari POSKENIRANO sliko
\g for passport me John can send MAGARI scanned photo.
\l To get a passport, John may send me even a scanned photo.’ (Crnic̆ 2011a: p. 108)

\l You should also give Moorthaemers a pat on the back.

\t Moorthaemers mag je ook een pluim geven .
\g Moorthamers may you also a plume give
\l You should also give Moorthaemers a pat on the back.’ or ‘Moorthaemers should also give you a pat on the back.’ (Sonar-id: WR-P-E-G-0000000694.p.360.s.1)

\t Je geeft hem niet één kans .
\g You give him not one chance
\l You’re not giving him a single chance.

\t Hem geef je niet één kans .
\g Him give you not one chance
\l You’re not giving him a single chance.’ (Sonar-id: WR-P-E-G-0000001320.p.142.s.1)

\t Hoe geef je inhoud aan een koningswens ?
\g How give you content to a king’s_wish
\l How do you make it so you get both a son and a daughter?’ (Sonar-id: WR-P-E-G-0000005091.p.727.s.1)

\t Kyng Arthure to þe messagers ʒaf grete ʒiftes .
\g King Arthur to the messengers gave great gifts
\l King Arthur gave great gifts to the messengers.’ (CMBRUT3,83.2505)

\t And herefore yeveth hym God pleynly his mercy .
\g And therefore gives him God plainly his mercy
\l And therefore god gives him plainly his mercy.’ (CMCTPARS,296.C1a.322)

\t This mayster gevyth commaundementes to the childe .
\g this master gives commandments to the child
\l This master gives commandments to the child.’ (CMINNOCE,7.101)

\t a . /petiçiɾa / >  petiçíɾa  ‘houseDIM’
\g b. /ʧineno-ko/ => [ʧnénoko] ‘daughter-in-law-NPSD’\t ¿Qué sí y qué no cabe en el mundo Kujo ?
\g what PART and what not fits in the world Kujo
\l What does and what doesn’t fit into Kujo’s world?’ (CdE)2

\t ¿Qué no debe hacer ante la picadura de alacrán ?   …   ¿Qué sí debemos hacer ante la picadura de un alacrán ?
\g what not should do in view of the sting of scorpion  what PART should do in view of the sting of a scorpion
\l What should I not do in the case of a scorpion sting? What should we do in case of a scorpion sting?’ (CdE)

\t Das sind die Artikel ,  PP aus DEnen  Hans vorgelesen hat .
\g those are the articles  out.of them Hans read has
\l These are the articles that Hans DID read (parts of) (to someone).

\t Jetzt frage ich ,  PP aus WELchen Artikeln  Hans vorgelesen hat .
\g now ask I  out.of which articles Hans read has
\l Now I ask myself, which article Hans DID read (parts of) (to someone).

\t A: John said that he wouldn’t come , right ?
\g B: No, no. On the contrary: John said that he WOULD come.\t A: Are those the articles that John didn’t read yet ?
\g B: No, no! Those are the articles that John DID read. The ones in the pile over there are the ones he didn’t read.\t A: Hans hat nichts davon erzählt , dass seiner Schwester jemand geholfen hat , oder ? B: Doch , doch: Tasächlich hat er gesagt , DASS seiner Schwester jemand geholfen hat . Aber sein Bruder hat den Umzug alleine gemacht .
\g  Hans has nothing about said that his sister someone helped has or  MOD.PART MOD.PART in fact has he said that his sister someone helped has but his brother has the move alone made
\l A: Hans has said nothing about whether his sister, anyone helped, right? B: No, he did: In fact he said that his sister, someone did help. His brother moved on his own.

\g before shortly was the reconstruction of-the museum completed
\l Recently, the reconstruction of the museum was completed.

\g the professor was very impressed by the museum director
\l The professor was very impressed by the museum’s director.

\t Ein innovativer Aussteller hat den Journalisten besonders beeindruckt .
\g a innovative exhibitor has the journalist especially impressed
\l An innovative exhibitor impressed the journalist especially.

\t Ein unheimlicher Zauberer hat den Jungen dabei geängstigt .
\g a scary magician has the boy thereby frightened
\l A scary magician frightened the boy in the course of this.’ a. Was war der Grund dafür? ‘What was the reason for this?’ b. Was war die Folge davon? ‘What was the consequence of this?’ Prompt: _____________________________________

\l Rui did not convince / persuade Ana to eat the bean stew, but she ended up eating eat, because she was hungry before going to bed.
