\t numu MUŠEN .ḪI .A kue uppešta nat arḫa ḫ ar ranteš eš er 
\g CONN=me birds REL you.sent CONN=they spoiled were
\l The birds which you sent to me, they were spoiled.’ (AT 125 11–12 (NH); Hoffner 2009: 373)

\t kāšmawa MUŠEN .ḪI .A kue ANA ENYA uppaḫḫun nuwaza mān ENYA apē MUŠEN .ḪI .A malāši nuwamu ENYA EGIRpa ḫatrāu
\g there=QUOT birds REL to lord=my I.sent CONN=QUOT=REFL if lord=my those birds approved.2SG CONN=QUOT=me lord=my back write.2SG.IMP
\l The birds which I have sent there to My Lord, if you My Lord approved of those birds, may My Lord write back to me.’ (AT 125 5–9 (NH); Hoffner 2009: 373)

\t ᵐMaraššantašma kuit ṬUPPU ḫarzi nat uezzi mān udai nat lē dattari
\g Maraššanta=TOP REL tablet has CONN=it goes if brings CONN=it PROH is.accepted
\l The tablet which Maraššanta has, if he proceeds to bring it, let it not be accepted.’ (Bo 86/299 ii 2–3 (NH); Otten 1988: 14)

\t purutma kuit dašket nu kuwapi KINaz human kittat apūnna apiya pēdā (i) 
\g mud=TOP REL took CONN where work all was.placed that=also there brings
\l The mud which he had taken, where all the work has been placed, he carries that too there.’ (KUB 7.41 Vo 36–38 (MH/MS?); Otten 1961: 118)

\t  jis laRkiine jis laRkeke saath khelaa  usne usko haraayaa
\g REL girl-ERG REL boy-GEN with played that-ERG that-ACC defeated
\l Every girl defeated the boy she played with.’ (Lit. ‘Which girl played with which boy, she defeated him.’) (Lipták 2009b: 5, ex. 14)

\t nukan uni KÚR Gašgan ERIN .MEŠ ŠU kuin kuwapi damašket  n ankan kuwašket
\g CONN=PTC that enemy Kaskean detachment REL REL.where caught CONN=it=PTC destroyed
\l and whichever he caught wherever, he destroyed it.’ (‘For any detachment x, location y such that he caught x in y, he destroyed x.’) (KBo 14.3 iii 17–19 (NH); Del Monte 2009: 18)

\t ŠA ŠEŠ ᵐḪimuDINGIRLIMma kuit uttar ḫatrāeš nankan kāša parā neḫḫi
\g of brother Ḫimuili=TOP REL matter you.wrote CONN=him=PTC here forth I.send
\l (Concerning) the matter of Ḫimuili’s brother which you wrote about, I am dispatching him (from) here.’ (HKM 2 10–13 (MH/MS); Hoffner 2009: 99)

\t LÚ .MEŠ ᵁᴿᵁKašgayamuššan kuiēš anda iyantat numu namma kattan UL kuiški wezzi
\g men Kaska=and=me=PTC REL.PL in marched CONN=me anymore with not anyone.SG comes
\l And the men of Kaska who used to march with me, no one comes with me anymore.’ (ABoT 1.60 Vo 5–7 (MH/MS); Hoffner 2009: 178)

\t gapirtanakan kuin ANA DÙ EME šipantaš nu NÍG .GIG ZAG .UDU ḫappinit zanuzi
\g mouse=TOP=PTC REL to artificial tongue she.sacrificed CONN intestines shoulders with.flame cooks
\l The mouse which she had sacrificed to the artificial tongue, she cooks the intestines and shoulders with the flame.’ (KBo 15.10 iii 58’–59’ (MH/MS); Görke 2013)

\t kuiš ŠEŠ .MEŠna NIN .MEŠna ištarna idālu iyazi nu LUGALwaš ḫaraššanā šuwāyezzi nu tuliyan ḫalzišten
\g REL brothers=and sisters=and among evil does CONN king’s head.ALL looks CONN assembly summon.2PL.IMP
\l Whoever does evil among (his) brothers and sisters and looks to the king’s head (with hostile intent), summon the assembly!’ If his testimony is dismissed, he shall pay with his head. (KBo 3.1 ii 50–51 (OH/NS); Hoffmann 1984: 34)

\t kuišan āppama uwatezzi nanza apāšpat dāi
\g REL=him back=TOP brings CONN=him=REFL he=FOC takes
\l whoever brings him back, he shall take him for himself.’ (KBo 6.2 i 53 (OH/OS); Hoffner 1997: 32)

\t nu DINGIR .MEŠ kuiēš kēdani UDti kuedani arkuwēšni IŠTU EMEYA ḫalziḫḫun …
\g CONN gods REL this.LOC day.LOC REL.DAT plea.DAT with tongue=my I.have.summoned 
\l And the gods whom I have summoned with my tongue on this day for which plea,’ may you, Sungod of Heaven, summon them from heaven and earth and … (KUB 6.45 iii 21–22 (NH); Rieken et al. 2017b)

\t nukan uni KÚR ᵁᴿᵁGašgan ERIN .MEŠ ŠUTI kuin kuwapi damašket  n ankan kuwašket
\g CONN=PTC that enemy Kaskean detachment REL REL.where caught CONN=it=PTC destroyed
\l and whichever of those enemy Kaskean detachments he caught wherever, he destroyed it.’ (‘For any detachment x, location y such that he caught x in y, he destroyed x.’) (KBo 14.3 iii 17–19 (NH); Del Monte 2009: 18)

\t nuššan kuedani DINGIRLIMni kuit tuēkkišši anda wezz ap an DINGIR .MEŠša kue UNUTE .MEŠ wezzapanta nat anzel iwar EGIRpa ŪL kuiški neuwaḫḫa n ḫart a
\g CONN=PTC REL.DAT god.DAT REL.NOM body=his on worn.out gods.GEN=also REL accoutrements worn.out CONN=them us like back not anyone renewed has
\l whatever is worn out on whichever god’s body, plus whatever accoutrements of the gods are worn out, no one has renewed them like us.’ (KUB 17.21 i 15’–17’ (MH/MS); Rieken et al. 2016a)

\t  ḪUR .SAG  kuwapitaza   eḫu
\g mountain REL.where=TOP=REFL come.2SG.IMP
\l Come (back from) the mountain where (you are).’ (KUB 36.90 Vo 36 (NH); Rieken et al. 2016c)

\t  paprezzi kuiš  3 GÍN KÙ .BABBAR pāi
\g is.impure REL 3 shekels silver gives
\l (The one) who is impure gives 3 shekels of silver.’ (KBo 6.2 i 57 (OH/OS); Hoffner 1997: 33)

\t  LÚ .MEŠ ᵁᴿᵁKašgayamuššan kuiēš anda iyantat  numu namma kattan UL kuiški wezzi
\g men Kaska=and=me=PTC REL in marched CONN=me anymore with not anyone comes
\l And the men of Kaska who used to march with me, no one comes with me anymore.’ (ABoT 1.60 Vo 5–7 (MH/MS); Hoffner 2009: 178)

\t   jo CD  salepar hai  Maya  us CDko  khariidegii
\g REL CD sale-on is Maya that CD-ACC buy-FUT
\l Which CD is on sale, Maya will buy that CD.’ (Bhatt 2003: 486, ex. 1a)

\t * jo vahaaN rahtaa hai  mujhko  vo kahaanii   jo Arundhatine uskebaaremeN likhii   pasand hai
\g REL there stay-HAB is I-DAT that story REL Arundhati-ERG that-about wrote like is
\l Who lives there, I like the story that Arundhati wrote about that boy.’ (Bhatt 2003: 500)

\t Ramne   jo laRkaa tumhaare piichhe hai   us laRkeko     jo kitaab Shantiniketanne chhaapii thii   vo kitaab   dii
\g Ram-ERG REL boy your behind is that boy-DAT REL book Shantiniketan-ERG printed was that book gave
\l Ram gave the book that Shantiniketan had published to the boy who is standing behind you.’ (Lit. ‘Ram gave [[which book Shantiniketan had published] that book] to [[which boy is behind you] that boy].’) (Bhatt 2003: 507)

\t  Kogo ty predložiš’  togo my vyberem t
\g REL you suggest that.one we will.appoint 
\l We will appoint who you suggest.’ (Izvorski 1996: 146)

\t nu kuiš kuedani arzananza ēšta nušši pro NUMUN .ḪI .A kuit  (an) iyat …
\g CONN REL.NOM REL.DAT tenant.farmer was CONN=him  seed REL sowed
\l And whoever has been made a tenant farmer to whomever, the seed that (he) has sown for him, …’ (KUB 56.1 i 28–30 (NH); Otten & Souček 1965: 30)

\t GU₄ .ḪI .Aya kuēz Š (ÙDU) Nit tūriyanteš nu gankūwar apattaya ŪL  (duq) qāri
\g cows=also REL.ABL yoke.ABL yoked CONN weight that=also=also not matters
\l And also the yoke with which the cows are yoked, that weight too does not matter.’ (KBo 4.1+58.17 Vo 11–13 (?/NS); Görke 2012)

\t  kuinza DUMUan LAMMAaš malaizzi  nu pro INA KUR Utašša LUGALeznani apūn tittanuddu
\g REL=REFL son Kurunta prefers CONN  in land Tarḫuntašša kingship.LOC him install.3SG.IMP
\l Whichever son Kurunta prefers, let (him) install him in the kingship in the land of Tarḫuntašša.’ (Bo 86/299 ii 92–93 (NH); Otten 1988: 20)

\t ANA PANI ABBA .ḪI .AYA ABBA  (AB)BA .ḪI .(A) (kuiēš)  kūrur ešer ammugma  takšulāir
\g before fathers=my forefathers REL hostile were with.me=TOP  they.were.at.peace
\l Those who were hostile in the time of my fathers and forefathers, with me (they) were at peace.’ (KUB 1.1 iv 58–59 (NH); Otten 1981: 26)

\t TUKULma kuin apiya ḫarkun nan ḫali (ššiyanun) 
\g weapon=TOP REL then I.held CONN=it I.decorated
\l The weapon which I held then, I decorated it.’ (KUB 1.1 ii 46 (NH); Otten 1981: 12)

\t nu kuit  LU GALuš tezzi nu apāt iyami
\g CONN REL king says CONN that I.do
\l Whatever the king says, I will do.’ (KBo 17.4 ii 12’–13’ (OH/OS); Montuori 2017)

\t DINGIRLIMmakan kuedani ANA ᴰᵁᴳGÌR .GÁN anda arranzi našta wātar kuit ANA ᴰᵁᴳGÌR .GÁN anda nat ANA PANI DINGIRLIM apēzpat IŠTU ᴰᵁᴳGÌR .GÁN dāi
\g god=TOP=PTC REL.LOC LOC vessel in they.wash CONN=PTC water REL LOC vessel in CONN=it before god that.ABL=FOC ABL vessel puts
\l The vessel in which they wash the deity, the water which is in , he puts it before the god with that vessel.’ Paraphrase: [The water which is inside [the vessel in which they wash the deity]], he puts the water before the god with that vessel. (KUB 27.16 i 30–33 (NH); Beckman 2015: 46)

\t andaatkan ḫarakdu
\g within=it.NOM=PTC perish.3SG.IMP
\l Let it perish within.’ (KUB 33.8 iii 14’ (NH); Rieken et al. 2009a)

\t nuwamu  iwaru kuit pāi
\g CONN=QUOT=me  dowry what gives
\l What dowry will (he) give me?’ (KUB 17.9 i 30 (NH); Rieken et al. 2009b)

\t nukan kēuš kuiēš NINDA .GUR₄ .RAuš išpantuzziyaliuš tēpawēš āššanteš nat mu (le akk) anzi
\g CONN=PTC these REL bread.offerers libation.pourers few remaining CONN=they=me PROH die.3PL.IMP
\l These few bread-offerers and libation-pourers who still remain, let them not die on me.’ (KUB 14.8 Vo 18–19 (NH); Rieken et al. 2017a)

\t  numukan  DINGIRLUM kuiš kēdani pedi tittanut numukan  ŪL kuitki šiwariya zi
\g CONN=me=PTC god REL this.LOC place.LOC installed CONN=me=PTC  not anything denies
\l The god who installed me in this place, (he) does not deny me anything.’ (KUB 21.38 Vo 15–16 (NH); Hoffner 2009: 289)

\t kuiš šagaīš kīšari ta LUGALi MUNUS .LUGALya  tarweni
\g REL sign occurs CONN to.king queen=and  we.tell
\l Whatever sign occurs, we tell (it) to the king and queen.’ (KBo 17.1 iv 9 (OH/OS); Montuori 2017)

\t nukan DINGIRLIM ENYA apūn menaḫḫanda uški nu PANI DINGIRLIM ENYA kāš MUNUSaš weḫattaru
\g CONN=PTC god lord=my her toward look.2SG.IMP CONN before god lord=my this woman go.back.and.forth.3SG.IMP
\l O god, my lord, look at (instead of me)! Let (instead of me) go back and forth before (= attend to) the god my lord.’ (KBo 4.6 Ro 14’–15’ (NH); Goedegebuure 2014: 401)

\t nu kuiš DUMUaš ANA LAMMA ZIanza kuinza DUMUan LAMMAaš malaizzi nu INA KUR Utašša LUGALiznani apūn tittanuddu
\g CONN REL son to Kurunta will REL=REFL son Kurunta prefers CONN in land Tarḫuntašša in.kingship him install.3SG.IMP
\l whichever son is Kurunta’s will, whichever son Kurunta prefers, let him (=Kurunta) install in the kingship of the land of Tarḫuntašša.’ (Bo 86/299 ii 92–93 (NH); Otten 1988: 20)

\t ᵐḪuidudduwalliš nan ᵁᴿᵁŠallašna ašašer
\g Ḫuidudduwalli CONN=him in.Šallašna they.settled
\l (As for) Ḫuidudduwalli, they settled him in the city of Šallašna.’ (HKM 113 Vo 14–15 (MH/MS); Hoffner & Melchert 2008: 408)

\t nu IG kuiš ḫašzi nu šuḫḫa parkiyanzi nankan šarā SUDanzi
\g CONN door REL opens CONN roof they.go.up CONN=him=PTC up they.draw
\l The one who opens the door, they go up to the roof and draw him up.’ (IBoT 3.148 iii 13–14 (MH/NS); CHD P: 156 s.v. park- 2a)

\t nu DINGIR .MEŠ kuit waštul uškatteni nu naššu DINGIR .MEŠniyanza weddu nat  (mema) u našmaat ŠU .GI AZU  MUŠEN .DÙ  memiya ndu  na š maat zašḫiyaz DUMU .LÚ .U₁₉ .LU aušdu
\g CONN gods REL sin you.see CONN either man.of.the.gods come.3SG.IMP CONN=it tell.3SG.IMP or=it old.women diviners augurs tell.3PL.IMP or=it through.dream person see.3SG.IMP
\l The sin which you gods see, either let a man of the gods come and let him tell it, or let the old women, diviners, and augurs tell it, or let an (ordinary) person see it through a dream.’ (KUB 24.3+KBo 51.18b ii 19’–22’ (NH); Rieken et al. 2016b)

\t nu kuiš DUMUaš alpanza našmaššikan garāteš adanteš nan tuīkkuš išgaḫḫi
\g CONN REL child sick or=him=PTC innards devoured CONN=him bodyparts I.anoint
\l Whatever child is sick, or his innards are devoured, I anoint his bodyparts (lit. I anoint him the bodyparts).’ (KUB 7.1+ i 39–40 (pre-NH/NS); Fuscagni 2017)

\t ᵐMaraššantašma kuit ṬUPPU ḫarzi nat uezzi mān udai nat le dattari
\g Maraššanta=TOP REL tablet has CONN=it goes if brings CONN=it PROH be.accepted
\l The tablet which Maraššanta has, if he proceeds to bring it, let it not be accepted.’ (Bo 86/299 ii 2–3 (NH); Otten 1988: 14)

\t nu É ᵈ  ᵐD utḫaliyaš DUMUYA :tapardu
\g CONN house Ishtar Tudḫaliya son=my administer.3SG.IMP
\l and Tudḫaliya my son shall administer the house of Ishtar.’ (KUB 1.1 iv 77–78 (NH); Otten 1981: 28)

\t ᵈUTUaz utnē  kuit k uitpat araiš nuš ḫūmandušp at ḫ u llanu n
\g sun.ABL land whichever=FOC rose.up CONN=them.ACC all.ACC=FOC I.defeated
\l Whatever land rose up from the east, I defeated them .’ (KBo 3.22 Ro 11–12 (OH/OS); Neu 1974: 10)

\t INA ᵁᴿᵁGašipūra kuiuš 2 LÚ .MEŠ ᵁᴿᵁMalazziya  ᵐP išišši ḫ lin  ᵐN aištūwarrinna appanteš naššan ŠU .ḪI .AŠU GÌR .MEŠŠUya SIG₅atten
\g in Kašepura REL. 2 men Malazziya Pišiššiḫli. Naištuwarri.=and captured.PTCP CONN=them.=PTC hands=their feet=their=and secure.2PL.IMP
\l The two men of Malazziya, Pišiššiḫli and Naištuwarri, who are held captive in Kašepura, secure them hand and foot.’ (HKM 65 4–8 (MH/MS); Hoffner 2009: 217)

\t De diskuterer båten som Jon blir glad om foreldrene kjøper .
\g they discuss boat.DEF that/which John gets happy if parents.DEF buy
\l They discuss the boat that John will be happy if his parents buy.’1

\t Nils unngår spillet som han blir frustrert når han taper .
\g Nils avoids game.DEF that/which he gets frustrated when he loses
\l Nils avoids the game that he gets frustrated when he loses.

\t Samtalen handler om tvserien som mange blir redde fordi de ser .
\g conversation.DEF revolves about tv-serie.DEF that/which many become scared because they watch.
\l The conversation is about the tv-series that many get scared because they watch.

\t Kollegaene bryr seg ikke om at advokaten antageligvis vil glemme kofferten sin ,
\g colleagues.DEF care themselves not about that lawyer.DEF probably will forget suitcase.DEF his
\l The colleagues do not care that the lawyer probably will forget his suitcase,

\t … men mappene blir de sinte om han glemmer igjen på kontoret .
\g … but files.DEF get they upset if he forgets again at office.DEF
\l … ‘but the files, they will be upset if he leaves at the office.

\t Han *(som) kjøpte skoene
\g He *(SOM) bought shoes.DEF
\l He/The man who bought shoes

\t Skoene (som) han kjøpte
\g Shoes.DEF (SOM) he bought
\l The shoes that he bought’ (Åfarli 1994: 82)

\t De erter fotballspilleren som ___ misliker at de nevner selvmålet .
\g they tease football-player.DEF who ___ dislikes that they mention own-goal.DEF
\l They tease the football player who dislikes that they mention the own goal.

\t De diskuterer selvmålet som fotballspilleren misliker at de nevner ___ .
\g they discuss own-goal.DEF that football-player.DEF dislikes that they mention ___.
\l They discuss the own goal that the football player dislikes that they mention.

\t De erter fotballspilleren som ___ blir flau om de nevner selvmålet .
\g they tease football-player.DEF who ___ gets embarrassed if they mention own-goal.DEF.
\l They tease the football player who gets embarrassed if they mention the own goal.

\t De diskuterer selvmålet som fotballspilleren blir flau om de nevner ___ .
\g they discuss own-goal.DEF that football-player.DEF gets embarrassed if they mention ___.
\l They discuss the own goal that the football player will be embarrassed if they mention.

\t Nils snakker med kunstsamleren som jubler om / når / fordi noen kjøper maleriet av Van Gogh .22
\g Nils talks with art dealer.DEF who celebrates if / when / because someone buys paitning.DEF by Van Gogh
\l Nils is talking to the art dealer who will celebrate if someone buys the painting by Van Gogh.’ ‘Nils is talking to the art dealer who will celebrate when someone buys the painting by Van Gogh.’ ‘Nils is talking to the art dealer who is celebrating because someone is buying the painting by Van Gogh.

\t n ye ce min ye , o ye muru san
\g I PAST man REL/DEM see he PAST knife buy
\l The man that I saw, he bought the knife’ ‘I saw that man, he bought the knife’ (Givón 2009: 99, ex. 4b)

\t Ich kenne die Frau , DIE hat dem Mann das Buch gegeben
\g I.NOM know the woman.ACC DEM.NOM has the.DAT man the book.ACC given
\l I know the woman, the one who gave the book to the man’ Historically: ‘I know the woman. THAT one gave the book to the man.’ (Givón 2009: 104, ex. 15a)

\t Ich kenne die Frau , die dem Mann das Buch gegeben hat
\g I.NOM know the woman.ACC DEM.NOM the man.DAT the book.ACC given has
\l I know the woman who gave the book to the man’ (Givón 2009: 105, ex. 16a)

\t Tiang ngatap biu
\g 1 AV.cut banana
\l I cut a banana.

\t Biu gatap tiang
\g banana OV.cut 1
\l I cut a banana.

\t Ayu nyimpit awakne
\g Ayu AV.pinch self-POSS.3
\l Ayu pinched herself.

\t *Awakne nyimpit Ayu
\g self-POSS.3 AV.pinch Ayu
\l (Lit.) ‘She pinched Ayu.

\t Awakne jimpit Ayu
\g self-POSS.3 OV.pinch Ayu
\l (Lit.) ‘She pinched Ayu.

\t *Ayu jimpit awakne
\g Ayu OV.pinch self-POSS.3
\l Ayu pinched herself.

\t Ayu ngenah sig awakne jelek sajan .
\g Ayu seem to self-POSS.3 bad very
\l Ayu seemed to herself to be very ugly.

\t #Ayu ngenah sig awakne jelek sajan .
\g Ayu seem to self-POSS.3 bad very
\l Ayu seemed to herself to be very ugly.

\t Bokuga Hanakoni okaneo  *kureru/yaru 
\g I-NOM Hanako-DAT money-ACC give-PREC
\l I give money to Hanako.

\t Tarooga bokuni okaneo  kureru/*yaru 
\g Taroo-NOM me-DAT money-ACC give-PRES
\l Taroo gives me money.

\t Injil ngrujuk awakne
\g Bible AV.reference self-POSS.3
\l The Bible references itself.

\t Yesus ngrujuk awakne
\g Jesus AV.reference self-POSS.3
\l Jesus references himself.

\t Ayu demen ajak foton awakne .
\g Ayu happy with photo-LNK self-POSS.3
\l Ayu likes a picture of herself.

\t Bukune misi foton awakne .
\g Book-DEF contain photo-LNK self-POSS.3
\l The book contains a picture of itself.

\t *Injil nglalahin anak sane kenyih teken awakne
\g Bible AV.influence person REL sensitive to self-POSS.3
\l The Bible influences people who are sensitive to itself.

\t Yesus nglalahin anak sane kenyih teken awakne
\g Jesus AV.influence person REL sensitive to self-POSS.3
\l Jesus influences people who are sensitive to himself.

\t  Bapan Ayu  sing nemenin awakne
\g Father Ayu NEG AV.like-APPL self-POSS.3
\l Ayu’s father does not like himself.

\t Nyoman ngaden Ayu nanjung awakne
\g Nyoman think Ayu AV.kick self-POSS.3
\l Nyoman thinks Ayu kicked him/herself.

\t Ayu ngorahin Nyoman awakne lakar malaib
\g Ayu AV.told Nyoman self-POSS.3 will run
\l Ayu told Nyoman that they will run.

\t Nyoman ngorahin Arta Ayu nanjung awakne
\g Nyoman AV.tell Arta Ayu AV.kick self-POSS.3
\l Nyoman told Arta that Ayu kicked him/herself.

\t Nyoman ningeh uli Arta Ayu nanjung awakne
\g Nyoman AV.hear from Arta Ayu AV.kick self-POSS.3
\l Nyoman heard from Arta that Ayu kicked him/herself.

\t Ia ningeh cang gedeg teken awakne
\g 3 AV.hear 1 angry with self-POSS.3
\l (S)he heard that I was angry with him/her.’ (Udayana 2013: p.199)

\t #Nyoman ngaden Ayu nanjung awakne
\g Nyoman think Ayu AV.kick self-POSS.3
\l Nyoman thinks Ayu kicked himself.

\t Ayu ngorahang awakne (ngenah) jegeg sajan .
\g Ayu AV.say self-POSS.3 (seem) beautiful very
\l Ayu said that she looks very beautiful.

\t #Ayu ngorahang awakne (ngenah) jegeg sajan .
\g Ayu AV.say self-POSS.3 (seem) beautiful very
\l Ayu said that she looks very beautiful.

\t Ayu ngorahang anak sane masolah becik jegeg sajan…
\g Ayu AV.said-APPL person REL behave good beautiful very
\l Ayu said that a good person is very beautiful…

\t …nanging tiang ngerasa anake ento tusing masolah becik .
\g …but 1 feel person-DEF DEM NEG behave good
\l …but I think that person isn’t good.

\t *Ayu ngorahang  idiote ento  (ngenah) jelek sajan .
\g Ayu AV.say idiot-DEF DEM (seem) ugly very
\l Ayu said that the idiot looks very ugly.

\t Nyoman ningeh uli  surat kabar  Ayu nanjung awakne
\g Nyoman AV.hear from document news Ayu AV.kick self-POSS.3
\l Nyoman heard from [the newspaper] that Ayu kicked him/herself.

\t Komen sane jelek indik awakne ring Instagrame ngae Ayu sebet .
\g comment REL mean about self-POSS.3 on Instagram AV.make Ayu sad
\l Mean comments about herself on Instagram made Ayu sad.

\t Indik Nyoman nyimpit awakne ngae Ayu gedeg
\g that Nyoman AV.pinch self-POSS.3 AV.make Ayu mad
\l That Nyoman pinched himself/herself annoyed Ayu.

\t *Indik Nyoman nyimpit  idiote ento  ngae Ayu gedeg
\g that Nyoman AV.pinch idiot-DEF DEM AV.make Ayu mad
\l That Nyoman pinched [the idiot] annoyed Ayu.

\t Indik Nyoman nyimpit anak masolah becik ngae Ayu gedeg…
\g that Nyoman AV.pinch person behave good AV.make Ayu mad
\l That Nyoman pinched a good person made Ayu mad…

\t …nanging tiang ngerasa ia tusing masolah becik
\g but 1 feel 3 NEG behave good
\l …but I think (s)he is not a good person.

\t Tiang ningeh kabar indik Nyoman … awakne demen ajak Ayu
\g 1 AV.hear news about Nyoman … self-POSS.3 like with Ayu
\l I heard something about Nyoman … he likes Ayu.

\t Arta ngorahin tiang kabar indik Nyoman … awakne demen ajak Ayu
\g Arta AV.tell 1 news about Nyoman … self-POSS.3 like with Ayu
\l Arta told me something about Nyoman … he likes Ayu

\t Nyoman ngaden Ayu ngenah sig awakne jelek sajan
\g Nyoman think Ayu seem to self-POSS.3 bad very
\l Nyoman thinks Ayu seemed to himself/herself to be very ugly.

\t Ngenah sig awakne ia jelek sajan .
\g Seem to self-POSS.3 3 bad very
\l (lit.) ‘It seems to herself that she is very ugly.

\t *Ayu ngenah sig awak jelek sajan .
\g Ayu seem to self bad very
\l (lit.) ‘Ayu seemed to herself to be very ugly.

\t Nyoman ngenah sig Ayu ganteng sajan .
\g Nyoman seem to Ayu handsome very
\l Nyoman seems to Ayu to be very handsome.

\t Nyoman ngenah sig Ayu jelek sajan .
\g Nyoman seem to Ayu bad very
\l Nyoman seems to Ayu to be very ugly.

\t Ayu ngenah sig anak bagus ento jelek sajan
\g Ayu seem to person good DEM bad very
\l Ayu seems to a good man to be very ugly.

\t Ayu ngenah sig anak jelek ento jelek sajan
\g Ayu seem to person bad DEM bad very
\l Ayu seems to a bad man to be very ugly.

\t *Ayu ngenah sig  idiote ento  jelek sajan .

\t alkalbu yanbaħu
\g the-dog.MS-NOM bark.3MS
\l The dog barks.

\t alkilaabu tanbahħu
\g the-dogs.MPL-NOM bark.3FS
\l The dogs bark (Dogs bark).’ (Fassi-Fehri 2004:44)

\t kalbun yanbaħu
\g dog.MS-NOM bark.3MS
\l A dog is barking.

\t kilaabun tanbaħu
\g dogs.MPL-NOM bark.3FS
\l Dogs are barking.’ (Fassi-Fehri 2004:44)

\t At in studint tûk is , is er ornaris grutsk .
\g If a student smart is, is he usually proud
\l If a student is smart, he is usually proud.’ (✔QVE)

\t At de studint tûk is , is er ornaris grutsk .
\g If the student smart is, is he usually proud
\l If the student is smart, he is usually proud.’ (*QVE) (Hoekstra 2010:51)

\t At men tûk is , is men ornaris grutsk .
\g If one smart is, is one usually proud
\l If one is smart, one is usually proud.’ (QVE reading: ‘Most smart people are proud.’) (Hoekstra 2010:51)

\l Richard, he was one of the good players that we had in Canada.

\g ‘Richard, he was one of the good players s.t. we did not have better players in Canada.’\t Il a invité tous les musiciens qu’ il y a pas dans la région . (3b)

\g he has invited all the musicians yesterday  that there.is negₓ in the area\t J’ai fait tout ce  que je pouvais pas faire _  pour le retrouver . (3a)
\g I.have done everything [that I could negₓ do] to him.find \t C’est incroyable qu’estce qu’ il a pas pu faire pour le retrouver ! (4c , 18)

\l It’s incredible what he could do to find him!

\l What didn’t he do to find him!

\g three take three add six
\l Take three add three (it's) six.

\l If you add three to three, (it's) six.

\l Add three to three makes six.

\l Discard two from five then there are three.

\l Five bananas, split off two [to] save then only three [are left].

\t Iwihing ano' kurung alu towo
\g five CAUS-affect less two three
\l Five minus two is three.

\t Yeting nu ayokung habel maiye hepot sua
\g five SPEC two=LOC 3.PAT-subtract if 3.ALIEN-remainder three
\l If two is subtracted from five, the remainder is three.

\t Yeting nu ayoku mia maiye sua
\g five SPEC two take-DUR if three
\l If two is taken from five, it is three.

\t Wesing ok womet aningbo su .
\g five two 3.LOC-take thus-SET=CONJ three
\l Take two from five thus there are three.

\l If a group of four is counted five times, it is twenty.

\l (D’abord) toi, tu t’es engagé sur la voie de droite, (ensuite) lui sur la voie de gauche.

\l Au bruit du coup de feu, surgirent (simultanément) d’un buisson un lapin et d’un terrier un écureuil.

\l Vous vous y êtes engagés en même temps, toi sur la voie de droite, lui sur la voie de gauche.

\t gwakɪndile ʊn̩dʊngʊ gʊmo . gyakɪndile mibɪlɪ nakamo nʊkʊbʊʊka kʊkʊbɪɪka
\g 3-PST-pass-PFV AUG-3-week 3-one 4-PST-pass-PFV 4-two COM=12-one COM=AUG-15-go-FV 17-15-put-FV
\l One week passed. Two weeks passed, not once going to hand it over.

\t po mwangambɪlɪ aatɪ hee . po mbʊʊke kwa kajamba kʊkʊmela ɪɪheela syangʊ”
\g as matronym=9-monkey 1-SUBSEC-say INTERJ then 1SG-go-SUBJ 17-ASSOC tortoise(1) 17-15-claim-FV AUG-money(10) 10-POSS.1SG
\l Then Monkey said Hee. ‎‎I shall go to Tortoise to demand my money.”

\t po alɪnkwenda , alɪnkwenda , alɪnkwenda
\g then 1-NARR-walk/travel-FV 1-NARR-walk/travel-FV 1-NARR-walk/travel-FV
\l He walked and walked and walked.

\t kangɪ po bo gɪkɪndile ɪmilʊngʊ mibɪlɪ , kangɪ alɪnkʊbuja kwa kajamba
\g again then as 4-pass-PFV AUG-4-week 4-two again 1-NARR-return-FV 17-ASSOC tortoise(1)
\l When two weeks had passed, he returned again to Tortoise's.

\t bo ikʊfika ikʊmmwania ʊmwanaake alipo ʊgʊʊso apa ?”
\g as 1-PRS-arrive-FV 1-PRS-1-ask-FV AUG-1-his_child 1-COP=16 AUG-your_father AUG-PROX.16
\l As he was arriving he asks his (Tortoise's) child Is your father here?”

\t iisikʊ lɪlɪngɪ po aaliisile mwangambɪlɪ
\g 5-day 5-5-other then 1-PST-come-PFV matronym=9-monkey
\l Another day Mr. Monkey came.

\t aaliisile nɪlyojo
\g 1-PST-come-PFV COM=AUG-5-anger
\l He came with anger.

\t lɪlɪno kʊmbako ɪɪheela jangʊ , kʊmbako ɪɪheela jangʊ” ikʊjoba munjɪla
\g now/today 2SG.PRS-1SG-give-FV=17 AUG-money(9) 9-POSS.1SG 2SG.PRS-1SG-give-FV=17 AUG-money(9) 9-POSS.1SG 1-PRS-speak-FV 18-9-path
\l Today you're giving me my money, you're giving me my money”, he is saying on his way.

\t alɪnkwa kʊfika paa kajamba
\g 1-NARR-go.FV 15-arrive-FV 16-ASSOC tortoise(1)
\l He arrived at Tortoise's.

\t aajile kʊbuja . Hahaha mwangambɪlɪ ʊlipo . gwisile , pole ! ngʊpa lɪlɪno ɪɪheela syako”
\g 1-PST-go-PFV 15-return-FV INTERJ matronym=9-monkey 2SG-COP=16 2SG-come-PFV sorry(<SWA) 1SG-PRS-give-FV now/today AUG-money(10) 10-POSS.2SG
\l He [Tortoise] went and returned. Hahaha, Mr. Monkey, you are here! You have come, sorry! I'm giving you your money now.

\t balɪnkʊm̩bona bo afumile bo kʊla
\g 2-NARR-1-see-FV as 1-come_from-PFV as 17-DIST
\l They saw him [Tortoise] as he came from over there.

\t ʊtɪ baalɪntaagile mummisyanjʊ
\g 2SG-say.SUBJ 2-PST-1-throw-PFV 18-18-4-bush
\l Do you know, they had thrown him into the bush.

\t po aajile kwenda kʊla
\g then 1-PST-go-PFV 15-walk/travel-FV 17-DIST
\l He had (gone and) had a walk there.

\t aajile kʊbuja
\g 1-PST-go-PFV 17-return-FV
\l He had gone and returned.

\t iisikʊ lɪmo , kalʊlʊ aalyaganiile niitugutu
\g 5-day 5-one hare(1) 1-PST-find-RECP-APPL.PFV COM=5-type_of_bird
\l One day, Hare met with Tugutu (a type of bird).

\t alɪnkʊtɪ gwe , tugutu , ʊgwe ! ʊkabagɪla ʊkʊngɪnda ʊne ʊkʊbopa , ʊne ngʊbopa fiijo , mbagiile ʊkʊkʊtola”
\g 1-NARR-say 2SG t.o.bird AUG-2SG 2SG-NEG-be_able-FV AUG-15-1SG-surpass-FV AUG-1SG AUG-15-run-FV AUG-1SG 1SG-PRS-run-FV INTENS 1SG-be_able.PFV AUG-15-2SG-beat-FV
\l He said You, Tugutu, you! You can't beat me in running, I run fast, I can beat you.”

\t iitugutu lyatile mma . ʊkabagɪla ʊkʊndola kalʊlʊ ʊkʊbopa . tʊbagiile pamo ʊkʊtolana , ʊkʊfwana”
\g 5-t.o.bird 5-PST-say-PFV no 2SG-NEG-be_able-FV AUG-15-1SG-beat-FV hare(1) AUG-15-run-FV 1PL-be_able.PFV maybe AUG-15-beat-RECP-FV AUG-15-be(come)_equal-FV
\l Tugutu said No. You, Hare, can't beat me in running. We can maybe have a tie.”

\t aatɪ mma popaa∼po twande kɪlaabo ʊkʊbopa”
\g 1-SUBSEC-say no REDUPL∼then 1PL-start-SUBJ 7-tomorrow AUG-15-run-FV
\l He (Hare) said Ok then, tomorrow let's start to run.”

\t po mwandugutu aabʊʊkile
\g then matronym=9-t.o.bird 1-PST-go-PFV
\l Mr. Tugutu went.

\t aabapaalile abanine bahaano
\g 1-PST-2-invite-PFV AUG-2-companion 2-five
\l He gathered five companions.

\t bo iisikʊ lya kɪlaabo , bo lɪfikile , mwandugutu aalɪm̩bɪɪkile mwandugutu nnine pabwandɪlo
\g as 5-day 5-ASSOC 7-tomorrow as 5-arrive-PFV matronym=9-t.o.bird 1-PST-1-put-FV matronym=9-t.o.bird 1-companion 16-14-start
\l When the next day arrived, Mr. Tugutu placed a fellow Mr. Tugutu at the start.

\t ɪɪmaeli jaa bʊbɪlɪ mwandugutu ʊjʊngɪ …
\g AUG-mile(9) 9-ASSOC 14-two matronym=9-t.o.bird AUG-1-other …
\l The second mile another Mr. Tugutu […]

\t na kʊbʊmalɪɪkɪlo , maeli gaa bʊhaano , mwandugutu ʊjʊngɪ
\g COM 17-14-end mile 6-ASSOC 14-five matronym=9-t.o.bird AUG-1-other

\t aaliko kajamba jʊmo . aalɪ moolo fiijo . akaaliiganile ʊkʊbomba ɪmbombo

\l There was a certain tortoise. It was very lazy. It did not like to work.

\t apa ʊmbeele ɪfindʊ . ɪnjala jandʊmaga
\g AUG-PROX.16 2SG-1SG-give-PFV AUG-8-food AUG-9-hunger 9-PST-1SG-bite-IPFV

\t fyobeene gwajobaga , nalooli lʊkafu
\g therefore 2SG-PST-speak-IPFV really 11-difficult
\l That is why you were speaking, it [the lock] truly is tough.' [Wage of the thieves]

\t nkɪpanga kɪla aalipo ʊnkiikʊlʊ ʊnhɪɪji ʊjʊ aabombaga ɪjaa kwiba ɪfindʊ ɪfi bapɪɪjile abanine ,
\g 18-7-village 7-DIST 1-PST-COP=16 AUG-1-woman AUG-1-thief AUG-PROX.1 1-PST-work-IPFV AUG-9-ASSOC 15-steal-FV AUG-8-food AUG-PROX.8 2-cook-PFV AUG-2-companion
\l In that village there was a thieving woman, who used to steal the food the others had cooked,

\t aafyʊlaga mundeko na muusefulɪla
\g 1-PST-remove-IPFV 18-10-earthen_pot COM 18-cooking_pot(9)(<SWA)
\l She used to take it out of earthen pots and cooking pots.

\t pala lɪnga abʊʊkile nkookola ʊmooto kʊbanine , lɪnga balɪ panja , aakuputulaga ɪfindʊ nʊkʊfyʊlamo fimo , aabʊʊkaga nafyo kʊmyake
\g 16-DIST if/when 1-go-PFV 18-15-fetch_fire-FV AUG-3-fire 17-2-companion, if/when 2-COP 16-outside 1-PST-uncover-IPFV AUG-8-food COM=AUG-15-remove-FV=18 8-one 1-PST-go-IPFV COM=REF.8 17-4-POSS.SG
\l When she went to her neighbours to get fire, if they were outside she would uncover the food, take some out and go home with it.

\t abanyambala baafwalaga ɪngʊbo jaa ng'ombe muno munsana
\g AUG-2-man 2-PST-dress/wear-IPFV AUG-9-skin 9-ASSOC cow(9) 18-PROX 18-3-waist
\l The men wore a skin of a cow here at the waist.

\t poope aalɪmmwagile ʊnkasi gwa Pakyɪndɪ ikʊbomba bo sila∼sila ɪsya mmajolo
\g 16-also 1-PST-1-find-PFV AUG-1-wife 1-ASSOC P. 1-PRS-work-FV as REDUPL∼10-DIST AUG-10-ASSOC 18-6-evening
\l Again he found Pakyindi's wife doing just like the day before.

\t looli ʊn̩dʊme am̩bʊʊlaga aatɪgɪ ngʊbʊʊka kʊkʊnyukula amajabʊ”

\t ʊmundʊ jʊmo aatiimaga ɪɪng'oosi

\t aalɪ nɪmbwa
\g 1-PST-COP COM=AUG-9-dog

\g REDUPL∼then AUG-1-person 1-DIST 1-NARR-go-FV 16-7-thicket 16-15-rest-FV
\l That man went into the thicket to rest.

\t lɪnga naalɪ ne laɪsi naabatʊʊlaga abalondo

\t lɪnga naalɪ jo ʊne naabʊʊkaga kɪlaabo
\g if/when 1SG-PST-COP REF.1 AUG-1SG 1SG-PST-go-IPFV 7-tomorrow
\l If it were me, I would go tomorrow.

\t lɪnga tʊkaalyagile ʊlwɪsi twafwaga

\t ee kalʊmbʊ ndɪ naakabalɪlo . ʊgwe gwalondaga bo ndɪɪli twaganile
\g yes 12-sibling_of_opposite_sex 1SG-COP COM=AUG-12-time AUG-2SG 2SG-PST-want-IPFV as when 1PL-find-RECP-APPL-SUBJ

\t fiki gwe mwinɪɪtʊ , gwe gwa bʊtatʊ , gwatʊbʊʊliile bo ʊsengiigwe , ʊkaalekaga fiki twesa tʊsengigwe ?

\t ʊmwana akendaga . ɪfyɪnja akendaga

\t bakeeganaga ʊbwegi bʊla bwa kʊpinya pamo kwikanisa . baalɪ nʊbwegi ʊbwa kyenyeeji
\g 2-NEG-PST.marry-RECP-IPFV AUG-14-marriage 14-DIST 14-ASSOC 15-tie-FV maybe 17-5-church(<SWA) 2-PST-COP COM=AUG-14-marriage AUG-14-ASSOC informal_type(<SWA)
\l They did not have weddings of that type where they tie the bond maybe at church. They had weddings of an informal type.

\t mbakooliile ʊkʊtɪ mbalagɪle amasyʊ bo ngaalɪ ʊkʊfwa

\l I've called you (pl.) to give you instructions before I die.

\t nsyɪsyɪ alɪnkʊm̩bʊʊla kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊtɪ ɪɪnyama jɪpiile , isaga tʊlyege !” po kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊtɪ taasi . jɪkaalɪ ʊkʊpya”
\g skunk(1) 1-NARR-1-tell-FV hare(1) 1-NARR-say AUG-meat(9) 9-be(come)_burnt-PFV come-IPFV 1PL-eat-IPFV.SUBJ then hare(1) 1-NARR-say yet 9-PERS AUG-15(INF)-be(come)_burnt-FV
\l Skunk told Hare “The meat is done, come let's eat!” Hare said “Later. It's not yet done.”

\t ɪlisikʊ lya kwanda aabʊʊkile kʊkʊkeeta ɪfilombe muno fijɪɪliile ʊkʊtɪ kalɪ fibɪfiifwe pamo fikaalɪ

\g Q 2SG-PERS 2SG.PRS-learn-FV _ yes 1SG-PERS
\l Are you still studying?' – Yes, I still am.

\t ikʊja pakʊkwela kangɪ , paapo ɪkɪkapʊ kɪmo kɪkaalɪ pakwisʊla

\t gakaalɪ nkʊkoma
\g 6-PERS 18-15-become_ripe-FV
\l They [the bananas] are still not ripe.' [overheard]

\t aba bakaja bakɪlisiti bakaalɪ bʊʊmɪɪliile ʊlwiho ʊlwa kʊlonda ʊkʊtiiligwa
\g AUG-PROX.2 2-NEG-be(come)-FV 2-christian 2-PERS 2-stick_to.PFV AUG-11-custom AUG-11-ASSOC 15-want-FV AUG-15-fear-PASS-FV

\t akaalɪ akafika pakaaja
\g 1-PERS 1-NEG-arrive-FV 16-12-homestead
\l S/he still has not arrived home.

\t taata ʊne nalooli ɪfyʊma ngaalɪ ngakaba ɪɪsala ɪjɪ

\t mmajolo naalambaleele bo ʊnkʊlʊ gwangʊ akaalɪ akafika pakaaja

\t mmajolo naalambaleele bo ʊnkʊlʊ gwangʊ akaalɪ ʊkʊfika pakaaja

\t bakaalɪ bafumuke
\g 2-PERS 2-famous
\l They are still famous.

\t amatunda gakaalɪ manyaafu
\g AUG-6-fruit 6-PERS 6-tasty
\l The fruits are still tasty.

\t po bo akaalɪ munjɪla po kajamba aatile
\g then as 1-PERS 18-9-path then tortoise(1) 1-PST-say-PFV
\l As he [Mr. Monkey] was still on the way, Tortoise said:' [Monkey and Tortoise]

\t ʊnkiikʊlʊ akaalɪ (alɪ) paasokoni
\g AUG-1-woman 1-PERS (1-COP) 16-market(9)(<SWA)
\l The woman is still at the market.

\t twakaalɪ twalyaga
\g 1PL-PST-PERS 1PL-PST-eat-IPFV

\t twakaalɪ twakateele
\g 1PL-PST-PERS 1PL-PST-be(come)_tired.IPFV

\t alimo ikwiba ɪfilombe fyangʊ
\g 1-COP=18 1-PRS-steal-FV AUG-8-maize 8-POSS.1SG
\l S/he constantly steals my maize.

\t ʊsajigwege nʊntwa paapo na ʊlʊ ʊkaalɪ ʊlimo kʊbomba ɪsya booloolo . kangɪ lɪlɪno po ʊbombile ɪngɪndɪlɪsi kʊsya kwanda
\g 2SG-bless-PASS-IPFV.SUBJ COM=AUG-1-lord because COM now 2SG-PERS 2SG-COP=18 2SG.PRS-do-FV AUG-10-ASSOC 14-kind again now/today then 2SG-do-PFV AUG-10-pass-INTS.AGNR 17-10-ASSOC 15-begin-FV

\t aalimo aatʊtaamyaga
\g 1-PST-COP=18 1-PST-1PL-trouble-IPFV
\l S/he constantly annoyed us.

\t ndipo ngʊlya (ɪɪsala joosa)

\t ɪɪnyumba jandile ʊkʊnyala , abandʊ bingi balipo bikwingɪla

\t ngwaga kʊʊsala ɪsi alɪ kʊkʊkina

\l I think he is playing (= is where they play).

\t leelo popaa∼po naameenye ʊkʊtɪ taata alɪ kʊkʊlɪma

\l I, however, knew that Father was farming.' (; orthography adapted)

\t bo bikʊgomoka munjɪla , kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊjɪbʊʊla ɪɪfubu alɪnkʊtɪ bakʊtuufiifye fiijo ʊgwe ʊkʊtɪ ʊlɪ nnunu , looli fifyɪma fyako fikɪndɪliile ʊbʊnywamu , batile ʊpungusye” .
\g as 2-PRS-return-FV 18-9-path hare(1) 1-NARR-9-tell-FV AUG-hippo(9) 1-NARR-say 2-2SG-praise.PFV INTENS AUG-2SG COMP 2SG-COP 1-good but 8-8-thigh 8-POSS.2SG 8-pass-INTS.PFV AUG-14-big 2-say-PFV 2SG-reduce-SUBJ
\l As they were on the road returning, Hare told Hippo, “They've praised you a lot, that you're a good person, but your thighs are too big, they have said you should lose weight.”

\t looli ngɪmba kalʊlʊ ikʊlonda ɪɪnyama ɪjaa kʊlya
\g but behold hare(1) 1-PRS-want-FV AUG-meat(9) AUG-9-ASSOC 15-eat-FV
\l But gosh, Hare wants meat for eating.

\t kalʊlʊ alɪnkwangala pala∼pala kɪsita kʊlʊbona ʊlʊbʊbi .
\g hare(1) 1-NARR-be_well-FV REDUPL∼16-DIST without 15-11-see-FV AUG-11-spider

\t ngɪmba ʊlʊbʊbi lʊbʊʊkile kʊkaaja kʊmyake

\l Gosh, Spider has gone home.

\t aakalangile iifumbɪ lɪla . ngɪmba iifumbɪ (ø) lya sota
\g 1-PST-fry-PFV 5-egg 5-DIST behold 5-egg (COP) 5-ASSOC python(9)
\l She fried that egg. Gosh, that egg is Python's.

\t bo amalile ɪmbombo jaake aasookilepo , aabʊʊkile kʊmyake

\l When he finished his work, he left and went home.

\t po bo ɪlindʊ lɪla lɪgonile itolo baalyegile amɪɪsi gala
\g then as AUG-5-monster 5-DIST 5-rest-PFV just 2-PST-take-PFV AUG-6-water 6-DIST
\l When that monster was deeply asleep they took that water.

\t po bo ikwɪmba po jɪlɪnkʊtupa
\g then as 1-PRS-sing-FV then 9-NARR-become_fat-FV
\l As it [child] was singing, it [snake] became fat.' [Snake and children]

\t bo akafika pala alɪnkwaganila nʊmundʊ panjɪla

\t bo tʊlɪ baniini twabʊʊkile kʊdalesalama
\g as 1PL-COP 2-little 1PL-PST-go-PFV 17-D.
\l When we were little we went to Dar es Salaam.

\t po bo batikʊjaaga po ɪlyebe lyaliisile ʊkwanda ʊkʊkola ʊtwana twa ngʊkʊ
\g then as 2-NEG-PRS-9-find-FV then AUG-5-crow 5-PST-come-PFV AUG-15-begin-FV AUG-15-grasp-FV AUG-12-child 12-ASSOC 10-chicken

\t ɪngwina nɪngambɪlɪ baalɪ bʊmanyaani fiijo akabalɪlo aka ijolo . baajaatanilaga nʊkwangala pamopeene . ɪngwina jiisaga nkʊjeega ɪngambɪlɪ nʊkʊbʊʊka najo palʊsʊngo pakwangala . iisikʊ lɪmo ʊnna gwa ngwina aalɪ m̩bine
\g AUG-9-crocodile COM=AUG-9-monkey 2-PST-COP 14-friendship INTENS AUG-12-time AUG-12-ASSOC old_times 2-PST-walk-RECP-APPL-IPFV COM=AUG-15-be_well-FV together AUG-9-crocodile 9-PST.come-IPFV 18-15-9-take-FV AUG-9-monkey COM=AUG-15-go-FV COM=REF.9 16-11-island 16-15-be_well-FV 5-day 5-one AUG-1-his_mother 1-ASSOC 9-crocodile 1-PST-COP 1-ill
\l Monkey and Crocodile were good friends long ago. They visited and accompanied each other. Crocodile used to come to pick up monkey and go with him to an island to spend time together. One day, Crocodile's mother was sick.

\t Juma alɪnkʊm̩bʊʊla Sambʊka alɪnkʊtɪ Po ngwegege jʊ∼jʊʊgwe , bʊle , paapo gʊnganile . ʊjʊ akangana ndeke .”

\l Juma told Sambuka Then I'll marry you, because you love me. The one who doesn't love me, I'll leave him.”

\t po balɪnkʊbʊʊka kʊkwipa ɪlyʊndʊ kʊla

\l They went to pluck grass there.

\g then 2-NARR-pluck-FV AUG-5-thatching_grass
\l They plucked grass.

\t po bo biipile ɪfikose , kʊkʊtɪ mundʊ ɪfikose , balɪnkʊja bandʊ baa kʊpinya
\g then as 2-pluck-PFV AUG-8-bundle every 1-person AUG-8-bundle 2-NARR-be(come)-FV 2-person 2-ASSOC 15-bind-FV
\l 'When they had plucked bunches, each one bunches, they began to tie [the grass].' [Throw away the child]

\t alɪnkʊmmwega ʊmwanaake
\g 1-NARR-1-take-FV AUG-1-his_child
\l She took her child.

\t alɪnkwenda nʊkʊtɪ fi , ʊkwanda ʊkʊmmongesya
\g a-NARR-walk/travel-FV COM=AUG-15-say what AUG-15-begin-FV AUG-15-1-breastfeed-FV
\l She then did what, began to breastfeed it.

\t bo ʊkʊmmongesya alɪnkʊtɪ Haa ! keeta ʊʊsyobile , gwe mwinangʊ . ʊtile ndaagile ʊmwana””
\g as 1-PRS-1-breastfeed-FV 1-NARR-say INTERJ watch-FV 2SG.1SG-deceive-PFV 2SG 1-my_companion 2SG-say-PFV 1SG-throw-PFV AUG-1-child
\l As she was breastfeeding it, she [the other woman] said Haa! Look, you've deceived me, my friend. You said I've thrown away the child.””

\t jʊla alɪnkwanda ʊkʊbuja ʊkʊbʊʊka kʊkʊnkeeta ʊmwanaake
\g 1-DIST 1-NARR-begin-FV AUG-15-return-FV AUG-15-go-FV 17-15-1-look-FV AUG-1-child
\l That one began returning, going to look for her child.

\t alɪnkʊtɪ oko kalʊlʊ ! tʊbopege leelo !”
\g 1-NARR-say INTERJ hare(1) 1PL-run-IPFV.SUBJ now/but
\l He [Tugutu] said Here we go, Hare! Let's run now!

\t po kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊbopa
\g then hare(1) 1-NARR-run-FV
\l Hare ran/was running.

\t alɪnkʊtɪ lɪnga tʊbopile amaelɪ jɪmo ngʊkʊkoolela ʊkutɪ bʊle , mwandugutu , ʊlipo ?” gwitɪke ʊtɪ ee , ndipo””
\g 1-NARR-say if/when 1PL-run-PFV AUG-6-mile(<EN) 9-one 1SG-PRS-2SG-call-FV COMP Q matronym=9-type_of_bird 2SG-COP=16 2SG-agree-SUBJ 2SG-say.SUBJ yes 1SG-COP=16
\l He said When we've run one mile, I'll call you saying Mr. Tugutu are you there?” You shall answer Yes, I'm here.””

\t po bo bandile ʊkʊbopa jʊla mwandugutu aasyeele pala∼pala
\g then as 2-begin-PFV AUG-15-run-FV 1-DIST matronym=9-t.o.bird 1-PST-remain.PFV REDUPL∼16-DIST
\l ‎When they had started to run that Mr. Tugutu had remained right there.

\t po kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊbopa mwene
\g then hare(1) 1-NARR-run-FV 1-only
\l So Hare ran/was running alone.

\t alɪnkʊmala amaelɪ gamo
\g 1-NARR-finish-FV AUG-6-mile 6-one
\l He completed one mile.

\t aagomoka ʊmwanike jʊla
\g 1-SUBSEC-return-FV AUG-1-young_person 1-DIST
\l Then that young woman returned.

\t po balɪnkwenda , balɪnkwenda , balɪnkwenda
\g then 2-NARR-walk/travel-FV 2-NARR-walk/travel-FV 2-NARR-walk/travel-FV
\l They walked, they walked, they walked.

\t balɪnkʊtɪ eh tʊkateele”
\g 2-NARR-say INTERJ 1PL-be(come)_tired.PFV
\l They said Eh, we're tired.”

\t silɪnkwangɪla mmwanya
\g 10-NARR-catch-FV 18-high
\l They caught (the bottles) in mid air.

\t ɪmbilipili jɪlɪnkʊsunyunduka ntʊsupa mula nʊkʊnyeelela mmaaso na mmilomo
\g AUG-9-pepper(<SWA) 9-NARR-come_out_of-FV 18-13-bottle 18-DIST COM=AUG-15-jump-APPL-FV 18-6-eye COM 18-4-lip
\l The pepper came out of the little bottles and flew into their eyes and mouths.

\t popaa∼po ɪngambɪlɪ silɪnkʊgwa paasi paapo jaalɪ ngalɪ fiijo
\g REDUPL∼then AUG-10-monkey 10-NARR-fall-FV 16-below because 9-PST-COP 9-fierce INTENS
\l And so the monkeys fell down because it was very hot.

\t silɪnkʊkuuta silɪnkʊtɪ , “Ho ! Ho ! Ho !”
\g 10-NARR-cry-FV 10-NARR-say INTERJ INTERJ INTERJ
\l ‎‎They cried and said, “Ho! Ho! Ho!”

\t simo silɪnkʊgwa paasi , puu !”
\g 10-one 10-NARR-fall-FV 16-below of_falling_down
\l Some fell down, “Splat!”

\t baabɪɪka amɪɪsi pamooto …
\g 2-SUBSEC-put-FV AUG-6-water 16-3-fire …
\l (intended: They light the fire. Then they wash the cooking utensils. Then they put the water on the fire …')

\t baasanjʊla nɪɪnywili …
\g 2-SUBSEC-comb-FV COM=AUG-hair(10) _
\l (intended: Long ago they used to dance a lot. They dressed well. They bathed. They combed their hair …')

\t po piitaasi ʊnnyambala jʊla alɪnkʊja mundʊ gwa kʊfunga ɪɪsafalɪ jaake jaa kʊbʊʊka kʊno baliko bala , kʊkʊmela ɪfyʊma
\g then later AUG-1-man 1-DIST 1-NARR-be(come)-FV 1-person 1-ASSOC 15-tie-FV AUG-journey(9)(<SWA) 9-POSS.SG 9-ASSOC 15-go-FV 17-PROX 2-COP=17 2-DIST 17-15-claim-FV AUG-8-rich
\l Then later that man started to set out for where they were, in order to claim the brideprice.

\t bo afikile kʊla bammwambɪlɪla kanunu
\g as 1-arrive-PFV 17-DIST 2-SUBSEC-1-receive-FV well
\l When he arrived there, they received him well.

\t aalya
\g 1-SUBSEC-eat-FV
\l He ate.

\t aagona
\g 1-SUBSEC-rest-FV
\l He slept.

\t po kɪlaabo ammwega ʊnkyameni nʊkʊm̩bʊʊla ɪsi sintwele pala
\g then 7-tomorrow 1.SUBSEC-1-take-FV AUG-1-chairman(<EN) COM=AUG-15-1-tell-FV AUG-PROX.10 10-1-carry.PFV 16-DIST
\l The next day he contacted a chairman and told him what brought him there.

\t po balɪnkwanda boope bo bʊkiile nʊlʊbʊnjʊ
\g then 2-NARR-begin-FV 2-also as 14-dawn-PFV COM=AUG-11-morning
\l Early in the morning they started.

\t balɪnkʊja bandʊ baa kooga booga

\l They began to bath.

\t baafwala kanunu
\g 2-SUBSEC-dress/wear-FV well
\l They got dressed up.

\t balɪnkʊja bandʊ baa kʊpinya ɪmisigo gyabo nʊkʊbʊʊka

\t alɪnkʊpimba ʊbʊfu bwake n̩goosi
\g 1-NARR-load-FV AUG-14-flour 14-POSS.SG N.
\l Ngoosi lifted that flour.

\t iitwɪka pantʊ
\g 1.SUBSEC.REFL-lift_to_head-FV 16-3-head
\l She loaded it on her head.

\t baalɪnkwendelela nɪɪsafalɪ

\l They continued their journey.

\g then 2-NARR-continue-FV REDUPL∼PROX.14
\l Thus they continued.

\t baaja kʊfika nkyeni kangɪ

\l They got further ahead.

\t mwandugutu aabʊʊkile

\l Mr. Tugutu went.

\t aabapaalile abanine bahaano …
\g 1-PST-2-invite-PFV AUG-2-companion 2-five _
\l He gathered five companions …

\t kangɪ maelɪ jɪngɪ jɪmo aalɪm̩bɪɪkile mwandugutu nnine …
\g again mile(9)(<EN) 9-other 9-one 1-PST-1-put-PFV matronym=9-t.o.bird 1-companion _
\l Another mile, he placed a fellow Mr. Tugutu …

\t na kʊlʊmalɪɪkɪlo , maelɪ gaa bʊhaano mwandugutu ʊjʊngɪ

\l At the finish line, the fifth mile, another Mr. Tugutu.

\t po mwandugutu ʊjʊngɪ , jʊla baajobaga na kalʊlʊ aaja pabwandɪlo pala
\g then matronym=9-t.o.bird AUG-1-other 1-DIST 2-PST-speak-IPFV COM hare(1) 1-SUBSEC-be(come)-FV 16-14-start 16-DIST
\l ‎‎The other Mr. Tugutu, the one who had been talking with Hare, he then was at the start.

\t balɪnkwabʊla , balɪnkʊgwaga ʊntʊ gwa gwise gwa n̩goosi gʊliko kʊbʊfu bʊla
\g 2-NARR-open-FV 2-NARR-3-find-FV AUG-3-head 1-ASSOC his_father(1) 1-ASSOC N. 3-COP=17 17-14-flour 14-DIST
\l They opened it [sack], they found that Ngoosi's father's head was in that flour.

\t ʊnnyambala jʊla aalondaga ʊkʊbopa , ʊn̩dʊme gwa n̩goosi
\g AUG-1-man 1-DIST 1-PST-try-IPFV AUG-15-run-FV AUG-1-husband 1-ASSOC N.
\l That man, Ngoosi's husband, was trying to run away.

\t bankola pala∼pala
\g 2-SUBSEC-1-grasp-FV REDUPL∼16-DIST
\l They caught him right there.

\l He [Pig] ran.

\l He broke Duck's head.

\l The livestock owner ran.

\g 1.SUBSEC.take-FV AUG-3-knife

\g then 18-7-room 18-DIST 1-SUBSEC-be(come)-FV 1-self just

\g then 1-self N. COM 1-1-husband 2-PST-be(come)-IPFV COM=AUG-7-room 7-POSS.PL
\l Ngoosi and her husband, they had their own room.

\t po piibalasi pala jaajapo ɪɪmeesa apa paa∼pa n̩goosi aatʊʊlile ʊbʊfu bwake
\g then 16-5-veranda 16-DIST 9-SUBSEC-be(come)-FV=16 AUG-table(9)(<SWA) AUG-PROX.16 REDUPL∼PROX.16 N. 1-PST-take_from_head-PFV AUG-14-flour 14-POSS.SG
\l On the veranda there was a table where Ngoosi had put the flour.

\t aanyakile ʊlwala
\g 1-PST-snatch-PFV AUG-11-grindstone
\l He [Monkey] snatched the grindstone.

\l He ran with that grindstone.

\l He went [=ran] into the bush.' [Monkey and Tortoise]

\t po kajamba ʊnnine alɪnkʊtɪ ndaga”
\g then tortoise(1) AUG-1-companion 1-NARR-say thanks
\l Tortoise's child said Thanks.”

\t po bingɪla mun̩gʊnda
\g then 2-SUBSEC.enter-FV 18-3-field
\l They entered the farm.

\t beega amasɪmbɪ
\g 2-SUBSEC.take-FV AUG-6-cocoyam
\l They took cocoyam.

\g 2-SUBSEC.take-FV 5-sidedish
\l They took a side dish.

\t beega fyosa
\g 2-SUBSEC.take-FV 8-all
\l They took all sorts of food.

\t alɪnkʊkoolela abanyambala amilile abaana !”
\g 1-NARR-call-FV AUG-2-man 1-devour-PFV AUG-2-child
\l She called to the men, She's devoured the children!”

\t po abanyambala banda ʊkʊbopa
\g then AUG-2-man 2-SUBSEC.begin-FV AUG-15-run-FV
\l [Some of the] men began to run.

\t banda ʊkʊbopa
\g 2-SUBSEC.begin-FV AUG-15-run-FV
\l They [some other men] began to run.

\t tʊkwa kʊkina
\g 1PL-PRS-go.FV 15-play-FV
\l We will go and play.

\t aatʊkwa kʊkina
\g FUT=1PL-PRS-go.FV 15-play-FV
\l We will go and play (at some distant time).

\t twisakwa kʊkina
\g 1PL-INDEF.FUT-go.FV 15-play-FV
\l We might go and play.

\t aatwisakwa kʊkina
\g FUT=1PL-INDEF.FUT-go.FV 15-play-FV
\l We might go and play (at some distant time).

\t lɪnga ʊliile , aakʊfwa
\g if/when 2SG-eat-PFV FUT=2SG.PRS-die-FV
\l If you eat it, you will die.

\t komma ʊkʊbʊʊka , amɪɪsi aagikʊja matalalɪfu
\g PROH AUG-15-go-FV AUG-6-water FUT=6-PRS-be(come)-FV 6-cold
\l Don't go, the water will be cold.

\t lɪnga ngʊlile angʊjenga ɪɪnyumba ɪɪnywamu
\g if/when 1SG-grow-PFV FUT=1SG-PRS-build-FV AUG-house(9) AUG-big(9)
\l When I am grown up, I will build a big house.

\t naamajolo angʊjapo pakaaja
\g COM=AUG-6-evening FUT=1SG-PRS-be(come)-FV=16 16-12-homestead
\l In the evening I will be at home.

\t #aaikʊkina ʊmpɪla
\g #FUT=1-PRS-play-FV AUG-3-ball
\l [][l](intended: He will be [=presumably he is] playing football.')

\t #aasikʊja nɪnjala
\g #FUT=10-PRS-be(come)-FV COM=AUG-9-hunger
\l [][l](intended: They will be [=presumably they are] hungry.')

\t po kajamba aatɪ hee . gʊʊhobokelege . lɪlɪno ndɪ nɪnjɪla . nsumwike kwa ɗaaɗa gwangʊ . alɪ nɪfyɪnja mia mooja . po abɪɪkile ʊbʊfumbwe
\g then tortoise(1) 1-SUBSEC-say INTERJ 2SG.1SG-be(come)_happy-APPL-IPFV.SUBJ now/today 1SG-COP COM=AUG-9-path 1SG-depart.PFV 17-ASSOC sister(1)(SWA) 1-POSS.1SG 1-COP COM=AUG-8-year one(SWA) hundred(SWA). then 1-put-PFV AUG-14-concern
\l Tortoise said “Hee. Forgive me. Now I am travelling. I'm heading to my sister's. She is a hundred years old. She has made an invitation.

\t po lee kookʊno ngʊbʊʊka . po leelo ɪɪheela jaako aakwegaga kangɪ bo niisile”
\g then now/but REF.17=17-PROX 1SG-PRS-go-FV then now/but AUG-money(9) 9-POS.2SG FUT=2SG.MOD.FUT-take-MOD.FUT again as 1SG-come-PFV
\l There I'm going. Your money you shall take when I've come back.”

\t po mwangambɪlɪ aatɪ ee , haya ! mma po angwisa kangɪ” . alɪnkʊbʊʊka kʊkaaja
\g then matronym-9-monkey 1-SUBSEC-say yes OK(<SWA) no then FUT=1SG-PRS-come-FV again 1-NARR-go-FV 17-12-homestead
\l Mr. Monkey said “Yes, OK. I'll come again.” He went home.

\t ee , alɪ nago lwele kʊkʊtɪ kɪlʊndɪ kikooga ɪndobo jɪmo . ʊgwe kʊlonda ʊnegege ɪndobo lwele , bʊle aakʊbwesya ?
\g yes, 1-COP COM=REF.6 eight every 7-leg 7-PRS-bathe-FV AUG-9-bucket 9-one AUG-2SG 2SG.PRS-want-FV 2SG-draw_liquid-IPFV.SUBJ AUG-10-bucket eight Q FUT=2SG.PRS-overcome-FV
\l Yes, it [Spider] has eight legs, every leg bathes in one bucket. You, do you want to draw eight buckets full, will you bear that?' [Hare and Spider]

\t mma , ngʊbaaga . poope angʊbaaga
\g no 1SG-PRS-2-find-FV. 16-also FUT=1SG-PRS-2-find-FV
\l No, I'm finding them (sic!). Even then I'll find them.

\t lɪnga ʊliile , kʊfwa
\g if/when 2SG-eat-PFV 2SG.PRS-die-FV
\l If you eat it, you die (i.e. this is a known fact).

\t looli ɪsi ngʊbabʊʊla , aamusikolege fiijo lɪnga mfwile

\l The things I tell you, you must stick to when I'm dead.

\t aaikʊja pakʊjenga
\g FUT=1-PRS-be(come)-FV 16-15-build-FV
\l He will be building.

\t aatʊkwa kʊkina ʊmpɪla
\g FUT=1PL-PRS-go.FV 15-play-FV AUG-3-ball
\l We will go and play football (at some distant time).

\t palʊbʊnjʊ aatwisakʊkina ʊmpɪla
\g 16-11-morning FUT=1PL-INDEF.FUT-play-FV AUG-3-ball
\l The day after tomorrow we might play football.

\t naamajolo bakaalɪ aabikʊmoga
\g COM=AUG-6-evening 2-PERS FUT=2-PRS-dance-FV
\l In the evening they will still be dancing.

\t leelo ʊne nikʊlaalʊʊsya nikʊtɪ: kalɪ bisakʊloboka bʊle∼bʊle palwɪsi ? namanga ʊlwɪsi lʊlʊʊ∼lʊ kɪsiba , kangɪ ɪngwina nyingi fiijo; mwene mum̩bwato mo bikʊsʊʊbɪla ʊkwenda
\g now/but AUG-1SG 1SG-PRS-ask-FV 1SG-PRS-say Q 2-INDEF.FUT-cross_over_water-FV REDUPL∼how 16-11-river because AUG-11-river REDUPL∼PROX.11 7-pond again AUG-10-crocodile 10-many INTENS 18-only 18-18-boat(1)(<EN) REF.18 2-PRS-hope-FV AUG-15-walk/travel-FV
\l Now I ask and say: How will they cross the river? Because this river is very deep and the crocodiles are many. Only in a boat they can travel.

\t bʊle gwe mwinangʊ , gwe kʊbala ɪɪnongwa sisii∼si , kʊtɪ fiki , kwinogona sabikʊloboka bʊle∼bʊle ?
\g Q 2SG 1-my_companion 2SG 15-read-FV AUG-issue(10) REDUPL∼PROX.10 2SG.PRS-say 8-what 2SG.PRS-think-FV come=2-PRS-cross_over_water-FV REDUPL∼how
\l You, my friend, who you are reading these words, how do you think that they will cross over?' (; orthography adapted)

\t ʊntwa alɪnkʊjoba alɪnkʊtɪ musyaganie ɪsi ikʊjoba ʊn̩dongi ʊnniongafu !” bʊle , Kyala atikʊbalongela kanunu abasʊngʊligwa baake , aba bikʊn̩dɪlɪla pamuusi na pakɪlo ? bʊle , isaikʊkaabɪla ʊkʊbatʊʊla ?
\g AUG-1-lord 1-NARR-speak-FV 1-NARR-say 2PL-10-find-RECP-CAUS-SUBJ AUG-PROX.10 1-PRS-speak-FV AUG-1-judge AUG-1-twisted Q God(1) 1-NEG-PRS-2-judge-FV well AUG-2-selected 2-POSS.SG AUG-PROX.2 2-PRS-1-lament-FV 16-3-daytime COM 16-7-night Q come=1-PRS-be_late-FV AUG-15-2-help-FV?
\l And the Lord said, Hear what the unjust judge saith. And shall no God avenge his own elect, which cry day and night unto him, though he bear long with them?

\t ngʊbabʊʊla ʊkʊtɪ , Kyala ikʊbalongela m̩bɪbɪ∼m̩bɪbɪ ɪfi bikʊlondigwa ʊkʊkaba . looli bo ikwisa nnyamundʊ , bʊle , isaikʊbaaga abandʊ aba bikʊmmwitɪka ?
\g 1SG-PRS-2PL-tell-FV COMP God 1-PRS-2-judge-FV REDUPL∼fast AUG-PROX.8 2-PRS-want-PASS-FV AUG-15-get-FV but as 1-PRS-come-FV 1-kinship-1-person Q come=1-PRS-2-find-FV AUG-2-person AUG-PROX.2 2-PRS-1-believe-FV
\l I tell you that he will avenge them speedily. Nevertheless when the Son of man cometh, shall he find faith on earth?' (Luke 18: 6–8)

\t po piibalasi jaajapo ɪɪmeesa apa paa∼pa N̩goosi aatʊʊlile ʊbʊfu bwake , bʊla bajile kʊsya , ʊbʊ naaikʊbʊʊka nabo ʊgwise
\g then 16-5-veranda(<SWA) 9-SUBSEC-be(come)-FV=16 AUG-table(9)(<SWA) AUG-PROX.16 REDUPL∼PROX.16 N. 1-PST-take_from_head-PFV AUG-14-flour 14-POSS.SG 16-DIST 2-go-PFV 15-grind-FV AUG-PROX.14 FUT=1-PRS-go-FV COM=REF.14 AUG-his_father(1)
\l On the veranda there was a table where Ngoosi had put the flour that they had gone to grind, the one that her father would go with.

\t po ʊmundʊ jʊla ʊgwa kɪlɪngo alɪnkwamula , alɪnkʊtɪ apa bo silɪ bʊno∼bʊno , ʊne ndekile , ngabagɪla ʊkʊʊla paapo nangwisa koonanga ɪkɪlɪngo kya baanangʊ abaa kwisa kwingɪlapo pamyangʊ”
\g then AUG-1-person 1-DIST AUG-1-ASSOC 7-inheritance 1-NARR-answer-FV 1-NARR-say AUG-PROX.16 as 10-COP REDUPL∼14-DEM AUG-1SG 1SG-let-PFV 1SG-NEG-be_able-FV AUG-15-buy-FV because FUT=1SG-PRS-come-FV 15-destroy-FV AUG-7-inheritance 7-ASSOC 2-my_child AUG-2-ASSOC 15-come-FV 15-enter-FV=16 16-4-POSS.1SG
\l And the kinsman said I cannot redeem it for myself, lest I mar mine own inheritance [lit. …I cannot buy it because I will come to destroy the inheritance of my children who will come to succeed me]') (Ruth 4:6)

\t tʊtike ɪmbilipili tʊbɪɪke ntʊsupa . tʊkwa kʊsisopela paapo ɪsyene sikwa kʊtɪgɪ bikʊtʊpa ɪfindʊ”
\g 1PL-pound-SUBJ AUG-9-pepper 1PL-put-SUBJ 18-13-bottle 1PL-PRS-go.FV 15-10-throw-APPL-FV because AUG-10-self 10-PRS-go.FV 15-say-IPFV 2-PRS-1PL-give-FV AUG-8-food
\l We should pound pepper and put it in little bottles. Then we will go throw them at them [monkeys], for they'll think “they're throwing food.”' (Thieving Monkeys)

\t ngʊsʊʊma mwege ʊlʊgoje , mumbinye ɪmbʊlʊkʊtʊ . mukole fiijo , musulusyege panandɪ∼panandɪ . lɪnga mfikile ngwa kʊjɪgɪsya ʊlʊgoje , ʊmwe mukʊlekesyaga
\g 1SG-PRS-beg-FV 2PL-take-SUBJ AUG-11-rope 2PL-1SG-bind-SUBJ AUG-10-ear 1PL-grasp-SUBJ INTENS 2PL-lower-IPFV.SUBJ REDUPL∼a_little if/when 1SG-arrive-PFV 1SG-PRS-go.FV 15-shake-FV AUG-11-rope AUG-2PL 2PL-MOD.FUT-let-CAUS-MOD.FUT
\l I beg you (pl.) to take a rope and tie it to my ears. Hold it tight, lower it step by step. When I arrive [at the ground] I will shake the rope and you shall let go of it.' [Hare and Spider]

\t ngwa kwisa nʊnkamu gwangʊ ʊnnywamu fiijo

\t bisakʊkʊtika
\g 2-INDEF.FUT-2SG-pound-FV

\t kʊkʊtɪ mundʊ fikʊtɪ ajege nʊtʊndʊ toosa ʊtʊ tʊkʊlondigwa ʊkʊbombela ɪmbombo syake

\t baatɪ po ɪlindʊ ɪlɪ tʊlɪgoge ʊkʊtɪ twege ɪkɪsipa kɪla mwipango , tʊtwale kʊn̩ganga . akam̩bujɪsye ʊmwana

\t isaga tʊbʊʊke tʊkam̩bʊʊle ʊnkʊlʊmba gwɪtʊ gwa finyamaana fyosa ɪɪsofu ʊkʊtɪ akoolele ʊlʊkomaano

\t mbagiile ʊkʊkʊtola ʊgwe ʊkʊbopa ʊlʊbɪlo , paapo kwenda panandɪ∼panandɪ . mbagiile ʊkʊtɪ ngafike kʊbʊmalɪɪkɪsyo nʊkʊgomoka bo ʊkaalɪ ʊlɪ pala∼pala ngʊlekile

\t aabʊngeenie amatunda ʊkʊtɪ lʊmo akʊʊlɪsye

\t ngʊbaasima , looli aamungasobesya ɪɪsindaano jangʊ

\l He told me not to work.

\t tʊngajaga nɪfinyonyo bo ɪɪfubu ɪjɪ jaafwile kʊʊnongwa ɪjaa filonda bo jɪkʊlonda ʊbʊnunu
\g 1PL-NEG.SUBJ-be(come)-IPFV COM=AUG-8-desire as AUG-hippo(9) AUG-PROX.9 9-PST-die-PFV 17-issue(9) AUG-9-ASSOC 8-wound as 9-PRS-search-FV AUG-14-beauty
\l We should not have desire like Hippo, who died because of his sores, when he was looking for beauty.

\t n̩dʊme gwangʊ , tʊlonde fimo ɪfya kʊntegela kalʊlʊ ʊkʊtɪ iikole tʊn̩goge . angandɪsya ʊkʊlya ɪfilombe fyɪtʊ paapo ikʊmala
\g 1-husband 1-POSS.1SG 1PL-search-SUBJ 8-one AUG-8-ASSOC 15-1-trap-APPL-FV hare(1) COMP 1.REFL-grasp/hold-SUBJ 1PL-1-kill-SUBJ 1-NEG.SUBJ-begin-CAUS-FV AUG-15-eat-FV AUG-8-maize 8-POSS.1PL because 1-PRS-finish-FV
\l My husband, let's look for something to trap Hare, so that he gets caught and we kill him. He mustn't eat our maize again, because he's finishing it.

\t balɪnkwinogona ʊkʊtɪ tʊbʊʊke tʊkiipe ɪlyʊndʊ ɪlya kʊgelekela kʊmwanya” ʊkʊtɪ bangɪtoonyeligwaga

\t abaganga bankaniisye ʊkʊtɪ angakina ʊmpɪla

\t ijolo n̩dwiho lwa baNyakyʊsa baalɪ naakajɪɪlo ka nkiikʊlʊ ʊkʊntiila ʊgwise gwa n̩dʊme , ʊjʊ tʊkʊtɪ nkamwana .

\l Long ago in the tradition of the Nyakyusa people they had a custom of the woman fearing the father of her husband, whom we call Nkamwana.

\g AUG-1-old 1-PST-say-PFV yes 2PL-rest-PFV 2PL 2-who AUG-2-young_person 2-PST-say-PFV REF.1 AUG-1PL 1PL-be_lost-PFV AUG-9-path 9-POSS.1PL 1PL-DESDTV-rest-FV=18

\t looli kalʊlʊ akaameenye ʊkʊkwela mmwanya , alɪnkʊlʊbʊʊla ʊlʊbʊbi alɪnkʊtɪ ʊne ngamanya ʊkʊkwela mmwanya”

\l Here I stay, I'll turn myself over. The legs will look up. ‎‎You'll search for a stone and grasp it. You'll put maize on top of me.

\t leelo lɪnga ʊgwise gwa nnyambala n̩gaala bwalwa kʊlʊsako ʊlʊnunu lɪnga ʊnkasi gwa mwanaake ikʊkɪnda pala ʊgwise gwa n̩dʊme ikʊmilwa mmɪɪsi jɪkʊja ngafu kʊʊnongwa jaa bʊgaala bwalwa bwake .
\g now/but if/when AUG-his_father(1) 1-ASSOC 1-man 1-drink 14-alcohol 17-11-luck AUG-11-good if/when AUG-1-wife 1-ASSOC 1-his_child 1-PRS-pass-FV 16-DIST AUG-his_father(1) 1-ASSOC 1-husband 1-PRS-drown-FV 18-6-water 9-PRS-be(come)-FV 9-difficult 17-issue(9) 9-ASSOC 14-drink 14-alcohol 14-POSS.SG
\l But if the father of the man is a drunkard and if by chance the wife of his child passes by while the father of her husband is drowning in the water, it is difficult because of his drinking.

\t bʊle ʊnkiikʊlʊ ʊjo ikʊbombaga fiki ? … kalɪ ikʊn̩dekaga afwege mmɪɪsi kʊʊnongwa jaa kʊtiila ʊkʊkilania ɪmbaatɪko paapo akam̩bonola ?

\t nkiisʊ kɪmo , aaliko ʊmalafyale jʊmo . ɪngamu jaake aalɪ jo Kapyungu
\g 18-7-land 7-one 1-PST-COP=17 AUG-chief(1) 1-one AUG-9-name 9-POSS.SG 1-PST-COP REF.1 K.
\l In some land there was a chief. His name was Kapyungu.

\t ʊmalafyale ʊjʊ aalɪ nɪfipanga fitatʊ
\g AUG-chief(1) AUG-PROX.1 1-PST-COP COM=AUG-8-village 8-three
\l This chief had three villages.

\t lɪnga ʊkaja nʊbʊjo bwa kʊgonamo kʊgona muunyumba ɪsya kʊpanga

\t ngaa nambombo , ngaa naheela

\l I don't have a job, I don't have money.

\t kangɪ mpaka ʊsikeete taasi ɪndalama ɪsi ʊlɪ nasyo muunyambɪ , pamopeene nʊtʊndʊ ʊtʊ tʊbagiile ʊkʊkʊtʊʊla kʊmbombo ɪjo

\l Again, you should first look at the money which you have in your pocket, together with other things which can help you with this work.

\t lɪlɪno tʊkaa nafyo nafimo ɪfindʊ ɪfya kʊlya nnyumba

\l The dog became very angry, it was thinking that maybe the cheetah would seize his meat.

\t ʊgwa kɪbɪlɪ aalʊkolile ʊlwigi mmaka matupu . looli joope kwalɪlile kwatile káa”

\t gwitɪke ʊtɪ ee , ndipo”

\t mwandugutu akaabopilepo . aabapaalile abanine . bo aba aababɪɪkile ʊkʊtɪ maelɪ jɪmo , maelɪ jɪmo , maelɪ jɪmo

\t po lɪnga ababʊʊlile abapaapi baake pamo ʊgwise gwa n̩dʊmyana jʊla , aajaga kʊnsʊʊmɪla kʊgwise gwa nkiikʊlʊ ʊkʊtɪ ʊmwanaako , ngʊlonda ʊkʊtɪ eegigwege nʊmwanangʊ”
\g then if/when 1-2-tell-PFV AUG-2-parent 2-POSS.SG or AUG-his_father(1) 1-ASSOC 1-boy 1-DIST 1-PST-go-IPFV 15-1-beg-APPL-FV 17-his_father(1) 1-ASSOC 1-woman COMP AUG-1-your_child 1SG-PRS-want-FV COMP 1.marry-PASS-IPFV.SUBJ COM=AUG-1-my_child

\t po jaatɪ niine ngʊbʊʊka bo akajapo maama jʊla ʊnkiikʊlʊ .” po bo jɪbʊʊkile ɪɪsota joope jaajile kwɪmba

\l Skunk also went, he (went and) searched for leaves. He came with those leaves, while Hare was asleep.

\t aafumile naamaka nkiina mula . aanyeelile aajile kʊtɪ tuu !” piisɪɪlya

\t po alɪnkʊgoloka , alɪnkʊgoloka . alɪnkwa kʊfika kʊjengiigwe kʊnunu fiijo . po alɪnkwa kʊbaaga balɪndɪlɪli baa kaaja kala . balɪnkʊn̩daalʊʊsya balɪnkʊtɪ kʊlonda fiki ?”

\l She went straight, she went straight. She (went and) arrived at a place well built. She (went and) met the guards of that village. They asked What do you want?”

\t po kanunu ʊkʊja m̩bombi gwabo kʊkabalɪlo akaa kʊlonda ʊkʊkaba ɪndalama ɪsya kʊʊlɪla ɪfibombelo , ɪfya kwisa kʊbombela kɪsita kʊlʊmbʊʊsigwa

\t Kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊbʊʊka kʊlʊbʊbi kʊkʊlaalʊʊsya lɪnga lʊmmwagile ʊnkiikʊlʊ

\l Thus they travelled, travelled, travelled and travelled.

\t ɪngwina jiisaga nkʊjeega ɪngambɪlɪ nʊkʊbʊʊka najo palʊsʊngo pakwangala
\g AUG-9-crocodile 9-PST.come-IPFV 18-15-9-take-FV AUG-9-monkey COM=AUG-15-go-FV COM=REF.9 16-11-island 16-15-be_well-FV
\l Crocodile used to come to pick up monkey and go with him to an island to spend time together.

\t ʊnhɪɪji ʊjʊ aalongwile nkyeni alɪnkwenda nʊkʊkola ʊlwigi
\g AUG-1-thief AUG-PROX.1 1-PST-lead.PFV 18-7-forehead 1-NARR-walk/travel-FV COM=AUG-15-grasp/hold-FV AUG-11-door
\l The thief who was going ahead then grabbed the door.

\t aagomoka ʊmwanike jʊla nʊkʊfika pakaaja pala nʊkʊm̩bʊʊla nʊkʊnnangɪsya ɪsi ʊn̩dʊme
\g 1-SUBSEC-return-FV AUG-1-young_person 1-DIST COM=AUG-15-arrive-FV 16-12-homestead 16-DIST COM=AUG-15-1-tell-FV COM=AUG-15-1-show-FV AUG-PROX.10 AUG-1-husband
\l That young woman returned and arrived at home and told and showed her husband these things.

\t nalooli ʊkʊkongana nʊlʊgano ʊlʊ aalɪ nalo n̩goosi alɪnkʊjonga nʊnnyambala jʊmo
\g really AUG-15-follow-RECP-FV COM=AUG-11-love AUG-PROX.11 1-PST-COP COM=REF.11 N. 1-NARR-run_away-FV COM=AUG-1-man 1-one
\l Because of the love that Ngoosi had, she eloped with a man.

\t ʊmundʊ ʊjʊ afumwike ʊkʊfuma patali

\l This person has been famous since long ago.

\t baajaatanilaga nʊkwangala pamopeene
\g 2-PST-walk-RECP-APPL-IPFV COM=AUG-15-be_well-FV together
\l They visited and accompanied each other.

\t iisikʊ lɪmo ʊnna gwa ngwina aalɪ m̩bine
\g 5-day 5-one AUG-1-his_mother 1-ASSOC 9-crocodile 1-PST-COP 1-ill
\l One day Crocodile's mother was sick.

\t bo jiitogile pamwanya pangwina ʊkʊbʊʊka kʊkʊnkeeta ʊnna gwa ngwina bo balɪ pakatɪ pamɪɪsi bikwenda ɪngwina jɪlɪnkwanda ʊkʊlɪla amasoosi
\g as 9-mount-PFV 16-high 16-9-crocodile AUG-15-go-FV 17-15-1-watch-FV AUG-1-his_mother 1-ASSOC 9-crocodile as 2-COP 16-middle 16-6-water 2-PRS-walk/travel-FV AUG-9-crocodile 9-NARR-begin-FV AUG-15-cry-FV AUG-6-tear
\l When monkey had mounted Crocodile, going to see Crocodile's mother, when they were travelling in the middle of the water, Crocodile started to cry.

\t po ɪngambɪlɪ jɪlɪnkʊtɪ fiki mmanyaani gwangʊ kʊlɪla ?”
\g then AUG-9-monkey 9-NARR-say 8-what 1-friend 1-POSS.1SG 2SG.PRS-cry-FV
\l Monkey said Why, my friend, are you crying?”

\t ɪngwina jɪlɪnkʊtɪ nsulumeenie fiijo paapo ʊlʊ niisile nkʊkwega ʊtikʊgomoka kangɪ
\g AUG-9-monkey 9-NARR-say 1SG-afflict.PFV INTENS because now 1SG-come-PFV 18-15-2SG-take-FV 2SG-NEG-PRS-return-FV again
\l Crocodile said I'm very sad, because this time that I've come to pick you up you won't return.”

\t po ɪngambɪlɪ jɪlɪnkʊtɪ fiki ndikʊgomoka kangɪ ?”
\g then AUG-9-monkey 9-NARR-say 8-what 1SG-NEG-PRS-return-FV again
\l Monkey said Why won't I return?”

\t ɪngwina jɪlɪnkʊtɪ twabʊʊkile kʊn̩ganga . ʊn̩ganga aatile jɪkʊlondigwa ɪndumbula jaa ngambɪlɪ . go nkota gwa jʊʊba gwangʊ . po ikʊpona
\g AUG-9-crocodile 9-NARR-say 1PL-PST-go-PFV 17-1-healer AUG-1-healer 1-PST-say-PFV 9-PRS-need-PASS-FV AUG-9-heart 9-ASSOC 9-monkey REF.3 3-medicine 3-ASSOC my_mother(1) 1-POSS.1SG then 1-PRS-heal-FV
\l Crocodile said: We went to a witch doctor. The witch doctor said that a monkey's heart is required. That is the medicine for my mother. Then she'll heal.”

\t ɪngambɪlɪ jɪlɪnkʊtɪ somma ʊkʊpaasya ! lee po keeta , ʊkaajobaga bo ʊkaalɪ ʊkʊʊnyeega ?”
\g AUG-9-crocodile 9-NARR-say PROH AUG-15-worry-FV now/but then watch-FV 2SG-NEG-PST-speak-IPFV as 2SG-PERS AUG-15-1SG-take-FV?
\l Monkey said Don't worry! Now look, why didn't you speak before picking me up?”

\t ɪngwina jɪlɪnkʊtɪ naapaasyaga ʊkʊtɪ aakʊkaana”

\l Crocodile said I was worrying that you would refuse.”

\t po ɪngambɪlɪ jɪlɪnkʊtɪ lɪno po ʊbombile kabiibi paapo ɪngambɪlɪ sitikʊja nɪndumbula mmunda . ɪngambɪlɪ tʊkʊsileka mmipiki . pala gʊʊnyaagile mumpiki ʊkafibona ɪfi fyasyutaga fiijo mula ?”
\g then AUG-9-monkey 9-NARR-say now/today then 2SG-do-PFV badly because AUG-10-monkey 10-NEG-PRS-be(come)-FV COM=AUG-10-heart 18-3?-inside_of_body AUG-10-monkey 1PL-PRS-10-let-FV 18-4-tree. 16-DIST 2SG-1SG-find-PFV 18-3-tree 2SG-NEG-8-see-FV AUG-PROX.8 8-PST-dangle-IPFV INTENS 18-DIST
\l Monkey said Now you did badly because monkeys don't have their hearts inside the body. Us monkeys we leave them in the trees. There where you met me, in the tree, didn't you see the things that were dangling in there?”

\t ɪngwina jɪlɪnkʊtɪ ee , mfibwene”
\g AUG-9-monkey 9-NARR-say yes, 1SG-8-see.PFV
\l Crocodile said Yes, I saw them.”

\t jɪlɪnkʊtɪ syo ndumbula syɪnʊ ɪsi silipo mula ? po ʊlʊ tʊgomoke , tʊkatʊngʊle jɪmo”

\l It said Are those your hearts in there? Then let's return, let's pick one.”

\t po ɪngwina jɪlɪnkʊgomoka mpaka kʊmbalɪ kʊlwɪsi
\g then AUG-9-crocodile 9-NARR-return-FV until 17-9-side 17-11-river
\l Crocodile returned to the shore of the river.

\t ɪngambɪlɪ jɪlɪnkʊbabʊʊla abanine
\g AUG-9-monkey 9-NARR-2-tell-FV AUG-2-companion
\l Monkey told the other monkeys.

\t jɪlɪnkʊfyʊka mumpiki gwa baamwembe

\g 1-NARR-10-tell-FV AUG-10-monkey AUG-companion.10
\l He told the other monkeys.

\t silɪnkwanda ʊkʊjɪtuunya naabaamwembe ɪngwina

\t fyobeene ɪngwina ʊm̩bɪlɪ gwake gʊkaja nnunu , paapo baajɪtuunyile fiijo

\l That is why, as for Crocodile, its body is not beautiful, because they threw at it hard.

\t jaalyandile ʊkʊbopa ʊkʊbopela mmɪɪsi

\t ʊbʊmanyaani bwa ngwina nɪngambɪlɪ bwamaliike

\t aka ko kapango
\g AUG-PROX.12 REF.12 12-story
\l This is the story.

\t po tʊkʊtɪ kalʊlʊ na nsyɪsyɪ baalɪ bamanyaani fiijo

\t bendaga boosa kʊkʊtɪ kʊno bikʊbʊʊka
\g 2-PST.walk/travel-IPFV 2-all every 17-PROX 2-PRS-go-FV
\l They went together wherever they went.

\t po leelo iisikʊ lɪmo kalʊlʊ na nsyɪsyɪ baabʊʊkile nkʊfwɪma
\g then now/but 5-day 5-one hare(1) COM skunk(1) 2-PST-go-PFV 18-15-hunt-FV
\l So one day Hare and Skunk went to hunt.

\t po bo bikʊfwɪma baakolile iikanga
\g then as 2-PRS-hunt-FV 2-PST-grasp/hold-PFV 5-guineafowl
\l When they were hunting they caught a guinea fowl.

\t po baahobwike fiijo
\g then 2-PST-be(come)_happy.PFV INTENS
\l They were very happy.

\t po balɪnkʊbʊʊka kʊkaaja
\g then 2-NARR-go-FV 17-12-homestead
\l They went home.

\t bo bafikile kʊkaaja baapeenyile iikanga lɪla

\l When they arrived home, they removed the feathers from that guinea fowl.

\t baapeenyile
\g 2-PST-remove_feathers-PFV
\l They removed feathers and removed feathers.

\t po baalyandile ʊkookya mmooto
\g then 2-PST-begin-PFV AUG-15-roast-FV 18-3-fire
\l They began to roast it over fire.

\t po bo bikookya po nsyɪsyɪ alɪnkʊm̩bʊʊla kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊtɪ ɪɪnyama jɪpiile , isaga tʊlyege !”
\g then as 2-PRS-roast-FV then skunk(1) 1-NARR-1-tell-FV hare(1) 1-NARR-say AUG-meat(9) 9-be(come)_burnt-PFV come-IPFV 1PL-eat-IPFV.SUBJ
\l As they were roasting, Skunk told Hare “The meat is done, come let's eat!”

\t po kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊtɪ taasi . jɪkaalɪ ʊkʊpya”
\g then hare(1) 1-NARR-say yet 9-PERS AUG-15-be(come)_burnt-FV

\t po nsyɪsyɪ alɪnkʊtɪ gwe jɪpiile . isaga tʊlyege !”
\g then skunk(1) 1-NARR-say 2SG 9-be(come)_burnt-PFV come-IPFV 1PL-eat-IPFV.SUBJ

\t kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊtɪ jɪkaalɪ ʊkʊpya”

\l Hare said “It's not yet done.”

\t aaliile pyʊ́
\g 1-PST-eat-PFV o.c.c.
\l He ate it up, he ate it up.

\t iisikʊ ɪlɪngɪ po balɪnkʊbʊʊka nkʊlambalala
\g 5-day AUG-5-other then 2-NARR-go-FV 18-15-lie_down-FV
\l ‎‎Another day they went to sleep.

\t po nsyɪsyɪ joope aabʊʊkile
\g then skunk(1) 1-also 1-PST-go-PFV
\l Skunk also went.

\t aajile kʊlonda amaani
\g 1-PST-go-PFV 15-search-FV AUG-6-leaf

\t aalɪnkupɪkiile pamwanya
\g 1-PST-1-cover.PFV 16-above
\l He covered him [with the leaves].

\t aakomile
\g 1-PST-hit-PFV
\l Then Skunk hit and hit and hit and hit him.

\t aabopile panja

\l He ran outside.

\t aasookile panja

\l He went outside.

\t po kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊlembʊka
\g then hare(1) 1-NARR-awake-FV
\l Then Hare woke up.

\t ikʊkuuta hɪhɪɪ . bangomile , bangomile , bangomile”

\t po nsyɪsyɪ jwani akʊkomile ?”

\t ndɪɪsi , ndɪɪsi , ndɪɪsi . ndɪɪsi , ndɪɪsi . bangomile .”

\l [Hare:] I don't know. I don't know, I don't know.”

\t po bo bafikile pala kalʊlʊ aalyegile ɪngoma

\t aalyandile ʊkʊkoma naaliile joosa ɪɪnyama mmooto . ndɪnkʊtɪ jɪbwesile . ndɪnkʊtɪ jɪbwesile”
\g 1-PST-begin-PFV AUG-15-hit-FV 1SG-PST-eat-PFV 9-all AUG-meat(9) 18-3-fire 1SG-NARR-say 9-be_burnt_down-PFV 1SG-NARR-say 9-be_burnt_down-PFV”
\l He began to beat it I ate all the meat on the fire. I said it had burnt. I said it had burnt.”

\t po nsyɪsyɪ alɪnkʊpɪlɪkɪsya
\g then skunk(1) 1-NARR-listen-FV
\l Skunk listened.

\t po bo abɪɪkile paasi ɪngoma joope nsyɪsyɪ eega ɪngoma
\g then as 1-put-PFV 16-below AUG-9-t.o.drum 1-also skunk(1) 1.SUBSEC.take-FV AUG-9-t.o.drum

\t aalyandile ʊkʊkoma ɪngoma ʊkʊtɪ naalɪkomile , naalɪkomile . naalɪkomile∼lɪkomile paanyuma”
\g 1-PST-begin-PFV AUG-15-hit-FV AUG-9-t.o.drum AUG-15-say 1SG-PST-5-hit-PFV 1SG-PST-5-hit-PFV 1SG-PST-REDUPL∼5-hit-PFV 16-back(9)
\l He started to beat the drum saying ”I beat him, I beat him. I beat him on the back.”

\t po kalʊlʊ alɪnkʊpɪlɪkɪsya
\g then hare(1) 1-NARR-listen-FV
\l Hare listend.

\t po bo ikʊpɪlɪkɪsya po aasumwike kalʊlʊ
\g then as 1-PRS-listen-FV then 1-PST-depart.PFV hare(1)
\l As he was listening, Hare stood up.

\t alɪnkʊm̩bʊʊla nsyɪsyɪ ngɪmba jo ʊgwe gwalɪngomile ?”
\g 1-NARR-1-tell-FV skunk(1) behold REF.1 AUG-2SG 2SG-PST-1SG-hit-PFV
\l He told Skunk So it was you who beat me!?

\t joope nsyɪsyɪ alɪnkʊtɪ ngɪmba jo ʊgwe gwaliile ɪɪnyama joosa ?
\g 1-also skunk(1) 1-NARR-say behold REF.1 AUG-2SG 2SG-PST-eat-PFV AUG-meat(9) 9-all
\l Also Skunk said So you ate all the meat!?

\t ngɪmba jo ʊgwe gwalɪngomile .”
\g behold REF.1 AUG-2SG 2SG-PST-1SG-hit-PFV
\l [Hare:] So you beat me!?”

\t ngʊtɪ jo ʊgwe gwaliile ɪɪnyama joosa .””
\g 1SG-PRS-say REF.1 AUG-2SG 2SG-PST-eat-PFV AUG-meat(9) 9-all
\l [Skunk:] I'm saying You ate all the meat.””

\t ngʊtɪ ngɪmba jo ʊgwe gwalɪngomile ?” ngʊkwania”
\g 1SG-PRS-say behold 1.REF AUG-2SG 2SG-PST-1SG-hit-PFV 1SG-PRS-2SG-ask-FV
\l [Hare:] I'm saying It was you who beat me?” I'm asking you.”

\t ngɪmba jo ʊgwe gwaliile ɪɪnyama joosa”
\g behold REF.1 AUG-2SG 2SG-PST-eat-PFV AUG-meat(9) 9-all
\l [Skunk:] So you ate all the meat.”

\t po baalyangɪleene mum̩bɪlɪ
\g then 2-PST-catch-RECP.PFV 18-3-body
\l They grasped each other's bodies.

\t kolaana , kolaana , kolaana baakoleene
\g grasp/hold-RECP-FV grasp/hold-RECP-FV grasp/hold-RECP-FV 2-PST-grasp/hold-RECP.PFV
\l Holding each other, holding each other, holding each other, they held each other.

\t po kalʊlʊ aalɪnkolile nsyɪsyɪ
\g then hare(1) 1-PST-1-grasp/hold-PFV skunk(1)
\l Hare grasped Skunk.

\t aalɪm̩bindile kʊkanwa
\g 1-PST-1-squeeze-PFV 17-12-mouth
\l He squeezed around his [Skunk's] snout.

\t aalyandile ʊkʊbinda kʊkanwa
\g 1-PST-begin-PFV AUG-15-squeeze-FV 17-12-mouth
\l He began to squeeze around his snout.

\t po joope nsyɪsyɪ aakolile ɪmbʊlʊkʊtʊ sya kalʊlʊ
\g then 1-also skunk(1) 1-PST-grasp/hold-PFV AUG-10-ear 10-ASSOC hare(1)
\l Also Skunk grasped Hare's ears.

\t aalyandile ʊkʊluusa , ʊkʊluusa
\g 1-PST-begin-FV AUG-15-pull-FV AUG-15-pull-PFV
\l He started to pull, to pull.

\t balɪnkʊlwa
\g 2-NARR-fight-FV
\l They fought and fought and fought.

\t po leelo jaaliisile ɪmbwa
\g then now/but 9-PST-come-PFV AUG-9-dog
\l Then Dog came.

\t jaatile ʊmwe namuleke ʊkʊlwa !”
\g 9-PST-say-PFV AUG-2PL COM=2PL-let-SUBJ AUG-15-fight-FV
\l He said “You (pl.), now stop fighting!”

\t po baalekeene
\g then 2-PST-let-RECP.PFV
\l They released each other.

\t po lʊʊ∼lʊ nsyɪsyɪ kʊbobonjeele kʊkanwa
\g then REDUPL∼now skunk(1) 17-be(come)_flat.PFV 17-12-mouth
\l So now Skunk is flat at the snout.

\t kalʊlʊ , ɪmbʊlʊkʊtʊ ndali
\g hare(1) AUG-10-ear 10-long
\l As for Hare, his ears are long.

\t akasumo kaa kʊmoga
\g AUG-12-custom 12-ASSOC 15-dance-FV
\l The custom of dancing.

\t baalipo abandʊ ba ijolo abatasi
\g 2-PST-COP=16 AUG-2-person 2-ASSOC old_times AUG-2-ancestor
\l There were the people of old times, the ancestors.

\t baalɪ niipenenga
\g 2-PST-COP COM=5-type_of_drum
\l They had the Penenga drum.

\t ɪndingala ɪjɪ jaajobigwaga ʊkʊtɪ iipenenga
\g AUG-9-drum AUG-PROX.9 9-PST-speak-PASS-IPFV COMP 5-penenga
\l This drum was called Penenga.

\t po ʊlʊsumo lwake baamogaga fiijo
\g then AUG-11-custom 11-POSS.SG 2-PST-dance-IPFV INTENS
\l As to its custom, they danced much.

\t kʊkʊmoga kwake baafwalaga kanunu fiijo
\g 17-15-dance-FV 15-POSS.SG 2-PST-dress/wear-IPFV well INTENS
\l For the dancing they dressed well.

\t boogaga fiijo
\g 2-PST.bathe-IPFV INTENS
\l They bathed well.

\t bamo baasanjʊlaga nɪɪnywili
\g 2-one 2-PST-comb-IPFV COM=AUG-hair(10)
\l Some combed their hair.

\t syafyʊkaga fiijo
\g 10-PST-climb-IPFV INTENS
\l It stood much.

\t baasanjʊlaga
\g 2-PST-comb-IPFV
\l They combed it.

\t baatɪgɪ ɪfibwesi
\g 2-PST-say-IPFV AUG-8-type_of_hairstyle
\l They called it Fibwesi [hairstyle].

\t bamo baasanjʊlaga
\g 2-one 2-PST-comb-IPFV
\l Some combed it.

\t baabɪɪkaga nɪɪsyɪti
\g 2-PST-put-IPFV COM=AUG-parting(9)
\l They parted it.

\t baakolaga naamakoma ng'ombe gaa kʊmogela
\g 2-PST-grasp/hold-IPFV COM=AUG-6-hit cow(9) 6-ASSOC 15-dance-APPL-FV
\l They also used whips for dancing.

\t gaajaga amafume fiijo
\g 6-PST-be(come)-IPFV AUG-6-embroidered INTENS
\l They were nicely embroidered.

\t gaafwanaga mundʊ atikʊkolapo
\g 6-PST-resemble-IPFV 1-person 1-NEG-PRS-grasp/hold-FV=PART
\l They [were so clean that it] appeared as if a person never held them at all.

\t looli leelo ngɪmba abandʊ bikʊkola kʊʊnongwa jaa kʊtɪ abandʊ bala baajaga biifyʊsi fiijo
\g but now/but behold AUG-2-person 2-PRS-grasp/hold-FV 17-issue(9) 9-ASSOC 15-say AUG-2-person 2-DIST 2-PST-be(come)-IPFV 2-clean INTENS
\l But truely, behold, people hold them because those people were very neat.

\t po lɪnga bo balɪ pakʊmoga baamogaga
\g then if/when as 2-COP 16-15-dance-PFV 2-PST-dance-IPFV
\l When people were dancing, they danced.

\t baalabɪlaga ʊbʊpande bʊmo bwene
\g 2-PST-go_in_direction-IPFV AUG-14-side<SWA 14-one 14-self
\l They tilted to one side.

\t lɪnga bikʊsanuka kangɪ baasanukɪlaga ʊbʊpande
\g if/when 2-PRS-alter-FV again 2-PST-alter-APPL-IPFV AUG-14-side
\l When they turned, they turned to the [other] side.

\t lʊmo baabopelaga na nkyeni
\g maybe 2-PST-run-APPL-IPFV COM 18-7-forehead
\l Sometimes they would run to the front.

\t po abakiikʊlʊ baajangapo bala baa kʊluluutɪla ʊkʊtɪ lulululululu”
\g then AUG-2-woman 2-PST-be(come)-IPFV=16 2-DIST 2-ASSOC 15-ululuate-FV COMP of_ululating
\l As for the women, there were those that ululuated lulululululu.

\t halafu lɪnga baluluutiile po baamogaga fiijo
\g afterwards(<SWA) if/when 2-ululate.PFV then 2-PST-dance-IPFV INTENS
\l When they [women] had ululuated, they [men] danced much.

\t joope ɪndingala baakʊbaga fiijo
\g 9-also AUG-9-drum 2-PST-beat-IPFV INTENS
\l They also beated the drum hard.

\t po lɪnga bakʊbile bo ʊlʊ , lɪnga jɪlɪ kwItete kʊla , jiisaga kʊfika mpaka kʊno
\g then if/when 2-beat-PFV as AUG-PROX.11 if/when 9-COP 17-I. 17-DIST 9-PST.come-IPFV 15-arrive-FV until 17-PROX
\l When they beated it like this, if it was in Itete over there, it [noise] would come to reach this place here.

\t akasumo katɪ fi , kanogeliile
\g AUG-12-custom 12-say what 12-be_satisfying-INTS.PFV
\l The custom is what, it is very enjoyable.

\t po abandʊ biisʊlaga pala pakʊkeeta
\g then AUG-2-person 2.PST-be(come)_full-IPFV 16-DIST 16-15-watch-FV
\l People crowded there to look.

\t kʊʊnongwa jaa kʊtɪ fiki , baamogaga kanunu fiijo
\g 17-issue(9) 9-ASSOC 15-say 8-what 2-PST-dance-IPFV well INTENS
\l For what reason, [because] they danced very well.

\t po lɪnga bamogile kʊlʊmogo lwabo abandʊ baahobokaga fiijo
\g then if/when 2-dance-PFV 17-11-dance 11-POSS.PL AUG-2-person 2-PST-be(come)_happy-IPFV INTENS
\l When they danced, people rejoiced much at their dance.

\t kʊʊnongawa jaa kʊti findʊ fiki , jʊla ʊgwa kʊkʊba joope akʊbile kanunu , abaa kʊmoga bamogile kanunu
\g 17-issue(9) 9-ASSOC 15-say 8-thing 8-what 1-DIST AUG-1-ASSOC 15-beat-FV 1-also 1-beat-PFV well AUG-2-ASSOC 15-dance-FV 2-dance-PFV well
\l For what reason, [because] the drum player had played well, the dancers had danced well.

\t po bo n̩di sisii∼si po lo lwiho lwɪtʊ twe baNyakyusa
\g then as 18 REDUPL∼PROX.10 then REF.11 11-custom 11-POSS.1PL 1PL 2-Ny.
\l So this is the custom of us, the Nyakyusa people.

\t iipenenga ɪlɪ baabootaga nʊkʊboota lɪnga pamo silimo ɪɪʃerehe
\g 5-t.o.drum AUG-PROX.5 2-PST-2-invite-IPFV COM=AUG-15-2-invite-FV if/when or 10-COP=18 AUG-festivity(9)(<SWA)
\l As for that drum, they invited and invited people when there was a celebration.

\t po baabʊʊkaga kʊkʊmoga
\g then 2-PST-go-IPFV 17-15-dance-FV
\l So they went to dance.

\t po palɪ sisii∼si silɪ m̩bʊpimba , m̩bʊpimba
\g then 16 REDUPL∼PROX.10 10-COP 18-14-short 18-14-short
\l So this is it in short, in short.

\t po situmukiile papaa∼pa
\g then 10-end_at.PFV REDUPL∼PROX.16
\l It has finished right here.

\t Towo med towo ta talang .
\g three take three add six
\l Take three add three (it's) six.

\t Sua mi suang hai maiye talaama
\g three take three-SEE 3.PAT-add.to if six
\l If you add three to three, (it's) six.

\t Su me su wotte aningbo taama
\g three take three 3.LOC-add thus-SET=CONJ six
\l Add three to three makes six.

\t Yasing alaku sussung allang (gang) atiga .
\g five two throw.away then (3SG) three
\l Discard two from five then there are three.

\t Muxui kam yusan , haraq ma gafa' mai ha si , kam yerig qai .
\g banana CLF five two come 3SG-split.off save then SIM CLF three only
\l Five bananas, split off two [to] save then only three [are left].

\t Iwihing ano' kurung alu towo
\g five CAUS-affect less two three
\l Five minus two is three.

\t Yeting nu ayokung habel maiye hepot sua
\g five SPEC two=LOC 3.PAT-subtract if 3.ALIEN-remainder three
\l If two is subtracted from five, the remainder is three.

\t Yeting nu ayoku mia maiye sua
\g five SPEC two take-DUR if three
\l If two is taken from five, it is three.

\t Wesing ok womet aningbo su .
\g five two 3.LOC-take thus-SET=CONJ three
\l Take two from five thus there are three.

\t Buk~bukna halakda nu ming yekna maiye kar ayoku .
\g RDP~group.of.four 3.PAT-count.CONT SPEC about five.times if ten two
\l If a group of four is counted five times, it is twenty.

\t Sii galget galledit joatkkaskuvllaid miehtá riikka .
\g they shall.PRES.3PL visit.INF secondary.school.PL.ACC all.over country.GEN
\l They are going to visit secondary schools all over the country.’ We can also note that complements of adpositions have genitive case. Here and in following examples I boldface the relevant syntactic head (adposition or noun) and underline its complement.

\g finally dry.heartwood cross-CSO CSO search-ISBJ-CSO find-NMLZ-CSO onto.path-DIR:hither
\l Later, crossing the dry log, they then searched and then got back onto the path.

\t kaʔʃɨ t̪'axer lahmin
\g walk poorly go.uphill=3ABS
\l She left.

\l That spoon is covered by a cloth so that [only] its round part is visible.

\t miémbrate que por amar a mí … mataste a tres hermanos míos

\t El que a mí aquí me truxo no es el diablo que dizes …
\g The who ACC I here I.ACC bring-PVF.3SG not is the devil that say-PRS.2SG …
\l The one who brought me here is not the devil as you say’ (1504, Esplandián, CORDE)

\t que nunca sentimos rumor de gente y a mí me pareció que debíamos salir del pueblo de aquella manera

\l because we never heard voices and I thought [lit. ‘it seemed to me’] that we had to leave the village that way’ (1519–26, Cartas, CORDE)
