\l Deplorable, the person who (…) must have raised a bow, pinched both those arrows, and shot them away!’ (MYS 13.3302)

\t kami tu se ni u wo yatu kaduke simo tu se ni u wo yatu kaduke
\g upper GEN stream DAT cormorant ACC eight-thing make.dive lower GEN stream DAT cormorant ACC eight-thing make.dive
\l …making all eight of [my] cormorants dive in the upper reaches, making all eight of [my] cormorants dive in the lower reaches…’ (MYS 13.3330)

\t tamasakani wa ga misi pito wo ika naramu yosi wo motite ka mata pitome mimu
\g by.chance I GEN see-SPST person ACC how COP-will opportunity ACC holding FOC again one-glimpse see-will
\l The person whom I met by chance –having what other manner of opportunity is it that [I] will see a glimpse of her again?’ (MYS 11.2396)

\t yamato no takasazinwo wo nana yuku wotomyedomo tare wo si makamu
\g Yamato GEN Takasazino ACC seven go girl-PL who ACC RES wrap-will
\l As for the seven maidens walking along the plain Takasazi in Yamato – whom (of them) will [you] wed?’ (KK 15)

\t nagatukwi no sigure no ame no yamagwiri no asibuseki a ga mune ta wo miba yamamu
\g 9th.month GEN shower GEN rain GEN mountain-mist as fretful I GEN breast who ACC see.if stop-will
\l As for my breast which is fretting like the mountain mist of the rain showers of the 9th month, if [I] see whom (other than you) shall it quieten?’ (MYS 10.2263a)

\t maywone kaki tare wo ka mimu to omopitutu kenagaku kwopwisi imo ni apyeru kamo
\g eyebrow scratch who ACC FOC see-will COMP think.while days-long yearn-SPST beloved DAT meet-STAT SFP
\l Scratching [my] eyebrow, thinking, “Whom (other than you) am [I] about to see?” here [I] am meeting my beloved (you) whom [I] have longed for day in and day out!’ (MYS 11.2614b)

\t kapyeru beku toki pa narikyeri miyakwo nite ta ga tamoto wo ka wa ga makurakamu
\g return ought time TOP become-MPST Capital COP who GEN sleeve ACC FOC I GEN lie.upon-will
\l The time has come for [us] to return. In the capital, the sleeve of whom (other than my departed wife) shall I use as my pillow?’ (MYS 3.439)

\t asigara no yapyeyama kwoyete imasinaba tare wo ka kimi to mitutu sinwopamu
\g Ashigara GEN eight-fold-mountain Crossing come-PFV.if who ACC FOC lord COMP seeing praise-will
\l If [you] cross the eight-fold mountains of Ashigara, then whom (else) shall [I], thinking [it] to be my lord, admire?’ (MYS 20.4440)

\t kasuga .nwo no pudi pa tirinite nani wo ka mo mikari no pito no worite kazasamu
\g Kasuga.field GEN wisteria TOP scatter-PFV.GER what ACC FOC ETOP PFX-hunt GEN person GEN breaking.off don-will
\l The wisteria flowers on Kasuga fields having scattered, what else shall the hunters break off and wear on their heads?’ (MYS 10.1974)

\t kokoro sape matureru kimi ni nani wo ka mo ipazu ipisi to wa ga nusumapamu
\g heart even offer.up-STAT lord DAT what ACC FOC ETOP say-NEG say-SPST COMP I GEN steal-will
\l To you whom [I] have given the very meaning (my very heart), what (else) would I steal from you by saying, “[It] is a thing which was said without speaking”?’ (MYS 11.2573)

\t moti no pi ni sasiiduru tukwi no takatakani kimi wo imasete nani wo ka omopamu
\g mid.month GEN day DAT direct-come.out moon as refinedly lord ACC making.come what ACC FOC think-will
\l Having you come resplendently like the moon that comes out on the 15th of the month, what (else) could [I] wish for?’ (MYS 12.3005)

\t yamagapi ni sakyeru sakura wo tada pitome kimi ni miseteba nani wo ka omopamu
\g mountain-saddle DAT bloom-STAT cherry.blossom ACC just one-glimpse lord DAT show-PFV.if what ACC FOC think-will
\l If [I] managed to show my lord just once the cherry blossoms that bloom in the saddle of the mountain, what (else) could [I] wish for?’ (MYS 17.3967)

\t ipye ni yukite nani wo kataramu asipikwino yamapototogisu pitokowe mo nakye
\g home DAT going what ACC recount-will (pillow.word) mountain-cuckoo one-chirp ETOP cry.IMP
\l Mountain cuckoo, sing even one note! Going home, what (other than that) shall [I] recount?’ (MYS 19.4203)

\t imasarani nani wo ka omopamu utinabiki kokoro pa kimi ni yorinisi monowo
\g now-newly what ACC FOC think-will PFX-lie.down heart TOP lord DAT depend-PFV-SPST given.that
\l At this late date, what more could [one] ask for, given that [my] heart, lying down, has given itself over to you?’ (MYS 4.505)

\t ametuti wo terasu pitukwi no kipami naku aru beki monowo nani wo ka omopamu
\g heaven-earth ACC illuminate sun-moon as limit lacking be ought given.that what ACC FOC think-will
\l Given that [it] must have no limit, just as the sun and moon which illuminate heaven and earth, what else could [one] wish for?’ (MYS 20.4486)

\t sipo pwinaba tamamo karitume ipye no imo ga pamadutwo kopaba nani wo simyesamu
\g tide ebb-PFV.if jewel-weed cut-gather.IMP home GEN beloved GEN beach-souvenir beg.if what ACC proffer-will
\l When the tide goes out, cut and gather some jewel-seaweed. If my darling at home asks for a beach souvenir, what (other than that) would [we] proffer?’ (MYS 3.360)

\t asipikwino tamakadura no kwo kyepu no goto idure no kuma wo mitutu kinikyemu
\g (pillow.word) jewel-vine GEN child today GEN like which GEN bend ACC seeing come-PFV-must.have
\l Oh child of the jewel-vine, seeing which bends in the mountain road must [you] have come here, as [I come] today?’ (MYS 16.3790)

\t idure wo ka wakite sinwopamu
\g which ACC FOC separating praise-will
\l …Which shall [I] praise, separating [it] out? …’ (MYS 18.4089)

\t watatumi no idure no kamwi wo inoraba ka yuku sa mo ku sa mo pune no payakyemu
\g sea.god GEN which GEN god ACC supplicate.if FOC go way ETOP come way ETOP boat GEN fast-be-will
\l Which god of the sea is it that, if [I] beseech it, the boat will be fast both on the way out and the way back?’ (MYS 9.1784)

\t ametusi no idure no kami wo inoraba ka utukusi papa ni mata kototwopamu
\g heaven-earth GEN which GEN god ACC beseech.if FOC dear mother DAT again word-ask-will
\l Which of the gods of heaven and earth is it that, if [I] beseech it, [I] will speak again to my dear mother?’ (MYS 20.4392)

\t augi tataugami nado yobe makuragami ni okisikado onodukara pikare tirinikeru o motomuru ni kurakereba ikade ka wa mimu idura idura tatakiwatasi miidete augi putaputato tukawi putokorogami sasiirete makarinamu to bakari koso iu rame
\g fan folding-paper etc. last.night pillow-head DAT put-SPST.although naturally pull-PASS scatter-PFV-MPST ACC search DAT dark.because how FOC TOP see-will where where pat-cross see-putting.out fan (mimetic) use pocket-paper stick-put.in go.home-PFV-will COMP RES FOC say EXT
\l Although [he] had put [his] fan and folded paper and such at the head of his pillow the night before, when [he] searches [for them] among the things that naturally became disturbed and scattered, it being dark, how shall [he] ever find them?— saying, “Where? Where?” patting the whole area, and finding them, [he] uses [his] fan, “woosh-woosh,” and sticking [his] pocket-paper in, what [he] would surely say is something like, “[I'll] be going now”.’ (Makura no sōshi, 61, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 18, p. 117)

\t nadeu koto naki pito no wegati nite mono itau iwitaru
\g any.in.particular thing lacking person GEN laugh-tending COP thing extremely say-STAT
\l A person who has nothing to commend himself, smugly saying things volubly.’ (Makura no sōshi, 26, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 18, p. 65)

\t Mikapa no kuni yatupasi to ipu tokoro ni itarinu soko wo yatupasi to ipikeru pa midu yuku kapa no kumode nareba pasi wo yatu wataseru ni yorite namu yatupasi to ipikeru .
\g Mikawa GEN country Yatsuhashi COMP say place DAT arrive-PFV this.place ACC Yatsuhashi COMP say-MPST TOP water go river GEN spider-hand COP.because bridge ACC eight-thing cross-STAT DAT depending FOC Yatsuhashi COMP say-MPST
\l [They] came to a place called Yatsuhasi. As for its being called Yatsuhashi, it was due to the fact that [they] spanned eight bridges over it, because the river of water divided into spider legs, that [they] called it “Yatuhashi”.’ (Ise monogatari, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 12, p. 120)

\t yoritamawite mikityau no katabira wo pitope utikaketamau ni awasete sa .to pikaru mono ga
\g depend-RESP.GER standing.blind GEN panel ACC one-layer PFX-hang-RESP DAT matching suddenly glow thing GEN
\l …and just as [Otodo], drawing near, draped a panel from a standing blind (over the crossbeam), suddenly something glowing …’ (Genji monogatari: ‘Hotaru’, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 22, p. 200)

\t aki .kaze ni patu .kari ga ne zo kikoyu naru tare ga tamaadusa wo kakete kitu ramu

\t momidiba no tirite tumoreru wa ga yado ni tare wo matu .musi kokora naku ramu
\g red.leaves GEN scatter pile.up-STAT I GEN dwelling DAT who ACC await.insect around.here cry EXT
\l In my dwelling on which autumn leaves, falling, have piled up — whom must the matsumushi be awaiting? — the matsumushi cries around here’ (Kokin wakashū, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 11, p. 100)

\t puna .kodomo no araarasiki kowe nite uraganasiku mo tooku kana to kinikeru utau o kiku mama ni putari sasimukawite nakikeri puna .bito mo tare o kou to ka oosima no ura kanasigeni kowe no kikoyuru
\g boat.man-PL GEN rough voice COP mournfully ETOP from.afar SFP COMP come-PFV-MPST singing ACC listen thus COP two-people direct-face cry-MPST boat.man ETOP who ACC yearn.for COMP FOC Ō-island GEN bay sad-appearing voice GEN be.audible
\l Even as [they] heard the boatmen in their rough voices singing, “Heartlorn, [we]’ve come so far!” the two faced each other and cried. So whom do the boatmen long for? Voices from Ō Island Bay sound so heartsick.’ (Genji monogatari, ‘Tamakazura’, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 22, p. 90)

\t medetaki ya tare wo ka toritamau to notamaweba sa .daisyau .dono no sakon .no .seusyau to ka
\g fortunate SFP who ACC FOC take-RESP COMP say.when Left.Major.Captain GEN Minor.Captain COMP FOC
\l As [he] said, “That’s fortunate. Whom is [she] receiving (as a groom)?” [she] replied, “(I am given to understand) that it is the son of the Major Captain of the Left, the Minor Captain,” …’ (Ochikubo monogatari, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 17, p. 89)

\t omuko no seusyau tare wo toritamau zo to towikereba sa .daisyau no sakon .no .seusyau .dono to
\g groom GEN Minor.Captain who ACC take-RESP FOC COMP say-MPST.when Left.Major.Captain GEN Left.Minor.Captain COMP
\l As the husband, Minor Captain Kurauto, asked, “Whom will [she] take (as a groom)?” [she] replied, “(Mother says) [it] is the son of the Major Captain of the Left, the Minor Captain of the Left,”…’ (Ochikubo monogatari, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 17, p. 147)

\t nani wo site mi no itadura ni oinu ramu tosi no omopamu koto zo yasasiki
\g what ACC doing body GEN in.vain COP grow.old-PFV EXT year GEN think-will content FOC embarrassing
\l Doing what must it be that [my] body has grown old in vain? How shameful [to me], what the years must be thinking!’ (Kokin wakashū, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 11, p. 404)

\t tatiwi no kewawi tawegatageni okonau ito aware ni asa no kiri ni koto naranu yo o nani o musaboru mi no inori ni ka to kikitamau
\g stand-sit GEN bearing withstand-hard-appearing undertake very pitiful COP morning GEN mist DAT otherwise be-NEG world ACC what ACC gobble.up body GEN prayer COP FOC COMP listen-RESP
\l Standing up and sitting down in a manner that appeared unbearable, (the old man) carried out the rites in a way that was so truly pitiful, [he] listened (to the old man), thinking, “Given that this world is no different than morning mist, these are the prayers of an earthly body hoarding up what, (I wonder)?” …’ (Genji monogatari, ‘Yūgao’, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 20, p. 158)

\t kono miko ni mawositamapisi pourai no tama no eda wo pitotu no tokoro ayamatazu motite opasimaseri nani wo motite to .kaku mawosu beki
\g this aristocrat DAT say-RESP-SPST Hōrai GEN jewel GEN branch ACC one-thing GEN place differ-NEG having come-STAT what ACC having that.this say ought
\l [He] has brought the branch with the jewels of Hōrai that [you] spoke to this lord about, with not a point of difference [in it]. Having what (as grounds) am [I] supposed to tell [him] this and that (as excuses)?’ (Taketori monogatari, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 12, p. 29)

\t saru koto ni wa nani no irawe o ka semu nakanaka naramu
\g such thing DAT TOP what GEN reply ACC FOC do-will awkward be-will
\l With respect to such a thing, what reply am [I] to make? [It] will be awkward.’ (Makura no sōshi, 131, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 18, p. 248)

\t kakerite mo nani wo ka tama no kite mo mimu kara pa ponopo to narinisi monowo
\g flying ETOP what ACC FOC soul GEN coming ETOP see-will shell TOP ember as become-PFV-SPST given.that
\l Even flying, what would [my] soul, coming here, see? Given that [her] remains are already turned to embers.’ (Kokin wakashū, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 11, p. 418)

\t ausaka no seki pa yoru koso morimasare kurureba nani wo ware tanomu ramu
\g Ōsaka GEN checkpoint TOP night FOC guard-excel grow.dark.when what ACC I rely EXT
\l It is at night that [they] guard the Osaka checkpoint more strongly. When the day ends, what shall I rely on?’ (Heichū monogatari, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 12, p. 459)

\t miya .no .omawe ni uti .no .otodo no maturitamawerikeru o kore ni nani o kakamasi uwe .no .omawe ni wa siki to iu pumi o namu kakasetamaweru
\g empress DAT Minister.of.the.Centre GEN give-RESP-STAT-MPST ACC this DAT what ACC write-SBJV emperor DAT TOP chronicle COMP say text ACC FOC write-CAUS-RESP-STAT
\l On the occasion of the Minister of the Centre giving [them] to the Empress, (she said), “What shall [I] write on these? On the Emperor's part, [he] is writing texts called ‘Chronicles’.” …’ (Makura no sōshi, 327, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 18, p. 467)

\t ka bakari kokoro .zasi oroka naranu pito .bito ni koso a mere kaguya .pime no ipaku nani bakari no pukaki wo ka mimu to ipamu isasaka no koto nari
\g this.way RES resolve negligent be-NEG person.person COP FOC exist EXT Shining.Princess GEN saying what RES GEN depth ACC FOC see-will COMP say-will trifling GEN thing be
\l … “It seems that [they] are people not lacking feeling to this degree.” The Shining Princess's reply: “[I] shall tell [you]: What degree of depth do [I] want to see? [It] is a mere trifling.”…’ (Taketori monogatari, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 12, p. 23)

\t awaregari medurasigarite kaweru ni nani o ka tatematuramu mamemamesiki mono wa masa nakari namu
\g impression-exhibit rareness-exhibiting return DAT what ACC FOC give-will practical thing TOP appropriateness lacking SFP
\l … making many signs of delight and interest (in me), when it was time [for me] to go home (she said), “What shall [I] give to you? Something practical just won't do.” …’ (Sarashina nikki, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 26, p. 298)

\t ware wa to omowi .agareru tiuzyau .no .kimi zo kanete zo miyuru nado koso kagami no kage ni mo katarawipaberiture watakusi no inori wa nani bakari no koto o ka nado kikoyu
\g I TOP COMP presuming Chūjō FOC from.before FOC be.visible and.the.like FOC mirror.cake GEN image DAT ETOP talk-HUM-PFV private COP prayer TOP what RES GEN word ACC FOC and.the.like say
\l (The one to speak was) Chūjō, who presumed (to herself that if anyone has something to wish for, then) surely myself! “[I] was saying to [your] image in the mirror-cake, ‘(your thousand-year image) appeared from earlier,’ and so on. As for prayers for myself, how much of a boon (could I possibly ask)?” [she] continued in this vein.’ (Genji monogatari, ‘Hatsune’, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 22, p. 144)

\t yoki kakemono wa arinu bekeredo karugarusiku wa ewatasu maziki o nani o ka pa nado notamawasuru mikesiki ikaga miyu ranee
\g good wager TOP exist-PFV ought.however lightly TOP can-hand.over impossible given.that what ACC FOC TOP and.the.like say-RESP PFX-visage how be.visible EXT
\l …However must the sight [of him] saying such things as “Though there ought to be a good wager, [I] can't be handing anything over too lightly, so what (shall I wager)?” have appeared (to others)?’ (Genji monogatari, ‘Yadorigi’, Shinpen Zenshū, vol. 24, p. 378)

\l John didn’t learn not to cook (i.e. ‘John still has the habit of cooking’).

\t fetos tolmise tesseris fores na pirovolisi o Janis
\g this.year dared.3SG four times SBJV shoot.3SG the John.NOM
\l This year there were four times that John dared to shoot.

\t fetos tolmise na pirovolisi tesseris fores o Janis
\g this.year dared.3SG SBJV shoot.3SG four times the John.NOM
\l This year John dared to shoot four times (in a row).

\t ksehase na ksevgali o Janis to pukamiso teseris fores
\g forgot SBJV rinse the John.NOM the shirt four times
\l John forgot to rinse the shirt four times.’ (four rinsings/forgettings)

\g forgot four times SBJV rinse the John.NOM the shirt
\l John forgot four times to rinse the shirt.’ (four forgettings)

\t den tolmise na fai kanis to tiri
\g not dared.3SG SBJV eat.3SG nobody the cheese
\l Nobody dared to eat the cheese.

\g learned.3SG gradually SBJV CL.DAT/GEN like.3PL the opera.NOM.PL when met.3SG the Jiani.ACC
\l She learned gradually to like opera, when she met John.

\l She tries not to feel sad about the financial crisis.

\l She managed not to feel anxious about the financial crisis.

\t apofasise na min tin katavali i asthenia

\l She decided not to become depressed by the illness.

\t iposhethike na min tin stenahori pia i siberifora tu jiu tis
\g promised.3SG SBJV NEG CL.ACC feel.sad.3SG anymore the behavior.NOM the son.GEN CL.POSS
\l She promised not to feel sad about her son’s behavior.

\l The Congress obliged Bush to sign the peace agreement.

\t riacaladxibeLH guLHeedaLHbeLH guixi'H

\l S/he wants to come tomorrow.

\t riacaladxi∅ gueedaLH∅ guixi'H

\t riacaladxibeLH guLHeedaLH∅ guixi'H

\l S/he wants him/her to come tomorrow.' (MP 34)

\g HAB=occur-gut=3 POT=come=3.HUM tomorrow
\l S/he wants him/her to come tomorrow.' (MP 77)

\l That’s not true. She only visited her mother.

\l If it is not raining we will go.

\t *Um’entsalitás ku7 i án’wasa xetspqíqen’kst táola , t’u7 aoz kw s7um’entsálitas ku stam’ .

\l They gave me $200 [I was told], but they didn’t give me anything.

\t Tsut sLémya7 kw sqwemémn’ek ku7 sMary , t’u7 plánlhkan ti7 zwáten — áts’xenlhkan sMary áta7 tecwpálhcwa inátcwas .
\g say NOM-name DET pregnant REPORT NOM-name but already-1sg.SUBJ DEM know-DIR — see-DIR-1sg.SUBJ NOM-name DEIC buy-place-DET yesterday
\l Lémya7 said that [she was told that] Mary is pregnant, but I already knew that – I had seen Mary at the store yesterday.

\l Who was late because he missed the bus?

\g – because she a mouse saw
\l Why did the cat jump? – Because it saw a mouse.

\l I don’t believe that Peter is going home because he has a headache.

\l intended: `Salzburg is in Austria but just barely (since it's so close to the border)' → marginal reading

\t Lydia ist noch am Vormittag abgereist .
\g Lydia is still in_the morning departed.
\l Intended: `It was still morning when Lydia left.' → temporal, subconstituent reading

\t (Felix hatte (schon) drei Bier .) Jetzt trinkt er noch ein Bier .
\g Felix had already three beers now drinks he still a beer
\l Felix (already) had three beers. Now he is having another beer.' → additive reading

\t Maria ist (gerade) noch größer als Peter .
\g Maria ist (just/barely) still taller than Peter.
\l Maria is still taller than Peter (but only just).

\t * Paul ist noch größer als Peter , aber Peter ist nicht groß .
\g _ Paul is still tall.COMP than Peter but Peter is not tall
\l * Intended as: `Paul is still taller than Peter, but Peter is not tall.

\t Peter ist größer als Kurt . Paul ist noch größer als Peter , aber Peter ist nicht groß .
\g Peter is tall.COMP than Kurt Paul is still tall.COMP than Peter but Peter is not tall
\l Peter is taller than Kurt. Paul is still taller than Peter but Peter is not tall.

\t Nist thes gisceid noh giuuant , uuio er girrit thaz lant , uuio er iz allaz uuirrit , ioh thesa uuorolt merrit .
\g Not-is of.this boundary nor measure, how he confuses the land, how he it all stirs, and this world injures.
\l There is neither boundary nor measure to which he disturbs the country as he causes it trouble and to the entire world.' (Otfried DDD_O_Otfr.Ev.4.20, edition 278–289 via ANNIS)

\t Ladotun auur tho then man , ther thes gisiunes biquam , quadun , sih thera .GEN dati .GEN noh tho baz biknati .SUBJ .PAST .3 .SG .
\g invited but then the man, who of.the seeing became, said, himself of.the deed still/even there better appraise.
\l They then requested of the man who gained eyesight to appraise/evaluate his action still/even there more thoroughly.' (1.OG2.OtfEbKell.202.105)

\t Thar uuarun mit githuinge thie iungoron noh tho inne , sie scolta ruaren NOH tho mer thaz selba uuoroltlicha ser .
\g There were with violence the apostles still there inside, they should move still/even there more the same earthly suffering.
\l The apostles were still inside with violence, they should continue to move/stir the earthly suffering.' (1.OG2.OtfEbKell.351.12)

\t Úbe árg uuéllen uuêlih íst , árg kemúgen , dáz íst nóh uuêlichera .
\g if evil.ACC to.want bad is, evil be.able.to.do, that is still/even worse.
\l If it is bad to want evil things, then to be able to do evil things is still/even worse.' (Notker.Boeth-DeConPhil.III.201)

\t Ér íst tero góto chúnnigosto_ . nóh tánne bíst tû chúnnigora_ . uuánda ratio gemág mêr dánne sermo_ .
\g He is of.the gods most.knowledgeable. Still/even then/there are you more.knowledgeable, because reason can.do more than the.conversation.
\l He is the most knowledgeable about the gods. But you are still/even more knowledgeable because reason can achieve more than conversation.' (1.OG3.N:Mart.Cap.II.111-121.J)

\t Michel ist íro guôllichi an dînemo haltâre christo .  Lat .  Ímo selbemo gíbest du noh mêrun guôllichi . unde mêrun ziêreda . sô dû in gesezzest ad dexteram tuam .
\g Great is her glory in your savior christ. [Lat.] him self give you still/even more glory. and more adornment. as you him set to_LAT right_LAT your_LAT.
\l Great is the glory of the church in your savior christ. You give him still/even more glory and more adornment by setting him at your right side.' (1.OG3.N:Ps:20.61–63)

\g today 2SG/2PL eat.CNV-PRF.EGO=Q
\l Have you eaten today?’ (elicited)

\t miadu kalē/kalēmen̊ kaifi
\g today 2SG/2PL eat.CNV-PRF.ALTER
\l You have eaten today.’ (elicited)

\t miadu ēnā/emīhun̊ kaifita ?
\g today 3SG/3PL eat.CNV-PRF.ALTER=Q
\l Has (s)he/have they eaten today?’ (elicited)

\t miadu ēnā/emīhun̊ kaifi
\g today 3SG/3PL eat.CNV-PRF.ALTER
\l (S)he has/they have eaten today.’ (elicited)

\t kalē bēnum̊ nuviyas kalēge zamīru kuran̊ bēnun̊_vegen̊ kalē tikam̊ kurāne . kaleakī vakīlek̊̊ . ēnāge furāna salāmat̊_kuran̊ kalē masakkat̊ kurāne
\g 2SG want NEG=be.PST.PTCP=CNCS 2SG-GEN conscience do.INF want_be.CVB=SUCC 2SG DEM2=action do.FUT.ALTER 2SG=COP lawyer-INDF 3SG-GEN life safety_do.INF 2SG work do.FUT.ALTER
\l Even if you don’t want to, because your conscience wants to do [that], you will do that. You are a lawyer. You will work to save his life.’ (from <www.esfiya.com/1849/>)

\t ekamaku balā_bala… aharen̊ moya kamek̊ kuram̊ta ? nūnī duvahakuves kurim̊ta ?
\g but look.CVB_IMP 1SG crazy action-INDF do.PRS-EGO=Q or day-UNSP=EMPH do.PST-EGO=Q
\l But look…do I do anything crazy? Or did [I] ever do [anything crazy]?’ (from <www.vaguthu.mv/evaguthu/story/210155/>)

\t aharen̊ ja^ m burōlek̊ nagam̊ta ?

\g 1SG food much eat-PST.EGO

\t Han / tal dzamen noj dzadza .
\g 2[SG] / 3[SG] food much eat-PST.ALLO.DIR.SG
\l You / she / he ate a lot.’ (The speaker witnessed the relevant event.) (Widmer fieldnotes)

\t Han / tal dzamen noj dzadʑi .
\g 2[SG] / 3[SG] food much eat-PST.ALLO.INFER.SG
\l You / she / he has eaten a lot.’ (The speaker infers that the relevant event must have taken place.) (Widmer fieldnotes)

\t  Keine Kinder und keine Erwachsenen  haben gestritten .
\g no children and no adults have quarreled
\l No children and no adults quarreled.

\l ≠ No child and no adult quarreled. (for many speakers)

\t Alle Kinder und alle Erwachsenen haben gestritten .
\g all children and all adults have quarreled
\l All children quarreled among themselves and all adults quarreled among themselves.

\l Monika need give no lecture.

\l It is not the case that Monika is obliged to give a lecture and it is not the case that Monika is obliged to give a seminar.

\l You don't need to compare any lecture with any seminar.

\l Reading 1: I think that Monika is not obliged to teach either a lecture or a seminar.

\t ek gár hoi tês ópsios hoi tôn mágōn oneiropóloi esḗmainon

\t tṑ dé hoi ṓmō kurtṓ

\t tò dé hoi oúnoma eînai Ioûn

\l and her name to be Io' (Herodotus 1.1.3)

\t hē dé hoi kómē ṓmous kateskíaze kaì metáphrena

\t egṑ dé hoi ha takhupeithḕs kheiròs ephapsaména

\l And Gorgos will sacrifice the blood of a herdsman's goat to you.' (Anthologia Graeca 6.157.3).

\t kaí spheas óllu' hṓsper ollúeis
\g and them.ACC destroy.2SG.PRS.IMPER like destroy.2SG.PRS
\l … and destroy them as you destroy.' (Archilochus, Fragment 27.2)

\t kaí sphin thalássēs ēkhéenta kúmata phílter' ēpeírou génētai

\l … and the sea's roaring billows shall become dearer than land to them.' (Archilochus, Fragment 74.8)

\l … so that the hook would slip off and not take hold.' (Thucydides 7.65.2)

\t hópōs àn periláboim' autôn tina

\t hópōs àn eudaimonoíēs
\g so IRR prosper.2SG.PRS.OPT
\l … for you to be happy.' (Plato, Lysis 207e)

\t skopô , hópōs àn ho mèn paîs hóde ho sòs kaì hē paîs hêde hōs rhâista diágoien , hēmeîs d' àn málista (àn) euphrainoímetha

\t hōs mèn àn eípoite kaì suneîte , ámeinon Philíppou pareskeúasthe , hōs dè kōlúsait' àn ekeînon pantelôs argôs ékhete

\t ouk oîd' hópōs án tis autà nomíseie mḕ eónta

\t hṓsper án , ei huiòs diṓikei ti mḕ kalôs ḕ orthôs , autò mèn toût' áxion mémpseos

\l Just as, if a son's management were in some way not good or correct, this itself (would be) worthy of blame' (Demosthenes 9.30)

\t khrḕ anthrōpínōs perì tôn pragmátōn eklogízesthai , hṓsper àn autòn ónta en têi sumphorâi
\g need.3SG.PRS humanely about the.N.GEN.PL deed.GEN.PL consider.FUT.INF.MID like IRR same.M.ACC.SG be.PTCP.PRS.M.ACC.SG in the.F.DAT.SG mishap.DAT.SG
\l It is necessary to judge a case humanely, as if one were in those circumstances oneself.' (Andocides 1.57)

\t hṓsper án tis autòs ṑn eklogízoito
\g like IRR someone.M.NOM.SG same.M.NOM.SG be.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG consider.3SG.PRS.OPT.PASS
\l … as if one were judging, being oneself …

\t toût' autò epideiknútō hṓsper àn humôn hékastos
\g this.N.ACC.SG same.N.ACC.SG display.3SG.PRS.IMPER like IRR you.GEN.PL each.M.NOM.SG
\l Let him demonstrate this very thing, as each of you would.

\t oudè homoíōs humîn , hṑsper àn trutánē rhépōn epì tò lêmma sumbeboúleuka
\g nor similarly you.DAT.PL like IRR scale.NOM.SG tilt.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG upon the.N.ACC.SG profit.ACC.SG advise.1SG.PRF
\l Nor, like you, have I advised as if I were a scale biased toward profit.' (Demosthenes 18.298; V. C. has hṓsper àn ei, has only hṓsper)

\t hṓsper àn parestēkótos autoû
\g like IRR stand.by.PTCP.PRF.M.GEN.SG him.GEN
\l … as if with him standing beside' (Demosthenes 19.226)

\t khrṓmenos hṓsper àn állos tis autôi tà prò toútou
\g use.PTCP.PRS.PASS.M.NOM.SG like IRR other.M.NOM.SG someone.M.NOM.SG him.DAT the.N.ACC.SG before this.N.GEN.SG
\l … as familiar as anyone could be with him up to then' (Demosthenes 21.117)

\t deî toínun toútois boētheîn , hṓsper àn hautôi tis adikouménōi
\g need.3SG.PRS therefore this.M.DAT.PL help.PRS.INF like IRR himself.DAT someone.M.NOM.SG wrong.PTCP.PRS.PASS.M.DAT.SG
\l Therefore you must help these people, just as anyone (would help) himself if wronged.' (Demosthenes 21.225)

\t hṓsper án tis sukophanteîn epikheirôn
\g like IRR someone.M.NOM.SG defraud.PRS.INF attempt.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG
\l … as would someone attempting to deceive' (Demosthenes 29.30; see following A; most have hṓsper àn eí tis, with which reading the example below should be understood.)

\t plḕn ei sēmeîon hṓsper àn állōi tiní , tôi khalkíōi proséstai
\g except if sign.NOM.SG like IRR other.N.DAT.SG something.DAT.SG the.N.DAT.SG copper.DAT.SG be.added.3SG.FUT.MID
\l … unless some mark shall be attached to the tablet, as there might be to anything else' (Demosthenes 39.10)

\t hṓsper àn doûlos despótēi didoús
\g like IRR slave.NOM.SG master.DAT.SG give.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG
\l … as a slave giving to his master' (Demosthenes 45.35)

\t hṓsper àn állos tis apotukhṓn
\g as IRR other.M.NOM.SG someone.M.NOM.SG miss.PTCP.AOR.M.NOM.SG
\l … as another might who failed to obtain what he wanted …' (Demosthenes 49.27)

\t hṓsper àn ei pròs hápantas anthrṓpous epolémēsan
\g like IRR if to quite.all.M.ACC.PL person.ACC.PL war.3PL.AOR
\l … as if they had fought the whole world.' (Isocrates 4.69)

\t hṓsper àn eí tōi Phrunṓndas panourgían oneidíseien
\g like IRR if someone.M.DAT.SG Phrynondas.NOM villainy.ACC.SG reproach.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l … as if Phrynondas should reproach someone with villainy' (Isocrates 18.57)

\t hṓsper àn ei ḗkouen
\g like IRR if hear.3SG.IMP
\l … as if he heard …' (Plato, Protagoras 341c)

\t hṓsper àn eí tis onomáseie kaì eípoi
\g like IRR if someone.M.NOM.SG name.3SG.AOR.OPT and say.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l … as if someone were to call and say …' (Plato, Cratylus 395e)

\t ēspázeto autón , hṓsper àn eí tis aspázoito
\g welcome.3SG.IMP.PASS him.ACC like IRR if someone.M.NOM.SG welcome.3SG.PRS.OPT.PASS
\l He kissed him, just as someone would …' (Xenophon, Cyropaedia 1.3.2)

\t hṓsper àn ei polemoûntes túkhoite
\g like IRR if war.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.PL happen.2PL.AOR.OPT
\l … as if you happened to be at war.' (Demosthenes 6.8)

\t hṓsper àn eí tis naúklēron aitiôito
\g like IRR if some.M.NOM.SG shipowner.NOM.SG accuse.3SG.PRS.OPT.PASS
\l As if some shipowner were to be accused …' (Demosthenes 18.194)

\t hṓsper àn eí tis eis Aíginan ḕ eis Mégara hormísaito
\g like IRR if someone.M.NOM.SG into Aegina.ACC or into Megara.ACC anchor.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID
\l … as if one were to anchor in Aegina or Megara' ([Demosthenes] 35.28)

\t hōsperaneì paîs
\g as.if child.NOM.SG
\l like a child' (Plato, Gorgias 479a)

\t ouk ést' adelphós , hóstis àn blástoi poté
\g not be.3SG.PRS brother.NOM.SG who.M.NOM.SG IRR bud.3SG.AOR.OPT sometime
\l There is no brother that could ever bloom for me' (Sophocles, Antigone 912)

\t ouk éstin oudeìs hóstis àn mémpsaitó se
\g not be.3SG.PRS nobody.M.NOM.SG who.M.NOM.SG IRR blame.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID you.ACC
\l There is no one who would blame you.' (Euripides, Electra 903; cf. also Heracleidae 972)

\t ouk éstin eis hó .ti àn anankaióteron analískoite khrḗmata
\g not be.3SG.PRS into which.N.ACC.SG IRR necessary.COMP.N.ACC.SG spend.2PL.PRS.OPT property.ACC.PL
\l There is nothing more necessary on which you could spend your money.' (Plato, Phaedo 78a)

\t ouk éstin , hóti án tis meîzon páthoi
\g not be.3SG.PRS which.N.ACC.SG IRR someone.M.NOM.SG greater.N.ACC.SG suffer.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l There is nothing greater that one can suffer …' (Plato, Phaedo 89d)

\t toutōnì ouk éstin , hátt' àn emoì eîpes hēdíō
\g this.N.GEN.PL.EMPH not be.3SG.PRS which.N.ACC.PL IRR me.DAT say.2SG.AOR sweeter.N.ACC.PL
\l There is nothing more pleasant than this that you could say to me.' (Plato, Phaedrus 243b)

\t oîmai gàr toioûton oudèn eînai , hótou àn apéskheto
\g think.1SG.PRS.PASS then such.M.ACC.SG nothing.ACC.SG be.PRS.INF which.N.GEN.SG IRR keep.off.3SG.AOR.MID
\l For I think that there is nothing from which such a person would have kept his hands.' (Demosthenes 24.138)

\t éstin , hóstis àn epsḗphisen ?
\g be.3SG.PRS who.M.NOM.SG IRR vote.3SG.AOR
\l Is there anyone who would have voted … ?' (Demosthenes 24.157)

\t éstin , hóstis àn hupémeinen ?
\g be.3SG.PRS who.M.NOM.SG IRR abide.3SG.AOR
\l Is there anyone who could bear … ?' (Demosthenes 19.309)

\t ou gàr ên , hó .ti àn epoieîte
\g not then be.3SG.IMP which.N.ACC.SG IRR do.2PL.IMP
\l For there was nothing that you could do.' (Demosthenes 18.43)

\t éstin oûn , hóstis àn toû xúlou kaì toû khōríou tosaútēn hupémeine phérein místhōsin ? ésti d' hóstis àn epétrepsen ?
\g be.3SG.PRS so who.M.NOM.SG IRR the.N.GEN.SG wood.GEN.SG and the.N.GEN.SG place.GEN.SG so.much.F.ACC.SG abide.3SG.AOR bear.PRS.INF rent.ACC.SG be.3SG.PRS then who.M.NOM.SG IRR entrust.3SG.AOR
\l Now, is there any man who would have submitted to the payment of so large a rental for the counter and the site? And is there any man who would have entrusted … ?' (Demosthenes 45.33)

\t ouk ést' oudeís , hóstis àn eípoi
\g not be.3SG.PRS nobody.M.NOM.SG who.M.NOM.SG IRR say.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l There is no one who would say …' ([Demosthenes] 13.22)

\t ou gàr ídois àn athrôn brotôn hóstis àn ei theòs ágoi ekphugeîn dúnaito
\g not then see.2SG.AOR.OPT IRR observe.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG mortal.GEN.PL who.M.NOM.SG IRR if god.NOM.SG lead.3SG.PRS.OPT escape.PRS.INF can.3SG.PRS.OPT.PASS
\l If you observed, you would not see any mortal who could escape if a god were to lead him on.' (Sophocles, Oedipus at Colonus 252)

\t ouk oîda eis hóntin' án tis állon kairòn anabálloito
\g not know.1SG.PRF into which.M.NOM.SG IRR someone.M.NOM.SG other.M.ACC.SG time.ACC.SG defer.3SG.PRS.OPT.PASS
\l I do not know to what other time one could delay' (Plato, Phaedo 107a)

\t ouk oîda hó .ti án tis khrḗsaito autôi
\g not know.1SG.PRF which.N.ACC.SG IRR someone.M.NOM.SG use.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID him.DAT
\l I do not know what use one could make of him' (Xenophon, Anabasis 3.1.40)

\t oudeìs gár estin hoútō rhā́ithumos hóstis àn déxaito
\g nobody.M.NOM.SG for be.3SG.PRS so indifferent.M.NOM.SG who.M.NOM.SG IRR receive.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID
\l For there is no one so cavalier that he would receive …' (Isocrates 9.35)

\t tôn dè katà taûta ekhóntōn ouk éstin hótōi pot' àn állōi epiláboio
\g the.N.GEN.PL but down this.N.ACC.PL have.PTCP.PRS.N.GEN.PL not be.3SG.PRS which.N.DAT.SG sometime IRR other.N.DAT.SG grasp.2SG.AOR.OPT.MID
\l But there is nothing else by which you could grasp the things that are always the same …' (Plato, Phaedo 79a)

\t hôn ouk éstin , hóstis ouk án tis kataphronḗseien
\g whom.M.GEN.PL not be.3SG.PRS who.M.NOM.SG not IRR someone.M.NOM.SG despise.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l … whom there is no one that would fail to despise' (Isocrates 8.52)

\t ou gár estin , perì hótou ouk àn pithanṓteron eípoi ho rhētorikós
\g not for be.3SG.PRS about which.N.GEN.SG not IRR persuasively.COMP say.3SG.AOR.OPT the.M.NOM.SG rhetorician.NOM.SG
\l There is nothing about which a rhetorician would not speak more persuasively' (Plato, Gorgias 456c; cf. also 491e)

\t oudeìs hoútō kakós , hóntina ouk àn autòs ho Érōs éntheon poiḗseien
\g nobody.M.NOM.SG so bad.M.NOM.SG whom.M.ACC.SG not IRR same.M.NOM.SG the.M.NOM.SG Eros.NOM inspired.M.ACC.SG make.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l (There is) no one so base whom Eros himself cannot inspire' (Plato, Symposium 179a)

\t oudeìs gár , hóstis ouk àn axiṓseien
\g nobody.M.NOM.SG then who.M.NOM.SG not IRR deem.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l There is no one who would think …' (Xenophon, Cyropaedia 7.5.61)

\t tís hóutōs phthonerós estin hós ouk àn eúxaito

\l Who is so envious that he would not have prayed … ?' (Lycurgus 1.69)

\t ouk ésth' hóstis àn ouk àn eikótōs epitimḗseié moi
\g not be.3SG.PRS who.M.NOM.SG IRR not IRR justly evaluate.3SG.AOR.OPT me.DAT
\l There is no one who would not justly censure me.' (Demosthenes 18.206)

\t tís d' ên hoûtō ḕ misódēmos tóte ḕ misathḗnaios , hóstis édunḗthē án

\l And was there anyone then who hated either the people or Athens so much that he could have … ?' (Lycurgus 1 39)

\t ou gàr ên hó .ti áll' àn epoieîte
\g not then be.3SG.IMP which.N.ACC.SG other.N.ACC.SG IRR do.2PL.IMP
\l For there was nothing else that you could do.' (Demosthenes 18.43; )

\t ouk éstin , hḗtis toût' àn Hellēnìs gunḕ étlē
\g not be.3SG.PRS who.F.NOM.SG this.N.ACC.SG IRR Greek.F.NOM.SG woman.NOM.SG endure.3SG.AOR
\l There is no Greek woman who would have dared this.' (Euripides, Medea 1339)

\t ést' oûn hópōs àn hōspereì spondês theoû kagṑ laboímēn
\g be.3SG.PRS so how IRR as.if libation.GEN.SG god.GEN.SG also=I.NOM take.1SG.AOR.OPT.MID
\l Then is there any way in which, as with a libation to a god, I too could take … ?' (Euripides, Cyclops 469)

\t ouk éstin hópōs àn egṓ poth' hekṑn tês sês gnṓmēs ét' apheímēn

\l There is no way that I would ever again willingly ignore your advice.' (Aristophanes, Birds 627)

\t oudèn autòs exēûron , hopóthen àn eikótōs hupereídete tḕn emḕn homilían
\g nothing.ACC.SG same.M.NOM.SG discover.1SG.AOR whence IRR justly despise.2PL.AOR the.F.ACC.SG my.ACC.SG company.ACC.SG
\l I myself have discovered nothing from which you could reasonably have despised my company.' (Lysias 8.7)

\t ouk éstin , hópōs àn ámeinon oikḗseian tḕn heautôn
\g not be.3SG.PRS how IRR better settle.3PL.AOR.OPT the.F.ACC.SG themselves.GEN
\l There is no way in which they could be better citizens of their country' (Plato, Symposium 178e)

\t ouk ésth' hópōs àn entháde meínaimi
\g not be.3SG.PRS how IRR here stay.1SG.AOR.OPT
\l There is no way that I could stay here.' (Plato, Symposium 223a)

\t ouk eînai éthnos , hopoíōi àn axiṓseian hupḗkooi eînai Thettaloí
\g not be.PRS.INF people.NOM.SG of.what.sort.N.DAT.SG IRR deem.3PL.AOR.OPT subject.M.NOM.PL be.PRS.INF Thessalian.NOM.PL
\l … that there would be no people such that the Thessalians would consider being subject to them.' (Xenophon, Hellenica 6.1.9)

\t éstin oûn hópōs àn enantiṓterá tis dúo theíē
\g be.3SG.PRS so how IRR opposite.COMP.N.ACC.PL someone.M.NOM.SG two put.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l So is there any way in which one could propose two more contradictory things … ?' (Demosthenes 24.64)

\t éstin oûn hópōs àn mâllon ánthrthpoi pánth' hupèr Philíppou práttontes exelenkhtheîen

\l Now is there any way in which people could be more clearly convicted of acting for Philip in every way … ?' (Demosthenes 19.165)

\t ouk ékhō hókōs ouk àn íson plêthos toís Pérsēisi exébale
\g not have.1SG.PRS how not IRR equal.N.ACC.SG quantity.ACC.SG the.M.DAT.PL Persian.DAT.PL cast.out.3SG.AOR
\l I hold that there is no way in which he would have cast overboard a number equal to that of the Persians …' (Herodotus 8.119.1)

\t toût' oûn estin hópōs tis àn humâs exapatḗsai
\g this.N.ACC.SG so be.3SG.PRS how someone.M.NOM.SG IRR you.ACC.PL deceive.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l Therefore, is there any way in which someone could deceive you in this … ?' (Xenophon, Anabasis 5.7.7)

\t ouk ésth' hopoîon stánt' àn anthrṓpou bíon oút' ainésaim' àn oúte mempsaímēn poté
\g not be.3SG.PRS of.what.sort.M.ACC.SG stand.PTCP.AOR.M.ACC.SG IRR person.GEN.SG life.ACC.SG nor praise.1SG.AOR.OPT IRR nor blame.1SG.AOR.OPT.MID sometime
\l There is no station of human life that I would ever praise or blame as being settled.' (Sophocles, Antigone 1156)

\t ou gàr ésth' hópōs mí' hēméra génoit' àn hēmérai dúo
\g not then be.3SG.PRS how one.F.NOM.SG day.NOM.SG become.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID IRR day.NOM.PL two
\l For there is no way that one day could become two days.' (Aristophanes, Clouds 1181)

\t kouk ésth' hópōs àn láthoi
\g and=not be.3SG.PRS how IRR hide.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l … and there is no way for him to escape notice.' (Aristophanes, Wasps 212)

\t ou gàr ésth' hópōs apeipeîn àn dokô moi tḗmeron
\g not then be.3SG.PRS how refuse.AOR.INF IRR think.1SG.PRS me.DAT today
\l For there is no way that I could think of refusing today …' (Aristophanes, Peace 306; cf. also Plato, Apology 40c)

\t ou gàr ésth' hópōs eûnoi génoint' án
\g not then be.3SG.PRS how right-minded.M.NOM.PL become.3PL.AOR.OPT.MID IRR
\l … for there is no way in which they could become well-disposed …' (Demosthenes 15.18)

\t éstin oûn , hópōs taût' án , ekeîna proeirēkṓs , etólmēsen eipeîn
\g be.3SG.PRS so how this.N.ACC.PL IRR that.N.ACC.PL say.before.PTCP.PRF.M.NOM.SG dare.3SG.AOR say.AOR.INF
\l So is there any way in which he could have dared to say these things, having previously said those … ?' (Demosthenes 19.308)

\t all' oudè phílōn pélas oudeís , hóstis àn eípoi
\g but nor friend.GEN.PL near nobody.M.NOM.SG who.M.NOM.SG IRR say.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l And neither is there any of his kin nearby who might say …' (Euripides, Alcestis 80)

\t oùte tis xénos aphîktai hóstis àn hēmîn saphés ti angeîlai hoîós t' ên perì toútōn
\g nor some.M.NOM.SG stranger.NOM.SG arrive.3SG.PRF.PASS who.M.NOM.SG IRR us.DAT clear.N.ACC.SG something.ACC.SG announce.3SG.AOR.OPT such.as.M.NOM.SG and be.3SG.IMP about this.GEN.PL
\l Nor has any stranger come who could tell us anything definite about this matter' (Plato, Phaedo 57a)

\t oud' angelós tis oudè sumpráktōr hodoû kateid' hótou tis ekmathṑn ekhrḗsat' án
\g nor messenger some.M.NOM.SG nor assistant.NOM.SG way.GEN.SG observe.3SG.AOR whom.M.GEN.SG someone.M.NOM.SG learn.PTCP.AOR.M.NOM.SG use.3SG.AOR.MID IRR
\l (Was there) no messenger or travelling companion from whom one might have learned something of use?' (Sophocles, Oedipus Rex 117)

\t katḗlpize eupetéōs tês thalássēs kratḗsein , táper àn kaì ên
\g hope.3SG.IMP easily the.F.GEN.SG sea.GEN.SG rule.FUT.INF which.N.NOM.PL IRR also be.3SG.IMP
\l He hoped that he would easily rule the seas, which might well have been.' (Herodotus 8.136.3)

\t toiaûta therapeúsantes heōutoús , hopoîá per àn etherapeúthēsan
\g such.N.ACC.PL treat.PTCP.AOR.M.NOM.PL themselves.ACC of.what.sort.N.ACC.PL all IRR treat.3PL.AOR.PASS
\l … treating themselves in just such a way as they would be treated' ([Hippocrates,] De arte 46.12; )

\t enómizon hóson ouk espleîn autoús; hóper àn , ei eboulḗthēsan mḕ katoknêsai , rhāidíōs àn egéneto
\g consider.3PL.IMP how.much not sail.in.PRS.INF them.ACC which.M.NOM.SG IRR if wish.3PL.AOR.PASS not shrink.AOR.INF easily IRR become.3SG.AOR.MID
\l They believed that they were not far from sailing in upon them, which might easily have come to pass if they had been unwilling to shrink from it.' (Thucydides 2.94.1)

\t eàn sumboúlous poiṓmetha toioútous hoíous per àn perì tôn idíōn hēmîn eînai boulētheîmen
\g if advisor.ACC.PL make.1PL.PRS.SBJV.PASS such.M.ACC.PL such.as.M.ACC.PL all IRR about the.N.GEN.PL private.N.GEN.PL us.DAT be.PRS.INF wish.1PL.AOR.OPT.PASS
\l … if we make such people advisors as we would wish to have for our private affairs …' (Isocrates 8.133)

\t khrḕ toioútous eînai kritás hoíōn per àn autoì tunkhánein axiṓseian
\g need.3SG.PRS such.M.ACC.PL be.PRS.INF judge.ACC.PL such.as.M.GEN.PL all IRR same.M.NOM.PL happen.PRS.INF deem.3PL.AOR.OPT
\l It is necessary (for them) as judges to be such as they themselves would find worthy' (Isocrates 15.23)

\t axiôn tḕn autḕn Pasíōni gígnesthai zēmían , hêsper àn autòs etúnkhanen
\g deem.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG the.F.ACC.SG same.F.ACC.SG Pasion.DAT become.PRS.INF.PASS penalty.ACC.SG which.F.GEN.SG IRR same.M.NOM.SG happen.3SG.IMP
\l … expecting the same penalty for Pasion that he would have incurred himself' (Isocrates 17.21)

\t prátteis háper àn doûlos phaulótatos práxeien
\g do.2SG.PRS which.N.ACC.PL IRR slave.NOM.SG basest.M.NOM.SG do.3SG.AOR.OPT
\l You are doing what the meanest slave would do' (Plato, Crito 52c)

\t ṓimēn dialéxesthai autón moi , háper àn erastḕs paidikoîs dialekhtheíē
\g think.1SG.IMP discuss.FUT.INF.MID him.ACC me.DAT which.N.ACC.PL IRR lover.NOM.SG darling.DAT.PL discuss.3SG.AOR.OPT.PASS
\l I thought that he would say to me what a lover would say to his favourites.' (Plato, Symposium 217b)

\t epoíoun háper àn ánthrōpoi en erēmíāi poiḗseian
\g do.3PL.IMP which.N.ACC.PL IRR person.NOM.PL in solitude.DAT.SG do.3PL.AOR.OPT
\l … they did what people would do in private.' (Xenophon, Anabasis 5.4.34)

\t tòn dè pólemon , di' hónper khrḗsimoi àn eîmen , eí tis humôn mḕ oíetai ésesthai

\t Phílippos d' háper eúxaisth' àn humeîs práxei

\l … and Philip will do just what you would have prayed for' (Demosthenes 6.30)

\t phileîn oíesthe deîn kaì timân , hoúsper àn kaì ho basileús

\t tò toùs autoùs miseîn kaì phileín , hoúsper àn hē patrís

\t teleîn dè autòn tà autà télē en tôi dḗmōi háper àng kaì Peiraieîs

\t egṑ gàr àn oîmai , ei déoi oîmai àn tòn mégan basiléa euarithmḗtous àn heureîn

\l For I think, if it were necessary … I think that the great king would find few …' (Plato, Apology 40d; cf. example (anan2) above)

\t oúte gàr àn hai tês selḗnēs ekleípseis toiaútas àn eîkhon tàs apotomás

\t méllōn gàr àn badízein tis ouk àn badíseien

\l For someone about to walk would not have walked' (Aristotle, On Generation and Corruption 337b.7)

\l For having (it) thus would be the most useful.' (Aristotle, Parts of Animals 654a.18)

\g so IRR so be.1PL.PRS

\t brakhù án ti prosktṓmenoi autêi perì autês àn taútēs mâllon kinduneúoimen
\g short.N.ACC.SG IRR something.ACC.SG gain.PTCP.PRS.PASS.M.NOM.PL same.F.DAT.SG about same.F.GEN.SG IRR this.F.GEN.SG more endanger.1PL.PRS.OPT
\l We should make but few new conquests, and should imperil those we have already won.' (Thucydides 6.18.2)

\t genoménēs d' àn arkhês aporeîn àn autón
\g become.PTCP.AOR.MID.F.GEN.SG and IRR beginning.GEN.SG puzzle.PRS.INF IRR him.ACC
\l … and, the command having become … he would be at a loss' (Thucydides 8.46.2)

\t oúte àn autôi tôi légonti oúte toîs akoúousi dêla àn eíē
\g nor IRR same.M.DAT.SG the.M.DAT.SG say.PTCP.PRS.M.DAT.SG nor the.M.DAT.PL hear.PTCP.PRS.M.DAT.PL clear.N.NOM.PL IRR be.3SG.PRS.OPT
\l Neither to the speaker nor to the hearers would it be clear …' (Hippocrates, On Ancient Medicine 1; )

\t oud' àn elaphrôs àn apeplíxato
\g nor IRR lightly IRR trot.off.3SG.AOR.MID
\l … nor would he have trotted off lightly' (Aristophanes, Acharnians 218)

\t pṓs dé g' àn kalôs légois án
\g how but even IRR well say.2SG.PRS.OPT IRR
\l But how can you say “well” … ?' (Aristophanes, Acharnians 308)

\t mammân d' àn aitḗsantos hêkón soi phérōn àn árton
\g mother.ACC.SG then IRR ask.PTCP.AOR.M.GEN.SG arrive.1SG.IMP you.DAT bear.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG IRR loaf.ACC.SG
\l When you cried for food I would come to you bringing bread.' (Aristophanes, Clouds 1383)

\t pôs án pot' aphikoímēn àn euthù toû Diós
\g how IRR sometime arrive.1SG.AOR.OPT.MID IRR straight the.M.GEN.SG Zeus.GEN
\l However could I go straight to Zeus?' (Aristophanes, Peace 68)

\t hē d' Hellàs àn éxerēmōtheîs' àn humâs élathe
\g the.F.NOM.SG then Greece.NOM IRR desolate.PTCP.AOR.PASS.F.NOM.SG IRR you.ACC.PL hide.3SG.AOR
\l And Greece, having been left destitute, escaped your notice.' (Aristophanes, Peace 646)

\t ouk àn priaímēn oud' àn iskhádos miâs
\g not IRR buy.1SG.PRS.OPT.PASS nor IRR fig.GEN.SG one.F.GEN.SG
\l I would not buy, not even for one fig.' (Aristophanes, Peace 1223)

\t kaì pôs àn éti génoit' àn eútaktos pólis
\g and how IRR still become.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID IRR well-ordered.F.NOM.SG city.NOM.SG
\l And how could a city become so well-ordered … ?' (Aristophanes, Birds 829)

\t egṑ dé tàn kán , eí me khreíē ekpieîn
\g I.NOM but and=IRR and=IRR if me.ACC need.3SG.PRS.OPT drink.up.AOR.INF
\l And so would I, even if I had to drink up …' (Aristophanes, Lysistrata 113)

\t egṑ dé g' àn kàn hṓsper ei psêttan dokô doûnai àn emautês partamoûsa thḗmisu
\g I.NOM but even IRR and=IRR like if turbot.ACC.SG think.1SG.PRS give.AOR.INF IRR myself.F.GEN.SG cut.off.PTCP.FUT.F.NOM.SG the=half.ACC.SG
\l And I would too, even if I expected to cut off half of myself and give it like a turbot.' (Aristophanes, Lysistrata 115)

\t mâllon àn dià toutogì génoit' àn eirḗnē
\g more IRR through this.N.ACC.SG.EMPH become.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID IRR peace.NOM.SG
\l Would peace come to pass rather through this?' (Aristophanes, Lysistrata 147)

\t phōnḕn àn ouk àn eîkhon
\g sound.ACC.SG IRR not IRR have.3PL.IMP
\l … they would not make a sound' (Aristophanes, Lysistrata 361)

\t ê tán se kōkúein àn ekéleuon makrá
\g in.truth and=IRR you.ACC wail.PRS.INF IRR order.1SG.IMP large.N.ACC.PL
\l Truly I would make you wail more.' (Aristophanes, Frogs 34)

\t ouk àn genoímēn Hēraklês án
\g not IRR become.1SG.AOR.OPT.MID Hercules.NOM IRR
\l I won't be Hercules' (Aristophanes, Frogs 581)

\t ouk àn phthánois tò géneion àn peridouménē
\g not IRR arrive.2SG.PRS.OPT the.N.ACC.SG beard.ACC.SG IRR bind.up.PTCP.PRS.PASS.F.NOM.SG
\l It wouldn't be too soon to tie on your beard.' (Aristophanes, Ecclesiazusae 118)

\t ísōs àn egṑ perì toû methúskesthai talēthê légōn hêtton àn eíēn aēdḗs
\g perhaps IRR I.NOM about the.N.GEN.SG intoxicate.PRS.INF.PASS the=true.N.ACC.PL say.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG less IRR be.1SG.PRS.OPT distasteful.M.NOM.SG
\l Perhaps I would be less disagreeable speaking the truth about intoxication.' (Plato, Symposium (Apology 41a) 176c)

\t eikótōs àn toùs erôntas mâllon àn phoboîo
\g justly IRR the.M.ACC.PL love.PTCP.PRS.M.ACC.PL more IRR frighten.2SG.PRS.OPT.PASS
\l You would reasonably be more frightened for the lovers' (Plato, Phaedrus 232c; has dḗ for the first àn)

\t tákh' oûn àn hupò philotimías epískhoi hēmîn àn toû gráphein
\g quickly so IRR under ambition.GEN.SG hold.back.3SG.AOR.OPT us.DAT IRR the.N.GEN.SG write.PRS.INF
\l So perhaps out of pride he may refrain from writing to us.' (Plato, Phaedrus 257c)

\t ouk àn rhāidíōs oudè pollà àn heúrois hōs toûto
\g not IRR easily nor many.N.ACC.PL IRR find.2SG.AOR.OPT as this.N.ACC.SG
\l You would not find many like this, nor easily.' (Plato, Republic 7.526c)

\t kàn olígou , eí me keleúois apodúnta orkhḗsasthai , kharisaímēn án
\g and=IRR little.N.GEN.SG if me.ACC order.2SG.PRS.OPT undress.PTCP.AOR.M.ACC.SG dance.AOR.INF.MID gratify.1SG.AOR.OPT.MID IRR
\l And I would almost gratify you if you were to bid me strip and dance' (Plato, Menexenus 236d)

\t pôs oûn án poté tis dúnait' àn hugiés ti légōn anteipeîn
\g how so IRR sometime someone.M.NOM.SG can.3SG.PRS.OPT.PASS IRR healthy.N.ACC.SG something.ACC.SG say.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG argue.AOR.INF
\l Then how could one ever argue … saying anything sound?' (Plato, Sophist 233a)

\t skholêi pot' àn autoîs tis khrḗmata didoùs ḗthelen àn mathētḕs gígnesthai
\g scarcely sometime IRR them.DAT someone.M.NOM.SG property.ACC.PL give.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG want.3SG.IMP IRR pupil.NOM.SG become.PRS.INF.PASS
\l Scarcely anyone would ever want to become (their) pupil, giving them money.' (Plato, Sophist 233b; cf. also Laws 5.742c)

\t stàs àn hṓsper hoûtos epì têi eisódōi légoim' án
\g stand.PTCP.AOR.M.NOM.SG IRR like this.M.NOM.SG upon the.F.DAT.SG entrance.DAT.SG say.1SG.PRS.OPT IRR
\l Standing at the door just like him, I would say …' (Xenophon, Cyropaedia 1.3.11)

\t humôn d' érēmos ṓn , ouk àn hikanòs oîmai eînai oút' àn phílon ōphelêsai oút' àn ekhthròn aléxasthai
\g you.GEN.PL then solitary.M.NOM.SG be.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.SG not IRR sufficient.M.NOM.SG think.1SG.PRS.PASS be.PRS.INF nor IRR friend.ACC help.AOR.INF nor IRR enemy.ACC.SG ward.off.AOR.INF.MID
\l But bereft of you I do not think I shall be able either to aid a friend or to ward off a foe.' (Xenophon, Anabasis 1.3.6)

\t dokoûmen d' án moi taútēi prospoioúmenoi prosbaleîn erēmōtérōi àn tôi órei khrêsthai
\g seem.1PL.PRS then IRR me.DAT here pretend.PTCP.PRS.PASS.M.NOM.PL attack.AOR.INF solitary.COMP.N.DAT.SG IRR the.N.DAT.SG mountain.DAT.SG use.PRS.INF.PASS
\l I do think, however, that if we should make a feint of attacking here, we should find the rest of the mountain all the more deserted' (Xenophon, Anabasis 4.6.13)

\t diaspasthéntes d' àn kaì katà mikrà genoménēs tês dunámeōs oút' àn trophḕn dúnaisthe lambánein oúte khaírontes àn apalláxaite
\g separate.PTCP.AOR.PASS.M.NOM.PL then IRR and down small.N.ACC.PL become.PTCP.AOR.MID.F.GEN.SG the.F.GEN.SG power.GEN.SG nor IRR food.ACC can.2PL.PRS.OPT.PASS take.PRS.INF nor rejoice.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.PL IRR deliver.2PL.AOR.OPT
\l But separated and with your force in small parts, you could neither get food nor emerge safe.' (Xenophon, Anabasis 5.6.32)

\t ôd' àn episkopoûntes ísōs àn katamáthoimen
\g thus IRR oversee.PTCP.PRS.M.NOM.PL perhaps IRR perceive.1PL.AOR.OPT
\l Perhaps by considering … we can thus discover …' (Xenophon, The Economist 4.5)

\t eîdes d' àn autês Pharnábazon thâtton án
\g see.2SG.AOR then IRR her.GEN Pharnabazus.ACC faster IRR
\l And you could see Pharnabazus more quickly than her.' (Epicrates, Fragment 2/3, line 17; )

\t ouk àn hēgeîsth' autòn kàn epidrameîn
\g not IRR lead.2PL.PRS.PASS him.ACC also=IRR rush.AOR.INF
\l Don't you believe he would even have rushed …' (Demosthenes 27.56)

\t hôd' àn theōroûsin génoit' àn phanerón
\g thus IRR behold.PTCP.PRS.M.DAT.SG become.3SG.AOR.OPT.MID IRR visible.N.NOM.SG
\l It might become clear by considering thus …' (Aristotle, Poetics 1460b, among many others; cf. on this example)

\t tí àn oíesth' ei apêlthon tí poieîn àn ḕ tí légein toùs asebeîs anthrṓpous toutousí
\g what.N.ACC.SG IRR think.2PL.PRS.PASS if leave.3PL.AOR what.N.ACC.SG do.PRS.INF IRR or what.N.ACC.SG say.PRS.INF the.M.ACC.PL impious.ACC.PL person.ACC.PL this.M.ACC.PL.EMPH
\l What do you think, if they had gone off … what (do you think) these ungodly persons would have done or said?' (Demosthenes 18.240)

\t avaθā adam hadā kamnai̯biš martiyai̯biš avam Gau̯mātam tayam magum avājanam utā tayai̯šai̯ fratamā martiyā anušiyā āhantā
\g then 1.NOM.SG with few.INS.PL.M man.INS.PL.M DEM.ACC.SG.M G.ACC.SG.M REL.ACC.SG.M magus.ACC.SG.M slay.1.SG.PST CONJ REL.NOM.PL.M=3.GEN.SG foremost.NOM.PL.M man.NOM.PL.M follower.NOM.PL.M be.3.PL.PST
\l then I with a few men slew that Gaumāta the magus and the men who were his foremost followers' (Behistun 1.57)

\t yadi imām dipim vai̯nāhi imai̯vā patikarā , nai̯diš vikanāhi utātai̯ yāvā tau̯mā ahati paribarāhidiš
\g CONJ DEM.ACC.SG.F inscription.ACC.SG.F see.2.SG.SBJV DEM.ACC.PL.M=CONJ sculpture.ACC.PL.M NEG=3.ACC.PL destroy.2.SG.SBJV CONJ=2.SG.GEN CONJ strength.NOM.SG.N be.3.SG.SBJV protect.2.SG.IMP=3.ACC.PL
\l If you shall look at this inscription or these sculptures, (and) shall not destroy them and, as long as there is strength to you, shall care for them, …' (Behistun 4.74 = 4.78)

\t taya adam akunavam utamai̯ taya pitā akunau̯š
\g REL.NOM/ACC.PL.N 1.NOM.SG make.1.SG.PST CONJ=1.SG.GEN REL.NOM/ACC.PL.N father.NOM.SG.M make.3.SG.PST
\l … which I built and which my father built.' (Xerxes D 15)

\t vašnā Auramazdāha adamšām xšāyaθiya āham
\g will.INS.SG.M A.GEN.SG.M 1.NOM.SG=3.GEN.PL king.NOM.SG.M be.1.SG.PST
\l 'By the favour of Auramazdā I was their king' (Behistun I.14)

\t vašna Auramazdāha adamšiš ajanam utā navā xšāyaθiyā agr̥bāyam
\g will.INS.SG.M A.GEN.SG.M 1.NOM.SG=3.ACC.PL defeat.1.SG.PST CONJ nine.ACC.PL.M king.ACC.PL.M capture.1.SG.PST
\l By the favour of Auramazdā I defeated them and captured nine kings' (Behistun IV.6)

\t vašna Auramazdāhā adamšim gāθavā niyašādayam
\g will.INS.SG.M A.GEN.SG.M 1.NOM.SG=3.ACC.SG place.LOC.SG.M set-down.1.SG.PST
\l By the favour of Auramazdā I put it in its proper place.' (NR^a 35)

\t haruvašim kāra avaina
\g whole.NOM=3.ACC.SG people.NOM see.3.SG.PST
\l All the people saw him' (Behistun II.75 = II.90)

\t Vivāna nāma Pārsa , manā bandaka , Harauvatiyā xšaçapāvā , abi avam , utāšam ai̯vam martiyam maθištam akunau̯š
\g V.NOM.SG.M name.LOC.SG.N Persian.NOM.SG.M 1.GEN.SG vassal.NOM.SG.M Arachosia.LOC.SG.F satrap.NOM.SG.M against DEM.ACC.SG.M CONJ=3.GEN.PL one.ACC.SG.M man.ACC.SG.M greatest.ACC.SG.M make.3.SG.PST
\l '(there was) a Persian, Vivana by name, my vassal, satrap in Arachosia, against him [he sent an army], and he made one single man their chief' (Behistun III.56)

\t nam sicut , quod apud Catonem est  . . . , per mihi scitum videtur  . . .: sic profecto se res habet
\g for just.as what in Cato.ACC.SG is.PRES.3SG _ very I.DAT.SG sensible.NOM.SG.N seem.PRES.3SG.PASS _ so really itself matter.NOM.SG.F has.PRES.3SG
\l for just as what Cato says …, to me seems very sensible …: so it really is' (Cicero, de Oratore 2.271)

\t per mihi benigne respondit
\g very I.DAT.SG kindly answer.IMPRF.3SG
\l he answered me very kindly' (Cicero, ad Quintum Fratrem 1.7(9).2)

\t quod ad me de Hermathena scribis , per mihi gratum est
\g what.ACC.SG at I.ACC.SG. about Hermathena.ABL.SG write.PRES.2SG very I.DAT.SG dear.NOM be.PRES.3SG
\l What you write to me about Hermathena I am very grateful for' (Cicero, ad Atticum 1.4.3)

\t per mihi , per , inquam , gratum feceris
\g very I.DAT.SG very say.VERB.DEFECT.1SG dear do.PRF.2SG.SUBJ
\l You would, I say, make me very, very grateful' (Cicero, ad Atticum 1.20.7)

\t pergratum mihi feceris , spero item Scaevolae
\g very.grateful.ACC.SG I.DAT.SG do.PRF.2SG.SUBJ hope.PRES.1SG likewise Scaevolae.DAT
\l you would make me very grateful, and, I hope, Scaevola, too' (Cicero, Laelius de Amicitia 16)

\t ista sunt pergrata perque iucunda
\g that.NOM.PL.N are.PRES.3PL very.pleasing.ACC.PL.N very.and delightful.ACC.PL.N
\l that is very pleasing and very delightful' (Cicero, de Oratore 1.205)

\t per enim magni aestimo
\g very namely great.GEN.SG.N appraise.PRES.1SG
\l for I very highly appraise' (Cicero, ad Atticum 10.1.1)

\t quod iudicium cunque subierat
\g what.ACC.SG.N trial.ACC.SG.N ever enter.PSTPRF.3SG
\l whatever trial they (=everyone) had faced' (Cicero, pro Sestio 68)

\t qua re cunque
\g what.ABL.SG.F matter.ABL.SG.F ever
\l because of whatever matter' (Cicero, de Divinatione 2.7)

\t quae loca cunque
\g what.ACC.PL.N place.ACC.PL.N ever
\l (to) all places' (Lucretius 4.867)

\t qua de causa cunque
\g what.ABL.SG.F for reason.ABL.SG.F ever
\l for whatever reason' (Lucretius 6.85)

\t quae semina cunque
\g what.ACC.PL.N seed.ACC.PL.N ever
\l all seeds whatsoever' (Lucretius 6.867)

\t quam rem cunque
\g what.ACC.SG.F matter.ACC.SG.F ever
\l whatever' (Horace, Odes 1.6.3)

\t quod ad cunque legis genus
\g what.ACC.SG.N to ever law.GEN.SG type.NOM.SG
\l to whatever type of law' (Cicero, de Legibus 4.26)

\t quam se cunque in partem dedisset
\g what.ACC.SG.F himself.REFL.ACC ever in division.ACC.SG.F give.PSTPRF.3SG.SUBJ
\l whatever side he held on to' (Cicero, de Oratore 3.60)

\t quo ea me cunque ducet
\g where it.NOM.SG.F I.ACC.SG. ever lead.FUT.3SG
\l wherever it will lead me' (Cicero, Tusculanae Disputationes 2.15)

\t quo te cunque verteris
\g where you.ACC.SG ever turn.PRF.2SG.SUBJ
\l wherever you turn' (Cicero, de Divinatione 2.149)

\t quae me cunque vocant terrae
\g what.NOM.PL.F I.ACC.SG ever call.PRES.3PL earth.NOM.PL.F
\l whichever lands summon me' (Virgil, Aeneid 1.610)

\t quo te cunque lacus miserantem incommoda nostra fonte tenet

\l in whatever spring the lake keeps you lamenting our troubles' (Virgil, Aeneid 8.74)

\t qui te cunque manent isto certamine casus
\g what.NOM.PL.M you.ACC.SG ever await.PRES.PL that.ABL.SG.N contest.ABL.SG.N calamity.NOM.PL.M
\l whatever calamities await you in that contest' (Virgil, Aeneid 12.61)

\t quo nos cunque feret melior Fortuna parente
\g where we.ACC.PL ever take.FUT.3SG good.NOM.SG.F.COMPARATIVE Fortuna.NOM.SG.F father.ABL.SG.M
\l wherever Fortune, who is better than my father, will take us' (Horace, Odes 1.7.25)

\t quae te cunque domat Venus
\g what.NOM.SG.F you.ACC.SG ever tame.PRES.3SG Venus.NOM.SG.F
\l whatever Venus tames you' (Horace, Odes 1.27.14)

\t delicias legit qui tibi cunque meas
\g delight.ACC.PL.F read.PRF.3SG who.NOM.SG you.DAT.SG ever my.ACC.PL.F
\l whoever read to you my cheerful verse' (Ovid, Tristia 2.78)

\t nomen quod tibi cunque datur
\g name.NOM.SG.N what.NOM.SG.N you.DAT.SG ever give.PRES.3SG.PASS
\l whatever name is given to you' (Martial 2.61.6)

\t quae meo quomque animo lubitum est facere
\g what.NOM.PL.N my.DAT.SG.M ever heart.DAT.SG.M please.PTCP.PRF.N be.PRES.3SG do.INF.PRES
\l to do whatever pleased my heart' (Terence, Andria 263)

\t garrulus hunc quando consumet cunque
\g talkative.NOM.SG.M this.ACC.SG.M at.what.time take.completely.FUT.3SG ever
\l a chatterbox will devour him at some time or other' (Horace, Satires 1.9.33)

\t necesse est , quo tu me modo voles esse , ita esse , mater
\g necessary be.PRES.3SG how you.NOM.SG I.ACC.SG way.ABL.SG.M want.FUT.2SG be.INF so be.INF mother.VOC.SG
\l it is necessary to be however you want me to be, mother' (Plautus, Cistellaria 1.1.47)

\t quo te modo iactaris
\g in.what.ABL.SG.N you.ACC.SG way.ABL.SG.M throw.IMPRF.2SG.SUBJ
\l how you would show off' (Cicero, pro Roscio Amerino 89)

\t quo te modo ad tuam intemperantiam innovasti

\l how you returned to your extravagance' (Cicero, in Pisonem 89)

\t quo te nunc modo appelem
\g in.what.ABL.SG.M you.ACC.SG now way.ABL.SG.M speak.to.PRES.1SG.SUBJ
\l how shall I address you' (Cicero, pro Scauro 50)

\t quonam se modo defendet
\g in.whatABL.SG.M ENCL.INTERR way.ABL.SG.M defend.FUT.3SG
\l how will he defend himself (…)?' (Cicero, pro Rabirio Postumo 19)

\t quo cunque igitur te modo …
\g in.what.ABL.SG.M ever therefore you.ACC.SG way.ABL.SG.M _
\l therefore, in whatever manner (…) you' (Cicero, pro Scauro 50)

\t per te ere obsecro deos immortales
\g by you.ACC.SG master.VOC.SG.M implore.PRES.1SG god.ACC.PL.M immortal.ACC.PL.M
\l Master, I implore you by the immortal gods' (Plautus, Bacchides 905)

\t per ego vobis deos atque homines dico
\g by there you.DAT.PL god.ACC.PL.M and man.ACC.PL.M speak.PRES.1SG
\l I assign to you by the gods and men' (Plautus, Menaechmi 990)

\t per te deos oro et nostram amicitiam , Chremes
\g by you.ACC.SG god.ACC.PL.M pray.PRES.1SG and our.ACC.SG.F friendship.ACC.SG.F Chremes.VOC.SG.M
\l I beg you, Chremes, by the gods and our friendship' (Terence, Andria 538)

\t per ego te deos oro
\g by I.NOM.SG you.ACC.SG god.ACC.PL.M pray.PRES.1SG
\l by the gods I beg you' (Terence, Andria 834)

\t per te dulcissima furta perque tuos oculos per geniumque rogo
\g by you.ACC.SG sweet.ELATIVE.ACC.PL.N theft.ACC.PL.N by-and your.ACC.PL.M eye.ACC.PL.M by spirit.ACC.SG.M ask.PRES.1SG
\l by the sweetest thefts, your eyes, and your Genius I beg' (Tibullus 3.11.7 (=4.5.7))

\t per ego te , inquit , fili , quaecunque iura iungunt liberos parentibus , precor quaesoque
\g by I.NOM.SG you.ACC.SG say.PRF.3SG son.VOC.SG.M whatever.ACC.PL.N right.ACC.PL.N attach.PRES.3PL child.ACC.PL.M parent.DAT.PL.M pray.PRES.1SG.PASS beg.PRES.1SG-and
\l “by whatever rights connect children to their parents,” he said, “I beg and entreat you, son”' (Livius 23.9.2)

\t per ego vos decora maiorum … oro et obtestor
\g by I.NOM.SG you.ACC.PL ornament.ACC.PL.N ancestors.GEN.PL.M _ beg.PRES.1SG and beseech.PRES.1SG.PASS
\l by the dignity of your forbears … I beg and beseech you' (Curtius 5.8.16)

\t per te quod fecimus una perdidimusque nefas … ades
\g by you.ABL.SG REL.ACC.SG.N do.PRF.1PL at.once squander.PRF.1PL-and sin.N.INDECL _ be.present.IMP.PRES.SG
\l by the sin which we commited and squandered together with you …, come' (Lucan 10.370)

\t per vos culta diu Rutulae primordia gentis  . . . , conservate pios

\t disque tulissent
\g apart-and carry.PRF.3PL.SUBJ
\l and they have carried away' (Plautus, Trinummus 833)

\t absque me esset; absque te foret; absque una hac foret; absque eo esset

\l and if it wasn't for me; and if it wasn't for you; and if it wasn't for this one thing; and if it wasn't for him

\l and without any content and purpose' (Cicero, ad Atticum 1.19.1)

\t absque te uno forsitan lingua Graeca longe anteisset , sed tu

\l the writings of Catullus also sang of these themes' (Propertius 2.34.87)

\t si pares aeque inter se , quiescendum; sin , latius manabit , et quidem ad nos , deinde communiter
\g if appropriate.NOM.PL.M equally between himself.ACC.PL.M rest.GRND.NOM.SG.N if.not more.broadly spread.FUT.3SG and indeed to we.ACC.PL then jointly
\l if they are evenly matched, one has to rest; but if it spreads, and indeed spreads to us, then [we must act] jointly' (Cicero, ad Attticum 16.13b2)

\t qui si conservatus erit , vicimus; sin  . . . , quod di omen avertant , omnis omnium cursus est ad vos
\g who.NOM.SG.M if rescue.PTCP.PRF.NOM.SG.M be.FUT.3SG win.PRF.1PL if.not _ who.ACC.SG.N god.NOM.PL.M omen.ACC.SG.N avert.PRES.3PL.SUBJ all.NOM.SG.M all.gen.pl.m road.nom.sg.m be.PRES.3SG to you.ACC.PL
\l if he will be saved, we have won. If not … this omen may the gods avert, the whole road leads for all to you' (Cicero, Epistulae 12.6.2)

\t si perficitis quod agitis , me ad vos venire oportet; sin autem … Sed nihil opus est reliqua scribere .
\g if finish.PRES.2PL who.ACC.SG.N do.PRES.2PL I.ACC.SG to you.ACC.PL come.INF.PRES be.necessary.PRES.3SG if.not on.the.other.hand _ but not.at.all work.NOM.SG.N be.PRES.3SG leave.behind.PTCP.NOM.PL.N write.INF.PRES
\l if you finish what you are dealing with, I have to come to you; on the other hand, if not … But it is not necessary to spell out the rest.' (Cicero, Epistulae 14.3.5)

\t si vir esse volet , praeclara συνοδία . Sin autem , erimus nos , qui solemus .
\g if man.NOM.SG.M be.INF.PRES want.FUT.3SG great.NOM.SG.F group.of.travellers.NOM.SG.F if.not on.the.other.hand be.FUT.1PL we.NOM.PL who.NOM.PL.M be.used.to.PRES.1PL
\l if he wants to be a man, it will be a great group of travellers. On the other hand, if not, we will continue as we are used to.' (Cicero, ad Atticum 10.7.2)

\t atque utinam tu quoque eodem die ! sin quod  . . . , multa enim utique postridie .
\g and hopefully you.NOM.SG also the.same.ABL.SG.M day.ABL.SG.M if.not who.NOM.SG.N _ much.ACC.PL.N because undoubtedly the.next.day
\l and hopefully you [can come over] on the same day as well! If not, because many things [may come up], then undoubtedly the next day.' (Cicero, ad Atticum 13.22.4)

\t donec proterva nil mei manu carpes , licebit ipsa sis pudicior Vesta . Sin , haec mei te ventris arma laxabunt .
\g as.long.as wanton.ABL.SG.F nothing I.GEN.SG hand.ABL.SG.F harvest.FUT.2SG be.allowed.FUT.3SG himself.ABL.SG.F be.PRES.2SG.SUBJ chaster.NOM.SG.M Vesta.NOM.SG.F if.not this.NOM.PL.N I.GEN.SG you.ACC.SG.M belly.GEN.SG.M weapon.NOM.SG.N stretch.FUT.3PL
\l as long as you will not steal anything from me with wanton hand, you may be chaster than Vesta herself. If not, these belly-weapons of mine will stretch you.' (Priapeia 31)

\t sin , ne te capiant , primo si forte negabit , taedia

\l if not, let not sadness capture you if he will refuse you at first' (Tibullus 1.4.15)

\t si animus hominem pepulit , actumst , animo servit , non sibi . sin ipse animum pepulit , vivit
\g if heart.NOM.SG.M human.ACC.SG.M push.PRF.3SG do.PRF.3SG.PASS heart.DAT.SG.M obey.PRES.3SG not himself.DAT.SG if.not himself.NOM.SG.M heart.ACC.SG.M push.PRF.3SG live.PRES.3SG
\l if his heart brings forward the human part of him, it is done, he obeys his heart and not himself. If he himself does not bring forward his heart, he lives' (Plautus, Trinummus 309)

\t Acanthio: At ego maledicentiorem quam te novi neminem . Charinus: Sin saluti quod tibi esse censeo , id consuadeo ? Acanthio: apage istiusmodi salutem , cum cruciatu quae advenit .
\g Acanthio.NOM.SG.M but I.NOM.SG. more.slanderous.ACC.SG.M than you.ACC.SG get.to.know.PRF.1SG nobody Charinus.NOM.SG.M if health.DAT.SG.F what.ACC.SG.N you.DAT.SG.M be.PRES.INF think.PRES.1SG he.ACC.SG.N recommend.PRES.1SG Acanthio.NOM.SG.M go.away of.that.kind health.ACC.SG.F with torture.ABL.SG.M which.NOM.SG.M arrive.PRES.3SG
\l Acanthio: But I don‘t know anyone who is more slanderous than you. Charinus: If I recommend you something which I think is healthy for you? Acanthio: Go away with such health which comes with torture.' (Plautus, Mercator 142f)

\t Some þe devell deceyves þurgh vayne glory , þat es ydil joy: when any has pryde and delyte in þamself of þe penance þat þai suffer , of gode dedes þat þai do . of any vertu þat þai have; es glad when men loves þam , sari when men lackes þam , haves envy to þam þat es spokyn mare gode of þan of þam;
\g some the devil deceives through vain glory that is idle joy when any has pride and delight in themselves of the penance that they suffer of good deeds that they do of any virtue that they have is glad when men loves them sorry when men lacks them haves envy to them that is spoken more good of than of them
\l (ROLLEP,86.368)

\g Because I am crippled as man may see _ and have been long.

\t Hittigúta míi xawaaqqitáyyoont , ko máncho ?
\g like_this[2]-F.ACC what-M.DAT speaker-2F.PROG 2S.VOC people-SG-M.OBL
\l Hey (my) man, why do you say this (lit. like this)?

\t … hanaqalígu ikkodáa hittígutaba’a
\g _ dish_sp-M.GEN=way-M.NOM however like_this[2]-F.PRED-F.COP2-NEG1
\l … but the preparation (lit. way) of the hanqalú-dish is not like this.

\t Hittíta xe’áyyoo burtukaanú xuudimbá’a
\g like_this[1]-F.ACC taste_good-3M.PROG.REL orange-M.ACC see-1S.NIPV-NEG1
\l I have never seen oranges that taste this good (lit. taste good like this!’)

\t ké mɔ̄ŋ̄ gāā klā tā̰ḭ́ḭ́ḭ́ kēé gɛ̄ ō mɔ̄ŋ̄ zòŋ̀ dìŋ̀ à mì wá
\g if LOG.PL went behind always like_this PRT PRT LOG.PL PROSP reach-PROSP 3SG at not
\l If we always go after him like that, we are not going to reach him.

\t Hittíguta
\g like_this[2]-F.PRED-F.COP2
\l Speaker A: ‘(Does it mean) to tie one to the other?’ – Speaker B: ‘Yes (lit. it is like this).

\t Hittínta
\g like_this[1]-F.ACC<N>
\l [Speaker A:] ‘Why did you buy this, what’s the use?’ – [Speaker B:] ‘(I bought it just) like this (= without considering its use).

\t Hittigúnta esáa mátit fiitíchchut hé’ee’e ikkeeráan …
\g like_this[2]-F.ACC<N> 1S.DAT one-F.NOM flowering_plant-F.NOM exist-3M.PRF-1S.O IRR …
\l (Preceding sentence: If I had, for instance, a silk scarf, I could wear it around my neck and walk around.) ‘And (lit. like this) if I had a flowering plant, …

\t … báaruhuu shambaláluhuu hittigúnta wólu uullá alí wó’u hórunkuu móoll goofáno
\g _ sea-M.NOM-ADD lake-M.NOM-ADD like_this[2]-F.ACC<N> other-M.NOM earth-F.GEN top-M.GEN water-M.NOM all-M.NOM<N>-ADD dry_up.3M.PCO finish-3M.IPV
\l … the sea, the lakes and (also) other (bodies of) water on the earth would all dry up.

\t Híttíkk kasalás hi’rríké’ isí kuntaalíichch íi kuntaaláan woraammí jáata kasalisí mereeróon ábbat ábbat háqqit yoo’íi xuujjóomm
\g like_this[1]=become.3M.PCO charcoal-M.ACC-3M.POSS buy<MID>-1S.PCO=SEQ 3M.GEN sack-M.ABL 1S.POSS sack-M.LOC put_in-1S.IPV.REL time-F.ACC charchoal-M.GEN-3M.POSS interior-M.LOC big-F.NOM big-F.NOM wood-F.NOM COP1.3.REL-NMZ1.M.ACC see-1S.PFV
\l (Context: Speaker bought charcoal from a seller who claimed to have the best quality product on the market.) ‘But when I had bought his charcoal and started putting it from his sack into mine, I found out that there were big pieces of wood (hidden) in his charcoal.

\g chili_pepper real DEF 3PL+3SG crush HAB like_this IDPH

\l When he throws himself in the water like this: duuu!

\t è ɓé wò kṵ̄ sɔ̰̀̀ɔ̰̀̀ɔ̰̀̀ à dɛ̀ŋ̀ à̰ ŋ̄ bò kēé ɔ̄ŋ́ dō kpɔ́

\l And he kept doing it until just one of them was left (lit. until they remained like this: a single one).
